definition: Abbreviation for: Database Management System.
Abbreviation for: Centre – Tracon Automation System.

Often used synonymously with B2B, e-marketplace, or Virtual Commerce Network (VCN). ITE is a more precise term, connoting many-to-many transactions, whereas the others do not specify the transactions.

Heavy automotive vehicles used to transport cargo. In the maritime industry, cargo is often carried by tractor-trailers. The tractor is the front part of the vehicle, also called a cab. The trailer is the detachable wheeled chassis behind the tractor, on which containers or other cargoes are placed. See: common carrier; heavy hauler; drayage.
Articles packed so that one rests partially or entirely within another, thereby reducing the cubic–foot displacement.

Approach developed by the American Defence Department and transferred to the business world, including rules, modelling tools, and computer applications (e.g. ERP) for tracking and optimising product flow from development to end of life.
A ship operating with no fixed route or published schedule.
The side-to-side (athwartship) motion of a vessel.
Refers to: One Thousand.
Abbreviation for: Hours of Service (Automated).

The total of all costs associated with the creation and release of a purchase order and its receipt, inspection, and put away as required. In calculating order quantities, the cost of placing a large number of individual orders is balanced against the cost of carrying inventory due to placing fewer orders with larger quantities on each.

Abbreviation for: Commuter Assistance Program. Program funded by the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) which supports numerous congestion reducing programs in a community in order to achieve the community’s traffic reduction and air quality goals.

Logistics information systems that address such long-term strategic questions as facility location and sizing, as well as transportation networks. These applications often make use of simulation and optimisation modelling.
Organisations with physical (vs. Internet-only) production or logistics facilities and operations
A firm that acts as an export sales agent for more than one non–competing manufacturer.
Abbreviation for: Developmental Electricity Pricing Programme.

A printed set of documents generated for a specific production order that often includes the bill of material, routing, pick slip, work instructions, production and labour reporting tickets, move tickets, and other support forms.
Guidance system that uses a special strip (taped or painted) on the floor to guide an AGV.

An inventory planning and fulfilment technique in which a supplier is responsible for monitoring and restocking customer inventory at the appropriate time to maintain predefined levels. The vendor is given access to current customer inventory, forecast, and sales order information and initiates replenishment as required.

Abbreviation for: Container Freight Station. A shipping dock where cargo is loaded (“stuffed”) into or unloaded (“stripped”) from containers. Generally, this involves less than container load shipments, although small shipments destined to the same consignee are often consolidated. Container reloading from/to rail or motor carrier equipment is a typical activity. These facilities can be located in container yards, or off dock.

Headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland, it is an international body composed of members representing standards organisations. The objective of the organisation is to promote the development of standards, testing, and certification in order to encourage the international trade of goods and services. As of 2002, ISO reports that its standards have resulted in certification of over 400,000 organisations around the world. ISO has concentrated on quality improvement and has issued the ISO 9000 series of quality system standards. ISO 14000 standards certify an organisation’s environment performance. For more information: www.iso.ch.
Abbreviation for: Bill of Lading.
Trailers that are unhooked from a tractor when the truck reaches its destinations.
Codes in which information is placed in two dimensions and read from side to side, and up and down, by special scanning equipment and which can be read, even if partially damaged.
Automated Flight Inspection System.
Sequenced plans or data communicated to multiple points at the same time in order to provide a common view and synchronise results
Abbreviation for: Airline Dispatch Office.
The process of becoming familiar with another culture. It helps in conducting transnational business.
In cost accounting, the lowest level component of a resource, activity, or cost object.
U.S. DoD ACAT 1 programs are Milestone Decision Authority Programs or programs designated ACAT 1 by the Milestone Decision Authority.

Destruction of product may be chosen as a means of disposition after product is received at returns processing centre. Destruction may be standard or “green” and is typically done in conjunction with a bonded outsource partner.

The characteristics of an item or process that indicate its conformance to designated parameters, and its degree of perceived customer acceptance or satisfaction. Quality characteristics often include reliability, consistency, and the ability to continue performance in stress or volume situations, but are critical only in relation to the value placed on them by the user or customer.
The reduction of the recorded value of materiel as a result of conversion or change of conditions while in stock (*reduction).
The bank that adds its confirmation to another bank’s (the issuing bank’s) letter of credit and promises to pay the beneficiary upon presentation of documents specified in the letter of credit.

Personnel that collaborate on a specific project or function, make use of a common database, schedule and method of communication, and update tasks and activities specifically related to that project or function.
Processes designed with relatively few sequential stages, each of which performs a relatively large part of the total task; the opposite of long this processes.
The applicable law in a specific country or region.
The cost attribute describes the cost of operating the process. It includes labor costs, material costs, and transportation costs. Cost is an internally-focused attribute.

Abbreviation for: Overall Work Rate. A measure of labour productivity, the OWR is a sign of operational efficiency. It usually measures how many total hours are used in a given warehouse operation to handle a particular volume of throughput. Also termed Overall Warehouse Rate. The number of hours often includes team managers and stock control administration, in addition to those job roles directly involved in handling stock. Absence and sickness both negatively affect OWR. A typical target OWR value for a composite warehouse might be 80, although actuals will of course vary from, for example, 55 to 95. Different target rates will be set for each temperature chamber. OWR is a term associated with Lean Manufacturing principles and Total Productive Maintenance (TPM) - also called Total Process Management and Total Productive Manufacturing.

A document of confirmation that goods have been delivered or services performed. The supplier may present a proof of delivery and the buyer may generate a goods receipt note. The goods receipt note is usually part of a three-way match between the purchase order, the invoice and the goods receipt note, and is needed to confirm that the invoice might be paid. When a two-way match occurs, the invoice is matched either to the purchase order or simply to the goods receipt note.
Set of marketing tools to direct the business offering to the customer. The four P’s are product, price, place and promotion.
The number of persons in a ship’s crew, including officers.
A government technique for developing fee and profit negotiation objectives, within percentage ranges established by regulation.

1. To prepare an anchor, after raising it by lifting it with a tackle to the cat head, prior to securing (fishing) it alongside for sea. (An anchor raised to the cat head is said to be catted.)2. The cat o’ nine tails.3. A cat-rigged boat or catboat.
An upper deck of a vessel that extends unbroken from stem to stern.
Round black shape hoisted in the forepart of a vessel to show that it is anchored.
A shipment in which the freight completely fills the trailer or container. Often refers to the quantity of freight required to fill a trailer, usually more than 10,000 pounds.
The written contract that spells out agreed upon terms between EDI trading partners.
Abbreviation for: Diving Support Vessel.
Abbreviation for: Regional Transportation Plan.
The designation provided in a classification by which a class rate is determined.

The measure of value received for the resources expended. It is directly proportional to the cost to a foe (damage, neutralization, deception, and/or counteraction) and indirectly proportional to the system cost.
The definition of operating or working days available for material and capacity planning, production order release and execution.
The date and time a vehicle or shipment is expected to depart on a journey.
The estimated useful period of a resource or system based on time, cycles, units processed, or other factors.

A shortening of the term, “Roll On/ Roll Off.” A method of ocean cargo service using a vessel with ramps which allows wheeled vehicles to be loaded and discharged without cranes. Also refers to any specialised vessel designed to carry Ro/Ro cargo
A type of tobacco or sweet cake.

To change the expected date of an open production, purchase, or interplant order by a planner or other person, based on a suggestion from MRP or other information. It requires a review process that evaluates the effect of moving the initial date, and increases reaction time while allowing for more control than a process in which MRP or other system suggestions for reschedules are automatically performed.
The ability of an operation to produce a process, product, or service.
Abbreviation for: General Aviation District Office.
Abbreviation for: Certified Financial Analyst.
Abbreviation for: Local Standard Time.
Imposing unnecessary technical requirements on suppliers.
A liquid cargo vessel of 50,000 to 70,000 DWT.

A lot size that always uses the same quantity (or a multiple) for a reorder; the timing of the order varies while the size of the order is constant. Fixed lots are sometimes used when a process may require stamping out 100 pieces at a time, or when a vendor will only ship a carton of 500 items. Using fixed lots may mean placing fewer orders, at the trade off of carrying more inventory for a period of time than may be required.

1. In the United Kingdom, a Royal Navy officer, usually a captain, responsible for the day-to-day operation of a naval dockyard.2. In the United States, a United States Coast Guard officer, usually a captain, responsible for enforcement of safety, security, and marine environmental protection regulations in a commercial port.
The (illegal) practice of mixing cargo with garbage.

A travel time reliability performance measure defined by the ratio of an actual 95th percentile travel time to the free-flow travel time; conceptually represents the once-a-month extra travel time travelers must spend compared to uncongested travel times (a value of 3.00 indicates a traveler should allow 60 minutes to make an important trip that takes 20 minutes in uncongested traffic).
Abbreviation for: Minimum Reception Altitude and Mutual Recognition Agreement.
A quantity of materials awaiting further processing. It can refer to raw materials, semi-finished stores or hold points, or to a work backlog that is purposely maintained behind a work centre
Abbreviation for: Transportation Computer Centre.
The minimum speed at which a vessel will answer the helm, below which she cannot be steered. Speed sufficient for the rudder to “bite.”
Sales of a business, valuable business assets or share that results in the creation of sustainable business opportunities and transfer of specialised skills or productive for black people.
Abbreviation for: Original Equipment Manufacturer.
A rail car without a roof and walls.
Abbreviation for: Built In Self-Test.

1. Situated within a vessel. 2. Situated within a vessel and positioned close (or closer than another item, when contrasted with that item) to her centreline. 3. Situated outside a vessel but nearer to her hull, e.g., the larger boat was tied up alongside the ship inboard of the smaller boat. 4. Nearer the pier or shore, e.g., the tanker and cargo ship were tied up at the pier alongside one another with the tanker inboard of the cargo ship.

An examination of changes in fixed and variable costs based on varying revenue and production levels that identify a break-even point, where revenues are equal to costs. It highlights the profit results from alternative levels of operation. Syn.: cost-profit-volume analysis.
A ship which acts as a mobile or fixed base for other ships and submarines or supports a naval base.

A set of international rules, issued by the ICC (International Chamber of Commerce) for the interpretation of the chief terms of delivery used in foreign trade contracts. The incoterms define the rights and obligations of the seller and the buyer, for instance transfer of the risk (at which point and time the risk passes from the seller to the buyer).

(1) To give plain meaning to contract terms unless the agency or legislation assigned a special meaning to the term.(2) When silent to an interpretation, cardinal rule allows for the meaning which fits most logically and comfortably into the body of both previously and subsequently enacted law to be utilised.
The grammar or rules which define the structure of the EDI standard.
Used in repetitive manufacturing environments to represent the amount of production per shift or hour.
The secretariat, which provides clerical and administrative support to the ASC X12 Committee.
In the Far East, a warehouse where goods are stored and delivered.
1. A unit of product.2. A protective casing around a product.
Abbreviation for: Africa Growth and Opportunity Act.
Actions taken to protect natural and human environments, investments, and mobility options.
A measure of bias in a forecast.
A term in performance-based logistics which refers to support in which maintenance operations for a particular military system are performed exclusively by contract support personnel.
See: Boatswain’s Call.
National Development Agency.
Abbreviation for: Statistical Process Control.
Results of quality tests that chart the percent and number of products or quality characteristics that do not conform to specification.
Abbreviation for: Weather Service Contract Meteorological Observatory.

Contract in which the buyer agrees to pay the supplier all materials costs and employee hours against predetermined hourly rates and margin for services rendered (identical to cost reimbursable contract).
Refers to: VHF Omnidirectional Range.
The cycle time between product conception and fulfilment. Reduction in time-to-market is a significant competitive advantage in industries with short product life cycles.
A mobility performance measure which primarily shows a trend over time and is not used to achieve a goal or objective or used in a decision-making process.
A condition in which traffic demand exceeds the capacity.
The total time required to place and receive purchased items, including order release, vendor transportation, and dock-to-stock activities.

The comparison of the projected completion date for an operation or project task to the required date, which indicates the amount of time it could be delayed without impacting later operations or tasks.

skills that are value adding to the activities of the measured Entities in line with its core business; in areas the measured Entity cannot outsource, or within the production/operational part of the measured Entity’s valuedchain as opposed to the supply side, service downstream operations.

A scheduling method that begins with a specified start date and moves forward into time to calculate a due or completion date based on the lead time required. It assumes flexibility in the due date, but not the start date.
See: Cost of Non-conformance.

A description of the transportation problem (not solution) explaining the primary goal or reason for which a project is being pursued. The statement should be specific enough so that the range of alternatives developed will offer real potential solutions and should reflect priorities and limitations in the area such as environment resources, growth management, land use planning, and economic development
Production exceeding the scheduled amount or costs exceeding budget.
Abbreviation for: Engineering Document Management Systems and Emission Dispersion Modelling System: A computer software program used to analyse air quality at airports.

A number resulting from an equation, showing the output of a process that spans departments. These types of measures are also known as a process measures because they span across the breadth of a process, regardless of functional/departmental segregation within the process. Example: Perfect Order Index.

Freight is most often measured by its weight, and transportation vehicles of varying sizes typically have weight capacities that cannot be exceeded due to engineering or regulatory reasons. Freight may also be measured by cube, which generally refers to the volume of the freight. A vehicle is said to cube-out if it does not exceed its weight capacity, but its volume is completely full.

The second of five phases in a project. Project planners identify how to accomplish the work, organize for the project, key personnel and resources required, tentative schedules, and budget requirements.
Stopping the production line whenever a defect is discovered.
To coil a line that is not in use so that it lies flat on the deck.

Sustained increase in the economic standard of living of the population of a country (or any other defined geographic region), normally accomplished by increasing its stocks of physical and human capital, and by improving its technology.
A quality technique that analyses variations in test results as a possible result of the gage or measurement device used, or operator interpretation of use.

A short board or swatch of heavy canvas, secured in a bridle of ropes, used to hoist a man aloft or over the ship’s side for painting and similar work. Modern boatswain’s chairs incorporate safety harnesses to prevent the occupant from falling

Identifier of a unique article at the pallet, case, or unit level. A coding standard for manufacturers and distributors allowing complete traceability down to the serial number. The EPC network is an open standard allowing supply-chain partners to share product information.
An idiom for the bottom of the sea.
Sporadic demand for end items that may also involve low volumes, and requires specific forecast and safety stock or lead time techniques. More typical of to-order than to-stock environments.

A committee of the ANSI, chartered in 1979, to develop uniform standards for the electronic interchange of business documents. The committee develops and maintains U.S. generic standards (X12) for Electronic Data Interchange.

The way individuals or organisations behave in a purchasing situation. The customer oriented concept finds out the wants, needs, and desires of customers and adapts resources of the organisation to deliver need-satisfying goods and services.
Abbreviation for: Union of South American Nations.
A container with no sides and frame members at the front and rear. Container can be loaded from the sides and top.
In water transportation, the deliberate sacrifice of cargo to make the vessel safe for the remaining cargo. Those sharing in the spared cargo proportionately cover the loss.
See: Second mate.

Purchased items, such as bar stock or food ingredients, transformed by manufacturing operations into an intermediate or finished item. Often used in reference to bulk or commodity items but may include individual components (piece parts) such as nuts, bolts, and screws.
An association of ship owners operating in the same trade route who operate under collective conditions and agree on tariff rates.

Terms of Sale, or INCOTERMS. Obsolete, although heavily used, term of sale meaning “cargo and freight,” whereby the seller pays for cost of goods and freight charges up to destination port. In July, 1990 the International Chamber of Commerce replaced C&F with CFR.
Abbreviation for: High Performance Product Sector.
Software functions that automatically substitute a pre-approved alternate component or product for picking to a production or customer order when the primary item is not available.
Abbreviation for: Twenty-foot Equivalent Unit. Method of measuring vessel load or capacity, in units of containers that are twenty feet long. A 40’ long container measures 2 TEUs.
Abbreviation for: Marine Corps Air Station.
Abbreviation for: Wide Area Augmentation System.
Abbreviation for: Minimum Safe Altitude Warning.

1. To make fast a line around a fitting, usually a cleat or belaying pin. 2. To secure a climbing person in a similar manner. 3. An order to halt a current activity or countermand an order prior to execution.
See: Bumpkin.
Haggling.
Abbreviation for: Runway.
Application features that allow progression from a summarized, general level to the detailed transactions and data comprising the totals.
Problem analysis based on informal judgment or experience versus data manipulation.

The presentation of a wide variety of information in the workplace. Such information may pertain to jobs themselves, to the business as a whole, to how work teams are progressing on a project. Kanban cards are examples of visible management, as are storage bins with sample pans displayed, tool shadow boards, storyboards, etc.
Early 20th-century slang term for a vessel’s radio operator, so called because he repeatedly struck a brass key on his transmitter to broadcast in Morse code.
A demand response method where an end item or service part is purchased and stocked against a forecast.
Abbreviation for: International Trade and Economic Development Division.
A model that assigns a likelihood to events or data within a population, expressed through ranked numerical values or estimates of best case, worst case, or most likely scenarios.
Abbreviation for: Low/Medium Frequency.

The local representative who acts as a liaison among ship owners, local port authorities, terminals, and supply/service companies. An agent handles all details for getting the ship into port; having it unloaded and loaded; inspected and out to sea quickly. An agent arranges for pilots; tug services; stevedores; inspections, etc., as well as, seeing that a ship is supplied with food, water, mail, medical services, etc. A steamship agency does not own the ship.
A forecast based on factors internal to an organisation, such as past shipment demand patterns, instead of external factors such as economic indicators or projections.

A large ocean-going vessel with extensive on-board facilities for processing and freezing caught fish or whales. Some also serve as mother ships for smaller fishing or whaling vessels. Those used for processing fish are also known as fish processing vessels.
Water transport vessels. Ships, boats, personal water craft, etc.
A dedicated internal organisational resource that provides technical or functional application problem-solving advice and follow up to system users.

The aft or trailing edge of a fore-and-aft sail; the leeward edge of a spinnaker; a vertical edge of a square sail. The leech is susceptible to twist, which is controlled by the boom vang, mainsheet and, if rigged with one, the gaff vang.
The act of obtaining permission to import merchandise from another country into the importing nation.
See: Communication tube

Data that describes the characteristics of an item. May include physical characteristics such as size and weight, transactional characteristics such as times sold/consumed and units sold/consumed, or group characteristics such as sales channel, commodity, hazardous classification, etc. Item profiles are used in warehouse design and slotting.
A ring, hook, or other device used to keep a line or chain running in the correct direction or to prevent it rubbing or fouling.
The rim or ‘eyebrow’ above a porthole or scuttle.
Abbreviation for: Design for Supply Chain.
Abbreviation for: Quality Function Deployment.
Relating to not meeting federal air quality standards.

A Dutch transoceanic sailing cargo vessel, square-rigged with two or three masts that were much taller than the masts of a galleon, developed in the 16th century and widely used in the 17th and 18th centuries.
Abbreviation for: Aeronautical Data-Link.
An inclined foot rest, attached to the boat, to which a rower may place and in some instances (usually in competition) attach his feet.
Abbreviation for: On-Time delivery to Commit date.
A tool that compares two or more bills of material to identify duplicates and highlight exceptions and differences in the components. Used in database maintenance and obsolescence reporting.
Abbreviation for: Undesirable Effect.
1. An eating place aboard ship. 2. A group of crew who live and eat together.
Abbreviation for: Business Continuity Plan.
A production order used to replenish inventory to the desired level, as opposed to a requirement for a specific customer order.
Act of purchasing in the spot market (that is at prices ruling on the purchase date) for prompt delivery, in contrast to forward purchase made now for future delivery at futures prices.
Location where cargo enters the care and custody of the carrier.
The Statistical Classification of Domestic and Foreign Commodities Exported from the United States.
A marine insurance term meaning that the assurer will not allow payment for partial loss or damage to cargo shipments except in certain circumstances, such as stranding, sinking, collision or fire.
The temperature of a surrounding body. The ambient temperature of a container is the atmospheric temperature to which it is exposed.
The period after a ship is launched, during which all the remaining construction of the ship is completed and she is readied for sea trials and delivery to her owners.
In rail car or container shipments, the weight of the empty rail car or empty container.
An official signature or seal affixed to certain documents by the consul of the country of destination.
Selecting of and working with two equivalent suppliers for a certain product.
Abbreviation for: Basic Accounting System.
The useful capacity of a process or operation after maintenance, changeover, and other stoppages and loading have been accounted for.
Abbreviation for: Touchdown/ Positioning Circle.
Abbreviation for American Bureau of Shipping.
Abbreviation for: Pay Master General.
The smallest order quantity which, in principle, is allowed.
A specific assurance made by the seller concerning the performance, quality, or nature of the goods or services sold.
Abbreviation for: Compound Annual Growth Rate.
Administrative Voice.
All rigging, cranes, etc., utilised on a ship to load or unload cargo.
A rowboat on davits at the stern of the boat.
Abbreviation for: Local Economic Development.
An e-auction which is used by suppliers to enforce bidding among a number of prospective buyers based on a starting price that is increased during the auction.
Demand that is uneven in terms of timing and quantity variations, and may require more investment in inventory or a longer response time than predictable, even demand.
Locating the position of a product or service such that it remains largely stationary, while transforming resources are moved to and from it.
An accounting method where bookkeeping is performed either as a result of completed or pending activities.

A Canada—U.S. initiative involving the Canada Border Services Agency, Citizenship and Immigration Canada, and the United States Customs and Border Protection and United States Immigration and Naturalisation.
Abbreviation for: Maintenance Monitoring Console.
A key event that defines the end of a phase or reaching a target or goal. Project management systems normally define milestones as activities with zero duration.
In e-commerce, a system for guaranteeing the security of financial transactions conducted over the Internet.
A test used to verify the acceptable functionality of a single program, operation or process that does not also test the impact and integration points with other programs or operations.
A shipment in which the freight does not completely fill the container or rail car; or a particular consignor’s freight when combined with others to produce a full carload.
Abbreviation for: Vendor Managed Replenishment.
Merchandise, commodities, or supplies for sale to consumers.
Abbreviation for: Time Of Flight.
The physical or perpetual quantity of current inventory.
Joint work and communication among people and systems— including business partners, suppliers, and customers—to achieve a common business goal.
To reduce in rank or rating; demote.
A type of ship invented and used by the Vikings for trade, commerce, exploration, and warfare, evolving over several centuries and appearing in its complete form between the 9th and 13th centuries.
Abbreviation for: Department of International Relations and Co-operation.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain Risk Management.
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Refers to locations used to store additional inventory that will eventually replenish forward pick locations. Also called overflow storage, reserve locations, backup storage. Also see: Forward Pick Locations
Refers to: Fourth Generation of Cellular Wireless Standards.
A procurement term employed when there is no competitive marketplace for the requirement, i.e. the product or service needed is available only from one source.
The return movement of a vehicle from its original destination to its original point of origin, often carrying goods back over the same route.
Various people, teams, functions, and organisations along the supply chain working together.

1. Originally (in the mid-to-late 19th century), an enclosed armoured rotating cylindrical box mounting guns which fired through gun ports, the turret rotating over a bearing mounted on a ship’s deck or within her hull. Turret-equipped ships contrasted sharply with those equipped with barbettes, which in the second half of the 19th century were open-topped armoured rings over which rotating gun(s) mounted on a turntable could fire. 2. Since the late 19th century, an enclosed armoured rotating gun house mounted above a barbette, with the gun(s) and their rotating turntable mounted in the barbette, protected by the gun house; in 20th- and 21st-century usage, this generally is any armoured, rotating gun installation on a warship.

1. A method of preparing an anchor for tripping by attaching an anchor cable to the crown and fixing to the ring by a light seizing (also known as becue). The seizing can be broken if the anchor becomes fouled. 2. A type of clinker dinghy, characteristically beamy and slow. 3. An inland racing boat with no keel, a large sail plan, and a planning hull.
Refers to RML Terminal.
A time series analysis model based on previous weighted outputs of a system.

Split month billing is a variation on monthly billing. The client is charged a “regular” rate for inbound storage in the first half of the month, and a “reduced” rate (i.e., 50% discount) for inbound storage with a receipt date after the 15th of the month.
Description of internal customer requirements for goods and/or services needed to be obtained from suppliers, which will serve as the basis for the purchase order.
A computer term referring to a communication protocol whereby messages are sent as blocks of characters. The blocks of data are checked for completeness and accuracy by the receiving computer.
A lighted or unlighted fixed aid to navigation attached directly to the earth’s surface. Lights and day beacons both constitute beacons.

Work performed by people, equipment, technologies, or facilities. Activities are usually described by the “action-verb-adjective-noun” grammar convention. Activities may occur in a linked sequence, and activity-to-activity assignments may exist.
A specialised watercraft designed for operation on a canal.
1. Traditionally, a launch was the largest ship’s boat carried by a warship. 2. In modern usage, a large motorboat. 3. To dispatch a ship down a slipway, prior to fitting-out and commissioning.
1. Abbreviation for: Advanced Manufacturing Technology. 2. Acronym for;The Association for Manufacturing Technology.

An independent society that certifies that a vessel has been built and maintained according to the society’s rules for that type of vessel and complies with the applicable rules and regulations of the country of the vessel’s registry, and the international conventions of which that country is a member. A vessel that receives its certification is referred to as being “in-class.”

A graphical tool used to chart the “break-even point” – the point where the total sales revenue axis line intersects with total cost axis line. Sales revenue, variable and fixed costs are plotted on the vertical axis while volume is plotted on the horizontal axis.

term: Warehouse Management and Transportation Execution Systems
definition: Logistics information systems that initiate and control the movement of materials between supply chain partners.
A part that has been reserved, but not yet withdrawn or issued, from stock and is thus not available for other purposes
Long-term movement up or down in a time series.
Abbreviation for: Computer Numerical Control.
An outstanding claim against an organisation which may include wages payable, accounts payable, short or long term loans, bonds, etc.
Abbreviation for: Noise Exposure Map.
Abbreviation for: Direct Debit.
A small iceberg or ice floe which is barely visible above the surface of the water.
Abbreviation for: Goods and Services Tax (Canada).
A situation in which management decision-making authority is given to managers at many levels in the organisational hierarchy.
Abbreviation for: Simulation Modelling System.
Aircraft Evaluation Group.
Abbreviation for: Marginal Visual Flight Rules.

The use of space within a storage area, trailer, or container. Cube utilisation is generally calculated as a percentage of total space or of total “usable” space. Note: there is a point at which too high percent utilisation can create inefficiency.
The yearly recurring variation on monthly demand.
Inventory system in which once a product has reached the predetermined minimum quantity enough replacement product is ordered to bring the level up to the predetermined maximum quantity.
An arrow diagram used in planning and managing processes and projects.
The standard terms and conditions on a purchase order or other document.
Abbreviation for: Emergency Operating Facility.
Abbreviation for: Current Reality Tree and Cathode Ray Tube
The inspection of a vessel pursuant to international conventions, by a classification society surveyor, on behalf of the flag state, that takes place every year

The life cycle cost view of an asset, which includes acquisition, setup, support, ongoing maintenance, service, and all operating expenses. It focuses attention on the sum of all costs of owning an asset, as opposed to the initial or vendor cost, and is useful in outsourcing decisions.
A third party that performs outsourced storage, order packing, shipment, and tracking activities for the original manufacturer or distributor.
Commodities that are not subject to import duties or can be transported exempt of regulation.
A warehouse authorised by customs to receive duty–free merchandise.
A tender which is open internationally for offers by the interested renderers. It is given wide publicity so as to have global reach.
Defined as the horizontal relationship of organisations that experience each other as effective competitors (for example, the leather and footwear industry and electronics industry).

The factor used to measure usage of a defined activity. For example, the materials support activity of a forklift driver retrieving goods from the warehouse could be driven either based on number of trips, or total time required on trips.
Price includes commission as well as CIF.
Test systems integrated into the production process that operate and report without human intervention.
Abbreviation for: Memorandum of Agreement and Military Operations Area.
Abbreviation for: Bonded Logistics Parks.

A computer term referring to a system of numerical notation that assumes only two possible states or values, zero (0) and one (1). Computer systems use a binary technique where an individual bit or “Binary Digit” of data can be “on” or “off” (1 or 0). Multiple bits are combined into a “Byte” which represents a character or number.
When an external provider takes full responsibility for the execution and coordination of outsourced activities.
The sale of a vessel as scrap metal.

The degree of insight into future requirements, or the key factors that will impact system performance. The ability to access or view pertinent data or information as it relates to logistics and the supply chain.
Abbreviation for: AWOS Data Acquisition System.
Abbreviation for: Business Process Re-engineering.
The recognised manual describing accepted methodology for computing the capacity and level-of-service for various types of roads; published by the Transportation Research Board (TRB).
Abbreviation for: En Route Flight Advisory Service.
The relative slackness of an anchor chain; this term means taut and extended.
The mix of goods and services produced by processes.

The process of buying and selling credits to emit carbon. Companies and organisations are assigned emission permits that stand for the amount of carbon they are allowed to emit. If a company or organisation emits less carbon, then it can sell its emissions permits. If emissions are more than its current permits, then it will need to buy emission permits from other companies or organisations that produce less carbon.
The use of the internet to facilitate buying and selling activities.
A situation where at the corporate level, a central purchasing department can be found where corporate contracting specialists operate at the strategic and tactical level.

Term used in describing functionality of Warehouse Management Systems to mix tasks to reduce travel time. Sending a forklift driver to put away a pallet on his way to his next pick is an example of task interleaving.
Data represented by individual values that can be ordered or assigned a specific rank on a scale.
Agents with broad powers and considerable latitude in using their own judgment to carry out duties assigned to them by their principals.
Relates to all specifications needed to select the right supplier, including quality, logistics, maintenance, legal, environmental, and budgetary requirements.
The various elements within the concept of quality, such asfunctionality, appearance, reliability, durability, recovery, etc

Trucking company which dedicates trailers to a single shipper’s cargo, as opposed to an LTL (Less Than Truckload) carrier which transports the consolidated cargo of several shippers and makes multiple deliveries.
Goods/products for which demand fluctuations affect each other.

The concept defined in lean theory which triggers production of materials only upon receipt of an actual customer order and aligns the production capacity of the supply chain to external customer demand patterns.

Broadly, there are three types of indefinite delivery or term type contracts. Indefinite quantity indefinite delivery contracts, indefinite quantity definite delivery contracts and requirements contracts.

A product or product line that requires a higher usage of direct labour as compared to other products that make more use of automation. Labour-intensive products may be candidates for outsourcing unless there is a unique skill set required.
The price of the product is determined on the market, and is generated exclusively by market circumstances such as demand, supply stock positions the economic situation and political factors.

1. A group of naval ships of the same or similar design. 2. A standard of construction for merchant vessels, including standards for specific types or specialised capabilities of some types of merchant vessels. A ship meeting the standard is in class, one not meeting them is out of class.

Incentives in procurement refer to the ‘carrots’ that may be offered to suppliers to motivate the supplier to perform to or above agreed standards. For example, a risk and reward contract will typically feature a bonus payable to the supplier if they exceed agreed performance standards. Another incentive that may be used is an extension of the contract. For example, the contract may be for an initial two-year period with an option to extend for a further one-year and then another one year, subject to satisfactory performance. The contract extension is an incentive to motivate the contractor to perform. In practice the use of incentives seeks to equip the buyer with some way of motivating performance once competitive tension is no longer present.

Sectors, sub-sectors or industries that have been designated by Government in line with national development and industrial policies for local production, where only locally produced services, works or goods or locally manufactured goods meet the stipulated minimum threshold for local production and content.
Abbreviation for: Off Premises Exchange.
Abbreviation for: Personal Digital Assistant.
Abbreviation for: Communications Command Centre.
Stocks of materials needed to support operations, but which do not form part of the final product, such as oil, paper, cleaners, etc.
Notice of Completion.
A specific course of action designed to attain a stated objective.
Flight Data Input/ Output Remote.
A merchant ship designed to transport unpackaged bulk cargo. Also called Bulk Freighter or Bulker.

An evaluation technique that may be used to score proposals. It can be applied to major areas and elements of management, operational suitability and other criteria, when identified for evaluation. Generally applied to technical and management areas.
Abbreviation for: United States Air Force.

In earlier use, below the orlop deck, the lower part of the interior of a ship’s hull, especially when considered as storage space, as for cargo. In later merchant vessels it extended up through the decks to the underside of the weather deck.
Abbreviation for: Simplified Short Approach Lighting System.
A retail sales term referring to the area where a sale occurs, such as the checkout counter. POP is also used to refer to the displays and other sales promotion tools located at a checkout counter.
A square yard used to spread the foot of a topsail where no course is set, e.g. on the foremast of a topsail schooner or above the driver on the mizzen mast of a ship rigged vessel
Abbreviation for: Estimated Time of Arrival.
The time that the container was discharged (grounded) from the train.
Abbreviation for: Service Oriented Architecture.
An attempt to capture the broad cost categories that are affected by, or affect, quality, usually categorised as prevention costs, appraisal costs, internal failure costs, and external failure costs.
Abbreviation for: Voice Recording System.
Abbreviation for: Quality of Work Life.
Any computer program, set of programs, or package of programs created to solve a particular business problem or function.
Refers to: Web Based Electronic Data Interchange.
The list of all suppliers with whom an organisation currently has transactions / dealings or has had dealings in the past few years.
Near Mid Air Collision.
Abbreviation for: Capacity to Promise.
The stage of the team development process of identifying problems and opportunities, establishing a plan of attack, and then implementing the plan.
Damage-Free Car. Boxcars equipped with special bracing material.
A site in which imported goods are exempted from custom duties. Countries establish it to encourage economic development such as manufacturing and distribution.

A travel time reliability performance measure defined by the ratio of an actual travel time (typically the 50th, 80th or 95th percentile travel time) to the free flow travel time. Conceptually represents the extra travel time travellers must spend compared to an uncongested travel time.
A factor is an agent who will, at a discount (usually five to eight percent of the gross), buy receivables.
Term sometimes used to describe forecast periods.
Letters, numbers, and other symbols placed on cargo packages to facilitate identification. Also known as marks.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Instrument Procedures.
Air freight carried in the belly of passenger aircraft.

General and consistent definition of all those individuals or organisations for whom work products are directly provided. When a work product is acquired with some form of compensation in return, the recipient is known as a client. If the acquisition is for the direct use of the work product, the recipient is known as the user.The end user is one who receives the intended benefit of the work product. (End users of consumable product such as food, fuel, and clothing are known as consumers.)
Abbreviation for: General Aviation Activity and Avionics.
An illegal form of discounting or refunding that effectively lowers the tariff price.
A pattern in which demand is not constant for each time frame but varies due to seasonality, trend, or other factors.

The point at which sellers have fulfilled their obligations so the goods in a legal sense could be said to have been delivered to the buyer. They are shorthand expressions that set out the rights and obligations of each party when it comes to transporting the goods.

Scattered, untimely and poorly planned urban development that occurs in urban fringe and rural areas. It frequently invades land important for environmental and natural resources protection. Sprawl is typically manifested by one or more of the following patterns: leapfrog development; ribbon or strip development; of large expanses of low-density development of one type, such as single family homes.

A storage area - physically separated from production or other areas - that has limited access. It is typically used to control critical or high dollar value items by issuing from the stockroom only against authorised order pick slips, as opposed to keeping them as open stock on the production floor.
The resources within an operation that are not immediately evident or tangible, such as relationships with suppliers and customers, process knowledge, and new product and service development.
Series of steps that begin with a request for purchase and end with notification of shipment received in satisfactory condition
A small cabin in a boat; a cabin, for the use of the captain, in the after part of a sailing ship under the poop deck.

A product development team mandate to improve a specified supply chain factor, X, through careful design. For example products may be “designed for” optimising manufacturing, supply, and/or usability.
Abbreviation for: Low Emission Zone.
Movement of a tractor, without trailer, over the highway.
Resting on or touching the ground or bottom (usually involuntarily).
Abbreviation for: Change Control Board.
Abbreviation: Industrial Virtual Reality.
A lease in which the lease payments are applied, in whole or in part, as installment payments for equity or ownership upon completion of the agreement.

Assets normally expected to be converted to cash or consumed during the normal operating business cycle (or one year), which usually includes cash, marketable securities, accounts receivable, and inventory.
A mathematical determination of a process’s capability to meet quality standards. A Cp ≥ 1 means the process is capable of meeting the measured standard.

1. A vessel used by the commanding officer of a group of naval ships (reflecting the custom of its commander, characteristically a flag officer, flying a distinguishing flag aboard the ship on which he or she is embarked. 2. Used more loosely, the lead ship in a fleet of naval or commercial vessels, typically the first, largest, fastest, most heavily armed, or, in terms of media coverage, best-known.
A term that refers to the information flows between higher and lower levels of planning and control systems within an organisation.

A business leader or senior manager who ensures that resources are available for training and projects, and who is involved in project toll gate reviews; also an executive who supports and addresses Six Sigma organisational issues.
The practice of placing a value on the profit generated by business done with a particular customer.
A clause in a warehouse policy that defines when coverage begins and ends.
The earned (standard) cost or budget value of project tasks completed for a given time period. It is compared to actual cost of work performed (ACWP) to determine variance conditions.
A ship’s store of merchandise, such as clothing, tobacco, etc., maintained aboard merchant ships for sale to the crew.
Relates to what processes, activities, and decisions actually create costs in the supply chain.

term: United Nations Standard Products and Services Code (UN/SPSC)
definition: The United Nations Standard Products and Services Code is a hierarchical convention that is used to classify all products and services. It was developed jointly between the UN and Dun & Bradstreet (D&B). Has a five level coding structure (segment, family, class, commodity, business function) for nearly 9,000 products.The consolidation of a quantity of individual items into one large shipping unit for easier handling. Loading one or more large items of cargo onto a single piece of equipment, such as a pallet.
A component or material (child) used in the production of an upper level item (parent).
Abbreviation for: Federal Procurement Data System.
Cost that would disappear if all products and processes were free of deficiencies; also known as the cost of poor quality.
Processes or individuals within an operation that supply products or services to other processes or individuals within the operation.

term: International Ship and Port Security Code (ISPS)
definition: It is an amendment to the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) Convention (1974/1988) on minimum security arrangements for ships, ports, and government agencies. Having come into force in 2004, it prescribes responsibilities to governments, shipping companies, shipboard personnel, and port/facility personnel to “detect security threats and take preventative measures against security incidents affecting ships or port facilities used in international trade.”
A document required on merchandise imported into the United States.
Abbreviation for: Any-Quantity Rate.
Lead time for a manufactured or purchased item that varies due to changes in quantity or process constraints.
Abbreviation for: National Transportation Safety Board.
Abbreviation for: Water Line.
A summary punitive implement.
The daytime identifier of an aid to navigation presenting one of several standard shapes (square, triangle, rectangle) and colours (red, green, white, orange, yellow, or black).
Trading firms who deliver their products to other companies. Their customers are the retail, industrial and service companies, which in their turn may deliver directly to the final consumer.
A chart that plots the relationship of one numeric variable to another on a horizontal and vertical axis, and determines the degree of dependency or interdependency.
A barge which loads material dumped into it by a dredger and discharges the cargo through the bottom.
A knot used to tie a rope or line to a fixed object. Also see: Bend.
An approach to job design that involves dividing a task down into relatively small parts, each of which is accomplished by a single person.

term: Time Charter Equivalent Earnings Per Day
definition: A measure of the average daily revenue performance of a vessel on a per voyage basis. Our method of calculating time charter equivalent earnings per day is consistent with industry standards and is determined by dividing voyage revenues (net of voyage expenses) by voyage days for the relevant time period. Time charter equivalent earnings per day is a standard shipping industry performance measure used primarily to compare period-to-period changes in a shipping company’s performance despite changes in the mix of charter types (i.e., spot charters, time charters, and bare boat charters) under which the vessels may be employed during specific periods.
Abbreviation for: National Treasury.

Partnering refers to the process of developing a relationship to one in which both parties are prepared to work cooperatively. It requires selecting the potential partner and facilitating changes in behavior, such as the replacement of competition with cooperation and the development of trust. If the parties have been used to claiming value from each other in win-lose negotiations, partnering implies creating and sharing that value. Partnering also describes the creation of a culture where the seller is open about their costs, and the buyer declines to behave opportunistically.
Abbreviation for: Local Noise Amplifier.
Inventory in a carrier’s possession, being transported to the buyer.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Equipment Systems.
Abbreviation for: Surface Movement Guidance and Control.
Abbreviation for: Voice Frequency.

An overhead allocation method based on overall cycle time as opposed to volume or number of units. It focuses on time as a factor in competition, and the consumption of resources of all types as time passes.
The embedded technology within a product or service, as distinct from process technology.
Contingent monies or considerations previously disbursed that are returned due to unrealized fulfillment of terms upon which the considerations were distributed.
See: Order Cycle.
Abbreviation for: National Environmental Policy Act.
The best fit of sample data points to a linear model by minimising the sum of the squares of deviations between the points and the line.
Abbreviation for: Cost, Insurance, Freight, Interest, and Exchange.
Body of law that deals with maritime cases. In the UK, it is administered by the Probate, Divorce, and Admiralty Division of the High Court of Justice or Supreme Court.

All activities, both value added and nonvalue added, required to bring a product from raw material state into the hands of the customer, bring a customer requirement from order to delivery, and bring a design from concept to launch.
The amount in degrees that a vessel tilts from the vertical.
The side of a ship sheltered from the wind (cf. weather side).

The products which are determined for delivery from stock. Additional terms for stock are: All-time stock, Anticipation stock, Available stock, Buffer stock, Calculated stock, Capacity loading stock, Closing stock, Consignment stock, Cyclical stock, Decoupling stock, Economic stock, Effective stock, Free stock, Lot-size stock, Maximum stock, Norm stock, Obsolete stock, Opening stock, Physical stock, Pipeline stock, Reserved stock, Safety stock, Seasonal stock, Shortage stock, Speculation stock, Strategy stock, Surplus stock, Work-in-progress stock.
Selecting of and working with one supplier for a certain product.
A travel mode that includes all motor vehicle traffic using a roadway except transit buses (includes such vehicles as trucks, recreational vehicles, motorcycles, and tour buses).(HCM definition)
A conventional or limited purpose entity generally restricted to providing specialised services, such as clearing funds or settling accounts.
A part master record that lists its description, unit of measure, dimensions, family and group classification, production or purchasing ordering data, and other pertinent information.
Abbreviation for: Small, Medium Enterprise Development Programme.

An indicator of how profitable a company is relative to its total assets. ROA gives an idea as to how efficient management is at using its assets to generate earnings. Calculated by dividing a company’s annual earnings by its total assets, ROA is displayed as a percentage. Sometimes this is referred to as “return on investment.”
A table that matches personnel, or other resources, with desired skills to provide views of the need for additional development, training, or the acquisition of new resources.
The forgone profit associated with a stockout.
Network Monitoring and Control System.
Abbreviation for: Federal Railroad Administration.
The prediction, projection or estimation of expected demand over a specified future time period.
A type of layout where resources are arranged sequentially, according to the steps required to make a product.
Abbreviation for: Strategic Air Command.

According to Roger Schmenner and Morgan Swink, “the greater the random variability either demanded of the process or inherent in the process itself or in the items processed, the less productive the process is.” This law is relevant to customization because completing upstream activities off-line helps isolate these activities from the variability caused by either the timing or the unique requirements of individual customers.
Material assets which are required to replace disposed items.
Charge for normal warehouse handling (inbound or outbound, or both) to customer.
The product audit provides an image of the degree to which a company succeeds in making everything run perfectly, i.e., according to the standards and requirements established by the company itself.
Abbreviation for: Letter of Intent.

A key project implementation strategy that tests normal business case scenarios in a proposed new system to uncover people, process and system issues, generate resolutions, and define action steps needed to complete the implementation. The pilot is normally done after initial vendor, or in-house education using a test database of representative data.
Abbreviation for: Computer Based Training.
A process manufacturing environment where material moves in a continuous stream instead of a discrete batch.
The protocol and standards that are used on the internet for formatting, retrieving, storing, and displaying information.

Containers designed to conform to the inside of an aircraft. There are many shapes and sizes of containers. Air cargo containers fall into three categories: 1) air cargo pallets, 2) lower deck containers, and 3) box-type containers.

Projects designed to improve vehicle and pedestrian safety on the city, county, and state highway systems. The program is divided into three subprograms – rail/highway crossings, highway safety, and traffic safety grants.
Abbreviation for: Tower Control Computer Complex.
The total amount of work required to produce a unit of output, usually measured in standard times.
The time between items emerging from a process, usually applied to ‘paced’ processes.
The quantity of goods required to sustain operations for a specified period of time, after which time, orders will be placed for more goods.
Abbreviation for: Remote Radar Weather Display.
ALS with Sequenced Flashers I.

Generally describes an unfinished item made of metal that is produced through pouring molten metal into a mould. A casting is later machined into a finished or semi-finished item. Also describes the process used to produce castings.

Abbreviation for: Principal Investigator and Production Incentive. Abbreviation for: Production Incentive. A South African Government initiative aimed at assisting the production industry to upgrade facilities.
A specific location from where goods will depart for movement.
An arithmetic measure of the acceptability of process variation.
Rigging which is used to support masts and spars, and is not normally manipulated during normal operations. Cf. running rigging.

A tender/offer submitted for a number of different goods or services in which the tenderer stipulates that the tender/offer is valid only if the contract is awarded for all items included in his tender/offer.

Systematic process to improve the coordination in planning and implementation of air, water, and land-based transportation facilities and services; required for transportation facilities connected to the National Highway System (NHS).
One leg of a move without a paying cargo load. Usually refers to repositioning an empty piece of equipment.

Any vessel entering U.S. waters from a foreign port must give a 96-hour ANOA. Vessels of 300 gross registered tonnage and greater must notify the U.S. Coast Guard’s National Vessel Movement Centre. Smaller vessels notify the appropriate Captain of the Port.
1. An oar used for sculling. 2. A boat propelled by sculling, generally for recreation or racing.
Abbreviation for: Flexible Machine Centre.
Deadweight tonne, which is a unit of a vessel’s capacity for cargo, fuel, oil, stores, and crew measured in metric tonnes of 1,000 kilograms.
Abbreviation for: Airmen’s Meteorological Information.
Cargo that is shipped as a unit or package (for example palletised cargo, boxed cargo, large machinery, trucks), but is not containerised
Hauling the buntline ropes over the sails to prevent chafing.
Activities and costs that can be eliminated without reducing performance function or value as perceived by the customer.
A short-sea vessel that transfers cargo between a central “hub” port and smaller “spoke” ports.
Logistics company takes responsibility for quality control relating to product delivery.
A budget tied to a specific volume or level of production, distribution, or other activity.
See: ABC Classification
The design contest is a procedure that is used to obtain a plan or a design based on competition among expert parties. The design is to be judged by a professional jury.
An alternative name for the ‘natural’ diagonal of the product process matrix.
Abbreviation for: Airport Layout Plan.

A remote secure location, such as a post office box, where customers send payments instead of to corporate headquarters, and where a local financial institution receives those payments and transfers to the vendor account. A system used to speed up the cash collection cycle.

The process of controlling and minimizing the range of new parts, equipment, materials, methods, and procedures that are used to produce goods or services. Its goal is to minimize the variety of all elements in the production or service delivery process. The main techniques of variety reduction are simplification, standardization, and specialization. A methodology used in value analysis.
A line used to control the shape of a sail.
The amount of time at a piece of equipment or work centre that is available for productive working after stoppages and inefficiencies have been accounted for.
A method of forecasting that uses people’s skills, knowledge, and judgment rather than more formal analysis.
The streamlined pull of products in response to customer requirements while minimising the total costs of distribution.

The value of the goods, declared by the shipper on a bill of lading, for the purpose of determining a freight rate or the limit of the carrier’s liability. Also used by customs as the basis for calculation of duties, etc.
The front rails of the chassis that rise above the plane of the chassis and engage in the tunnel of a container leading to the connection to tractor.
Abbreviation for Report of Service Activity.
Value of inventory at standard cost before any reserves for excess and obsolete items are taken.
An anti–trust act of the U.S. Congress making price discrimination unlawful.
Assume the demand for an item is directly related to the demand for other items, with this relationship used to control stocks.
Abbreviation for Remote Monitoring Subsystem Concentrator.

The Supply Chain Operations Reference Model developed by the Supply-Chain Council to measure total supply chain performance. It includes delivery and order fulfilment performance, supply chain response time, production flexibility, warranty, and returns processing costs, cash-to-cash cycle time, inventory and asset turns, and other factors in evaluating the overall effective performance of a supply chain.
A vertical line inside a compass case indicating the direction of the ship’s head.
Shipments consisting entirely of units of a single commodity, such as cars, lumber, or scrap metal.
Abbreviation for: Western Electric Company.
See: Commonality.
Abbreviation for: World Health Organisation.
Abbreviation for: Trailer Load and Taxi Lane.
A method where an item is purchased only when required by a customer order specifying that item.
Competitive factors that are neither order-winning nor qualifying; performance in them does not significantly affect the competitive position of an operation.
A laser identifies the bin for the next item in the rack; when the picker completes the pick, the barcode is scanned and the system then points the laser at the next bin.
Abbreviation for: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.
The percentage of freight bills that are error-free.(error-free freight bills / total freight bills) * 100. Billing accuracy is key to profitability and customer satisfaction.

Both the act of rigging a temporary mast and sails and the name of the resulting rig. A jury rig would be built at sea when the original rig was damaged, then it would be used to sail to a harbour or other safe place for permanent repairs.

A facility that connects urban, urbanising or rural areas within multi- county regions, provides connections from regional activity centres to the Strategic Intermodal System (SIS)/ Emerging SIS, or otherwise serves important regional travel. Examples of regionally significant facilities could include highway, waterway, rail and transit corridors serving major regional commercial, industrial or medical facilities, and regional transportation hubs such as passenger terminals, commercial service and major general aviation airports, deep-water and special generator seaports, and major regional freight terminals and distribution centres.
Abbreviation for: Daily Vehicle Miles of Travel. The total miles travelled by all vehicles in a specific area over a 24-hour period; often used to compare changes in travel patterns over time.
Abbreviation for: Primary Rate Interface.
The link between two entities in a system or network, such as the relationship between a vendor and a customer or two activities in a project.

A vessel, typically an obsolete or captured warship, used for naval gunnery practice or for weapons testing. The term includes both ships intended to be sunk and ships intended to survive and see repeated use as a target.

Also called second officer, a licensed member of the deck department of a merchant ship, third – or on some ocean liners fourth – in command; a watchkeeping officer, customarily the ship’s navigator. Other duties vary, but the second mate is often the medical officer and in charge of maintaining distress signaling equipment. On oil tankers, the second mate usually assists the chief mate with tank-cleaning operations.
Abbreviation for: Shipper Load, Shipper Count/Shipper Load, Driver Count.
A boat, ship, or airplane.
In this situation the price is based on the amount of profit that should be realised. Based on the fixed and variable costs and the expected selling price, the required sales volume is calculated.
A data collection device where a magnetic card is swiped, or pulled, through a slot in the middle.
Abbreviation for: Total Average Cycle Time.
Dangerously steep and breaking seas due to opposing currents and wind in shallow areas.
The ratio of demand to capacity.
A model that depicts the design process as the progressive reduction of design options from many alternatives down to the final design.
Explains how to professionalize purchasing, using strategic management processes and enabling processes.
National Airspace System or Naval Air Station.
Activities between the buyer and seller that enhance or facilitate the sale or use of the seller’s products or services.
Any country where an organisation has its world headquarters.
A legal term meaning the action for the recovery of property. A writ of replevin allows for the repossession of property.
A computer-based model of a product, process or service that can be tested for its characteristics before the actual process, product or service is produced.
Abbreviation for: Vertical Integration.

Abbreviation for: Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment directive. European Community directive 2002/96/EC where manufacturers are responsible for disposing of electrical and electronic equipment waste.
A manufacturing environment with batch or continuous transformation of gas, liquid, or powder, fixed facilities, low complexity, and relatively few transactions.

An inattentive helmsmen might allow the dangerous situation to arise where the wind is blowing into the sails ‘backwards’, causing a sudden (and possibly dangerous) shift in the position of the sails.
When one party confers with another identified party and, prior to taking action(s), considers that party’s views.
Relates to building mechanical and electrical services.
Pricing largely based on competitor prices.
A standard numeric code developed by the United Nations to classify commodities used in international trade, based on a hierarchy.
A collection of firms that typically exist for only a short period. Virtual supply chains are more flexible than traditional supply chains, but they are also less efficient.
Damage to the body caused by repetitive activities.

Air Force Material Command conducts research, development, testing, and evaluation, and provides the acquisition management services and logistics support necessary to keep Air Force weapon systems ready for war. The command develops, acquires, and sustains the aerospace power needed to defend the United States and its interests for today and tomorrow
A ship designed and equipped to carry out research at sea, especially hydrographic, oceanographic, fisheries, naval, polar research, and oil exploration.

A document, required by some foreign countries, describing a shipment of goods and showing information such as the consignor, consignee, and value of the shipment. Certified by a consular official of the foreign country, it is used by the country’s custom.
A business that operates trucks primarily for transporting its own products and raw materials. The principal business activity of a private carrier is not transportation.
An air carrier that transports cargo only
Those causes of loss for which the carrier is not legally liable. The elemental risks of ocean transport.
A software, functional, or network system provided by a third party who owns the underlying resource and provides access, on a subscription basis, determined by usage and service levels.
The rate by which new customers are acquired, or existing customers are retained. A key selling point to potential marquis partners.

A standard tariff provision in motor carrier pricing designed to compensate carriers for shipments that take up floor space in equipment without offering much weight or ability to load other freight on top to achieve an optimal load. Normally adds significant cost to the freight bill from the carrier.
1,000 board feet. One MBM equals 2,265 C.M.
Commercial risk is related to the uncertainty with regard to the price we will pay and the costs that we will incur when having outsourced our activities to the supplier
A penalty charged to a customer returning goods for credit that covers the labor charges incurred in processing the receipt.
Abbreviation for: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
A series of high-level, non-procedural computer languages that use menus, drag-and drop, point-and-click, and English-like wording to design and develop applications.

A specifically designed sail for tighter reaching legs. Reaching sails are often used in racing with a true wind angle of 35 to 95 degrees. They are generally used before the wind angle moves aft enough to permit spinnakers to be flown

The U.S. Air Force Air Mobility Command’s mission is to provide global air mobility. The command also plays a crucial role in providing humanitarian support at home, and around the world. It includes: AMC Airmen–active duty, Air National Guard, Air Force Reserve and Civil Reserve Air Fleet

Describes a unit of measure and the way multiple physical units are packaged. A case would typically be a sealed corrugated carton where a standardised quantity (greater than one) of a specific item is packed.

The available production time divided by customer demand. For example, if a widget factory operates 480 minutes per day and customers demand 240 widgets per day, takt time is two minutes. Takt is German for a precise interval of time.
Abbreviation for: Strategic Supply Chain Management Leadership Program (PMAC Canada).

Management approach based on considering events that trigger, interrupt, suspend, or modify the movement of flows. It is based on a computer application, developed by the American firm, AMR Research, to direct, alert, simulate, track, and measure activities making up the Logistics Chain. This system assumes data integration and process synchronisation among the set of applications used to manage the Logistics Chain (SCE and SCP).
The expected or actual date of a shipment's arrival.
A letter from the shipper to its agent that lists the particulars of a shipment, the documents being transmitted, and instructions for the disposition of those documents.
Formal description of a single customer-supplier pair within a business process.
The function in the organisation that develops new knowledge and ideas and operationalises the ideas to form the underlying knowledge on which product, service, and process designs are based.

A part number composed of characters that do not imply anything about the characteristics of the part or the family it belongs to. Separate code and description fields are used to convey associated information instead of building it into the part number itself.
Abbreviation for: Public Procurement Unit.
The order fulfilment state a distribution operation achieves when it can respond, closest to real time, to changes in demand while shipping 100% of customer compliant orders at the least cost.
A technique used in requirements planning where available resources are calculated on demand using a beginning balance and known or planned supply and demand for the period.
A rope used as a punitive device. See: Teaser, Togey
The standard amount of days a given item can be stored after a receipt before it must be tested, or is declared unusable for shipments or production purposes.
Abbreviation for: Caribbean Community

The life cycle management of a product and/or process that includes design, ordering, shipping, customer usage, and service or warranty repair history to ensure conformance to the desired configuration. It includes history and documentation on the materials, production facilities, manufacturing process, and engineering changes over the product life cycle.
Refers to: Threshold.
Abbreviation for: Polish Register of Shipping.
1. Abbreviation for: Problem Identification Document. 2. A discrete component item such as nuts, bolts, or screws used in an upper-level assembly.
The central structural basis of the hull.
Level to which the stock of a given article at a customer’s location is filled up by the replenishment process. Can be defined manually or calculated by a forecast.

Internal or external personnel who are responsible for the installation of a project or system. Team members include the project leader, functional team leaders, functional team members, and technical support and consultants as required. Team members may be assigned on a full-time basis, on a part-time basis as required for their area of responsibility, or on an ad-hoc basis to solve a specific issue.
Outsourcing tasks to a large, undefined group of people via an open call.
Abbreviation for: Functional Units or Systems.
A response that solves a project or system issue by the use of alternate methods or a change in procedures in place of a program modification.

1. A “box,” typically 10 to 40 feet long, which is primarily used for ocean freight shipments. For travel to and from ports, containers are loaded onto truck chassis or on railroad flatcars. <br> 2. The packaging, such as a carton, case, box, bucket, drum, bin, bottle, bundle, or bag, that an item is packed and shipped in.
Abbreviation for: Freedom of Information Act.
A technique that brings together scores that indicate the relative importance and relative performance of different competitive factors in order to prioritize them as candidates for improvement.

AIDC describes the direct entry of data into a computer system, programmable logic controller (PLC), or other microprocessor-controlled device, without using a keyboard. In the supply chain, the most common data-collection technologies are bar codes, voice technology, radio frequency identification (RFID), and sensors. Since it is possible to encode a wide range of information, from basic item identification to comprehensive details about that item, AIDC technologies provide a reliable means, not only to identify, but also to track items.
The materials and equipment required to assemble a special project overseas, such as a factory or highway.

American Standard Code for Information Interchange; ASCII format—simple text based data with no formatting. The standard code for information exchange among data processing systems. Uses a coded character set consisting of 7-bit coded characters (8 bits including parity check).
Additional travel time beyond a set norm.
The standard language for describing the contents and appearance of pages on the World Wide Web.
Pointing the ship towards the direction of the wind; generally not the fastest point of travel on a sailing vessel.
Vertical wooden peg or pin inserted through the gunwale to form a fulcrum for oars when rowing. Used in place of a rowlock.
The primary measure of system performance relating to the expected percentage of the supported system that will be available at a random point in time and not out of service for lack of spares.
In the theory of constraints, a cause and effect diagram that links problems, or undesirable effects (UDE).
Small platforms built into the sides of a ship to spread the shrouds to a more advantageous angle. Also used as a platform for manual depth sounding.
One or more companies, or individuals, who participate in the flow of goods and services from the manufacturer to the final user or consumer.

A steamship (ocean carrier) service running on a particular international route. Examples: NSCSA (National Shipping Company of Saudi Arabia), American President Lines (APL), Maersk Sealand, Evergreen, etc.
To leave room between two ships moored (berthed) to allow space for manoeuvre.
Abbreviation for: International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification, and Watchkeeping Steamer.
Only raw materials and components are kept in stock. Every customer order is a specific project.
Abbreviation for: Air Carrier District Office.
