Defined as the practice of partnering among distribution channel members that changes the traditional replenishment process from distributor-generated purchase order to one based on actual or forecast consumer demand.
A sailor who takes soundings with a lead, measuring the depth of water.
The process by which activities along a value chain are relatively reduced to minimise its impact on the environment.

The documentation for a new or proposed system that states design strategy, provided functionality, source of inputs and audience or target user base, and may state performance or other targets. An overall translation of project or system requirements into a defined specification that supports those requirements.

In cost management, an approach to inventory valuation in which variable costs and a portion of fixed costs are assigned to each unit of production. The fixed costs are usually allocated to units of output on the basis of direct labour hours, machine hours, or material costs. Syn.: Allocation Costing
Abbreviation for: Information Technology.
Document showing contents and loading sequence, point of origin, and point of destination for a container. Vessels are required by law to carry such a document for each container carried.

It implies purchasing a security, commodity, or currency in one market with the intention of financial gain. In international currency transactions, profits can be made by simultaneous buying and selling of one, or more than one, currency. In arbitrage it is the aberration in the market that is taken advantage of
A method whereby a business dispenses its product, such as a retail or distribution channel, call centre, or web based electronic store front.

A chunk of sandstone used to scrub the decks. The name comes from both the kneeling position sailors adopt to scrub the deck (reminiscent of genuflection for prayer), and the stone itself (which resembled a Bible in shape and size).
Abbreviation for: Dangerous Goods and Director General.
A U.S. Customs program wherein at least two designated customs ports will enter cargo that arrives at either port without the necessity of an in-bound document.
Abbreviation for: Forum for China-Africa Co-operation.

The generic set of performance indicators that can be used to set the objectives or judge the performance of any type of operation; although there are alternative lists proposed by different authorities, the five common performance objectives are quality, speed, dependability, flexibility, and cost.
An archaic practice. An acknowledgement of cargo receipt signed by a mate of the vessel. The possessor of the mate’s receipt is entitled to the bill of lading, in exchange for that receipt.
The fourth of five phases of a project. In this phase, the organization actually starts to execute the project plan.
Device that uses a moving laser to read bar codes. Devices can be portable hand-held units, or fixed units.
A system of creating balance by featuring a set of qualitative measures in the formal measurement system.
A performance dimension that refers to the ability to deliver products or service when promised.
A project cost measurement that tracks the actual costs associated with tasks performed in a given time frame and compares them to budget costs to track rate variances.
See: Cumulative Lead Time
Abbreviation for: Environmental Goods & Services.

Abbreviation for: Gross Margin Return on Inventory Investment. Calculation that shows your margin relative to your average inventory investment. Calculated by dividing your annual gross margin (dollars) by your average inventory (dollars). Particularly useful in determining which items provide the greatest profit potential relative to your investment in inventory. As with all calculations that use ‘gross margin’ as an input, the output may be flawed if other costs not included in the gross calculation vary significantly from one item to another.
The number of times an inventory cycle turns over during the year. A frequently used method to compute inventory turnover is to divide the average inventory level into annual costs sale.
Abbreviation for: Computerised Assembly Mock Up.
Abbreviation for: Strategic Business Unit.
1. An angle in the hull. 2. A line formed where the sides of a boat meet the bottom. Soft chine is when the two sides join at a shallow angle, and hard chine is when they join at a steep angle.
Abbreviation for: Remote Communications Air/Ground.
A planning system such as MRP that generates high message volume and continual changes to recommended order dates and quantities due to an excessive level of MPS, engineering, or database changes.
Specifications which are so restrictive as to limit or exclude competition.

A rope, tackle, or hydraulic ram running from the mast at or just above deck level to a point part-way along the boom of a yacht’s mainsail or mizzen. Its function is to pull the boom down, flattening the sail in strong winds, reducing twist and preventing the boom from kicking up when running.
Abbreviation for: Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast.
Abbreviation for: Virtual Product Data Management.
Abbreviation for: Ultra High Frequency.
A set of purchasing activities that aims to ensure that inputs various parts of a value chain are on time and value for money.
U.S. Customs’ “Automated Broker Interface,” through which brokers file importers’ entries electronically.
The weight shown in a waybill and freight bill, i.e., the invoiced weight.
Abbreviation for: Memorandum of Understanding.
The degree to which the rate or level of output varies from a process over time, a key characteristic in determining process behaviour.

Large volume production of the same basic product or product line, based on the type and timing of demand and facility design and capabilities, which can be for either finished goods or lower level items.
A document that states all the parts to be issued.
An actual order, not a forecast or planned order, from a customer for specific products or services.
Ability to respond quickly and efficiently to changing customer and consumer demands.
The wedge-shaped part of an anchor’s arms that digs into the bottom.
A short, smoothbore, cast iron naval cannon, used from the 1770s to the 1850s as a powerful, short-range anti-ship and anti-crew weapon.
Funding for performance-based logistics (PBL) programs.
The incorrect rejection of a true hypothesis.
Automatic manipulators that can be programmed and reprogrammed to transform resources.
The person or company who is usually the supplier or owner of commodities shipped. Also called Consignor.
The difference between the minimum value and the maximum value in a set of data.The range helps identify best and worst case and process variability.
Ability to locate spare parts for a manufacturer’s warranty program.
Abbreviation for: India, Brazil, South Africa.
Professional signs that can be created in stores.
Abbreviation for: South African Excellence Foundation.

A person responsible for ensuring that a vessel remains in ‘trim’ (that the cargo and fuel are evenly balanced). An important task on a coal-fired vessel, as it could get ‘out-of-trim’ as coal is consumed.
Abbreviation for: Communications Service Authorisation.

A problem, according to Webster’s Collegiate dictionary (11th edition), can be defined as a question proposed for a solution or as a state of difficulty that needs to be resolved.These two definitions suggest two important characteristics:•Having a problem is by nature a state of affairs that is plagued by some difficulty or undesired condition. •A problem presents a challenge that needs to be solved in order to establish more desirable conditions
Spreaders from the bows to spread the bowsprit shrouds.
The reverse movement of a boat or watercraft through the water.
Laying the keel of a ship in a shipyard to begin her construction.
The batch processing of a complete set of records, such as in MPS, MRP, or CRP, that does not provide a net update based on a selected subset of records such as those with activity only.
Portable conveyor that can be expanded, contracted, and flexed around curves.
Net Register Tons. Also see: Net Tonnage. Theoretically the cargo capacity of the ship. Sometimes used to charge fees or taxes on a vessel.
Abbreviation for: Direction Finding Indicator and Development Finance Institution.
These include spreadsheets, qualitative assessments, vendor rating, supplier audits, and cost modelling.
Abbreviation for: The International Air Cargo Association.
When the host shows a quantity on hand for a product but the inventory system shows a quantity of zero, the item ordered is marked out within the system. Also see: Markout.
Abbreviation for: Canadian Green Building Council.
Part of a scheduling system that checks progress and makes sure that plans are actually being achieved.
Abbreviation for: Wildlife Hazard Management Plan.
Place where cargo is transferred to another carrier.
A system designed to be fully operational at purchase or implementation time and not require additional modification or investment.
The difference between a standard or expected value and the actual result, and often characterised as favourable or unfavourable.
A forecast model useful for low volume, intermittent demand that may include zero demand in some periods
A contract that consolidates requirements by pre-establishing a bid opening date and requiring using agencies to submit requirements by a specified time.

1.A payment credited to a company’s account for not performing based on contract terms, and  2.An amount charged to a contractor for materials, equipment, services, or other charges which were paid by the owner and furnished to the contractor.

An unusually high product demand outside normal parameters, possibly due to promotion, price break, or substitution. Forecast systems filter abnormal demand based on past history and not assume the same demand will occur in the future.
Abbreviation for: Graphical Evaluation and Review Technique.
A pallet so designed that the forks of a fork lift truck can be inserted from two sides only.
Refers to: Service A.

The calculation of a shipment’s chargeable weight based upon the dimensions and cubic size of a shipment rather than by consideration of the actual weight (which will be a lesser amount). Factors are used to establish the dimensional weight.
A state or region’s ability to compete in global markets, as evidenced in the attraction of new businesses and the expansion of existing businesses.
A schedule of warehouse or transportation charges for a client.
An amateur yachter.

A document prepared by a transportation line at the point of a shipment; shows the point of origin, destination, route, consignor, consignee, description of shipment, and amount charged for the transportation service. It is forwarded with the shipment or sent by mail to the agent at the transfer point or way bill destination. Unlike a bill of lading, a way bill is NOT a document of title.
The papers attached or pertaining to goods requiring transportation and/or transfer of ownership. These may include the packing list, hazardous materials declarations, export/customs documents, etc.
A punitive instrument.
Facility where paint is re-blended to be repackaged and sold.
A network of highways which are important to the United States’ strategic defence policy and which provide defence access, continuity, and emergency capabilities for defence purposes.
A bearing relative to the direction of the ship: the clockwise angle between the ship’s direction and an object.
A multi-modular cargo inventory control and release notification system through which carriers submit their electronic cargo declaration 24 hours before loading. See also: 24 Hour Rule.

One of the elements comprising a company’s total supply-chain management costs. These costs consist of the following: 1. Opportunity Cost: The opportunity cost of holding inventory. This should be based on your company’s own cost of capital standards using the following formula. Calculation: Cost of Capital x Average Net Value of Inventory. 2. Shrinkage: The costs associated with breakage, pilferage, and deterioration of inventories. Usually pertains to the loss of material through handling damage, theft, or neglect. 3. Insurance and Taxes: The cost of insuring inventories and taxes associated with the holding of inventory. Total Obsolescence for Raw Material, WIP, and Finished Goods Inventory: Inventory reserves taken due to obsolescence and scrap and includes products exceeding the shelf life, i.e., spoils and is no good for use in its original purpose (do not include reserves taken for Field Service Parts). 5. Channel Obsolescence: Aging allowances paid to channel partners, provisions for buy-back agreements, etc. Includes all material that goes obsolete while in a distribution channel. Usually, a distributor will demand a refund on material that goes bad (shelf life) or is no longer needed because of changing needs. 6. Field Service Parts Obsolescence: Reserves taken due to obsolescence and scrap. Field Service Parts are that inventory kept at locations outside the four walls of the manufacturing plant, i.e., distribution centre or warehouse.

Abbreviation for: Export Commodity Classification. Number designation within the United States Department of Commerce, Bureau of Industry & Security applied to articles subject to export controls by the United States government.

The Russian acronym for Theory of Inventive Problem Solving, a technique that attempts to define a specific problem as a system and identify elements in the system that need correction to reach the desired solution.
The average inventory level over a period of time.
Abbreviation for: Flight Service Automation System.
Abbreviation for: Certified Public Accountant.
A stage in the product and service design process that formalises the underlying idea behind a product or service.
Combination of a tractor and two semi-trailers connected in tandem by a converter dolly.
A private boat that sells goods.
1. Relationship of ship’s hull to waterline. 2. Adjustments made to sails to maximise their efficiency.
A management approach with three phases: process planning (design), process transfer (implementation, planning, and deployment), and process operations (including commitment and workflow management).

Regular updating (usually manually) of stock levels of one or more items. This regular count for all or part of inventory is used to correct the variance between the stock levels provided by the Perpetual Inventory and the actual levels.
Cargo moving under customs control where duty has not yet been paid.
A sale of damaged cargo (from the French word "arrimage").

Setup tasks for a machine or other production resource that requires an idle (non-producing) status, until complete. Systems that seek to reduce lead time and enable small lot size production emphasise techniques to reduce or eliminate internal setup tasks.
Abbreviation for: Customer Service Office.
A wharf licensed and attended by customs authorities.
Of or relating to trade, affairs, or business within a country.
Abbreviation for: Group Systems Support Service Division.

The costs associated with managing inventory, returned for any of the following reasons: repair, refurbish, excess, obsolescence, End-of- Life, ecological conformance, and demonstration. Includes all applicable elements of the Level 2 component Inventory Carrying Cost of Total Supply Chain Management Cost
Pull management model in which the quantities produced correspond as close as possible to market demand. Just-in-time is a hyper-direct logistics flow management model.

A sufficient quantity of food. Meals on board ship were served to the crew on a square wooden plate in harbour or at sea in good weather. Food in the Royal Navy was invariably better or at least in greater quantity than that available to the average landsman. However, while square wooden plates were indeed used on board ship, there is no established link between them and this particular term. The OED gives the earliest reference from the U.S. in the mid-19th century.
Abbreviation for: Interfacility Communications Processor.

Third party legal or commercial rights that restrict withhold or defer any benefit associated with ownership of any Equity instrument. the party rights include only those created against a black participant to ensure, for a lender, repayment of a loan advanced to that participant for financing their purchase of their equity instrument Glossary | Threshold Values, Public Procurement in the measured Entity; held against a juristic person or trust that is in the chain of ownership between the measured Entity that the eventual black participant serving the same purpose.
Abbreviation for: Technology and Human Resources for Industry Programme.
Abbreviation for: Closed Corporations Act, Act No 69 of 1984 and abbreviation for Customs-Controlled Area.
Abbreviation for: Khula Enterprise Finance Ltd.

Software-based systems that aid manufacturing engineers in creating a process plan to manufacture a product who’s geometric, electronic, and other characteristics have been captured in a CAD database.
Abbreviation for: Arrival Aircraft Interval.
Abbreviation for: Peripheral Adapter Module.
A means of sorting data. For example, number of quality faults by frequency of occurrence.
From the French timonnier. A name given, on particular occasions, to the steersman of a ship.
Abbreviation for: Supplier Development and Sustainable Development.
The timber immediately above the keel of a wooden ship.

Electronic communication platform enabling companies to communicate with their partners (suppliers and distributors) to facilitate business transactions, and to optimise economic performance. Electronic marketplaces are generally divided into three categories: 1. The “vertical” marketplaces bringing together all actors of a channel (for example, agri-food producers, distributors, and intermediaries, textile, chemicals, etc.). 2. The “horizontal” marketplaces bringing together companies located at the same stage of the value creation chain and belonging to the same business sector (for example, all distributors). 3. The “transverse” or “public” marketplaces to which any type of company can belong whatever their business sector (for example, a marketplace bringing together companies specialised in MRO products).
To communicate or confer with another party to reach an agreement or compromise to settle some matter.

The process of identification and analysis of risk; and the decision to either accept or mitigate the exposure to such risk when compared to the potential impact on the achievement of the organisation’s objectives.
A document used to detail proposed goods or services requirements and invites responses and bids from prospective suppliers.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Specialists.
The scope of work for services generally indicating the work to be performed, the level of quality and effort, the timelines, requirements specifications, outputs and the deliverables.
Flight Data Processing.

A person who manages all the logistical work of bringing components, raw materials, etc. in small quantities to work stations to minimise work-in-process inventories. This allows machines to be placed closer together, and spares the operator from having to interrupt his/her cycle time, thus minimising transportation muda. Water spiders usually are experienced workers. They know where needed parts or raw materials are stored, and serve several workstations.

A narrow basin or vessel used for the construction, maintenance, and repair of ships, boats, and other watercraft that can be flooded to allow a load to be floated in, then drained to allow that load to come to rest on a dry platform.

A system installation or conversion plan that defines scope and goals, resources required, scheduled activities, scheduled activity durations, and actual project status. A high-level plan may communicate only major phases and milestones, while detail plans include specific descriptions of the individual tasks involved and the critical path.
A measurable definition of the goals, resources, timing, and desired outcome of an implementation project or activity.

A system where the production and movement of inventory items is determined by a pre-existing schedule that authorises a material issue or transfer, or the start of a production operation. The using department or location receives material when determined by the feeder location and not based on their own generation of a replenishment signal.
Abbreviation for: Control Area/ Flight Information Region.

A system of technologies and processes that sense and react to real-time demand across a network of customers, suppliers, and employees. In other words, a consumer purchase triggers real-time information movement throughout the supply network, which then initiates movement of product through the network.

Spreadsheet model for arterial level of service (LOS) analysis: Generalised LOS analysis tool. Yields quick answers and inexpensive results due to low cost input data. Often used as a screening or first cut LOS call followed by a more refined ART-PLAN or HCS analysis.
A reduced rate that carriers offer to shippers and/or consignees who load and/or unload LTL or AQ shipments.
Abbreviation for: Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (EU).
To thread a line through blocks to gain a mechanical advantage, such as in a block and tackle.
The practice of inspecting only a sample of products or services produced rather than every single one.
Abbreviation for: Public Switched Data Network.

In forecasting, a software function that compares multiple possible forecast methods to past actual demand to determine the best method for future use. Also used generically to indicate the best alternative from given choices.
Shipment of goods to a foreign country.
A logic tree in the theory of constraints that identifies and sequences obstacles that must be overcome to achieve an overall goal.
The identifier assigned for a specific production lot or batch and used in subsequent material transactions and tracing activities.

Components and materials issued to the production floor based on the cumulative requirements for multiple production orders, shifts, or days. Not used in to-order environments where lot traceability is an issue.

A report is an informative document with data organized in a narrative, graphic, or tabular form. Reports can be prepared on random requests or periodic regularity as required by the user. Procurement organisations use various reports (eg: spend report, supplier base report, accounts payable report) to study factors influencing enterprise-wide spend and to streamline the entire procurement operation.

A production scheduling and tracking system used to analyse and report resource availability and status, schedule, and update orders, collect detailed execution data such as material usage, labour usage, process parameters, order and equipment status, and other critical information. It accesses bill of material, routing, and other data from the base ERP system and is typically the system used for real-time shop floor reporting and monitoring that feeds activity data back to the base system.

The acquisition of real property rights for use on a transportation corridor in advance of the fiscal year in which right of way acquisition would normally occur. This is done to take advantage of favourable prices or the availability of land and to preclude further development that would make the property more costly to the public.
Data that has been adjusted or reduced to eliminate redundancies and anomalies.
Abbreviation for: Direct Marketing of South Africa.

Abbreviation for: Export-Import Bank of the United States. An independent U.S. Government Agency which facilitates exports of U.S. goods by providing loan guarantees and insurance for repayment of bank–provided export credit.
Facility Central Processing Unit.
A consumable or reparable product for which the manufacturer has specified a finite life in either some form of time period or in number of cycles or activities.
Abbreviation for: Officer of the Deck, Officer of the Day.

A South African Government medium to long term initiative aimed at creatively empowering black people to enable them to actively participate in the industrialisation and socio- economic development of the country
Abbreviation for: Federal Prison Industries.

The term co-product is used to describe multiple items that are produced simultaneously during a production run. Co-products are often used to increase yields in cutting operations, such as die cutting or sawing, when it is found that scrap can be reduced by combining multiple-sized products in a single production run. Co-products are also used to reduce the frequency of machine set-ups required in these same types of operations. Co-products, also known as by-products, are also common in process manufacturing such as in chemical plants. Although the concept of co-products is fairly simple, the programming logic required to provide for planning and processing of co-products is very complicated.
Method of storing product two loads deep in an aisle.
A portable flight of steps down a ship’s side.
The act of calling for freight by truck at the consignor’s shipping platform.
A model or equation that incorporates a random variable.

A structured set of general ledger accounts that fills an organisation’s requirements in gathering, reporting and analysing financial entries. Detail G/L accounts are normally rolled-up, or summarised at higher levels for reporting purposes.
One of the pair of stays that stabilise the bowsprit horizontally affixed to the forward end of the bowsprit and just aft the stem.

A naval auxiliary ship with fuel tanks and dry cargo holds designed to replenish other ships with fuel and supplies while underway on the high seas. Also referred to as replenishment oiler or fleet tanker.
The time it takes to pick and document specific stock for an order.
Abbreviation for: High Level Data Link Control.
An agreement, where a party feels it did not obtain something beneficial.
Having no night watches.
A non-commissioned officer responsible for the sails, ropes, rigging, and boats on a ship who issues “piped” commands to seamen.
International shipments wherein the delivery terms are to have the goods delivered cleared through customs at the country of destination at the designated consignee location.
Companies that offer “water-taxi” service to ships at anchor.

A cross-functional executive group that sets overall parameters and provides high-level project guidance by interaction with the project leader, milestone status review, and approval of resource requirements.

An agency that obtains negotiated large-volume transportation rates from carriers, and resells this capacity to shippers. Unlike freight forwarders, will not handle freight and owns no pickup/delivery equipment or storage facilities.
See: Adaptive loop, and learning loop.

Method of preparing orders by separating operations of stock picking and packaging. This method implies several steps in the handling of stock but allows for batch picking that can be very effective if the number of customers to be delivered to is limited.
Abbreviation for: East London Industrial Development Zone.
A lot size technique that uses look ahead and look back functions to consider additional periods in modifying an initial calculation based on least total cost.
Abbreviation for: Accounts Receivable.
Abbreviation for the Railway Service: Container On Flat Car.
A term used to describe the extra costs that are incurred in running an operation as it gets larger.
1. Estimated Time of Arrival, Completion, Departure, Readiness, or Sailing. 2. Estimated Time of Availability. That time when a tractor/partner carrier is available for dispatch.
A propeller with folding blades, furling to reduce drag on a sailing vessel when not in use.
System that controls the flow of information throughout an organization and makes sure that everyone has the information they need to work properly.
An extra charge sometimes added to steamship freight rates; justified by higher fuel costs. Also known as Fuel Adjustment Factor or FAF
A daily record of the hours an interstate driver spends driving, off duty, sleeping in the berth, or on duty not driving.
A relatively short period when a sailor is allowed ashore for recreation. Also see: shore leave.

Maintenance, routine and operating categories are low value categories which are not an input to the production process, but which are used in support of operations. The term is a subset of indirect materials and represents a level of classification of categories. Examples of MRO categories would be cleaning materials, lubricants, laboratory supplies, spare parts, gaskets and industrial consumables, and in some procurement organisations these categories would not be aggregated as MRO, but managed individually.
Location where shipment begins its movement.

A running sum for consecutive periods of capacity capabilities for a given resource that indicates total availability over those periods, and aids in determining whether rescheduling will resolve intermittent problems.
A naval stores clerk.
Abbreviation for: Wildlife Hazard Assessment.

A method of analysis that determines whether or not the cost of government activity yields more benefits to society than if it remained in the private sector. A typical example is daycare. Should it be provided by the agency as a government service, or should it be left to the private sector?
Abbreviation for: Theory of Constraints (Eli Goldratt).
Abbreviation for: Congress of South African Trade Unions.
Abbreviation for: Manufacturing Execution System Association.

The process of reviewing a proposed MPS, comparing to stated higher-level production plan, resource availability, and management parameters, and firming it and releasing to the rest of the system. The frequency of regenerating and reviewing the MPS, typically weekly, depends on the industry, process flexibility, forecast accuracy and many other factors.
Broad-based BEE scorecard in codes series 100 to 500 applicable to entities with annual revenue in excess of R50 million.
Where the customer or customers play an important part in the character of the product or service offering.

If a sample produces a particular result, and increasing the sample size it continues to produce the same result, the sample has stability and can be assumed to be representative of the population. This is an important characteristic when the population size is unknown or extremely large.
Abbreviation for: Universal Time (Coordinated).

A repairable inventory item that can be repeatedly restored to a fully serviceable condition and re-used over the normal life cycle of the parent equipment to which it is related.Such items have a repair lead time as well as procurement lead time and normally have a serial number that is retained throughout the rotable life regardless of the extent of replacement of it component parts
A price recognized as the fair economic value of an item, based on the cost of the item plus an acceptable margin for the supplier.
See: Available Stock.

Abbreviation for: Clean Air Act Amendments. 1990 amendments to the federal Clean Air Act which classify nonattainment areas and lay out rules for dealing with air pollution in such areas; specifically brought transportation decisions into the context of air quality control.
A load transported from one customer-related facility to another; does not include product shipped to a consignee.
Maximum rated weight of a truck, including its cargo.
Abbreviation for: Environmental Land Management Study.

Sometimes spelled jackass bark. A sailing ship with three (or more) masts, of which the foremast is square-rigged and the main is partially square-rigged (topsail, topgallant, etc.) and partially fore-and-aft rigged (course). The mizzen mast is fore-and-aft rigged.
Abbreviation for: Uniform Resource Locator.

term: Logistics Structure, Making to Stock (central stock) (MTS)
definition: Finished products are kept in stock at the end of the production process and from there shipped directly to many geographically dispersed customers, as in the manufacture of many consumer electronics products (such as dishwashers and refrigerators).
The percentage resulting from the formula in Annexe 100(c) of statement 100.
Abbreviation for American National Standards Institute.

A bill of material with a single, or few levels. Intermediate levels in a bill require activities related to opening orders, moving material in and out of stock, and creating associated routings and bills for each level. Reducing the number of levels can reduce costs by eliminating those activities and often contributes to a corresponding reduction in lead time.

Creating production schedules that automatically take resource availability into account. Schedule dates are moved forward or backward in time as far as necessary to stay within prescribed capacity, and some systems also contain rules to move orders for certain products to approved alternate facilities when the initial resource is full. Finite scheduling systems normally do not ensure that material plans are automatically revised in conjunction with production rescheduling.
Remote Control Unit.

term: Pipe, Bos’n’s, or a Bos’n’s Call
definition: A whistle used by Boatswains (bosuns or bos’ns) to issue commands. Consisting of a metal tube that directs the breath over an aperture on the top of a hollow ball to produce high-pitched notes. The pitch of the notes can be changed by partly covering the aperture with the finger of the hand in which the pipe is held. The shape of the instrument is similar to that of a smoking pipe.

A cannon pointing forward or aft, often of longer range than other guns. Those on the bow (bow chaser) were used to fire upon a ship ahead, while those on the rear (stern chaser) were used to ward off pursuing vessels. Unlike guns pointing to the side, chasers could be brought to bear in a chase without slowing. Also Chase Piece, or Chaser.
A special form of the moving average model in which the forecast for the next period is calculated as the weighted average of the current period’s actual value and forecast.
Management authority to make decisions that is restricted to a few managers.
A load sufficient in size to fill a container either by cubic measurement or by weight.
The ability to achieve higher and improved levels of capability in the face of change. An adaptable process maintains its effectiveness efficiently in the face of change over time.
A listing of open production orders that shows current location, units in progress, projected completion dates, and sometimes material usage and cost data.
An organisational strategy and structure where all inventoried items are controlled from a single location or group.

1.On the beach, shore, or land (as opposed to aboard or on board). 2.Towards the shore. 3.“To run ashore”: To collide with the shore (as opposed to “to run aground,” which is to strike a submerged feature such as a reef or sandbar).
Classification of product or process imperfections by source and cost.
The formalization of what is intended to happen at some time in the future.
Abbreviation for: Enterprise Marketing Automation.
Specialised lift trucks designed to be used in narrow aisles of 8 to 10 feet.
Abbreviation for: Coefficient Variation of Demand.
Abbreviation for: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009.
Abbreviation for: Low Altitude Alert System.
Operating profits less interest expenses plus or minus results from investments and other activities.

Sorting equipment integrated into a conveyor to move materials off of the conveyor at fixed points. Pop-up sorters are installed in fixed positions and may consist of a series of wheels or small belts that are normally located slightly below the conveyor rollers. The wheels or belts are momentarily raised (pop-up) to enable diverting materials off of the conveyor.
A market segmentation strategy where the intended audience for a given product is divided according to geographic units, such as nations, states, regions, counties, cities, or neighbourhoods.
One type of design decision that determines the most effective place to locate a factory; manufacturers focus primarily on labor costs or resource proximity.

Computer-supported simulation systems used by retail buyers to optimise their income per square metre of shelf space. These systems enable the simulation of several display layouts (for a different number of facings) based on detailed cost information, to decide on the most profitable layout. Important concepts, underlying space management systems, are direct product cost (DPC) and direct product profitability (DPP).
A calculation which yields future availability based on planned production or purchases and consumption across multiple future periods. Also see: Available-to-Promise.
A lead time that does not vary because of quantity changes. A manufacturing process such as curing, drying or baking may require a set amount of time regardless of the volume being processed.

Movement of employees from one job to another in an effort to relieve the boredom often associated with job specialisation as well as exposing the employee to other jobs in order to achieve cross-training and upward mobility opportunities (Business, 2002).
Manufacturing Planning and Control System.
The primary monetary contributor to the supply chain. This is where a business firm should direct its marketing and service initiatives.
Transports heavy or oversized cargoes mounted to its top deck instead of inside a hold. Machinery, appliances, project cargoes, and even recreational vehicles move on deck barges.
Abbreviation for: National Economic Development and Labour Council.
Abbreviation for: Electronic On Board Recorder.
See: Negotiations
Sequence of repeated events for stock holdings; the time between consecutive replenishments.
Port where cargo is unloaded and enters a country.
Abbreviation for: United Nations Recommendations on the Transportation of Dangerous Goods.

A neighbourhood, community, or region with compact, multidimensional land use patterns that ensure a mix of uses, minimise the impact of cars, and promote walking, bicycling, and transit access to employment, education, recreation, entertainment, shopping, and service.
Lists the data elements for which standards exist. The Joint Electronic Document Interchange (JEDI) committee developed a data dictionary that is employed by many EDI users.
A quality test measuring the assumption that the distribution characteristics of a set of data is reasonable (similar to expected).
The analysis of the first item manufactured in a production run to verify correct setup and process alignment.
Combined weight of all loads, gear, and supplies on a vehicle.
Abbreviation for: Simplified Direction Finding and Software Defined Network.
Abbreviation for: In-Plan Switching.
Abbreviation for: European Article Numbering.
The idea that every function in an organisation uses resources to produce products and services for (internal) customers, therefore, all functions are, to some extent, operations.

With regards to EDI, a formal notice (by message or code) from an electronic mailbox system or EDI server indicating that a message sent to a trading partner has reached its intended mailbox or been retrieved by the addressee.
The process related to the movement and storage of products from the end of the production line to the end user.

Standard valuable method for assets ,an Economic interest, or any other instrument or right relevant to measurement understatement 100, undertaken using normal valuation methods that represent standard market price.
Abbreviation for: HERTZ.
A type of PBL contract pricing that combines a cost basis with an award fee feature. The incentive feature allows a base fee to be adjusted based on success in meeting target performance goals.
A small, highly manoeuvrable sailing ship with lateen rig used by the Portuguese in the 15th and 16th centuries to explore along the West African coast and into the Atlantic Ocean.
Abbreviation for: Voice over Internet Protocol.
Costs of activities not directly associated with producing or delivering products or services. Examples are the costs of information systems, process engineering and purchasing.
The person responsible for buying, storing, and selling all stores on board ships, including food, rum, and tobacco. Originally a private merchant, later a warrant officer.
Abbreviation for: Inner Marker.
The marketing, offering, buying, and selling of securities, currency, financial products, and other instruments of investment over a network.
The charge made for towing a vessel.
Long-distance motor carrier operations, opposite of local operations.
See: Appraisal
A mechanism by which a business coordinates its decisions regarding structural and infrastructural elements.
Abbreviation for: Local Airport Advisory.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain Event Management.
Abbreviation for: Quality of Service.
Abbreviation for: Minimum Descent Altitude.
A spar used to extend the bowsprit.
A blend of improvement elements from Lean and Six Sigma.
A technique for optimising interrelated supply chains such that the most important of them (the primary supply chain) is not compromised by optimisation made to subordinate supply chains.
The outsourcing of the warehousing function by the seller of the goods.
Abbreviation for: Uniform Code Council.

A product, or product line, that has a higher content of material and a corresponding lower level of labour when compared to other products. A material-intensive product often contains high-value components that require minimal labour or further processing to create the finished item.
An unofficial market or trade in something, especially controlled or scarce goods.
Slang term for an aircraft carrier.
A rebuild/remanufacture process the extent and cost of which cannot be determined until the item is disassembled and evaluated. By definition, an internal repair must contain labour and parts.

Frequent purchases in small quantities to meet only immediate, short term requirements. Also, it is a practice of planning inbound material purchases and flows without the need for significant inventory levels.

1.Purportedly an acronym. A type of sonar used by the Allies for detecting submarines during the First and Second World War. 2.Abbreviation for: Allied Submarine Devices Investigation Committee (World War I). The term has been generically applied to equipment for “under-water supersonic echo-ranging equipment” of submarines and other vessels.
A documented and approved revision to a product or process specification.
Abbreviation for: Regional Communications Control Centres.
The crew of a ship.

Actual material usage for a given order or schedule that is different than the standard amount. Variance analysis seeks to isolate dollar variances due to usage (using more or less of the correct material) from substitution (using different material than originally intended).
An allowable variation from a predefined standard. A variance is not considered significant unless it exceeds the limit set by a tolerance level.
Use of computer simulation to facilitate sequencing of production operations, analysis of production flows, and layout of manufacturing facilities.
A place for a container on board a container ship; typically, one TEU fits in a slot.

A classification of products into three categories for the benefit of goods flow control and stock control, based on a products area of application within a product division. G = General products that may be required in several main article groups or operations centres and are administered centrally in the division. U = Unique products that are used uniquely in one main article group or operations centre but in several of its products, and administered locally in the division. S = Specific products that are used exclusively in one higher level product, and whose procurement is effected per individual order.
External structure consists of a number of links (companies, institutions) that are connected via markets.
A description method that is used when a product or service is proprietary or when there is a perceived advantage to using a particular supplier’s products or services.
The second-in-command of a commercial ship.
A human resource benefits plan where enrolled members can select and accumulate predefined medical, investment, and other options.

An executive person responsible for the entire organisational operations including manufacturing. Reports directly to the Chief Executive Officer or the Managing director. Please see also to chief supply chain management officer.
A type of buoy with a large bell and hanging hammers that sound by wave action.
The highest acceptable value for some measure of interest.
Abbreviation for: Weather Service Meteorological Observatory.
The average time spent by vehicles travelling at the free flow speed over a facility length.
A low strip running around the edge of the deck like a low bulwark. It may be shortened or have gaps in it to allow water to flow off the deck.

1. In the 17th century, any warship built for speed and manoeuvrability. 2. In the 18th and early 19th centuries, a sailing warship with a single continuous gun deck, typically used for patrolling, blockading, etc., but not in line of battle. 3. In the second half of the 19th century, a type of warship combining sail and steam propulsion, typically of ironclad timber construction, with all guns on one deck. 4. In the 20th and 21st centuries, a warship, smaller than a destroyer, originally introduced during World War II as an anti-submarine vessel but now general-purpose.

1. Toward the front of a vessel. 
2. In front of a vessel.
The amount of planned and actual demand placed on a resource for a given time period that determines its requirements and can be used in calculating over- or under-capacity situations.
The value of inventory at either cost or market value. The value of the inventory is usually computed on a First In First Out (FIFO) or average cost basis.

A specified inventory level used to trigger a reorder when the total of current on-hand inventory and open scheduled receipts falls below that level. The order point is set to cover demand expected until the order is received, and often includes a buffer based on past variability in the demand or the lead time.
Abbreviation for: Signal-to-Noise Ratio.

Best Alternative to a Negotiated Offer describes the option for a negotiator if agreement cannot be reached. It proposes that a negotiator who must reach a deal is in a weaker position than a negotiator who has an alternative option.

A notice of intent to solicit a bid and negotiate with a single firm. Other suppliers are not invited to bid on these requirements but can forward letters of intent indicating their interest before the closing date. Notice of bidding requests will then be solicited from letters of interest that have been received.
The percentage of requisitions filled from stock present on the shelf. The opposite is: Stock out rate.
Goods are to be considered dangerous if the transport of such goods might cause harm, risk, peril, or other evil to people, environment, equipment, or any property whatsoever.
A travel mode in which vehicles (including busses, streetcars, and street-running light rail) stop at regular intervals along the roadway to pick up and drop off passengers.
The function of using the bill of material to generate component item demand quantities and timing, given a requirement for the parent
Confirmation from the buyer (a local authority for example) that they agree with the proposed terms of contract, thereby creating a binding contract.
Aims at providing high customer service by responding quickly to different or changing circumstances.
A publication setting forth the charges, rates, and rules of transportation companies.
Refers to: Navigational Aid.
The average speed of vehicles not under the influence of speed reduction conditions (typically assumed to be 5 mph over the posted speed limit.
A boat which makes the rounds of a fleet at anchor to see that due watch is kept at night.
Smallest definable and repeatedly executable unit of work to transform inputs into outputs; usually performed by one individual.
A line used to control either a mobile spar, or the shape of a sail. A downhaul can also be used to retrieve a sail back on deck.

A measure of the effectiveness with which a company responds to actual demand. The stock-out percentage can be a measurement of total stock-outs to total orders, or of line items incurring stock-outs during a period of total line items ordered.
The systematic regulation of stock levels with respect to time and quantity.

Any sort of ship or vessel that carries cargo, goods, and materials from one port to another, including general cargo ships (designed to carry break bulk cargo), bulk carriers, container ships, multipurpose vessels, and tankers. Tankers, however, although technically cargo ships, are routinely thought of as constituting a completely separate category.

The ratio of the measured time required to produce a given output, divided by the sum of the time required to produce a given output, based on the rated efficiency of the machinery and labour operations.
See: Project Development and Environmental

A process improvement and error or defect prevention tool that examines the individual processes within a system, identifies the control or decision points, and uses a series of ‘why’ questions to determine the reasons for variations in the process paths.

1. A ship’s ventilator with a bell-shaped top which can be swiveled to catch the wind and force it below. 
2. A vertical projection of a ship’s funnel which directs the smoke away from the bridge.
A set of wheels built specifically as rear wheels under the container.
The component products, services, and parts within a product or service design that provide benefits to the customer.
Abbreviation for: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration.
Abbreviation for: Single Event Level.
A notation on a bill of lading that the cargo has been stowed on the open deck of the ship.
The extent to which the unit price changes with the volume purchased.
A railroad industry association that represents the larger U.S. railroads.
Individual or firm that employs longshoremen and who contracts to load or unload the ship.
Payment for production based on the number of units processed, rather than the number of hours used.
Abbreviation for: Mobility Management Process. Florida’s congestion management system (CMS).
Abbreviation for: European Economic Community.

Yards held rigidly perpendicular to their masts and parallel to the deck. This was rarely the best trim of the yards for efficiency but made a pretty sight for inspections and in harbour.The term is applied to situations and to people figuratively to mean that all difficulties have been resolved or that the person is performing well and is mentally and physically prepared.
Abbreviation for: High Performance Computing and Communications.

term: Dory or Doree, Dori, or (RN) Dorey
definition: A shallow-draft, lightweight boat, about 5 to 7 metres long, with high sides, a flat bottom and sharp bows. Traditionally used as fishing boats, both in coastal waters and in the open sea.
Abbreviation: Diplomacy, Intelligence, Defense, Trade & Industry Sector Education and Training.
Abbreviation for: En Route Maintenance Processor System.

A review and determination, through observation and study, of pertinent information about a job - including specific tasks and necessary abilities, knowledge, and skills (Business, the Ultimate Resource, 2002).

In a costing system, the initial standard established at the beginning of a fiscal year, used for creating budgets and performance measurements for that period. The base standard may be frozen to provide a consistent starting point for the period; the current standard is updated to reflect changes in process or material costs during the year.
A shipping term where the seller covers all import duties and taxes.
The computer-to-computer exchange of messages. The format of email is usually unstructured (free-form) rather than structured. X.400 has become the standard for email exchange.

A description of the transportation problem (not solution) explaining the primary goal or reason for which a project is being pursued. The statement should be specific enough so that the range of alternatives developed will offer real potential solutions and should reflect priorities and limitations in the area such as environmental resources, growth management, land use planning, and economic development.
Certified Quality Engineer.
A double-entry record system showing inventory balances on hand, on order, and available for future orders.

Large mass of sand or earth, formed by the surge of the sea. They are mostly found at the entrances of great rivers or havens, and often render navigation extremely dangerous, but confer tranquillity once inside. See also: touch and go, grounding. Alfred Lord Tennyson’s poem “Crossing the bar” is an allegory for death
Third party operation of a warehouse, funded by suppliers, containing vendor-owned stock for delivery to a customer. Also see: lineside warehouse on page 315

Abbreviation for: Unified Planning Work Program. Developed by Metropolitan Planning Organisations (MPOs); identifies all transportation and transportation air quality activities anticipated within the next one to two years, including schedule for completing, who is doing it, and products to be produced.
A vehicle that is utilised to move and transfer product/freight in a distribution centre, warehouse, terminal, manufacturing site, or dock. Often referred to as a forklift.
Abbreviation for Affiliated Network for Social Accountability.
1. The tube under the hull to bear the tailshaft for propulsion (usually at stern). 2. A torpedo tube mounted in the stern of a submarine.

A cargo movement in which the water carrier provides a through service between an inland point and the port of load/discharge. The carrier is responsible for cargo and costs from origin on to destination. Also known as IPI or Through Service.
The recipient of products or services from a supplier.
A term used in quality management to confirm the adherence to specification of a product or service. Syn.: compliance.
Identification number assigned to specific product for tracking purposes that is usually tied to a date or a production run.
Abbreviation for: Machine Vision. Prefix for: Motor Vessel.
Abbreviation for: New Partnership for Africa Development.
Activity aimed at bridging time, place, quantity, assortment, and knowledge between a buyer and a seller.
Used for transporting bulk liquids, such as petroleum, chemicals, molasses, vegetable oils, and liquefied gases.
The market for the immediate chartering of a vessel, usually for single voyages.
In case of damage or wear from shipping, product is repacked with all materials included into manufacturer boxes.
A program, function, or system that operates on its own and has no interfaces.

A wooden part (vertical timbers or planking) of the centreline structure of a boat, usually between the sternpost and amidships. It is used to “fill the spaces where, owing to the shape of the vessel, the floor-timbers have to be discontinued.
Abbreviation for: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortisation.

For decisions involving uncertainty, expected value analysis provides a rational approach for selecting the best course of action. The expected value is calculated by multiplying the probability of each outcome by its forecast payoff.
The midway point between a vessel’s centre of buoyancy when upright and her centre of buoyancy when tilted.
Products which are not consumed immediately, but whose purchasing value is depreciated during its economic life cycle.
A rotating or movable warehouse device used to store multiple, small parts for picking in a high usage volume environment.
Cost avoidance is a variance between the historical and the actual purchase price paid per unit. A cost avoidance is not considered to be sustainable.

The parts of the ship or a boat, including sailboats, fishing boats, passenger ships, and submarines, that project above her main deck. This does not usually include its masts or any armament turrets.
A situation in which the deck of the vessel is partially or wholly submerged, possibly as a result of excessive listing or a loss of buoyancy.
A movable bridge used in boarding or leaving a ship at a pier; also known as a ‘brow.’
An additional extra tax.
Abbreviation for: Purchasing Management Association of Canada.
Abbreviation for: Facilities and Equipment.
See: Corrective Action.
The same as FOB named inland carrier, except the buyer pays the transportation charge and the seller reduces the invoice by a like amount.
Abbreviation for: Plan View Display.
An authorisation to withdraw allocated stock items from the stockroom. When presented to the stockroom, they can be exchanged for the parts designated.
The definition of system uptime or availability as 99.999%, or an approximate downtime of 5 minutes per year.
Favourable position over another sailing vessel with respect to the wind. Also: Weather gauge or Weather-beam.

Creating production schedules that automatically take resource availability into account. Schedule dates are moved forward or backward in time as far as necessary to stay within prescribed capacity, and some systems also contain rules to move orders for certain products to approved alternate facilities when the initial resource is full. Finite scheduling systems normally do not ensure that material plans are automatically revised in conjunction with production rescheduling.

Person responsible for creating a future state map and leading door-to-door implementation of the future state for a particular product family. Makes change happen across departmental and functional boundaries.

Though dry storage can have other meanings in different industries, in warehousing it is typically used to describe non-refrigerated storage of food products (canned goods, dry goods, etc.). Also see: Cold storage.
A member of a vessel’s crew involved in commissary duties or in personal services to passengers or other crew members.

Buyers operating at the corporate level with global sourcing responsibilities for key commodities. It is their job to negotiate for large volumes of products and components (in the case of raw materials), large investment projects, and services.

A buyer who has requested his/her bank to arrange an L/C on his behalf. In some countries where the buyer may have trouble arranging an import license, the applicant may be a third party acting on behalf of the buyer.
Abbreviation for Return on Assets.
Also known as an order picker, an order selector is a specialised lift truck that allows a person to ride on it with the pallet in order to pick from various locations and levels.
See; AFMC

There are various uses and users for CONOPS. The primary purpose of the CONOPS is to provide a vision for an initiative or desired capability. In general, the CONOPS provides guidance to those users requiring direction and/or information on developing their own documents, schedules, milestones, and plans.
The ratio of standard deviation divided by the mean for a given sample used to measure spread.

The process of identifying and cataloging activities for detailed understanding and documentation of their characteristics. Accomplished by interviews, group sessions, questionnaires, observations, and reviews of physical records of work
Cargo that is being transported in containers that can be transferred easily from one transportation mode to another.
Abbreviation for: Engineering Execution Systems.

term: Intelligent Label (“tag” or Radio Frequency Label)
definition: Programmable and re-recordable label, read without contact using radio-frequency identification (RFID).
A movement of equipment from an origin rail ramp to a destination rail ramp only.
Abbreviation for Return on Owners' Equity.
Abbreviation for: Government Communication and Information System.
Abbreviation for: Flight Information Region.
Internationally recognised, standard label format, designed for use on any transport unit, including cartons, shippers (or inners) and pallets to identify the goods being transported.
A sophisticated engineering system designed to document, verify, and diagnose failures, recommend and initiate corrective action, provide follow-up, and maintain comprehensive statistical records.
A term used in planning and control, usually to indicate staff scheduling, the allocation of working times to individuals so as to adjust the capacity of an operation.
Abbreviation for Procurement Marketing and Access Network.
Specify how the agent, i.e. contractor, should deliver the work.
To store, or to put away e.g. personal effects, tackle, or cargo.
The restrictions imposed on exchanging a country’s currency against those of other countries.
Abbreviation for: Total Quality Engineering.
A levy on a vendor's sale by an authorized level of government.
Single-purpose semi-trailer designed to carry a shipping container.

1. Formed during the creation of the Department of Homeland Security in 2003, CBP consists primarily of the customs inspection function formerly performed by the U.S. Customs Service, as part of the Department of Treasury, the immigration inspection function formerly performed by the Immigration and Naturalisation Service (INS), and the Border Patrol, formerly part of the Department of Justice.2. Focuses on improving the security of private companies’ supply chains with respect to terrorism. In exchange for companies participation CBP will provide reduced inspections at the port of arrival, expedited processing at the border and penalty mitigation.
A charge for delaying a steamer beyond a stipulated period.
Those costs associated with checking, monitoring, and controlling quality to see if problems or errors have occurred. An element within quality-related costs.
A description method that is used when an organisation needs to provide very detailed descriptions of the characteristics of an item or a service.
Current assets minus current liabilities. The portion of current assets available for other uses after satisfying current obligations.

An analytic technique that compares the costs and benefits of investments, programs, or policy actions in order to determine which alternative or alternatives maximize net profits. Net benefits of an alternative are determined by subtracting the present value of costs from the present value of benefits. A comparative evaluation of the trade-off between the cost of a good or service and the value or benefit to be obtained in order to choose among alternatives.
The effects of a transportation project, including (a) direct (primary) effects; (b) indirect (secondary) effects; and (c) cumulative effects.
A third party, specific application designed to enhance or extend a base system through increased functionality
Abbreviation for: Remote Tower Alphanumerics Display.
A work centre where the specified capacity is constrained by labour availability instead of machine availability.

A salute on the bos’n’s pipe(s) performed in the company of the deck watch on the starboard side of the quarterdeck or at the head of the gangway, to welcome or bid farewell to the ship’s Captain, senior officers, and honored visitors.
A set of techniques, originally pioneered by Denso in the Toyota Group in Japan, to ensure that every machine in a production process always is able to perform its required tasks.
1. A vessel traveling downstream. 2. Eastward-traveling vessels in the Great Lakes region (terminology as used by the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation).

term: American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM)
definition: Not-for-profit organisation that provides a forum for the development and publication of voluntary consensus standards for materials, products, systems, and services.

A single detail record. The term line item is most commonly used to describe the detail (each line that reflects an item and a quantity) on sales orders or purchase orders. For example, if a customer orders 20 red pens, 50 black pens, and 10 green pens, this equates to an order with three line items.
The number of telephone calls made or received over a specific period of time.
A process by the Florida Department of Transportation for design and environmental assessment of transportation projects.
Air Taxi Commercial Operator.
Frequency Division Multiplexing.
See: Percent of Fill
Abbreviation for: United States Code.
Standard legal and commercial conditions that will apply to every purchase order issued by the buyer.
Giving employees the responsibility, authority, training, and tools necessary to manage quality.

A variety of arrangements under which two or more governmental entities pool their commodity and/or service requirements to purchase aggregated quantities thus achieving economies of scale. The process usually involves a single combined bid or request for proposal in which all of the participating entities are named or their participation implied.

A systematic analysis tool that organises the effects of a problem and its possible causes, in a graphical display that often resembles the skeleton of a fish. Developed by Dr. Kaoru Ishikawa, it is sometimes referred to as an Ishikawa diagram.
A progressive sourcing strategy where considerations go beyond value for money considerations to include impact on people and society as whole.
Cargo Not Otherwise Specified. Usually the rate entry in a tariff that can apply to commodities not covered under a specific item or sub–item in the applicable tariff.
The estimated or measured completion status of a process or project used to analyze the probability of meeting a projected date, or in initiating a contracted progress payment.

1. In the Age of Sail, a warrant officer responsible for the hull, masts, spars, and boats of a vessel, and whose responsibility was to sound the well to see if the vessel was making water. 2. A senior rating responsible for all the woodwork aboard a vessel.
The pooling of purchasing requirements across multiple areas to lower costs.
Liners are vessels sailing between specified ports on a regular schedule; schedule is published and available to the public. Most large container shipping companies operate liner services.
Abbreviation for: Flight Standards District Office.
Time spent processing or transforming material against an order or schedule, and does not include setup, queue, or move time

Maritime industry abbreviation for: Lighter Aboard Ship. A specially constructed vessel equipped with an overhead crane for lifting specially designed barges and stowing them into cellular slots in an athwart ship position.
The bed of the sea.
Abbreviation for: Vehicle/ Pedestrian Deviation.

A specific factor that a business sees as being central to the way it, or its employees, works. It fulfills three key criteria: 1. It provides consumer benefits 2. It is not easy for competitors to imitate 3. It can be leveraged widely into many products and markets. A core competency can take various forms, including technical/subject matter know-how, a reliable process, and/or close relationships with customers and suppliers. It may also include product development or culture, such as employee dedication.
A system where the production or movement of inventory items is initiated as required by the using department or location or to replace items removed from an authorization queue.
A third party, licensed to make transportation arrangements.
The total rate from the point of origin to final destination.

Systems of hardware and software used to process transactions in warehouses and manufacturing operations. Data collection systems may consist of fixed terminals, portable terminals and computers, radio frequency (RF) terminals, and various types of barcode scanners (a.k.a. Automated Data Capture, AIDC, Automatic Identification & Data Collection).

Also called the third officer, a licensed member of the deck department of a merchant ship, fourth – or on some ocean liners fifth – in command; a watch-keeping officer, customarily also the ship’s safety officer, responsible for the ship’s firefighting equipment, lifeboats, and other emergency systems. Other duties of the third mate vary depending on the type of ship, its crewing, and other factors.

Abbreviation for: Metropolitan Transportation Plan. A transportation plan with a twenty-year planning horizon; developed by each MPO; must be updated at least triennially in non-attainment areas and every five years in attainment areas; should be cost-feasible.
A government document declaring designated goods to be shipped out of the country. To be completed by the exporter and filed with the U.S. Government.
The stepped curve that connects valid sections of a family of cost curves when there are price discounts.
Automated Flight Service Station.
To furl or truss a sail by pulling it toward the mast, or the ropes used for this purpose.
Activities needed to select contractor for the work based upon competitive bids.
A Future Reality Diagram is a sufficiency-based logic structure designed to reveal how changes to the quo would affect reality-specifically to produce desired effects.
Abbreviation for: Precision Approach Radar and Preferential Arrival Route.

1. A soldier trained for service afloat in a (primarily) infantry force that specialises in naval campaigns and subordinated to a navy or a separate naval branch of service rather than to an army. 2. An alternative term for a navy, uncommon in English, but common in other languages. 3. Of, or pertaining to, the sea (e.g., marine biology, marine insurance, marine life, marine salvage). 4. A painting representing a subject related to the sea.
Refers to: Publication.
The variance created by the actual price paid to a vendor compared to the standard cost.
Abbreviation for: Service Oversight Centre.
An e-auction used by buyers to enforce competitive bidding among a limited number of prequalified suppliers based on a starting price that is lowered during the auction.
A partial deck, above the upper deck and at the head of the vessel; traditionally the sailors’ living quarters. The name is derived from the castle fitted to bear archers in time of war.
Also known as addictive manufacturing, a technology that produces three-dimensional objects by laying down layer upon layer of material.
A log or report of accounts payable invoices created for a specific batch, vendor, date range, or other parameter.
The examination of the management of the flow of information, inventory, processes, and cash from the earliest supplier to the ultimate consumer, including the final disposal process.
A forecast technique that tests the performance of a variety of forecast models and suggests the best fit for a given set of products and demand parameters.
Abbreviation for: Sector-Specific Assistance Scheme.
An attribute of a product or service that might help the customer select between two competing products (e.g., metallic paint or a sunroof in a car).
The money obtained by the cook selling slush ashore. Used for the benefit of the crew (or the cook).
Instructions given by a shipper to a bank indicating that documents transferring title to goods should be delivered to the buyer only upon the buyer’s acceptance of the attached draft.

A business entity that purchases a product from a manufacturer, adds enhancements and then sells it to another organisation. Many large computer manufacturers have agreements with resellers to deliver, install and configure their equipment.
person who had acquired through training qualification and experience the knowledge and skills necessary for undertaking and task assigning to then under the codes.
Abbreviation for: ATS Contingency Command Post.
See: Fill Rate
Abbreviation for: Demand Flow Management, Demand Flow Manufacturing, and Design For Manufacturability.
When the anchor is secured for sea. Typically rests just outside the hawse pipe on the outer side of the hull, at the bow of a vessel
The smokestack of a ship, used to expel boiler steam and smoke or engine exhaust.
Abbreviation for: Container on Flat Car.
To change the direction of a sailboat so that it is more upwind. To bring the bow windward. Also called heading up. This is the opposite of falling off.

Software-based engineering process that includes the use of modelling in multiple dimensions and in software simulated “normal operating conditions” in order to discover weaknesses, design improvement opportunities, and general refinement before physically building a tangible prototype.
The shed on a wharf that is designed to protect cargoes from weather damage and is used only for short-term storage. Warehouses operated by private firms which house goods for longer periods.
Also known as broken case picking, piece picking describes a process where individual items are picked for orders.
Work measurement technique for building up a time from previously time’s elements.
The difference between the planned and actual output or production rates for a given period.
Abbreviation for: Touchdown and Lift-off Area.
A clause that prohibits railroads from hauling commodities that they produced, mined, owned, or had an interest in.

A type of contract in which a source of supply is established for a specified period of time for specified services or supplies; usually characterized by an estimated or definite minimum quantity, with the possibility of additional requirements beyond the minimum, all at a predetermined unit price.
Measures of quality that can be measured on a continuously variable scale, for example length, weight, etc
Also known as the Kraljic portfolio, it categorizes products into four quadrants (leverage, strategic, routine, and bottleneck) based on financial impact and supply risk.

This measures the average number of units purchased over a period of time and compares that value to target values. This KPI provides important data about customer purchase trends, and the effectiveness of a sales teams at moving product quickly.
Storage place for products. Principal warehouse activities include receipt of product, storage, shipment, and order picking.

In order to obtain the clean bill of lading, the shipper signs a letter of indemnity to the carrier on the basis of which may be obtained the clean bill of lading, although the dock or mate’s receipt showed that the shipment was damaged or in bad condition.
Abbreviation for: Fine Pitch Technology.
A cluster of pilings to which a boat or barge ties up.
Abbreviation for: Make To Order.
The process of monitoring operations activity and coping with any deviations from the plan; usually involves elements of re-planning.

Trailer creep (also known as trailer walk, dock walk) occurs when the lateral and vertical forces exerted each time a lift truck enters and exits the trailer cause the trailer to slowly move away from the dock resulting in separation from the dock leveller. Factors that affect trailer creep are the weight and speed of the lift truck and load, the grade of the drive the trailer is parked on, the softness of the suspension, the type of transition (dock levellers, dock boards) being used, and whether the trailer has been dropped off, (spotted) or if it is still connected to the tractor.
Abbreviation for: Aeronautical Information Service and Automotive Investment Scheme.
Perceived value of materials (often considered as place utility when materials are in the right locations, and time utility when they are available at the right time).
An industry abbreviation for: Hazardous Material.

All purchased materials and services that do not become part of the company’s value proposition. May be classified into MRO-supplies, investment goods (also referred to as capital expenditure or CAPEX) and services (identical to non-BOM-materials or non-production materials).

A ramp on the shore by which ships or boats can be moved to and from the water. Slipways are used for building and repairing ships and boats. They are also used for launching and retrieving small boats on trailers towed by automobiles and flying boats on their undercarriage.

To take up the last bit of slack on a line such as a halyard, anchor line or dockline by taking a single turn round a cleat and alternately heaving on the rope above and below the cleat while keeping the tension on the tail.
Also, Act of Grace. A letter from a state or power authorizing action by a privateer.
Request for x. A generic term for RFI, RFP, and RFQ.
A status awarded to a supplier who consistently meets predetermined objectives of quality, cost, delivery, financials, and count. Incoming inspection may not be required.
Abbreviation for: Letter of Readiness.
Pricing goods or services at the documented cost, plus an agreed-upon fixed percentage or dollar amount.
A machine that aids in the transfer of product from one pallet to another. The pallet inverter flips over the pallets and product in order to put the product on the new pallet and take off the old.

Vale stream mapping is a graphic tool that helps you to see and understand the flow of the material and information as a product makes its way through the value stream. It tries together lean concepts and techniques.

The tendency of a project to include more tasks or to implement more systems than originally specified, which often leads to higher than planned project costs and an extension of the initial implementation date.

1. Abbreviation for: Environmental Impact Statement. A comprehensive study of the impacts of and alternatives to proposed projects; required by the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). 2. Abbreviation for: Executive Information System.
These encompass all products which are purchased to be sold, after negligible added value, either together with other finished products or manufactured products (identical to finished products).

The activities undertaken by an organization and its suppliers to deliver the customer value proposition. Secondary supply chains are subordinate to the primary supply chain but can be optimized in their own right.
A ratio that contrasts the total length of time customers have to wait between asking for a product or service and receiving it (D) and the total throughput to produce the product/service (P).
The actual amount of labour time an item or product requires to be completed by a process step, as timed by direct observation.
Organisational change management is a comprehensive set of structures and procedures for the decision-making, planning, execution, and evaluation phases of the change process.
Any non-naval passenger- or cargo-carrying vessel, including cargo ships, tankers, and passenger ships but excluding troopships.
The mathematical relationship between throughput time, work-in-process, and cycle time (throughput time equals work-in-process X cycle time).
The stand on which the ship’s compass is mounted.
Abbreviation for: Switched Compressed Video Telecommunications Service.
Outsourcing by a government or a public agency.
Abbreviation for: Proposed Boundary Crossing Time.
