The total volume of traffic on a highway segment for one-year, divided by the number of days in the year
1. The deck of a ship immediately above the hold. 2. In British usage, those members of a ship’s company who are not officers, often used in the plural (the lower decks).
Abbreviation for Radio Microwave Link.
An exempt, for-hire air carrier that will fly anywhere on demand; air taxis are restricted to a maximum payload and passenger capacity per plane.
The middle section of a vessel with reference to the longitudinal plane, as distinguished from fore or aft.
A system of aids to navigation in which characteristics of buoys and beacons indicate the sides of the channel or route relative to a conventional direction of buoyage (usually upstream).

Demand for components and material calculated, or dependent, on the demand from another item in the system and not due to outside demand such as a customer or inter plant order for that item. The demand is derived from exploding an upper level bill of material, as opposed to generating a forecast for the dependent demand item.
Overseas Private Investment Corporation, an agency of the U.S. Government which helps U.S. businesses invest overseas.
Abbreviation for: Outer Marker.
Abbreviation for: Tin Whiskers and Taxiway.
Abbreviation for: Gross Vehicle Weight. The combined total weight of a vehicle and its container, inclusive of prime mover.
The idea that all operations processes are made up of smaller operations processes.
A dry bulk vessel of 35,000 to 49,000dwt. (Note that a “Handy” dry bulk carrier is from 10,000 to 34,000dwt.) A “Handymax Tanker” is a liquid bulk carrier of 10,000 to 60,000dwt.
When U.S. Customs orders shipments without entries to be kept in their custody in a bonded warehouse.

Sighting the positions of the sun and moon using a sextant and using a nautical almanac to determine the location and phase of the moon and calculating the relative effect of the tides on the navigation of the ship.
See: Clerks
A manufacturing process where products are completed from components as a result of a series of continuous activities. Henry Ford is widely recognised as the father of the assembly line.
Abbreviation for: Master Scheduling.
An order indicating that the ship is now on the desired course relative to the wind and that the sails should be trimmed (‘hauled’) to suit.
Technology that assists in the management of processes rather than directly contributes to the creation of products and services, for example information technology that schedules activities.
Abbreviation for: En Route Navigational Aids.
Radio Communications Link.

A manufacturing environment where the final product is assembled based on the receipt of a customer order (instead of to stock). The assembly is normally performed using standard components, modules, and sub-assemblies that are already stocked based on forecasts developed from past usage history. An ATO environment allows each customer order to specify a custom combination of previously-defined standard options.
Abbreviation for: Emergency Voice Communications System.
Refers to: Clearway.
Abbreviation for: General National Airspace System.
The earliest an activity can be finished, calculated by adding the activity’s duration to its earliest start time.

1. Discrete manufacturing processes create products by assembling unconnected distinct parts as in the production of distinct items such as automobiles, appliances, or computers. 2. A manufacturing environment often characterised by individual, separate unit production, low unit volume, high product complexity, variable lead times, and production to order vs. to stock.
A docking facility for small ships and yachts.
An output from an inventory control system designating those items, by part number, description, and quantity, to be picked from stock to satisfy customer demand.
An engine mounted within the hull of a vessel, usually driving a fixed propeller by a shaft protruding through the stern. Generally used on larger vessels. Also see: Sterndrive and Outboard motor.

A type of air circulation in a temperature control container. Air is pulled by a fan from the top of the container, passed through the evaporator coil for cooling, and then forced through the space under the load and up through the cargo. This type of airflow provides even temperatures.

All departmental costs are rolled up in this metric, including distribution costs, procurement costs, warehousing costs, transportation costs, and manufacturing costs. From these, it is possible to calculate cost of goods sold, cost per unit, or cost per kilogram, which are all useful KPI’s relative to total cost.
1. A floating barrier controlling navigation in rivers and harbors. 2. A spar attached to the foot of a fore-and-aft sail.
NDB with Distance Measuring Equipment
An executive person responsible for the entire organisational procurement. Reports directly to the Chief Executive Officer or the Managing director.
A stay which holds the bowsprit downwards, counteracting the effect of the forestay. Usually made of wire or chain to eliminate stretch.
Periodically, the buyer invites suppliers through a standardised survey to suggest ideas which may improve business relationships.
Modes of transportation that do not utilise highway right-of-way. Examples include fixed guideway transit, rail, and water modes.
The party that hires a vessel for a period of time or for a voyage.

The price paid for the use of money. Since most businesses borrow money, the interest rate is factored into their cost of doing business and may be reflected in the selling price of commodities and services (Schiller, 2000).
A variation of ARIMA modelling that creates a forecast using regression and moving average and incorporates previous errors. Most often used in developing short-term forecasts

Abbreviation for: Institute of Transportation Engineers: An international society of professionals in transportation and traffic engineering; publishes Trip Generation (a manual of trip generation rates by land use type).
The part of a management information system that deals with the information needed for stock control.
Abbreviation for: Retail Finance Intermediaries.

Defined as the systematic gathering, classification, and analysis of data considering all relevant factors that influence the procurement of goods and services for the purpose of meeting present and future company requirements.

A firm that charters vessels for its service requirements, which are handled by their own offices or appointed agents at ports of call. Vessel operators also handle the operation of vessels on behalf of owners.
Abbreviation for: Radar Air Traffic Control Centre.

A quantity scheduled to be produced or in production. For discrete products, the batch is planned to be the standard batch quantity, but during production, the standard batch quantity may be broken into smaller lots. In non-discrete products, the batch is a quantity to be produced in a given time period based on a formula or recipe, which is often developed to produce a given number of end items.
Assessing the internal quality and control system of an organisation using a systems approach.
Abbreviation for: Advanced Planning and Scheduling; Advanced Planning Systems; and Airport Planning Standard.
A party that acts to arrange for export and import movement of goods for shippers and consignees.
A piece of equipment similar to a forklift that lifts from above rather than below. Used to handle containers in the storage yard to and from storage stacks, trucks, and railcars.
In the postponement supply chain model, this is the point where an end product assumes unique characteristics through final assembly configuration and/or packaging.
Abbreviation for: Kilobits Per Second.
Abbreviation for: Mean Time Between Failures.
A projection from the side of a vessel for protection, stability, or the mounting of equipment such as armaments or lifeboats.

An internal or external person, department or organisation that purchases or receives goods and services. Identifying the true customer and the product or service attributes that will satisfy them is a key task in defining value added and non-value added activities.
It refers to purchasing by many agencies within an organisation rather than one central agency looking after all purchasing.
A more descriptive term for what is technically a product layout.

term: Maintenance, Repair and Operating Materials (MRO Items)
definition: These products, sometimes referred to as indirect materials or consumable items represent materials, which are necessary for keeping an organisation running in general, and for the support activities in particular.

Abbreviation for: Programmable Logic Controller. A computerized device used to control functions of machines. PLCs are used in the automation of manufacturing equipment and material handling equipment, such as automated conveyor systems. Also, abbreviation for: Product Life Cycle.
The ‘tractor’ unit that tows trailers.

Those value activities that are required to support the company’s primary activities. These include procurement, technology development, human resources management, and facilities management (i.e. those activities aimed at maintaining the firm’s infrastructure).
Contraction for: Shipper’s Export Declaration.
Refers to: Service C.
Abbreviation for: Public Service Regulations.
A lifting device composed of one mast or pole and a boom or jib which is hinged freely at the bottom.

The concept that capacity should be understood, defined, and measured for each level in the organisation, including market segments, products, processes, activities, and resources. In each of these applications, capacity is defined in a hierarchy of idle, non-productive, and productive views.

A formal ruling by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Transportation that a transportation project or group of projects do(es) not individually or cumulatively have a significant environmental effect on the natural or human environment.
Those persons who, because of disability, income, status, or age, are unable to transport themselves or to purchase transportation services.
Abbreviation for: Weather Message Switching Centre Replacement.

Abbreviation for: Major Metropolitan Transportation Investment. A highway or transit improvement of substantial cost that is expected to have a significant effect on capacity, traffic flow, level of service or mode of service at the transportation corridor or subarea scale.

Material that will contribute to a finished product, but is not the finished product itself. Examples would include tires for an automobile, power supply for a personal computer, or a zipper for a ski parka. Note that what is a component to the manufacturer may be considered the finished product of their supplier.
A pallet measuring 1.20m x 1.00m, and weighing approximately 40 kg. Height—0.15m.
An arrangement among shipper, carrier, and consignee whereby the carrier leaves a trailer filled with freight at a destination and hooks up and hauls away an empty trailer.
The parameters placed on a column within a database or data entry form on a website. An example of a parameter would be the 8-character limitation for any text entered into a particular data field.

The percentage of items, SKUs or order value that arrives on or before the requested ship date. (Number of On Time Items / Total Items) * 100. The on time shipping rate is key to customer satisfaction. A high rate indicates an efficient supply chain.
Abbreviation for: Kilohertz.
An EOQ that corresponds to a point on the valid total cost curve when costs are discounted.
Abbreviation for: Value Added Distribution.

Represents the procurement of goods and services that are not directly incorporated into a product being manufactured. They include such as computers, safety boots and goggles, uniforms, office supplies, janitorial services, equipment, furniture, etc.
A phrase often included in charter parties and freight contracts referring to local rules and practices which may impact upon the costs borne by the various parties.
Logistics Service Provider handling of operations related to assembling intermediate production goods.
An allowance built into a system or process that provides for continued operation or a successful outcome even with less-than-perfect results.
Abbreviation for: Controlled Visual Flight Rules.
The Japanese term for fail-safe.
A conveyor system device that moves products using a stationary arm for sorting.
What sailors call inboard engines.
To formally place (a naval vessel) into active service, after which the vessel is said to be in commission. Sometimes used less formally to mean placing a commercial ship into service.
Abbreviation for: Independent Software Vendor.
Theory that business success is primarily achieved through deploying a company’s external and internal resources.
Articles which are taken apart to reduce the cubic footage displaced or to make a better shipping unit and are to be re-assembled.
Abbreviation for: Closed Loop Corrective Action.
See: Transmitting station.
An organisation that markets a product composed of components and subsystems manufactured by other companies under its own name and brand.
Combining several small orders into larger ones for MRP.
A subset of micro-marketing focused on customising assortments, quantities, and displays.

The practice of outsourcing non-core internal functions to third parties. Functions typically outsourced include logistics, accounts payable, accounts receivable, payroll, and human resources. Other areas can include IT development, or complete management of the IT functions of the enterprise.
AUTOVON Service.
Prefix for “Turbo-Electric Vessel,” used before a ship’s name.
A forecast that projects historical patterns into the future.
A system that combines available to promise inventory availability with current capacity capabilities when calculating customer order schedule dates.
The set of characters, normally alphanumeric, that identifies a specific manufactured or purchased item and is used in all database, order, inventory, and other functions.
A bracket that serves as a fulcrum for an oar. Also called "Thole."
Cargo that is not liquid and normally does not require temperature control.
Those activities that are critical to a company’s customer value proposition.
The unique identification number of a freight container, normally referring to a container used in ocean mode transportation/ multi-modal transportation.

The business process that coordinates and monitors all changes to the business processes and applications operated by the business as well as to their internal equipment, resources, operating systems, and procedures. The change management discipline is carried out in a way that minimises the risk of problems that will affect the operating environment and service delivery to the users.
Software and concept originated by Eliyahu Goldratt to exploit his theory of constraints (TOC).
An approach to rate making whereby the ante is based only upon the shipment weight and distance; widely used in TOFC service.
The process of confirming receipts or shipments based on weight.
The maximum speed of a ship. Faster than ‘full speed.’
Abbreviation for: Integrated Noise Model.
Abbreviation for: Maintenance Automation Program, Military Airport Program, Missed Approach Point, Millennium Africa Recovery Plan and Modified Access Pricing.
Variables that are related to the personalities of the persons involved in the purchase decision-making process.
Abbreviation for: Distributed Feedback.
Abbreviation for: Dynamic Ocean Tracking System.
A calculated or manually- entered date that defines when material or production is required to be available for use.
Abbreviation for: Middle Marker.
Breaking down waste material into its elemental components, which then can be used in other production process.

Any leaning programme for which the measure Entities has: Any form of independence written certificates as referred to in the “Learning Achievement “column of the learning programme matrix, or if it does not have such certification: An enrolment certificate issued by the independence person responsible for the issue of certification referred to in statement 300 confirming the employee has: Enrolled for, is attending and is making satisfactory progress in the learning programme; or Enrolled for but not attended the learning ;or Attended the training programme but has failed an evaluation of their learning progress.
Measure entity with a business in the republic of South Africa and elsewhere which maintain its international headquarter outside the Republic.
The process of aligning operations within a specific production line, and feeder lines to consuming lines, which minimises fluctuations in production levels and operation downtime.
Abbreviation for: Miles Per Gallon.

A term used to refer to the observation that any change, even a small one, in the requirements for items at the top of the bill of material can have drastic effects on items further down the bill of material.
An enlisted sailor, one who is housed before the foremast.
Sailing more than about 160° away from the wind. If directly away from the wind, it’s a dead run.
Help text associated with the specific part of the system a user is currently involved with, and the method with which it is being used.

A small platform partway up the mast, just above the height of the mast’s main yard. A lookout is stationed here, and men who are working on the main yard will embark from here. See also crow’s nest on page 142

Contract in which the buyer agrees to pay the supplier all materials costs and employee hours against predetermined hourly rates and margins for services rendered (identical to cost reimbursable contract).
Quality at source as a means of achieving TQM.
Abbreviation for: Automated Test Equipment.
A type of manufacturing process where items are moved through different manufacturing steps in groups, or batches.
A file containing a series of GIF (Graphics Interchange Format) images that are displayed in rapid sequence by some web browsers, giving an animated effect.
A trailer towed by a rigid truck that has a single or bogie axle group at the center of the trailer and relies on the rigid truck to support the front of the trailer.
Abbreviation for: Special Federal Aviation Regulation.

The conversion of working days into calendar days is based on the number of regularly scheduled workdays per week in a manufacturing calendar. To convert from working days to calendar days: If work week: Calculation: = 4 days, multiply by 1.75 = 5 days, multiply by 1.40 = 6 days, multiply by 1.17

Total lead time for an end item, calculated by taking the individual lead times for all items on the critical path through all levels of the bill of material. The cumulative lead time describes the lead time required to finish an end item if no raw materials, components, or intermediate levels were on hand and had to be ordered and produced to create the final item.
The formal acceptance of a new process, system or program by the appropriate end user.
A functional group or department within an organisation that acts as a silo or island in its lack of interaction with other groups and in not sharing its internal data or processes.
Refers to the situation where someone within the client organisation does not buy from the preferred suppliers with agreed contracts.
A sailing vessel with three or more masts; with a square-rigged foremast and all other masts fore-and-aft rigged.

A computer software industry term which describes software offered for sale by commercial developers. This includes products from vendors such as SAP, Oracle, Microsoft, etc., as well as from smaller vendors.
Abbreviation for: Always within Institute Warranties Limits (Insurance purpose).
Abbreviation for: Minimum Navigation Performance Specification.
Abbreviation for: Material Requirements Planning.
The acceptable time range in which deliveries can be made.
1. A long journey by ship. 2. To go on such a journey.
A maritime term referring to fuel used aboard the ship. In the past, fuel coal stowage areas aboard a vessel were in bins or bunkers.
Abbreviation for: Airport Reference Code.

A method where the determination of a product’s location within the warehouse, or distribution centre, is based on:
1.	Product’s ABC Classification, and
2.	The number of times or rate at which the product is accessed
A multi-tier storage system normally designed to handle pallets, cartons, or other standard containers and designed for manual or automated pick/put away access.
A strategy used to vary workforce levels, in which additional full-time or part-time employees are hired during peak demand periods, while smaller permanent staffs are maintained year-round.
See: “harness cask.”
Abbreviation for: European Free Trade Association.
RA method of performing product recalls where a range of known lot numbers is expanded on the front and back end in order to capture any risk.
The network of supplier and customer operations that have relationships with an operation.
A calculated and purposive perversion of the law and company policy for the purpose of benefiting.
Abbreviation for: Always Afloat. A contract term requiring that a vessel not rest on the ground. In some ports a ship is aground when approaching or at berth.
Abbreviation for: Distributor Integration.
An amount charged to a client for monthly storage; it is based on the amount of product stored in the warehouse on the first day of the month or specified by the contract.
See: Program and Resource Plan.

A means to track the real-time status of all orders and categorises them based on the action taken, such as “Backordered,” “On Hold,” or “Shipped.” This data may be presented in many different ways since it incorporates information related to the specific circumstances of a supply chain. As well as monitoring the date and status of orders, this metric can also include information such as order accuracy.
A complete description of an item such as size, shape, capacity, dimensions, tolerances, etc.
Without packing.
A rule for reducing the costs of MRP by combining several smaller batches into larger ones

- A company incorporated for public benefit or other object relating to one or more cultural or social activities, or communal or group interest; and - The income and the property of which are not distributable to its incorporators, members, directors, officers or persons related to any of them.
Trends reflecting changes in the statistical distribution of weather over periods of decades or longer (e.g., rainfall, flooding [hundred year storm], storm surge, and mean high water).
A fore-and-aft triangular sail set on a long yard mounted at an angle to the mast.
Abbreviation for: Open to Buy.
Abbreviation for: Virtual Reality Modelling Language.
Abbreviation for: Persistent, Bioaccumulative and Toxic.
Abbreviation for: Keyboard Video Display Terminal.
A lower–than–usual tariff rate assessed because a shipper offers a greater volume than specified in the tariff. The incentive rate is assessed for that portion exceeding the normal volume.
A curve which suggests that there is some optimal quality level, Q. The curve is calculated by adding costs of internal and external failures, prevention costs, and appraisal costs.
The total time required to receive, fill, and deliver an order for an existing product to a customer, timed from the moment that the customer places the order until the customer receives the product.
A technique examining product requirements and process groupings to allocate tasks and machines to cells in a cellular layout.
Forward of the bow. Used to hail a boat or a ship, as in "Boat ahoy!".
Abbreviation for: Decision Height.
Documents used to inform the government of an importing country about the nature, value, and origin of goods being imported.

A label used to provide additional classification or information about a resource, activity, or cost object. Used for focusing attention, and may be subjective. Examples are a characteristic, a score or grade of product or activity, or groupings of these items, and performance measures.
One of a number of Warfare branch specialist officers.

A charge against earnings that does not involve a cash payment for the write off of the cost of an asset less salvage value over its estimated useful life. A variety of depreciation methods have been developed to specify the rate and amount of the write off for each fiscal period.
Traditional nickname for the Red Ensign, the civil ensign (flag) carried by United Kingdom civilian vessels.

An item with an identifying product number that is not normally built and then stocked, but is immediately used in the next stage of production. MRP processing logic will blow through a phantom down to the next level (and not generate planned orders for the phantom), but will net against its on-hand inventory if it does occasionally exist. A phantom bill of material is sometimes used to ease maintenance when a set of parts consumed in production has identical usage across many bills of material.
A standard or basis of measurement, such as cost, size, volume, etc.
A vessel with three hulls.

Describes a condition where the weight capacity of a trailer or container has been met. The term “weighted out” is most likely used when you have met the weight capacity of the trailer or container but still have physical space left in the trailer or container. Also see: Cubed out.
Behind a vessel. Move in a reverse direction.
Abbreviation for: Cost, Insurance & Freight, i.e., price includes cost (of goods), insurance, and transport.
A person or company shown on the bill of lading as the shipper.
To stimulate larger quantity orders many suppliers use quantity discounts in which advantage for the buyer is that it can realise a lower price per unit.
Case picking describes a process where cases are picked for orders.
An Incoterm of sale meaning the seller has delivered when the cargo is given to the carrier nominated by the buyer at the named place.

A computer application that automatically structures, analyses, and interprets data stored in the Data Warehouse to provide value-added information that supports the company’s decision-making process.
The use of a 24-hour clock instead of AM and PM when reporting actual labour or machine time or specifying deliveries.

An area into which merchandise may be brought into the country for further processing. Duty is paid only on the items brought in, normally at a lower rate than for finished goods, and paid only at the time of sale.
Time spent by a specific job or order waiting to be processed by a resource that is currently not immediately available for that job.
Stands for Plan, Do, Check, Act cycle, perhaps the best known of all improvement cycle models.
One that agrees to furnish materials or services at a specified price.
Waiting out a storm by dousing all sails and simply letting the boat drift.
A graphical representation of a quality test that shows process variability distribution based on the mean, upper and lower specification limits in the form of a box

An extremely narrow, and often disproportionately long, rowing boat outfitted with long oars, outriggers to hold the oarlocks away from the boat, and sliding seats, specifically designed for racing or exercise.

A system that includes if, then, not equal to, not greater than, or less than, and other parameters to construct an allowable process or product. In describing the configuration of a product from a menu of choices, it may provide that if option X is chosen, option Y cannot be chosen and 2 of option Z must also be selected

The conveyance, by a lessor to a lessee, of the right to use a tangible asset usually for a specified period of time in return for rent. At a specified period of time the lessee may purchase the equipment outright by paying an additional specified sum.
Any vehicle with more than four wheels touching the pavement during normal operation.

Software that provides the functionality to change the arrangement of data fields on a computer screen that accesses a mainframe computer program. Screen Mapping is frequently used in combination with terminal emulation software to “Remap” data fields from a standard mainframe program to be used on the smaller screen of a portable handheld device. Also known as: Screen scraping.
A rate published on traffic moving from an interior point to a port for transhipment to a foreign country.
Demand for an item composed of both dependent demand (the item is required by an upper-level assembly) and independent demand (the item is required on its own for a sales or inter-plant order).
Grouping like parts or materials under one buyer’s control for the procurement of all requirements to support production.

The general condition of the free surface on a large body of water with respect to wind waves and swell at a certain location and moment, characterised by statistics, including the wave height, period, and power spectrum. The sea state varies with time, as the wind conditions or swell conditions change
Routine audit of location records to ensure that records are compatible with actual placement of product within the warehouse.
In shipbuilding, an elevation of the lines of a ship, viewed from above and divided lengthwise.

1.An additional import duty imposed in instances where imported goods are priced at less than the normal price charged in the exporter’s domestic market and cause material injury to domestic industry in the importing country. 2.A tariff imposed to discourage sale of foreign goods, subsidised to sell at low prices detrimental to local manufacturers

A quality measure and improvement program developed by Motorola that focuses on the control of a process to the point of ± six sigma (standard deviations) from a centreline, or 3.4 defects per million items. It includes identifying factors critical to quality as determined by the customer, reducing process variation and improving capabilities, increasing stability, and designing systems to support the six sigma goal.
A small, triangular sail, above the skysail. Used in light winds on a few ships.
A boat with wing-like foils mounted on struts below the hull, lifting the hull entirely out of the water at speed and allowing water resistance to be greatly reduced.

The total standard or actual cost for an imported purchased item, composed of the vendor cost, transportation charges, duties, taxes, broker fees and/or any other charges. The total landed cost of an import item must be considered in evaluating foreign vs. domestic purchase decisions.
The process of developing graphic representations of the organizational relationships and/or activities that make up a business process.
A decision by a firm to emphasise one performance dimension over another, based on the recognition that excellence on some dimensions may conflict with excellence on others.

The force that holds a vessel upright or returns it to upright position if keeled over. Weight in the lower hold increases stability. A vessel is stiff if it has high stability, and tender if it has low stability. In a ship, stability is indicated by several characteristics. Initial stability is measured by the metacentric height; also known as “GM.” If GM is low, the vessel makes long slow rolls, and is considered tender. When GM is too high, the vessel is considered stiff, and may return violently to the upright position when rolling, with possible damage to cargo and injury to passengers and crew. Other stability considerations include the vessel’s range of stability, maximum righting arm, and the angle of heel at which the maximum righting arm occurs.
Abbreviation for: Global Shippers’ Forum.
See: Family Group.
Lifts temporary quarantine of a vessel; granted pratique by Health Officer.
Abbreviation for: Direction Finding.
How business takes account of its economic, social, and environmental impacts.
Abbreviation for: Remote Tower Radar Display.

Tasks that can be completed based upon detailed information provided by the computer system. An order picking task where the computer details the specific item, location, and quantity to pick is an example of a directed task. If the computer could not specify the location and quantity forcing the worker to choose locations or change quantities, it would not be a directed task. Directed tasks set up the opportunity for confirmation transactions.
Weights (often scrap or pig iron) used as permanent high-density ballast.
The recipient of the outcome of a supply chain who is internal to your organisation.
A decline in the value of a country’s currency visa versus the currencies of other countries.
Abbreviation for: Quality Control.
A large sail used only for sailing downwind, requiring little attention.

The period of time measured by a single person working for one hour. Standard man-hours specify the amount of time normally expected to be used in a process or operation, based on estimation or past history.
Material used for caulking hulls. Often hemp picked from old untwisted ropes.
Processes that are high-volume and low-variety; products made on a continuous process are usually produced in an endless flow, such as petrochemicals or electricity.

term: EQUITY EQUIVALENT INVESTMENT PROGRAMME SOUTH AFRICA
definition: public programme or scheme of any government department, provincial or local government in the republic of South Africa or any other programme approved by the minister as an Equity Equivalent Programme.

Defects or minor non-compliance contained within a response to a bid. A defect which is easily correctable. Deviations from the exact requirements of the solicitation that do not affect the price, terms, or conditions of the bid document. A minor informality or irregularity is one, which is merely a matter of form and not of substance, or pertains to some immaterial or inconsequential defect or variation of a bid from the exact requirement of the IFB, the correction or waiver of which would not be prejudicial to other bidders. Example: Failure to execute a required certificate.
Software that uses abstract reasoning, pattern recognition, ‘‘learning,” and/ or problem-solving to approach tasks.
The work content needed to produce an item in a process expressed as a percentage of total throughput time.
Abbreviation for: Air Traffic Control Radar Beacon System.
A loss discovered before or at the time of delivery of a shipment.
An analysis most frequently employed in a machine or process area to project capacity for additional business.
An act beyond human control, such as lightning, flood, or earthquake.
See: Long Range Transportation Plan.
The property of a system that allows two-way communications on a timely, if not real-time basis, as opposed to a system in which information flows only one way on a batch or scheduled basis.

The combination of hardware and software that retrieves Internet web information and transfers web pages to a web browser. The web server also provides messaging, data, interaction management, and secure communications.
Refers to: Mitre Corporation.
Allows foreign merchandise arriving at one port to be transported in bond to another port, where a superseding entry is filed.

A notice issued to the successful bidder advising them that it is the government’s intent to award a contract. In construction contracting, it is common practice to require completion of performance in a specified number of days after issuance of the notice to proceed.
A professional organization in the field of logistics.
The ability of a feedback instrument to measure what it was intended to measure; also, the degree to which inferences derived from measurements are meaningful.
The largest vessel that can transit the locks of the St. Lawrence Seaway. Length is 226 meters (740 feet); Beam is 24 meters (78 feet); Draft is 7.92 meters (26 feet).
Traditional Royal Navy term for the Captain, a survival from the days when privately owned ships were often hired for naval service.
A field in the master schedule record indicating an estimate of inventory levels at the end of each week based on current data.
The measurement of total space or volume available, or required, in transportation and warehousing. Calculation: floor space x height.
The cost associated with inventory storage facilities, such as material handling equipment and personnel. It does not include the costs of holding inventory due to insurance, scrap, etc.
The conveyance of goods directly from the vendor to the buyer.
1. An oared warship of the 1500s equipped with a gun deck, larger, and equipped with more sails than a galley. 2. A flat-bottom commercial sailing vessel of the North Sea and western Baltic Sea.
Abbreviation for: Canadian Industrial Transportation Association and Commission for International Trade Administration.
Abbreviation for: Information Technology Agreement.
A combination of a tractor and three semi-trailers connected by two converter dollies.
An airport that serves corporate aviation, flight schools, air charter operations, light cargo or private pilots flying for business or recreation.
Nautical Mile.
The name of the fake illness a malingerer is pretending to suffer from.
Abbreviation for: Annual Average Daily Traffic.
Abbreviation for: Radar Processing Group.
Water carriers that transport freight between East and West Coast ports, usually by way of the Panama Canal.
A transit mode operated by rubber tired vehicles that follow fixed routes and schedules along roadways.
Two tag types are defined in generation 1 standards. Class 0 tags are programmed with identifying numbers at the point of manufacture. Class 1 tags can be programmed in the field.
A policy initiative aimed at regaining production control of a sector decimated by imports.

The process of creating physical models and solid objects from computer aided design (CAD), stereo lithography or other specifications. It normally uses a series of layers to build a physical object, and aims to reduce design cycle time and enable multiple test iterations at lower cost before moving to volume production.
Abbreviation for: Automatic Surface Observation System.
A warehouse belonging to a point of sale of the sales organisation.
Often used synonymously with RFP, but may involve a final price quotation request for a precise set of requirements.
1.A partition separating one part of a ship, freight car, aircraft or truck from another part. 2.An upright wall within the hull of a ship. Particularly a watertight, load-bearing wall
The lowest charge that can be assessed to transport a shipment.

eBid is an online bidding system which eliminates traditional paper bids and replaces them with an electronic process via the internet. stocks of physical and human capital, and by improving its technology.
A shipment loaded into a container at the pier or terminal, thence to the consignee’s facility.
Ropes employed in the operation of reefing.
A tariff imposed by a government on imported goods, exported goods, or the use of goods.

The detailed description of the requirements to produce a given item, which includes the operations performed, the order in which they are done, the labour or machine resources required at each operation, and the rate those resources process the item at each operation. It may also include tooling and process or other specifications, and serves as the basis for manufacturing lead time calculations, detailed capacity planning, and the cost standards associated with production. Released production orders normally include the standard routing and bill of material, unless modified for a specific order.

May apply to RFP’s and IFB’s and are conditions set out in the specifications/statement of work that must be met without alteration. Mandatory requirements should be clearly identified. Not meeting mandatory requirements may be grounds for disqualification.
Abbreviation for: Product Lifecycle Management.
U.S. Customs’ automated program under AMS. It allows for electronic reporting of inbound (foreign) cargoes in the U.S.
In a forecast, the difference between the actual value and the forecast value.

1.From the mid-19th century to the mid-20th century, a classification for a wide variety of gun- and sometimes torpedo-armed warships, usually but not always armoured, intended for independent scouting, raiding, or commerce protection; some were designed also to provide direct support to a battle fleet. Cruisers carried out functions performed previously by the cruising ships (sailing frigates and sloops) of the Age of Sail.  2.From the early 20th century to the mid-20th century, a type of armoured warship with varying armament and of various sizes, but always smaller than a battleship and larger than a destroyer, capable of both direct support of battle fleet and independent operations, armed with guns and sometimes torpedoes. 3.After the mid-20th century, various types of warships of intermediate size armed with guided missiles and sometimes guns, intended for air defence of aircraft carriers and associated task forces or for anti- ship missile attacks against such forces; virtually indistinguishable from large destroyers since the late 20th century.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Doppler Weather Radar.
Abbreviation for Advisory Circular.
A large usually round tub lashed to a vessel’s deck and containing dried and salted provisions for daily use.
Position of an anchor just clear of the bottom.
A structure that improves the streamlining of a vessel.
Detailed design and specifications, indicated by a drawing, of the required product.

Very heavy cargoes that require specialised equipment to move the products to and from ship/truck/rail/barge and terminals. This “heavy lift” machinery may be installed aboard a ship designed just for such transport. Shore cranes, floating cranes, and lift trucks may also be adapted for such heavy lifts.
A rope or cable serving to hold a mast up from side to side.

The process of designing a product to meet a specific cost objective. Target costing involves setting the planned selling price and subtracting the desired profit, as well as marketing and distribution costs, thus leaving the required target cost. Also known as design to cost.
Refers to: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, Recover.
People who buy goods and services to satisfy their wants.
Abbreviation for: Cubic Meter.
Abbreviation for: Inventory levels at the end of a specified period.
The end of a vessel. Opposite of bow.

1. An acronym for Sound Navigation and Ranging, a method of using sound pulses to detect, range, and sometimes image underwater targets and obstacles or the bed of the sea. Also see echo sounding and ASDIC. 2. The equipment used to conduct such searches, ranging, and imaging.

A security attachment to an electronic message to verify the identity of the sender and enable the receiver of the message to reply. Digital certificates are issued by third parties known as certification authorities.

A chain of events described by W. Edwards Deming: improve quality, decrease costs, improve productivity, increase market with better quality and lower price, stay in business, provide jobs, and provide more jobs.

An inventory relief system where components of a parent are deducted before being physically picked or used, based on the explosion of the parent bill of material. Often uses the parent schedule date rather than the actual reporting of parent production.
A situation in which an equipment operator deposits a trailer or boxcar at a facility at which it is to be loaded or unloaded.
The horizontal spar from which a square sail is suspended.
The British Naval Ensign or Flag of the British Merchant Navy, a red flag with the Union Flag in the upper left corner. Colloquially called the “red duster.”

Source-to-pay or S2P is the entire end-to-end process involved in procurement. It spans every process, right from spend management, strategic sourcing and vendor management to purchasing, performance management and accounts payable.
In a convoy, a ship that is unable to maintain speed and falls behind.

Guidance system used with AGVs that uses a rotating laser (mounted on top of the vehicle) to determine the vehicles location. Reflective targets need to be strategically placed along the vehicle’s route. Must always maintain clear line-of-site to reflective targets for the system to work properly.
Payments that are made based upon deliveries made for each project planning stage.

Salvageable material, either scrap or waste, that may be sold or used as trade-in. Worst-Case Scenario: In planning, to examine the worst possible environment or outcome and evaluate results around which to formulate next step.

The verification of vendor processes, delivery cycle, and quality levels that allow that supplier to be categorised as an acceptable provider of a specific material or service, as determined by the customer. It may include the pre-certification of parts shipped as having acceptable quality and the elimination of incoming inspection when received.
Abbreviation for: Against All Risks (insurance clause), Airport Acceptance Rate, and Association of American Railroads.
Freight charges paid by the shipper before the release of bills of lading.

The methods employed by financial institutions to ensure the validity of a check prior to funding or clearing the check for payment to the party making the demand. Normal methods employed confirm validity of the check number, account number, amount on the check, date range, and other specified (negotiated) elements. Used in freight payment auditing activities.
Abbreviation for: Clothing and Textiles Competitiveness Improvement Programme.
A special marking, positioned amidships, that indicates the draft of the vessel and the legal limit to which the vessel may be loaded for specific water types and temperatures.
The rate at which product moves through a warehouse.
A spar used to help control a spinnaker or other headsail.
Abbreviation for: Airport Service Radar Area.
Fibres of old rope packed between spars or used as a fender.
Abbreviation for: Demand Driven Supply Network.

License plates are often used with warehouse management systems. They are basically an ID number placed on a pallet, tote, carton or other container, and are used to track the contents of that container as it moves through the warehouse. The license plate will almost always have a bar code that contains this ID number. So by scanning a single bar code on the pallet you can initiate or complete movement transactions for all items and quantities on that pallet.
The capacity of a process or facility as it is designed to be, often greater than effective capacity.
Costs that do not change in the short term as a function of changes in production volumes, distribution volumes, labor, or machine hours.

Abbreviation for: Public Transportation Facilities and Equipment Management System. A systematic process (required under ISTEA) used by state agencies and MPOs to collect and analyze information on the condition and cost of transit assets on a continual basis. Data is used to help people choose cost-effective strategies for providing and keeping transit facilities and equipment in good condition.
A classification of smaller shipments.

Processing logic in MRP and other planning systems that assumes it is easier to reschedule an existing order than to place a new order. When requirements and supply are not aligned, the system will suggest the reschedule of all open scheduled receipts as needed, before suggesting a new order
Abbreviation for: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite.

The department and support systems responsible for personnel sourcing and hiring, applicant tracking, skills development and tracking, benefits administration, and compliance with associated government regulations.
Syn.: wall-to-wall inventory.
Central Processing Unit.
Abbreviation for: Central Weather Service Unit.
A ship’s sick list. The list of men unable to report for duty was given to the officer or mate of the watch by the ship’s surgeon. The list was kept at the binnacle.
Buyers wants to pay as little and seller charge as much as possible.
The integration of physical objects into an information network where the physical objects become active participants in business processes.
Activities or process changes that decrease the cost to process a purchase order or a payment transaction. Procurement credit cards are an example of a transaction cost reduction.
Abbreviation for: Demand Solutions Requirements Planning.

Global sourcing is defined as proactively integrating and coordinating common items and materials, processes, designs, technologies and suppliers across worldwide purchasing, engineering and operating locations.
An element of the Toyota Production System that averages volume and sequence of scheduled items to provide level production and help enable JIT.
Abbreviation for: Civil Aeronautics Board.

Of a fore-and-aft rigged vessel sailing directly away from the wind, with the sails set on opposite sides of the vessel—for example with the mainsail to port and the jib to starboard, to maximise the amount of canvas exposed to the wind. Also see: running.

Type of conveyor that uses gravity to move materials. Skatewheel conveyor and roller conveyor are the most common types of gravity conveyor used, however, even a simple steel chute is essentially a gravity conveyor.

A technique which uses a system of goals and metrics to monitor performance. Analysis of these measurements can help businesses in periodically setting business goals, and then providing feedback to managers on progress towards those goals. A specific measure can be compared to itself over time, compared with a pre-set target, or evaluated along with other measures.

The shipping manifest summarises the list of deliveries (bills of lading) that a carrier has been assigned by a shipper. It is very often reorganised by the carrier to reflect the contents of the trailer, instructions specific to each delivery, and the order of stops the driver must follow.
Abbreviation for: Continuous Wave.

1. The bottom of the ship touching the bottom, but not grounding. 2. Stopping at a dock or pier for a very short time without tying up, to let off or take on crew or goods. 3. Practice of aircraft on aircraft carriers touching the carrier deck and taking off again without dropping hooks.

Is the level for which further specific protective security measures shall be maintained for a limited period of time when a security incident is probable or imminent, although it may not be possible to identify the specific target.
These buyers responsible for buying and non-productrelated goods and services.

A distribution inventory management system that has two order points. The smallest equals the original order point, which covers demand during replenishment lead time. The second order point is the sum of the first order point plus normal usage during manufacturing lead time. It enables warehouses to forewarn manufacturing of future replenishment orders.
Abbreviation for: Instrument Meteorological Conditions and International Marketing Council of South Africa.

The discipline of estimating, tracking, and controlling product and service costs. Accurate cost analysis helps provide the basis for make/buy decisions, market entry and exit, product and process changes, and many other measures and factors involved in organisational success.
Demurrage/Despatch money. (Under vessel chartering terms, the amount to be paid if the ship is loading/discharging slower/faster than foreseen.)
A knot passing behind or around an object.
Abbreviation for: Data Communications Control Unit.
1. Abbreviation for: Departure. 2. Agency responsible for the implementation of environmental regulations, including air monitoring and assessment.
Abbreviation for: Business Reviews.
The point of equilibrium of the total weight of a container ship, truck, train, or a piece of cargo.

The percentage of orders that are fulfilled on or before the customer’s requested date used as a measure of responsiveness to market demand.
Delivery measurements are based on the date a complete order is shipped or the ship-to date of a complete order.
A complete order has all items on the order delivered in the quantities
requested. An order must be complete to be considered fulfilled. Multiple line items on a single order with different planned delivery dates constitute multiple orders, and multiple planned delivery dates on a single line item also constitute multiple orders.
Money being paid to other companies in return for goods and services.

Includes determining the purchasing needs, selecting the supplier, arriving at a proper price, specifying terms and conditions, issuing the contract or order, and following up to ensure proper delivery and payment.
When only part of an integrated function is outsourced while coordination remains with the client.
Abbreviation for: Take-off Distance Available.
Abbreviation for: Organised Track System.

A highly portable, machine-independent application component that can be executed either on a web server or locally within a client browser. Applets are installed, maintained, and upgraded on the server, and are transparently downloaded on demand whenever they are needed. They are stored on the client machine and “refreshed” from the server the next time the client connects to that particular server.
Partially completed final products that are still in the production process either as an accumulation of partially completed work or the queue of material awaiting further processing.
Abbreviation for: Approved Vendor List.
See: Product structure
Abbreviation for: Interfacility Data.
The weight prescribed by agreement between carrier and shipper for goods shipped in certain packages or in a certain number.
A mathematically based algorithm for scheduling a set of project activities as part of project management

Set of technologies resulting from convergence between information systems, telecommunications and audio-visual for processing and/or exchanging information. Example: Electronic Forms Interchange (EFI) through the Internet.

A closed loop or eye at the end of a line, rope, cable, etc. It is made by unravelling its end and joining it to itself by intertwining it into the lay of the line. Eye splices are very strong and compact and are employed in moorings and docking lines among other uses.
Abbreviation for: South African Qualifications Authority.
The competitive factors that have a minimum level of performance (the qualifying level) below which customers are unlikely to consider an operation’s performance satisfactory
A fixed lead time that does not vary based on process or quantity considerations.

Goods that have been shipped by an originating source but not yet received. Treated as an expected receipt by planning systems, and classified as belonging to either the shipping or receiving entity based on the contracted freight terms for purposes of claims and inventory status.
U.S. Food and Drug Administration.
Abbreviation for: En Route Automated Radar Tracking System.

As used in growth management, the requirement that public facilities and services needed to support development shall be available at the same time the impacts of such development will occur. For transportation facilities and service, there are specific legal criteria that address the time requirements for providing services and facilities, jurisdiction over level of service standards for specific portions of the highway and road system, and other issues.
A point beyond the midpoint of a ship’s length, towards the rear or stern.
Is a hybrid model that strives to combine the best of “In” and “Out” sourcing to provide the most cost effective solution.
The acceptable risk of having a shortage of an item which is used in calculating the required level of safety stock.
Trading firms that through physical stores or webstores deliver products and services directly to consumers.

1. The effect of the helm on a vessel; the act of steering a vessel. 2. 19th- and early 20th-century term for the section of a passenger ship that provided inexpensive accommodation with no individual cabins.
Abbreviation for: Days Payable Outstanding.
Abbreviation for: United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea Undercharge. To charge less than the proper amount.
Refers to the deliberate misrepresentation of the true BEE status of an entity, which in a false or favourable BEE status being conferred or claimed.
An exponent used in mathematical equations to express the level of a variable quantity (or, the power to which a number must be raised to produce a specific result).
Items returned, damaged, or subject to freight claims.
Abbreviation for: Transportation Research Board.
Abbreviation for: Corrective Action Report.
A basic operation in which product is moved to assigned storage or reserve locations until needed to replenish the locations for picking.
A document transferring a container from one carrier to another, or to/from a terminal.
The total quantity of material on open purchase, production, or replenishment orders - total scheduled receipts.
A place to moor a vessel.
Abbreviation for: Radar Approach Control (FAA).
To skim over the water at high speed rather than push through it.

term: This is a partial table to show the format. The full content can be formatted in the same way. Let me know if you need the entire table in a separate document! 😊
definition: A third-party service dedicating vehicles and drivers to a single customer.
Abbreviation for: Accelerated Shared Growth Initiative for South Africa.
A large destroyer suitable for commanding a flotilla of destroyers or other small warships; a type of flotilla leader.
The adjustment or manipulation of a data set to fit a model or curve, as in the use of the alpha factor in exponential smoothing.
A composite index of wholesale prices of a representative group of commodities.
The ability to identify the lot or batch numbers of consumption and/or composition for manufactured, purchased, and shipped items. This is a federal (U.S.) requirement.
Transverse members fitted to the bottom side rails of a container, which support the floor.

Visual systems on the plant floor and design areas and elsewhere that enable anyone familiar with the work to understand its status and condition at a glance, or to respond to work priorities. This can be done with standard layouts, signal lights, Kanban systems, or other methods. The distinguishing feature is that communication is rapidly executed by line of sight.
A designated area of the warehouse near the loading dock where product is placed or arranged for shipment.
The downstream flow of products through various outlets or ‘channels’ which may consist of distributors, retail stores, on-line fulfilment.
Abbreviation for: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union.

The element of the triple bottom line that assesses the performance of a business in relation to the people and the society with which it has contact; and/or environmental mission and a legal responsibility to respect the interests of workers, the community and the environment as well as shareholders.
The individual who provides customer support via telephone in a call centre environment.
Abbreviation for Automated Optical Inspection.

This type of clause covers merchandise if the damage amounts to three percent or more of the insured value of the package or cargo. If the vessel burns, sinks, or collides, all losses are fully covered. In marine insurance, the word average describes partial damage or partial loss.

A report of demand for a given machine, or machine centre, by production orders released to the floor, that normally compares load and capacity in terms of hours or units, and identifies the orders creating the demand.

A charter under which the ship owner is paid on a per-day basis for a specified period of time. Typically, the ship owner is responsible for providing the crew and paying vessel operating expenses while the charterer is responsible for paying the voyage expenses and additional voyage insurance.
A principle based on the assumption that an area will specialise in the production of goods for which it has the greatest advantage or least comparative disadvantage.
The most common way of selling is by adding a fixed percentage mark-up to the cost (cost-based pricing).
Abbreviation for: Omnidirectional Approach Lighting System.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain Risk Management.

A technique for moving or turning a ship by using a relatively light anchor known as a kedge. The kedge anchor may be dropped while in motion to create a pivot and thus perform a sharp turn. The kedge anchor may also be carried away from the ship in a smaller boat, dropped, and then weighed, pulling the ship forward.
Real-time link to a provider’s mainframe system.
Abbreviation for: Central American Common Market.

A systems approach to help monitor contract implementation. Particularly useful for contracts for large projects where different activities have to be carried out in a sequence within a time frame and where delay in the completion of one segment of a project is likely to delay the execution of the whole project.
A published transaction set approved by ANSI. The standards are reviewed every six months.
The ability to communicate what makes the company, product or service unique and to stand out from other companies, products or services within the marketplace.

Australian Product Number Barcode unique to a product: 13 digit barcode or number, containing country prefix number (2), company number (5), item number (5) and a check digit (1). Also called GTIN - Global Trade Item Number

term: Logistics Structure, Engineering and Making to Order (ETO)
definition: In this situation there is no stock at all. The purchase and order of materials takes place on the basis of the specific customer order and the entire project is carried out for this one specific client. As a result this type of production structure results in long lead times.
A shipment in which the freight does not completely fill the container; or a particular consignor’s freight when combined with others to produce a full container load.
Inventory that is moving from one link in the supply chain to another.
Abbreviation for: Simple Object Access Protocol.

Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats analysis - the organisation and analysis of factors that will impact organizational effectiveness; often used in formulating strategic and business plans.
A business which is majority owned or controlled by a recognized local or individual as defined by government.
Suppliers are invited to submit a detailed bid which meets the requirements as laid down in the request for quotation against the lowest possible price (identical to request for quotation).
Automated En-Route Air Traffic Control.

1. A type of open boat that is relatively narrow and pointed at both ends, enabling it to move either forwards or backwards equally well. 2. On modern warships, a relatively light and seaworthy boat for transport of ship’s crew. 3. A type of vessel designed as a lifeboat or “monomoy” used for recreational and competitive rowing in the San Francisco Bay area and coastal Massachusetts. 4. Informally, any whaler of any size. 5. Informally, any vessel engaged in whale watching.
The state of not having inventory at a location and available for distribution or sale.

The number of tons of 2,240 pounds that a vessel can transport of cargo, stores, and bunker fuel. It is the difference between the number of tons of water a vessel displaces “light” and the number of tons it displaces when submerged to the “load line.” An approximate conversion ratio is 1NT = 1.7GT and 1GT = 1.5DWT.
National Consumer Tribunal.
Abbreviation for: Principal Interexchange Carrier.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Radar Service.

A repository of data within the Global Data Synchronisation Network, where trading partners can obtain, maintain, and exchange information on items and parties in a standard format through electronic means.
A business strategy that aims at doing every operation using the least possible resource—people, space, stock, equipment, time, etc.
Sell through is the percentage of units sold versus the number of units that were available to be sold. Calculate by dividing the Number of Units Sold / Beginning Inventory x 100
Project management term for reducing time spent on critical path activities to shorten the project.

The function of EDI processing software that ensures that all transmissions contain the mandatory information demanded by the EDI standard. Compares information sent by an EDI user against EDI standards and reports exceptions. Does not ensure that documents are complete and fully accurate, but does reject transmissions with missing data elements or syntax errors.
Abbreviation for: Frequently Asked Questions.
A production operation or project task begun before its predecessor has been started.
Notice of Readiness (when the ship is ready to load).
The operation of drawing a vessel forward by means of long lines.

The “cut” of a sail refers to its shape. Since this would vary between ships, it could be used both to identify a familiar vessel at a distance, and to judge the possible sailing qualities of an unknown one. Also used figuratively of people.

Small flat lengths of braided cord attached by eyelets to a sail along the reef band, used to secure the excess fabric after reefing. Typically, a reef point consists of two lengths of cord which taper towards their ends—the narrow end of each is threaded through an eye in the wide end of the other and then the pair are rove through the eyelet in the reef band such that one length hangs before and the other abaft the sail.
A measure of how much production volume can be achieved over a set period of time.
Abbreviation for: Tentative Calculated Landing Time.
Abbreviation for: Finite Planning and Flight Plan.
National Research Foundation.
The extent to which a chosen course of action meets a previously established goal or standard.
Sailing as close as possible towards the wind (perhaps only about 60°) in a zig-zag course to attain an upwind direction to which it is impossible to sail directly. Also see: tacking.
A pallet designed so that the forks of a fork lift truck can be inserted from all four sides. See Fork lift.
An invoice provided by a supplier before shipment, informing the buyer of the kinds and quantities of goods, their value, and specifications (weight, size, etc.).
Assembly of two axles and suspension that is attached to the chassis in one place, and cannot be moved fore and aft.
Refers to the barcode sticker placed on a pallet of product.
A set of drawings showing various sail combinations recommended for use in various situations.
A valve in the hull of a boat.

Zone of meeting, tension, or overlapping between the objectives, responsibilities, and/or activities of two or more entities: actors of the Logistics Chain (inter-organisational interfaces) or sub-systems of the same organisation (intra-organisational interfaces).
A phrase used by Porter (1985) to describe the concept of multiple value chains across multiple companies to illustrate the flow of raw materials into end products.
The fourth mast, or the aft most mast where it is smallest on vessels of less than four masts.
Abbreviation for: Invitation to Bid. Sometimes referred to as Invitation for Bid (IFB).
Abbreviation for Air National Guard Base.
The factors such as delivery time, product or service specification, price, etc. that define customers’ requirements.
The combination of all technical and corresponding administrative actions intended to retain an item in, or restore it to, a state in which it can perform its required function.
An on-time shipment is classified as a shipment that is off the dock and in transit on schedule. An on-time delivery is one that reaches the recipient on schedule.

A model that conveys the idea that, as projects move forward, the cost of making changes to the original project plan increases, but the ability of project managers to influence the project goes down.
An open-air extension of the bridge to port or starboard, intended for use in signalling.
1. Zig-zagging so as to sail directly towards the wind (and for some rigs also away from it). 2. Going about.
Kilo or metric ton. 1,000 Kilos or 2,204.6 pounds.
To bring to the same level, rate or status, as in the synchronisation of linked production resources to the same timing and volume, or in distributing the same set of data to remote databases.
Space in the warehouse (in square feet or meters) that is actually used for storage. This does not include aisles, docks, offices, and staging areas.

Abbreviation for: Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (also known as Supplier Questionnaire). Usually issued to people and organizations wishing to express an interest in tendering for works, goods, or services, or to join an “Approved List.”
A large cockroach.
A slang term for an open-top trailer or container with a tarpaulin cover.
1. A storm from the south west. 2. A type of waterproof hat with a wide brim over the neck, worn in storms.
Abbreviation for: Bitmap Image, Best Management Practices, and Best Manufacturing Practices.
A method of categorising purchased materials and suppliers based on product type, using departments or functional area. Plans are used to evaluate suppliers in groups. Also see: Weighted-Point Plan.

Refers to the practice of using RFID, Smart Card, or other forms of Near Field Communications technology to gather data electronically without the need to actually make contact physically with the item.
A small sailing vessel with lugsails set on two or more masts and perhaps lug topsails, widely used as traditional fishing boats, particularly off the coasts of France, England, and Scotland.
Tendency for a propeller to push the stern sideways. In theory, a right-hand propeller in reverse will walk the stern to port.
Abbreviation for: High Altitude Route System.
When a bill of lading is accepted or signed by a shipper or shipper’s agent without protest, the shipper is said to acquiesce to the terms, giving a silent form of consent.
Contacting a supplier or carrier with the goal of speeding up the delivery date of an inbound shipment.
Abbreviations for: Port of Discharge & Port of Destination.
A series of boat races, usually of sailboats or rowboats, but occasionally of powered boats.
Abbreviation for: Building Owners and Managers Association of Canada (see also BESt).
Abbreviation for: General Services Administration.
The metal stovepipe chimney from a cook shack on the deck of a ship or from a stove in a galley.
A man-made pile of rocks and rubble, often surrounding an offshore lighthouse or as a base for an aid to navigation.
Purchased or manufactured items that failed usability tests and require additional labor or materials to avoid scrapping.
Abbreviation for: FAA Aeronautical Centre.
The fitness of a vessel for its intended use.

The functions and processes that review requirements and defined parameters to suggest new operating, material, and capacity plans and changes to existing plans, but are not used for the activities that carry out (execute) those plans.
Rock or coral, possibly only revealed at low tide, shallow enough that the vessel will at least touch if not go aground

The second of three stages in the Corridor Planning and Screening Process, during which multiple corridor options are evaluated against meeting the preliminary mobility and connectivity needs identified during the concept stage. The range of corridor options considered includes operational strategies to optimise efficiency for all modes, capacity improvements within existing facility rights of way, or new facilities of alignments. High level costs and potential financing or partnership opportunities are also considered during this stage. The products of Evaluation Stage include an Evaluation Report with a Corridor purpose and need; an Implementation Plan laying out DOT and partner commitments for addressing corridor issues and opportunities, including specific action items for moving forward; and guidance for incorporating one or more projects into appropriate state, regional, and local plans.
In a vessel, the compartment containing the steering gear.
The measure of a business’s efficiency to create a product of acceptable value with minimal cost to the consumer.

The amount earned from an investment or operation after expenses are deducted. Gross profit refers to pre-tax net sales less the cost of sales, while net profit also includes deductions for interest, taxes, depreciation, and other expenses.
A South African Government initiative designed to assist and incentivise organisations in the manufacturing and production sector.
Setting rate within a conference tariff that is different from the rate(s) for the same items established by other conference members.

The average of the last ‘x’ number of numerical values out of a set that contains a larger number of historical values. A six-month simple moving average forecast is the average of the demand from the previous six periods; with each new period the last period is added and the oldest period deleted before recalculating the new average.
If the foot of a sail is not secured properly, it is footloose, blowing around in the wind.

The marrying of two or more portions of one shipment that originate at different locations, moving under one bill of lading, from one shipper to one consignee. Authority for this service must be granted by tariff publication.
A tangible, non-monetary asset used in normal business operations that exists in and is depreciated over multiple fiscal periods.
Abbreviation for: Transportation Computer Assisted Design.
The policy with regards to the level and location of stock to be held and where and how this should be done.
Receipt for product received into the warehouse.
A mechanical method of increasing force, such as a tackle or lever.
The inventory that exists because material cannot be transported instantaneously.
See: Boatswain’s Call.
Wood placed in bottom of ship to keep cargo dry. Also see dunnage.
The practice of loading a smooth-bore cannon with two cannon-balls.
A traditional Royal Navy term for an ordinary sailor.
The total of material, labour, and overhead costs allocated to a single unit and used in inventory valuation, and margin and variance analysis.
A ship’s weapons.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Unit.
An inventory stock location used when the primary location is full.
High waterproof boots for use at sea. In leisure sailing, known as sailing wellies.
Planning that covers time periods ranging from weeks down to just a few hours out.
A reporting system that presents a view of orders or records based on individual dates, rather than accumulating them into a larger time frame. Useful for short-term detail planning and analysis
Abbreviation for: American Society for Testing and Materials.
A trailer which has a section of deck lowered to increase the cubic capacity of the trailer.
Software that speeds access, and simplifies data analysis, queries, etc. within a database management system. Often the basis of an executive information system.

When cargo is unloaded from a ship, a clerk checks the actual count of the goods (number of boxes, drums, bundles, pipes, etc.) versus the amount listed on the ship’s manifest. He will note shortages, overages, or damage. This is used to make claims if needed.
One of two major decision categories addressed by a strategy. Includes the policies, people, decision rules, and organisational structure choices made by a firm.
The measure of the delay between a request and its answer.
A lease agreement for a piece of transportation equipment that does not include the provision of fuel or crew for its operation. It is often found in the airline industry.
Abbreviation for: Sector Partnership Fund.
See: Community Impact Assessment

A project implementation technique in which an existing system is run in parallel with the new system, with the comparison of operations and results to verify that the new system will properly replace the functions of the old. Parallel conversions are often difficult due to the time, expense, and viability of operating two systems and problems in comparison and verification when functions have changed significantly. A parallel is often not necessary when the conference room pilot and issue identification and resolution phases are done well, and adequate resources are made available at cut over time.
A user based perception of how well a service or facility is operating.
Materials not produced by logistics.

A bill that totals the quantities for components used in all levels and does not represent the structure level by level. The requirements for a component used in more than level are added together and shown as one number.
An itemised list of goods shipped to a buyer, stating quantities, prices, shipping charges, etc.
To have the ship’s sails arranged so as to counteract each other. A ship in this condition or in the process of achieving this condition is lying to.
Sailing with wind coming across the vessel’s beam.
Abbreviation for: Center Traffic Management Advisor.

To separate discrete levels from the total of a given item, based on time, specific batch identifier, or some other factor. On-hand inventory is sometimes layered to isolate the specific timing of the costs that created the total.
Abbreviation for: Software as a Service.
Abbreviation for: Application Integration Middleware and Airman’s Information Manual.
The European directives apply to all governmental institutions, including the State, regional or local authorities, and bodies governed by public law.
Abbreviation for: Project Funding for Emerging Exporters.

In cost reimbursement contracts, an agreed-upon amount beyond the initial cost estimate, usually reflecting a variety of factors, including risk and services. The fee may initially be fixed (Cost-plus-fixed-fee arrangement) or it may vary (cost-plus-incentive-fee or cost-plus-award-fee arrangement).
Abbreviation for: Flight Inspection National Field Office.
Syn.: Vendor scheduling.

A pick slip that combines requirements for production components based on a set of multiple orders, date range, production facility, destination, or other method. Material issued to a consolidated pick slip is sometimes moved to production using a transfer to a new stock location, and is not considered issued to work in process at that point.
Abbreviation for: Total Production System (Japan).
A term (usually pejorative) used in medium-term capacity management to indicate varying the size of the workforce through employment policy.
The process of transferring products or services to customers.

A deck that has slight positive curvature when viewed in cross-section. The purpose of this curvature is usually to shed water, but in warships it also functions to make the deck more resistant to shells.

A chain or rope used for hoisting or lowering a yard. A tye runs from the horizontal centre of a given yard to a corresponding mast and from there down to a tackle. Sometimes specifically called a chain tye or a rope tye.
Operating a truck without cargo.

A rule that supersedes an originally calculated lot size.
