An attachment to the front end of a forklift that is used to handle product on a slip sheet.

The quality life cycle costs identified with conformance and customer satisfaction, usually categorised as prevention (training and predictive process controls), appraisal (inspection and testing), internal failure (rework, scrap, downtime), and external failure (customer returns processing, warranty charges, replacements
Abbreviation for: Fixed Order Quantity.
Delivery of a good directly from the consignor to the consignee’s specified location.
An order quantity which, in principle, must not be exceeded.

When a sailing vessel loses control of its motion and is forced into a sudden sharp turn, often heeling heavily and in smaller vessels sometimes leading to capsize. The change in direction is called broaching-to. It occurs when too much sail is set for a strong gust of wind, or in circumstances where the sails are unstable
A system that uses automatic machines and controls to locate, transport, store, and retrieve materials as directed by order requirements.
A group of points to which rates are made the same as or in relation to rates to other points in the group.
Service to key origin-destination markets and population centres.

term: Packet, Packet Boat, or Packet Ship
definition:
1. Originally, a vessel employed to carry post office mail packets to and from British embassies, colonies, and outposts. 
2. Later, any regularly scheduled ship, carrying passengers, as in packet trade.
Traditional Royal Navy nickname for the Royal Marines.
A timekeeper accurate enough to be used to determine longitude by means of celestial navigation.
Abbreviation for: Minimum Obstruction Clearance Altitude.
Situation in which a company within a certain category with clear intent buys from just one supplier.
Distance of one minute of longitude at the equator, approximately 6,076.115. The metric equivalent is 1852.
Also able-bodied seaman. A merchant seaman qualified to perform all routine duties.

The person designated by a company for ensuring that a ship security assessment is carried out, and that a ship security plan is developed, submitted for approval, and thereafter implemented and maintained for liaison with port facility security officers, and the ship security officer.
A surprisingly large wave for a given sea state; formally, a wave whose height is more than twice the significant wave height (i.e., the mean of the largest third of waves in a wave record).
Abbreviation for: Error Correction Code.
The portion of the production capability that is currently in use, or is scheduled for use.
Abbreviation for: Compass Locator at Outer Marker.
A fixed-price contract with a provision for rewarding the supplier for faster delivery or superior performance.
A large sail flown in front of the vessel while heading downwind.

Defined as the percentage reduction in rejects within a five-year period. Example: if yield improves from 95% to 98%, that means rejects have been reduced by 60% -- from 5% to 2%. Therefore, yield improvement equals 60%.
Abbreviation for: Airport Capital Improvement Plan.
A warehouse order picking scheme in which all zones are picked at the same time as required to fill multiple item requirements for a given order or destination.

1.A method of managing inventory through the use of levels set against overall inventory or class value. 2.Establishing the overall levels of inventory desired, and implementing controls to ensure that individual replenishment decisions achieve this goal.

A production plan that varies the level of inventory in order to maintain an even production level for a given period. Level production plans may be a result of facility restraints, or to accommodate seasonal demand.

This strategy aims at marketing products which are perceived by the customer as being unique. Product individuality can be in the design (Swatch watches), the logo (Lacoste), the technology (Apple), service (American Express), and many other dimensions.
A system message usually created during MRP calculations to call attention to a current or potential problem and suggest corrective action.
Abbreviation for: Modified Final Judgment.
Stocking inventory in a production facility or logistics network near the consuming point, rather than in a central location and moving when required.
A contract that establishes a single vendor or multiple vendors as the source for a broad range of goods and/or services associated with a given commodity and sector.
Refrigerated trailer with insulated walls and a self-powered refrigeration unit. Most commonly used for transporting food.

The largest size vessel that can traverse the Panama Canal. Current maximum dimensions are: Length: 294.1 meters (965 feet) Width: 32.3 meters (106 feet) Draft: 12.0 meters (39.5 feet) in tropical fresh water Height: 57.91 meters (190 feet) above the water.
Abbreviation for: On The Job Training.
Abbreviation for Return on Net Assets.

A publication, such as Uniform Freight Classification (railroad), or the National Motor Freight Classification (motor carrier), that assigns ratings to various articles, and provides bill of lading descriptions and rules.
A cargo on which the transportation charge is assessed on the basis of weight.

An inventory investment and activity measure that compares inventory usage (as defined by the annual cost of goods sold) divided by the inventory investment (as defined as the average inventory level at standard cost). Higher values indicate a more efficient use of inventory; absolute targets can only be set based on relevant industry figures, as the turnover for grocery chains is vastly different than for capital goods manufacturers.
Non-Directional Radio Homing Beacon.
Abbreviation for: Defence Visual Flight Rules and Day Visual Flight Rules.

A paper or electronic document that requests delivery of materials or services and is normally initiated by the using department. It usually includes requested dates and quantities, but may leave the determination of pricing and vendor sourcing to a purchasing agent. MRP generations often treat accepted requisitions as a scheduled receipt in the same manner as a purchase order
Upper edge of the hull.
Combination of a tractor and two semi-trailers connected in tandem by a converter dolly.

Highway Performance Monitoring System. The system used by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) to provide information on the condition of the nation’s highway system, its use, performance and needs.
A code that classifies scrap, inventory write-offs, order changes, or other transactions for analysis and corrective action.

In contract management, the final stage of a project is the close out, involving all the administrative, legal and financial processes needed to bring the contract to an end. These processes include ensuring that the contractor has fulfilled their obligations, that all financial liabilities have been resolved, that the performance of the contractor has been recorded, that any outstanding claims have been identified, and that the rights and obligations of the parties in respect of ongoing liabilities such as latent defects have been recorded and executed as per the terms of the contract.

Represents a complete record of the transaction between exporter and importer with regard to the goods sold. Also reports the content of the shipment, and serves as the basis for all other documents relating to the shipment.
Abbreviation for: Doppler Very High Frequency Omni-Directional Range.
Another term for functional layout.

Coupling device used in double trailer, triple trailer, and truck-trailer combinations. It has a curved, fixed towing horn and an upper latch that opens to accept the drawbar eye of a trailer or dolly.
Abbreviation for: Central European Free Trade Agreement.

1.A structure constructed on a coast as part of a coastal defence system or to protect an anchorage from the effects of weather and longshore drift. 2.A structure built on the forecastle of a ship intended to divert water away from the forward superstructure or gun mounts.
Federal Emergency Management Agency (USA).
A unit of bearing equal to one thirty-second of a circle, i.e., 11.25°. A turn of 32 points is a complete turn through 360°.
Abbreviation for: Army Radar Approach Control (AAF) and Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee.
A comprehensive plan to guide the long-term physical development of a particular transportation facility.
White light displayed by a ship at anchor. Two such lights are displayed by a ship over 150 feet (46 m) in length

A charter of a vessel under which the ship owner is usually paid a fixed amount of charter hire for a certain period of time during which the charterer is responsible for the vessel operating expenses and voyage expenses of the vessel, and for the management of the vessel, including crewing. A bareboat charter is also known as a “demise charter” or a “time charter by demise.”
Sales revenue minus cost of goods sold. Syn.: gross profit.
Abbreviation for: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise.
People in a vehicle making use of a mode.
The actual time recorded by a machine when used for production, and used in efficiency and utilisation calculations.
Abbreviation for: Operating System.
Networked organisational structures where clusters of resources have delegated responsibility for the strategy management of those resources.

Bid rigging occurs when suppliers communicate with each other before lodging their bids and agree amongst themselves who will be the successful bidder and at what price. This practice is one type of collusive tendering and may be discouraged by introducing new bidders and, regularly benchmarking offers against industry standards.

An Internet site or sites that conduct sourcing, pricing, delivery, and other operations on a business-to-business (B2B) basis. Exchanges are often classifies as private, which link two or more specific companies and do not communicate with a larger group, or public, which provide for a sourcing and bid process for any company that has joined the exchange.
These buyers are responsible for buying and non-product-related goods and services.
Any refuse or rubbish which is discarded into a refuse container or dustbin which is known as “gash fanny” (South African Navy).
An instrument used in navigation to measure water depth; the line attached to a lead. Also referred to as: sounding line.

Notations made when the cargo is received at the carrier’s terminal or loaded aboard a vessel. They show any irregularities in packaging or actual or suspected damage to the cargo. Exceptions are then noted on the bill of lading.
The ability to trace items through their lot number. This is helpful when a specific product is needed or information about a specific product is required.
A cross-functional group that reviews production or purchased items on hold due to usability concerns and determines their disposition, which may include rework, scrap, or returning to the vendor.
See: High-Occupancy Vehicle.
Are tools used by the buyer to invite suppliers to bid simultaneously based on a predetermined purchasing specification using web technology.

The engineering crew of the vessel, i.e., crew members who work in the vessel‘s engine room, fire room, and boiler room, so called because they would be covered in coal dust during the days of coal-fired steamships.
See: Acquisition Categories.
A document issued by the U.S. Government; authorises the export of commodities for which written authorisation is required by law.
To reenlist. When a sailor extends his or her service another term.
A term used in Railway transportation where the delivery of the consignment can be taken only on production of the Railways Receipt.
A large carton that is used to hold and protect smaller cartons or packages of product. Using a master carton reduces handling as one larger piece instead of multiple small pieces.
Abbreviation for: Middle Frequency.

The unit used to purchase an item. This may or may not be the same unit of measure used in the internal systems. For example, steel may be purchased by the ton, but it may be issued and used in square inches.
A container constructed to carry grain, powder, and other free–flowing solids in bulk. Used in conjunction with a tilt chassis or platform.
Abbreviation for: International Standard for Social Accountability.
Abbreviation for: Officer of the Watch.
On the beam, a relative bearing at right angles to the centreline of the ship’s keel.
Abbreviation for: Science and Technology Directorate.
Abbreviation for: Command Communications Service Designator.
Effectiveness measurement is the extent to which the output of a process or sub-process meets the needs and expectations of its customers. Quality is often thought of as a synonym for effectiveness.
The outsourcing process is structured around three phases: strategic, transition, and operation.

Abbreviation for: World Class Manufacturing. World class manufacturing is the philosophy of being the best, the fastest, and the lowest cost producer of a product or service. It implies the constant improvement of products, processes, and services to remain an industry leader and provide the best choice for customers, regardless of where they are in the process.
A supplier who has a dominant position in a market, restricting client organisation choice.
To be placed in reserve or mothballed. The latter usage is used in modern times and can refer to a specific set of procedures used by the US Navy to preserve ships in good condition.
A philosophical concept of government, the public, resource users and businesses all taking responsibility and working together to care for natural resources.
A situation in which demand patterns for a product run in cycles, driven by seasonality or other predictable factors.

Branded shipping documentation which can include customer logo printed on packing slip, logo watermark, inclusion of recurring message about customer’s business, and personal message for specific end user recipients.
Abbreviation for: Airspace and Traffic Advisory Service.
Refers to: En Route Broadband Secondary Radar.
Abbreviation for: Finding of No Significant Impact.

Portion of the bid price represented by the cost of components, parts or materials which have been or are still to be imported (whether by the supplier or its subcontractors) and which costs are inclusive of the costs abroad (this includes labour or intellectual property costs), plus freight and other direct importation costs, such as landing costs, dock duties, import duty, sales duty or other similar tax or duty at the port of entry.

1. When a vessel is not attached to the shore or seabed. 2. Any gear not fastened down or put away properly. 3. Any person or thing that is misplaced or missing. When applied to a member of the navy or marine corps, such a person is “absent without leave” (AWOL) or, in United States Navy and United States Marine Corps terminology, is guilty of an “unexcused absence” (UA).
To utilise a third-party provider to provide services previously performed in-house.
A hybrid structure represents a combination of the centralised and the decentralised structure. The terms ‘hybrid’, ‘pooling’ and ‘co-ordination’ are used interchangeably.
Abbreviation for: DITCO Automated Bulletin Board System.
The process of converting sourced inputs into a product or service that customers value.
Abbreviation for: Federal Telecommunications System 2000.
1. To gain access to a vessel. 2. The side of a vessel. 3. The distance a sailing vessel runs between tacks when working to windward.
Activities required to offer the company’s value proposition to its customers, including inbound logistics, operations, outbound logistics, marketing and sales, and customer service.
Two horizontal struts at the upper ends of the topmasts of sailboats, used to anchor the shrouds from the topgallant mast.
Abbreviation for: International Technical Union.

Here the buyer actively solicits ideas for improvement from suppliers. These ideas may relate to new product design, current product designs, operational processes, quality assurance, logistics activities, inventory and distribution activities and transactional processes.
Syn.: lot-for-lot.

An electrical device designed to recognize and decipher barcode labels. When the scanner passes over the barcode, it converts the barcode into electrical signals representing data. The Portable Tele-transaction Computer can then enter this data into files in its memory.
See: Boatswain.
Permission given to a carrier or consignee to return a product.

Abbreviation for: General Department Store Merchandise. A classification of commodities that includes goods generally shipped by mass–merchandise companies. This commodity structure occurs only in service contracts.
Abbreviation for: Spatial Development Initiatives.
A means of transportation.
An outsourced provider that manages all, or a significant part, of an organisation’s logistics requirements and performs transportation, locating, and sometimes product consolidation activities.
Off or outside a vessel. If something or someone falls or is thrown into the water, it is said to have gone overboard.

When documents presented do not conform to the requirements of the letter of credit (L/C), it is referred to as a “discrepancy.” Banks will not process L/Cs which have discrepancies. They will refer the situation back to the buyer and/or seller and await further instructions.

The international carrier is obligated to make declarations of the ship’s crew and contents at both the port of departure and arrival. The vessel manifest lists various details about each shipment by B/L number. Obviously, the B/L serves as the core source from which the manifest is created.

A box, carton, or other container with specified dimensions that will be used on an ongoing (reusable) basis to facilitate item counts, the design of storage and transportation resources, and to limit handling damage.

1. The costs incurred to support and ensuring continued availability of an asset, such as scheduled and unscheduled repairs and support staff. 2. In software agreements, the annual fees paid to the vendor that allows ongoing use of the system.

A level of quality which indicates that a process is well controlled (i.e., tolerance limits are ±6 sigma from the centre line in a control chart). The term is usually associated with Motorola, which named one of its key operational initiatives Six Sigma Quality.

An approach to improving operations performance that implies major dramatic change in the way an operation works; for example, business process re-engineering (BPR) is often associated with this type of improvement, also known as innovation-based improvement, contrasted with continuous improvement
An e-auction which is used by buyers to enforce competitive bidding among a limited number of prequalified suppliers based on a starting price that is lowered during the auction.

Guidance systems are used to guide automated guided vehicles through plants, and guide lift trucks in very-narrow-aisle storage areas. Wire-guided and Rail-guided tend to be the most common guidance systems, but others including laser, optical systems, and magnetic tape are also available. See also Wire-guided, Rail-guided, Laser-guided, and Optical-guided.
The degree of novelty required of an operation’s resources during the implementation of a new technology or process.
The actual or standard pay rate for a labour hour.

A category workbench is a onepoint reference for all category related enquiries and information. It provides the visibility, decision support and strategic planning hub around which procurement processes like sourcing, purchasing, contract management and supplier management can work most efficiently.

Software functionality that allows a product to be defined by selecting various pre-defined options, rather than having every possible combination of options pre-defined as specific SKUs. Placing an order for a computer and specifying hard drive, processor, memory, graphics card, sound card, etc. would be an example of configuration processing.

The situation of a particular product, at a particular item, with regards to the relationship between the expected demand and/or requirement, the physical stock and the outstanding procurement orders.
The size beyond which cars or loads cannot use bridges, tunnels, etc.

Service processes devoted to producing knowledge-based or advice-based services, usually involving high customer contact and high customization. Examples include management consultants, lawyers, architects, etc.
Abbreviation for: United Nations Statistics Division.
An established reason for the existence of an outcome.
Abbreviation for: Delivered at Frontier (Incoterms).
Charts, diagrams, and graphical displays used to define a problem and identify and categorize alternative solutions.
Time planned for production operations that did not occur due to unscheduled problems such as machine downtime, material or personnel availability, or other situations.
Features in order entry systems that compare line item prices to standard costs and flag instances that violate a predefined margin percentage.
Abbreviation for: Presumed-to-Conform.
A point located en route between two other points.
Includes suppliers that meet the buyer’s prequalification criteria and will be requested to submit a detailed bid.
A term used to indicate medium-term capacity planning that aggregates different products and services together in order to get a broad view of demand and capacity

Components are manufactured goods which will not undergo additional physical changes, but which will be incorporated into a system with which there is a functional relationship by joining it with other components.
The electrical load for all non-propulsion systems on a ship.

Ability to track a product from the development stage to its end of life. Traceability includes: • Tracking: real-time location of the entity in the Logistics Chain; • Tracing: possibility of obtaining information in non-real time from data recorded about the flow (flow memory).
Bid Adjudication Committee - An independent committee that meets to evaluate and adjudicate on bids.
Damage to product that occurred while in the warehouse (i.e. water leak, dropped product, etc.).
A hull construction design in which a vessel has an inner and outer side and bottom separated by void space.

A sub-process within procurement that assists in amongst other things, maximising the long term value (for business, industry, and society) of every cent spent to source a tangible or intangible product.

Software and systems that support sales staff lead generation, contact, scheduling, performance tracking, and other functions. SFA functions are normally integrated with base systems that provide order, product, inventory status, and other information and may be included as part of a larger customer relationship management (CRM) system.
Software the converts or “translates” business application data into EDI standard formats, and vice versa.
Measuring the accuracy in a ship’s magnetic compass so its readings can be adjusted – often by turning the ship and taking bearings on reference points.
Rules used to determine the order in which jobs should be processed when resources are limited and multiple jobs are waiting to be done.

RFID is an automatic identification method, relying on storing and remotely retrieving data using RFID tags or transponders. RFID tags can be attached to or incorporated into products, animals, or persons for identification using radio waves. Chip-based RFID tags contain silicon chips and antennas. Passive tags require no internal power source, whereas active tags require a power source.
A motor carrier industry association that is made up of sub-conferences representing various sectors of the motor carrier industry.
United States Navy slang for a manoeuvre in which a submerged Soviet or Russian submarine suddenly turns 180 degrees or through 360 degrees to detect submarines following it.
Design and set-up of warehouse storage.

A product architecture in which each functional element maps into its own physical chunk. Different chunks perform different functions; the interactions between the chunks are minimal, and they are generally well defined.

A warehouse area where a company maintains battery chargers and extra batteries to support a fleet of electrically powered materials handling equipment. The company must maintain this area in accordance with government safety regulations.
A technique of network analysis.
Pieces of timber that make up a large transverse frame.

The systematic and coordinated set of activities required to provide the physical movement and storage of goods (raw materials, parts, finished goods) from vendor/ supply services, through company facilities, to the customer (market) and the associated activities (e.g. packaging, order processing, etc.) — in a manner which will enable the organisation to contribute to the explicit goals of the company.

To reduce the area and efficiency of a sail by expedient means (slacking the peak and tricing up the tack) without properly reefing, thus slowing boat speed. Also used in the past as a sign of mourning.
(1) The stern of a ship where it curves upward and inward. (2) A voyage.
Refers to: Facsimile Equipment.
The process of listing bidders and prices. In a term contract, with many line items and options in the basis of award, abstracting can be a lengthy and involved process
The requirement for a particular product or component arising from a number of sources, internal or external.
The negative difference between actual available or delivered quantity and the required quantity.
The offer received from a vendor in response to a solicitation. A response includes submissions commonly referred to as "offers," "bids," "quotes," or "proposals."
A thin temporary patch.
A channel where the water rises and falls to allow boats to travel a dammed river.

The later occurring of the date of commencement of statement 100 and the date upon which the earliest of all still operative transaction undertaken by the measured entity measured entities in order to achieve black rights of ownership, become effective and unconditional.
The stage of the team development process of establishing team rules and procedures; helps the team find its own uniquely collaborative rhythm.
Debris or cargo that remains afloat after a shipwreck. Also see: jetsam.
Purchasing cost reductions are sustainable in character. These may result from a change of the specification, a change of supplier, or omitting an unnecessary product quality requirement.
Abbreviation for: Air Traffic Navigation Systems.
To climb steadily upwards, from the motion of a sailor climbing shrouds on a sailing ship (originally “hand over hand”).
A way to recognise a shipment or particular item.

All procured materials and services that no not become part of the company’s value proposition may be classified in MRO supplies, investment goods (also referred to as capital expenditure, or CAPEX) and services (identical to non-BOM-materials or non-production materials).
Abbreviation for: Bilateral Investment Treaty.
Abbreviation for: Citizen’s Advisory Committee. Advisory committee utilised by most metropolitan planning organisations (MPOs) for citizen input into the transportation planning process.
The award of a bid to a bidder in response to his/her bid or price quotation.
Control/management of available labour pool, involving time and attendance and scheduling of employees.
All stakeholders belonging to the same value chain are challenged to improve the (buying) company’s value proposition to its final end customers i.e. consumers.
Abbreviation for: Telecommunications Service Priority.
Abbreviation for: Customer Integrated Decision Making.

A material demand pattern where periods of demand are separated by periods with little or no demand. Similar to a cyclical demand pattern, but without any expected cyclical pattern. Syn.: lumpy demand.

A process in which order pickers selecting full cases from pallet rack locations perform an immediate cycle count at the completion of the pick for that location, using a Radio Frequency or voice terminal. The use of the count-back program is just one component of being able to prove perfect order picking and the highest degree of inventory accuracy.
A person who guides a vessel over dangerous sandbars.
To incline from the perpendicular; something so inclined is raked or raking, e.g., a raked or raking stem, stern, mast, funnel, etc.

A list of critical items that have been identified as high risk areas, which should rank order the identified risk by likelihood and priority. The items Glossary | Waiver Of Bids contained on the list should be those identified in risk assessment as having the greatest unacceptable impact on the program and/or contract, and the risk reduction tactics that have been identified and will be put into action in the event the risk materializes.
Abbreviation for: Operations Committee.
An agreement where a contracting party accepts a new party in place of the prior party (relieving the prior party of any further obligations).
The payment of a portion of a total invoice or estimated cost based on the accomplishment of milestones, cost recovery agreements, or other contractual methods.
Radio Frequency scanning and transmission of data.
A legal entity, operates a business which includes indentifying opportunities in the market, taking risks with a view of being rewarded with profits.
Abbreviation for: Federal Trade Commission (USA).
A legal claim upon goods for the satisfaction of some debt or duty.
Often used synonymously with RFP, but may involve a final price quotation request for a precise set of requirements.
The Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment codes of good practice including all the statements issued under section 9 of the Act.
Theory that business decision-making should focus on managing internal resources to establish competitive advantages.
Abbreviation for: Best in Class.
Determining the correct transportation charges due to the carrier. Auditing involves checking the accuracy of the freight bill for errors, correct rate, and weight.

The strategic process of determining the long-term, future costs and benefits of alternative courses of action, which may include a new investment, an additional financial investment in an existing resource, or the abandonment of an existing system or resource.
Non-Aligned Movement.
Definition
Cost of goods sold (COGS) for a given sales period, or used in place of COGS in service industries.

A contract clause which may be contained within boilerplate language that allows either contracting party the right to cancel a contract, either in whole or in part, due to failure of the other party to perform satisfactorily.
Abbreviation for: Aircraft Situation Display.

The means by which the Department of Transportation responds to and implements the solutions that have been arrived at during community impact assessment. Considerations include the safety of transportation system users, efficient use of energy, protection of the natural and manmade environment, relationships between land use and transportation planning, and local and state economic development goals.
A three digit numerical representation that identifies a transaction set.
In the context of forecasting; unpredictable movement from one time period to the next.
A generalized model of customer and competitor behavior through the life of a product or service, consisting of four stages: introduction, growth, maturity, and decline.
Place where cargo is loaded and leaves a country.
When the trough of a wave is amidships, causing the hull to deflect so the ends of the keel are higher than the middle. The opposite of hogging.
Abbreviation for: Municipal Finance Management Act, Act No 56 of 2003.
A vessel ranging in size from a small boat to a large ship tasked to carry military dispatches from ship to ship, from ship to shore, or, occasionally, from shore to shore.
An assigned area in which containers are prepared for loading into a vessel, train, truck, or airplane or are stacked immediately after discharge from the vessel, train, truck, or airplane.
Stacking lift truck with outriggers where the load can be repositioned by moving the mast or fork arm carriage.
The process of making a choice between producing a product oneself or buying it.
Refers to a truck or trailer on which there is a single rear axle.

A snub-nosed boat with push knees used for pushing barges. A small towboat (called a push boat) may push one or two barges around the harbour. A large towboat used to push from 5 to 40 barges in a tow is called a line boat. Also see: Tug boat.
The minimum standard required from Verification Agencies in order for them to be accredited and gazetted by the minister in terms of section 14 of Act.

Used when cost and resource baselines are well-documented, cost and pricing risk are minimal, and both DoD and contractor can define price, incentives, and performance outcomes with a high degree of confidence.
The commercial trade processing system developed by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to facilitate legitimate trade while strengthening border security.

Term used to describe vehicles that use a wire embedded in the floor to guide the vehicles. Wire guidance systems are frequently used with order selectors and turret trucks in very narrow aisle applications. They are also used with automated guided vehicles.

A warehouse vehicle, also called a lift truck, which is used for lifting and transporting pallets of product. A forklift may have a special attachment on the front for specialised handling of product.
Clear plastic film that is wrapped around a pallet of product to secure it.

Shipment of goods on shipper’s own account. A bill of adventure is a document signed by the master of the ship that carries goods at owner’s risk. Also, a term used in some insurance policies to mean a voyage or a shipment.
Abbreviation for: Operational Acceptable Level of Traffic.

The person designated as responsible for the development, implementation, revision, and maintenance of the port facility security plan, and for liaison with the ship security officers and company security officers.
Abbreviation for: Tracking Signal.
Monitoring and recording shipment movements from origin to destination.

The defined accumulation of an organisation’s internal set of best practices, past issues or problems and their resolution, product and process data, and other any other information that can be used as a basis for analysis and training. It is organised into meaningful categories and provides access methods to query and report the elements of the knowledge base.
A measure of the operational capability added by a system as a function of its Life Cycle Cost (LC;-C).

1. Shipboard lifeboat, kept on board a vessel and used to take crew and passengers to safety in the event of the ship being abandoned. 2. Rescue lifeboat, usually launched from shore, used to rescue people from the water or from vessels in difficulty.
A percentage or fixed-dollar amount allocating overhead expenses to production.
This compares the accuracy of your inventory by taking a headcount of items in stock and comparing it to what’s recorded in your database.
A port where cargo is received by the ocean carrier and transferred into containers, but then moved to another coastal port to be waded on a vessel.

The inventory level set to trigger reorder of a specific item. Reorder point is generally calculated as the expected usage (demand) during the lead time plus safety stock. Fixed reorder point implies the reorder point is a static number plugged into the system. Dynamic reorder point implies there is some system logic calculating the order point. Generally this would be comparing current inventory to the forecasted demand during the lead time plus safety stock. Syn.: Order point.
Describes the functionality which the product must have for the user.
Abbreviation for: Public Switched Telephone Network.

A facility, function, department, etc. that impedes; (a) production (e.g. a machine or work centre where jobs arrive at a faster rate than they can be completed), and (b) performance (e.g. a warehouse or distribution centre where goods arrive at a faster rate than they can be transported or stored, thus causing stock-piling at improper moments, or in unwanted areas).
The centreline plank of a laid deck. Its sides are often recessed, or nibbed, to take the ends of their parallel curved deck planks.
A class of quantitative forecasting models in which the forecast is modeled as a function of something other than time.
A structure built on the shore of a harbour extending into deep water so that vessels may lie alongside it.

A cycle counting procedure that establishes a given set of parts that will be counted each time a cycle count is performed, usually daily, until each item attains 100% accuracy. Done to uncover procedural and system problems that lead to inventory errors for that family or type of part.
Abbreviation for: Quad Flat Package.
A term used to refer to the timely, error-free provision of a product or service in good condition.
The offer of goods for transportation or the offer to place cars or containers for loading or unloading.
Abbreviation for: Voice Switching and Control System.
A situation in which the equipment operation stays with the trailer or boxcar while being loaded or unloaded.
A measure of the error in a forecast, which does not have a precise meaning, but is useful for other analyses.

1. A smooth curve, usually referring to a line of the hull which has no deviations. 2. To make something flush. 3. A line is fair when it has a clear run. 4. A wind or current is fair when it offers an advantage to a boat.
A measure which is of strategic importance to a company or department.
The third mast, or mast aft of the mainmast, on a ship.
Quantity of freight (in tons) required to fill a railcar; amount normally required to qualify for a carload rate.
The positioning of an operation in a queue or list based on its status relative to meeting a due date, and its effect on later operations.
Please see Chief Procurement Officer.
The combination of shipments from multiple vendors in close geographic proximity into one shipment received by the customer, normally done for a defined route on a recurring basis.
The U.S. federal body charged with enforcing acts of the U.S. Congress that affect common carriers in interstate commerce. STB replaced the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) in 1997.

Defined as the percentage reduction in rejects within a five-year period. Example: if yield improves from 95% to 98%, that means rejects have been reduced by 60% --from 5% to 2%. Therefore, yield improvement equals 60%.

Systems or functions that exhibit the highest level of performance in their class. Trade-offs occur in multiple-function systems when the costs of integrating several systems offset the benefits of having the best system in each individual area.

The United Nations Standard Products and Services Code [UNSPSC] is a coding system for goods and services. It enables buyers and sellers to describe goods and services in a common way without referring to any suppliers’ in-house catalogue codes and descriptions. The UNSPSC framework adopts a four or five level classification, using the labels Segment, Family, Class, Commodity and Business Function (optional).
Abbreviation for: Country of Origin and Chief Operating Officer.
Abbreviation for: Environmental Metrology Laboratory.
Abbreviation for: Metric Ton.
Abbreviation for: Ocean Shipping Reform Act (USA).
Abbreviation for: Simplified Short Approach Lighting System With Sequenced Flashing Lights.

An MRP process which uses a “phantom bill of material,” and permits MRP logic to drive requirements straight through the phantom item to its components.The MRP system usually retains its ability to net against any occasional inventories of the item. See Phantom Bill of Material. Abbreviation for: Bales
The loss of space caused by irregularity in the shape of packages. Any void or empty space in a vessel or container not occupied by cargo

The number of individual products produced or sold by an organisation. The mix is defined by the industry and manufacturing environment, and management strategies that position the company as a specialty, niche, or broad-based supplier of goods and services. Instances where the product mix varies widely from period to period often requires more investment in facilities and inventory, and may result in lower levels of customer service
The International Standards Organisation set of specifications for environmental management systems.

The United States Navy term for a smaller, lightly armed warship built in large numbers during World War II (and in smaller numbers thereafter), cheaper, slower, and less-well-armed than a destroyer, but larger and more heavily armed than a corvette and designed to escort convoys of merchant ships or naval auxiliaries or second-line naval forces. Employed primarily for anti-submarine warfare, but also provided some protection against aircraft and smaller surface ships. Generally known as “frigates” in other navies, and designated as such in the U.S. Navy by the 1970s.
Assumption of the operation of a customer’s warehouse facility. Can include purchase of the facility or taking over the lease. Can include assumption and management of the customer’s associates.
Abbreviation for: Failure Mode Effects and Criticality Analysis.
Cost of loading and unloading a vessel is borne by the charterer/shipper.

The lead time an operation or process takes to process an input and return the output to the original source, such as documents submitted to a department that returns them after entry or approval, or dry cleaning.
Abbreviation for: Short Approach Lighting System.
Abbreviation for: Aircraft Certification Field Office.
Abbreviation for: Business Performance Measurement and Business Process Management.
A structure where procurement related activities are grouped or consolidated at corporate level.

The classic use of the term bulk (bulk materials, bulk inventory, bulk storage) in inventory management and distribution refers to raw materials such as coal, iron ore, grains, etc. that are stored or transported in large quantities. This would include rail cars, tanker trucks, or silos full of a single material. However, this term can also have a variety of other definitions based upon the specific industry or facility. For example, a small-parts picking operation may refer to a case storage area as “bulk,” while a case- picking operation may refer to the full-pallet area as the “bulk area.”
A generic term for bids, quotations and proposals, received from a Supplier in response to Solicitation Documents.
Abbreviation for: Secure Trade Partnership (Singapore) and Seda Technology Programme.
Federal (U.S.) law that governs the definitions of management and labour and that establishes wage payment, hours worked, and other employment practices.
Abbreviation for: Delivery in Full.
A train of a specified number of rail cars, perhaps 100, which remain as a unit for a designated destination, or until a change in routing is made.

The separation of invoices, orders, inventory, and production lots into time buckets based on due dates, receipt dates, expiration dates, or other factors.. Used to focus attention on past due and most urgent items

A term in economics, where demand for one good or service occurs as a result of demand for another. This may occur as the former is a part of production of the second. For example, demand for coal leads to derived demand for mining, as coal must be mined for coal to be consumed.
A checklist used to develop new work-study methods intended to eliminate, combine, simplify, or reorder job elements to improve efficiency.
Certificate issued by consular officials of some importing countries at the point or place of export when the subject goods are exported under bond.
A load consisting of items or packages held together by one or more means and shaped or fitted for handling, transporting, stacking, and storing as a unit.
The decisions that concern the operations systems, methods, and procedures, and shape its overall culture.
The process of making something as good, or as effective as possible, with given resources and constraints.
A product shipped by aircraft, railroad car, ship, barge, or truck.

A computer term used to define a string of 7 or 8 bits, or binary digits. The length of the string determines the amount of data that can be represented. The 8-bit byte can represent numerous special characters, 26 upper case and lower case alphabetic characters, and 10 numeric digits, totaling 256 possible combinations.
The latest date a project task or activity can be completed without delaying the entire project.

A form of intergovernmental cooperative purchasing in which two or more public procurement agencies agree on specifications and contract terms and conditions for a given item of common usage and combine their requirements for these items in a single request for competitive sealed bids. Once bids have been received and discussed by the participants, each public procurement agency issues and administers its own purchase order or contract.

The documentation for a new or proposed system that states design strategy, provided functionality, source of inputs and audience or target user base, and may state performance or other targets. An overall translation of project or system requirements into a defined specification that supports those requirements

A method of inventory bookkeeping where the book (computer) inventory of components is automatically reduced by the computer after completion of activity on the component’s upper-level parent item, based on what should have been used as specified on the bill of material and allocation records. This approach has the disadvantage of a built-in differential between the book record and what is physically in stock. Syn.: Explode-to-deduct.

A manufacturing method in which commonly-used raw materials and components may be stocked based on previous demand history, but further processing into higher-level items is not done until receipt of a customer order.
The description applied to suppliers and customers that are in immediate relationships with an operation with no intermediary operations.
Same as supply chain management, but with emphasis on consumer pull vs. supplier push.
Extra services that a distribution centre will perform in order to meet the needs of their customers. Typically refer to special assembly, packaging, or picking services.
A standard numerical code used by the U.S. Government to classify products and services.
Cost of goods, marine insurance, and all transportation (freight) charges are paid to the foreign point of delivery by the seller.
Abbreviation for: Value Added Tax.
In sail boating, portion of the hull immersed in water.
The waterline corresponding to the maximum draft to which a vessel is permitted to load, either by free-board regulations, the conditions of classification, or the conditions of service.
An arrangement under which part or all of the purchases of two or more governmental units are made by a joint purchasing office. Also referred to as consolidated purchasing.
Customs form permitting in bond cargo to be moved from one location to another under customs control, within the same customs district. Usually in motor carrier’s possession while draying cargo.
Business conditions that force companies to hold inventory.

Your company sells and ships to the distributor. The distributor sells and ships to the end user. This may occur in multiple stages. Ultimately, your products may pass through the Indirect/Distributor Channel and arrive at a retail outlet. Order information in this channel may be transmitted by electronic means. These means may include EDI, brokered systems, or linked electronic systems.
Written guarantee from a third-party guarantor.
Reduce the amount of stock held.

A ship used to train students as sailors, especially a ship employed by a navy or coast guard to train future officers. The term refers both to ships used for training at sea and to old, immobile hulks used to house classrooms.
Abbreviation for: Locator Middle Marker.

An inventory classification scheme that ranks items based on past (or projected) annual usage times cost or price, with A items accounting for the top 10–20% in terms of number of items, and 60–70% of dollar volume. B items account for the next 20–25% of items and 20- 30% of dollar volume, and C items account for the bottom 60–70% of items and only 15–30% of the dollar volume. A Class D is sometimes used for obsolete or non-moving items. ABC categories are often used in specifying the amount of attention and control paid to specific items—with the tightest control over A items—in exception reporting, and in selecting items for periodic inventory cycle counts (A items are counted the most frequently).
A warehouse located between customers and manufacturing plants to provide increased customer service and reduced distribution cost.
Prices for future deliveries of spare parts and services after delivery of the work.
Abbreviation for: Commercial Motor Vehicle.
A document or digital record which authorises and provides notification of a modification to a product or order.

Dynamic management tool, quickly drawn up, showing a series of quantitative (financial and non-financial) and qualitative indicators, allowing a logistics manager to track and validate the key points they wish to control and, if necessary, to take short-term corrective actions.
The electronic transmission of data, usually in computer-readable form, using a variety of transmission vehicles and paths.
Entity to whom money is payable. The entity for whom a letter of credit is issued. The seller and the drawer of a draft.

Generally a horseshoe or U-Shaped work area layout that enables workers to easily move from one process to another in close proximity and pass parts between workers with little effort. Cells typically focus on the production of specific models in ‘part families’ but can be adjusted to many different products as needed.
A rate based upon the number of miles the commodity is shipped.

A group of specific indirect costs created by the same cost drivers; the total cost pool amount is usually allocated to specific products or cost centers on the basis of estimated production over a period of time.
The idea that the design of products and services on one hand, and the processes that create them on the other, should be integrated.
A table showing the amounts of principal and interest due at regular intervals and the unpaid mortgage balance after each payment.

A standard product numbering and barcoding system used by the retail industry. UPC codes are administered by the Uniform Code Council; they identify the manufacturer as well as the item, and are included on virtually all retail packaging.

The law developed by an Italian economist in the 1800s based on the principle that the vast majority of an end result (wealth, cost, quality problems, etc.) is determined by a small percentage of a group (the number of people, items, etc.) Often stated as the 80/20 rule, it is used in inventory counting and quality systems to concentrate attention on the small (20%) number of sources that account for 80% of inventory value or quality issues.

term: Fixed Price Plus Incentive Fee Contract
definition: Contractor receives fixed price for the work plus extra payments based upon superior performance.
See: National Highway System
See: Long Range Program Plan
Activities related to scheduling, releasing, and tracking production orders and reporting material and resource usage.
Abbreviation for: Technology Transfer Centre.
A hood forward of a hatch or cockpit to protect the crew from wind and spray. Can be soft or hard.

An analysis method that measures planned and actual input and output for a linked set of resources to identify the source of disruptions in output. If the plan for a given work centre calls for 100 units/day of output and it is only achieving 80, I/O control identifies whether it is getting the required input as planned (therefore the problem is at that work centre) or if it is getting only enough input for 80 units, which indicates a problem in a feeder work centre.

A message usually sent through EDI, from a vendor to a customer at the time of the vendor shipment, that notifies the customer of the order, item, and quantity information. Some customers may refuse receipt or penalise the vendor if the ASN is not communicated at shipment time or within a specified time frame.
A listing of open (unshipped) customer orders, normally time-phased and valued at actual individual order prices, which may include margin and profitability analysis.

Based on traffic lights, this is a system to add a colourful visual status check to a progress report, indicating whether status is good or progress is to plan (green), or there is some cause for concern but overall status is still on track (amber), or activities are behind plan (red
Shows how the proportion of the sum of squared error that is explained by a regression.
A light illuminating a sector or very narrow angle and intended to mark a direction to be followed.

Is the person on board the vessel, accountable to the master, designated by the company as responsible for the security of the ship, including implementation and maintenance of the ship security plan and for the liaison with the company security officer and the port facility security officers.
These are high-tech, high-volume products, which are often supplied at customer specification.
The level of demand for a product which is based on actual history and/or known customer contracts. Syn.: Base load demand.
Syn.: Production database.
National Aviation Weather Advisory Unit.
The systems that enable the creation of detailed optimized plans and schedules, taking into account resource, material, and dependency constraints to meet deadlines.
Abbreviation for: Airport Network Simulation Model.

A manufacturing facility that groups similar equipment into departments or areas. Production orders are moved to successive departments as required to complete all routing operation steps, as opposed to grouping all production equipment required for a product or line in one area.
Abbreviation for: Instrument Flight Rules.
Abbreviation for: Aircraft Identification.
A technique that analyses all the production inputs, life-cycle use of a product and its final disposal in terms of total energy used and waste emitted.
An organisation within the United Nations to which all national and other standard setting bodies (should) defer. Develops and monitors international standards.

Refers to the status of inventory as it relates to its ability to be sold or consumed. Availability calculations are used to determine this status. Availability calculations vary from system to system, but basically subtract any current allocations of holds on inventory from the current on-hand balance. An example of an availability calculation would be: [Quantity Available] = [Quantity On Hand] - [Quantity On Hold] - [Quantity Allocated To Sales Orders] - [Quantity Allocated to Production Orders].
The very end of a yard. Often mistaken for a “yard,” which refers to the entire spar. As in to hang “from the yardarm” and the sun being “over the yardarm” (late enough to have a drink).
An item cost standard created at the beginning of a fiscal period that is retained for budget and comparison purposes even if material or production changes occur.
A midshipman (Royal Navy slang.)
The second section of the mast above the deck; formerly the upper mast, later surmounted by the topgallant mast; carrying the topsails.
A vertical lever connected to a tiller, used for steering on larger ships before the development of the ship’s wheel.
Pair of axles and associated suspension usually located close together.

Returns Management Authorisation; the process of providing an authorisation number for returned product via call centre, fax, web, or e-mail. Criteria would be established and adhered to ensure returns guidelines are followed

A technique that attempts to manage production flow through the identification of a bottleneck that sets the pace of releasing materials to production (drum), a buffer inventory to ensure continued operation of the bottleneck, and the system to control communications and information flow from the drum to the material release point (rope).
The shipment volume at which the LTL charges equal the TL charges at the minimum weight.
The process of deciding who should belong to a team.
Fundamental analysis and radical redesign of a business process to improve quality, cycle time, cost, and asset utilization.
A grouping of similar goods or services that enables an organisation to analyse its spend.

A bid that contains pricing aberrations, for example, low or nominal prices may be bid for some items and high or enhanced prices may be bid for other work. This may happen in time and material contracts or construction contracts where upfront payment may be made for mobilization. It is wise policy to state in the bid documents that “unbalanced bids may be deemed non-responsive”. Unbalanced bids may be deemed to be non-responsive, and may be both mathematically unbalanced and materially unbalanced.
Navigation Canada.
Container yard jargon for a forklift truck used for heavy lifting of containers.
Abbreviation for: Remote Transmitter.

A generic term in South African which means African, Coloureds and Indians Who are citizen of the republic of South Africa by birth and decent; or Who became citizens of the republic of South Africa by naturalisation Before 27 April 1994; On or after 27 April 1994 and who would have been entitled to acquire citizenship by naturalisation prior to that date.

A business strategy which sets a product or service price based on the benefit it provides the customer, rather than on the cost of the product, market price, competitor or historical price. Value based pricing includes advertising or surveying to determine or measure the anticipated benefit the customer will receive and align the value delivered. Pricing is based upon the perceived or actual value that the end user will receive.

An additional level of multi-unit packaging within a case, carton, or other larger packaging. For example, you may have a case that contains 600 units of an item, but within that case, you have 24 smaller boxes or bags that each contain 25 units. These smaller packages are called inner packs.
The location where consolidation takes place.
Abbreviation for: Transcribed Weather Broadcast.
The U.S. Customs’ “Automated Manifest System.”
A ship propelled by internal- combustion engines. Also known as: Motor vessel (MV).
Abbreviation for: TRACON Traffic Management Advisor.
Abbreviation for: Local Multi-Point Distribution System.

A cost that can be directly traced to a cost object since a direct or repeatable cause-and-effect relationship exists. A direct cost uses a direct assignment or cost causal relationship to transfer costs. Direct costs can consist of materials used and labour directly involved in production.
A draft that matures on a fixed date, regardless of the time of acceptance.
Defined as a series of companies (links) in which the consecutive stages of production of an economic product take place, from primary producer to consumer.
A measurable, individual transaction or status change with specific start and end timing that can be attributed as a source of requirements or a trigger for other events.
Team of two drivers who alternate between driving and resting.
Abbreviation for: Invitation for Bid.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System.
Abbreviation for: Environmental Assessment.
An approach to maintenance management that monitors the condition of process equipment and performs work on equipment only when it is required.
A warehouse storage device where items are stocked at the rear and a conveyor is used to move the items to the front for picking.
A process that performs necessary, albeit not value-added, activities.
A sheet of plastic with air bubbles in it that is used as a packing material.
The purchaser’s agreement to an offer submitted by a vendor.
Abbreviation for: Air Defence Identification Zone.
The connection that permits messages to flow freely between two networks.

term: Clothing and Textile Competitiveness Improvement Programme
definition: South African Government initiative designed to build capacity in the textile sector and in other areas of the apparel chain.
Liquid products refined from crude oil, whose colour is less than or equal to 2.5 on the National Petroleum Association scale. Clean products include naphtha, jet fuel, gasoline, and diesel/gas oil.
A method of constructing wooden hulls by fixing planks to a frame so that the planks butt up against each other. Cf. “clinker built.”
Creating a product from existing components into an individual order. Syn.: build to order.
Abbreviation for: AUTODIN Terminal (FUS).
In the context of manufacturing customisation, activities that occur prior to the point of customisation.
Average Inventory Level = (Current Inventory + Previous Inventory) / 2.

A device to slow a boat down in a storm so that it does not speed excessively down the slope of a wave and crash into the next one. It is generally constructed of heavy flexible material in the shape of a cone. Also see: Sea anchor on page 467.
Abbreviation for: Advanced Weather Radar System.
The action of ordering or producing up to the Max in a Min-Max system even though inventory has not reached the Min. May be used to avoid downtime on machines, etc.
Abbreviation for: General System of Preferences.
The physical, bricks-and-mortar assets a company uses in the value creation process.
Foul-weather clothing worn by sailors.

A formal, written contract protocol that establishes the approach for planning and managing the interim period between the beginning of a contract and its expiration. A well-managed, detailed transition plan will reduce problems that may occur in new contracts, extensions of contracts, and contract renewals. Examples include contracting for uniforms, security guard services, and food services in institutions such as a prison.
An organisation maintained for the surveying and classing of ships so that insurance underwriters and others may know the quality and condition of the vessels offered for insurance or employment.
Abbreviation for: Service Delivery Point.
In project management, a set of parallel activities that begin or stop at the same time.
Refers to: Type (FAACIS).
Abbreviation for: Mean Absolute Percentage Error (Statistics).

Abbreviation for: Internal Combustion Engine. 2. Abbreviation for: Intergovernmental Coordination Element. Required element of a local government comprehensive plan addressing coordination between adjacent local governments.
A group of individual items considered to have the same characteristics for purposes of creating aggregate production, capacity, financial or sales plans.

The scale describing wind force devised by Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort in 1808, in which winds are graded by the effect of their force (originally, the amount of sail that a fully rigged frigate could carry).
Another name for a moving average model. The name refers to the fact that using averages to generate forecasts results in forecasts that are less susceptible to random fluctuations in demand.
Goods or services purchased for use as input in the production of final goods or services (Schiller, 2000).
Abbreviation for: Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa.
Provides the assignment to the supplier or service provider. Equivalent to customer or buyer.
Tools and methods that extract and perform multidimensional data analysis and enable a variety of views, such as rotation, summarisation, and trend analysis.
The bow fitting which clamps the bowsprit to the stem.
Numerous shipments from different shippers to one consignee that are consolidated and treated as a single consignment.
The amount on which an Ad Valorem, or customs duty, is calculated.
Items delivered directly to the end user bypassing the inspection process/route.
Used with reference to charges assessed for cargo movement past a line-haul terminating point.
Abbreviation for: Living Standard Measure.
The cat o’ nine tails, which in principle is only used on board on the captain’s (or a court martial’s) personal orders.
A method of assessing performance in project management by combining the costs and times achieved in the project with the original plan.
Abbreviation for: Quality Breakdown.

A reorder system that determines the timing and quantity of suggested reorders based on a specified order point and forecasted demand for a designated item, and not by exploding the bill of material. It generates multiple suggested orders as required, as opposed to an order point system that suggests a single reorder, and is typically used for independent demand items.

1. A set of essentially interrelated, parallel transportation facilities for moving people and goods between two points. 
 2. A geographic area used for the movement of people and goods. 
 3. Highway, rail line, waterway, and other exclusive-use facilities that connect major origin/destination markets within Florida or between Florida and other states/nations.
A process that shifts roles to the supply chain member best positioned to perform them.
Abbreviation for: Weather Service Forecast Office.
To update a file or database through acceptance of entered data.
Abbreviation for: Limited Remote Communications Outlet.
The process of analysing the stock position and the stock pattern as well as signaling differences with regard to the stock norms.
Abbreviation for: US Coast Guard’s Automated Mutual-Assistance Vessel Rescue System.
National Airspace Data Interchange Network.

A planned facility that is designed as part of the Strategic Intermodal System (SIS) or Emerging SIS before it is operational. Planned facilities must be projected to meet all applicable criteria and thresholds, be agreed to by partners, and be financially feasible.
The shape of a boat or ship in which the contours of the hull come in a straight line to the keel.
In the direction that the wind is blowing towards.
Abbreviation for: Knowledge Management.
Abbreviation for: Institute of Supply Management.
Syn.: Work-in-Process (WIP).
Abbreviation for: Every Day Low Prices (Retail).
Material that has been rejected by the customer or the buyer’s inspection department and is awaiting shipment back to the supplier for repair or replacement.

1. A liquid cargo vessel of 10,000 to 60,000dwt. Also referred to as a Handymax Tanker. Often built with many segregated cargo tanks and thus sometimes called a “drug-store tanker.” 2. A tanker designed to carry a variety of liquid products varying from crude oil to clean and dirty petroleum products, acids, and other chemicals, as well as edible oils. The tanks are coated to prevent product contamination and hull corrosion. The ship may have equipment designed for the loading and unloading of cargoes with a high viscosity.
Relating to the connections that have both ends within a single region.
Officially stipulated portion of local production and content as officially determined by the designated government department.
Notice to Airmen.
Relating to the connection between any two or more cities. Such connections may be within a region (see Intraregional) or between two regions if the cities are different regions (see Interregional).
A space in the forward part of the ship, typically beneath the bow in front of the foremost collision bulkhead that contains the anchor chain when the anchor is secured for sea.
Abbreviation for: National Severe Storms Forecast Centre.
A post or pair mounted on the ship’s bow, for fastening ropes or cables.
Abbreviation for: Future Reality Tree.

an Entity controlled by a measure Entity whether directly or indirectly controlled by the natural persons who have direct or indirect control over that measured Entity or the immediate family of that natural person.
A temporary storage area on a computer for cut or copied items.
Usually measured as the cost of freight per item or SKU. Total freight cost / number of items.
In or into any of the spaces below the main deck of a vessel.
The price paid for a product is based upon competitive tendering among a number of preselected suppliers. E-auctions or other formal tendering vehicles may be used.

The direct contractual relationship existing between parties that allows either party to enforce contractual rights against the other and seek remedy directly from the other party with whom the relationship exists.

Abbreviation for: Certified Fellow in Production and Inventory Management, by the American Production and Inventory Control Society. This certification recognises superior knowledge and performance in contributing to the profession.

A term which refers to capturing operational data in real-time or close to it, making it possible for an enterprise to react more quickly to events. This is typically done through software and includes features to provide alerts/notifications when specific events occur. Also see: Supply Chain Event Management.
A term used for goods in transit, or on the way to a destination.
Sometimes called ‘core business,’ this is the capability that is considered central to a company’s competitive strategy.
A written receipt in full, in discharge from all claims.
A balance sheet item that shows the amount a company paid for the inventory it has on hand at a particular point in time.

On or above the deck, in plain view, not hiding anything. Pirates would secret their crews below decks, thereby creating the false impression that an encounter with another ship was a casual matter of chance.
A package that includes all the value-added physical and intangible activities that a service organisation provides to a customer.
The practice of comparing and rating a company’s products or services against those of competitors. Also see: Benchmarking on page 64
An agreement in which one government contracts with another for the delivery of goods and services (Harney, 1992).
A small opening, or lid thereof, in a ship’s deck or hull.
The cost to borrow or invest capital.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Telecommunications Network.
Abbreviation for: Council on Environmental Quality.
Abbreviation for: Visual Approach Slope Indicator.
Abbreviation for: Airbus Industries Group.
An articulated five-platform rail car. Used where height and weight restrictions limit the use of stack cars. It holds five 40-foot containers or combinations of 40-and 20-foot containers.
Abbreviation for: Aircraft Surge Launch and Recovery.
A database query tool used to create ad-hoc reports without programming knowledge.
Abbreviation for: Altitude/Height
Abbreviation for: Distribution Centre. A warehouse that manages and distributes inventory per the direction of corporate systems and customer demand.

Also known as (U.S.) Federal Bill of Lading Act of 1916. U.S. federal law enacting conditions by which a B/L may be issued. Penalties for issuing B/L’s containing false data include monetary fines and/or imprisonment.
Contractor guarantees the actual output or outcome of the work to be delivered.
A location in which stock is held.

A type of sailing vessel characterised by the use of fore-and-aft sails on two or more masts with the forward mast being no taller than the rear masts, first used by the Dutch in the 16th or 17th century.
A Great Lakes slang term for a vessel without any self-unloading equipment.

Set of activities with the goal of making available the desired items and quantities of finished goods to the customer and/or end consumer at the desired time (information contained in the FRP) at the best pricing terms. This process involves the definition of a distribution policy (inventory management method for finished goods, delivery cycle time, management of inbound transport, subcontracting to Logistics Service Providers, etc.).
Abbreviation for: Interactive Terminal Interface.
To surrender the vessel to an enemy, from the custom during the Age of Sail of lowering the vessel’s ensign to indicate that she is surrendering.
See: Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals.

A company that offers access over the Internet to application (e.g. word processors, database programs, Web browsers, development tools, communication programs) and related services that would otherwise have to be located in their own computers. Sometimes referred to as “apps-on- tap,” ASP services are expected to become an important alternative, especially for smaller companies with low budgets for information technology. The purpose is to try to reduce a company’s burden by installing, managing, and maintaining software
Ganging of smaller shipments to cut cost, often as directed by a system or via pooling with a third party.
The relative slackness of an anchor chain; this term means somewhat slack, but not vertical nor fully extended.
Altitude-Encoded Beacon Reply and Altitude Reporting Mode of Secondary Radar.
Abbreviation for: True Air Speed.
Individual employed in a port to load and unload ships.
Abbreviation for: Difference in Longitude.
Abbreviation for: Computerised Maintenance Management System.
A blue and white flag (the flag for the letter “P”) hoisted at the foretrucks of ships about to sail. Formerly a white ship on a blue ground, but later a white square on a blue ground
Abbreviation for: International AFSS.
The range and variety of products made available by one business
Abbreviation for: Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals.
An extension of the Lean philosophy to supply chain efforts beyond production. Lean supply chain management seeks to minimise the level of resources required to carry out all supply chain activities.

A Metric which quantitatively tells us something about mobility – measure could be considered as two types: 1. A mobility metric directly tied to achieving a goal or objective or used in a decision making process. 2. An indicator or context measure which is not used to achieve a goal or objective.

The system and process of placing cargo material in a standard-size container, in which the contents are not to be re-handled while the container is moved between ship, rail, truck, or other transportation modes.
Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking: A tool used by the federal government to solicit public input into the development of a proposed regulation; notice usually published in the Federal Register
The allocation of a budget, cost, or other value on a predetermined percentage basis.
The combination of the origin and destination points.
Abbreviation for: Computer Aided Engineering.
The elapsed time for an operation that includes setup and run hours, but does not include queue or move time.

An order that authorizes the manufacture of a specific quantity of an item or group of items, contains release and due dates, and documents requirements for the materials and resources used. It is assigned a separate number or identifier used in reporting material and labor transactions.

A reorder system that places orders when on-hand and scheduled receipts reach a predefined level, instead of using requirements suggested by MRP from a bill of material explosion. An order point system is normally used to trigger a single order when needed, but may also be time-phased in projecting inventory levels in the future, based on forecast demand in multiple periods and triggering multiple orders as needed.
Project activities for which the earliest start time and latest start time are equal. Critical activities cannot be delayed without lengthening the overall project duration.
An inventory model that determines how much to order by determining the amount that will meet customer service levels while minimising total ordering and holding costs.

End items that can be promised to customer order requirements for a given period, based on an uncommitted or available status, calculated as: on- hand inventory, less booked customer orders, plus expected master schedule receipts for the period. Cumulative ATP includes past due orders and indicated total availability for successive periods
Truck or tractor design in which the cab sits over the engine on the chassis.
A calculation that projects how long the current on-hand inventory will last, given a predetermined rate of usage, and assuming no replenishment.
National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications and National Radio Communications Systems.
Standardized unit for measuring intermodal container capacity on ships, railcars, etc.

Selling of goods or services to the buyer with the highest offer at the time of a sale. Usually, at the time of return approval, the product owner may elect to route the product to an auction service after receipt at a returns processing centre.
A rope that ties something off.
Abbreviation for: International Mobile Telephone.
Create invoice documents (or transmissions) based on outbound shipments to the client’s end customer. Invoices may include mailing addresses, terms, and pricing
High-tech, high-volume products, which are often supplied at customer specification.
The officer in charge of the ship. “Captain” is a courtesy title often given to a master.
The backlog of unfilled orders, or of material ready to be or already being processed.
Abbreviation for: Finish to Order.
Abbreviation for: Central Control Unit.
Abbreviation for: Employee Involvement and Employment Insurance (Canada).

1. The process of verifying the eligibility of a device, originator, or individual to access specific categories of information, or to enter specific areas of a facility. This process involves matching machine-readable code with a predetermined list of authorised end users. 2. A practice of establishing the validity of a transmission, message, device, or originator, which was designed to provide protection against fraudulent transmissions.
Alternative spelling of dispatch boat.
Processes that deal with discrete, usually highly customized products.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Air Traffic Control Automation.

The point in the supply chain where a production order becomes customerspecific. Downstream of this point activities are planned based upon customer order and further downstream activities are planned based on forecast
Abbreviation for: Packet Switched Network.
Engaging in a contractual relationship with one or more parties.
The pin or bolt on which a ship's rudder pivots. The pintle rests in the gudgeon.
A fee charged by a carrier to compensate for the detention of the carrier’s equipment in excess of allowable free time for loading, unloading , reconsigning, or stopping in transit.
Fixed-path equipment. Materials handling devices that include cranes, monorails, and stacker cranes.
The book inventory calculated as a result of all issue, receipt, and adjustment transactions, as opposed to verification by physical count.
The process of comparing data sets to resolve discrepancies and prove accuracy.
Abbreviation for: Preferential Trade Agreement.
A device to read barcodes and communicate data to computer systems.
