A computer term for the most commonly used type of Local Area Network (LAN) communication protocol, using coaxial or twisted pair wiring.
Abbreviation for: Methods- Time Measurement.
The deletion from records of materiel due to shortage or loss by any cause (*radiation).
Abbreviation for: Industrial Development Zones.
Adjustable support bars used inside trailers to prevent movement of the load. Also known as: Load bars, Cargo bars.
Abbreviation for: Watertight.

A variation from the solicitation that does not affect the price of the contract or does not give a respondent an advantage or benefit not enjoyed by other respondents, or does not adversely impact the interests of the contracting party.
A control limit within a stock control system which could indicate the point which an order should be placed. Or indicate if stocks are too low, for a specific item.
Product is loaded onto a pallet and then secured with strapping.

term: American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII)
definition: A standard code that allows interchange of 128 alphanumeric, and related characters, between different information systems.
The total elapsed time between the creation and acceptance of a purchase order and payment.
A term used in acceptance sampling to indicate the highest defect level a consumer is willing to “tolerate.”
The total set of conditions in which a company sells its products, with special attention to the number of parties in the market and the nature of the product being traded.

For parcel shippers, pick-to-carton logic uses item dimensions/weights to select the shipping carton prior to the order picking process. Items are then picked directly into the shipping carton. When picking is complete, dunnage is added and the carton sealed, eliminating a formal packing operation. This logic works best when picking/packing products with similar size/weight characteristics. In operations with a very diverse product mix, it’s much more difficult to get this type of logic to work effectively.

The simultaneous recording of a customer sale and its effect on inventory levels, typically done in a retail environment using automatic data collection systems. Real-time POS data is sometimes used to automatically trigger replenishment orders as required and can be used in sales analysis to review end-customer rather than distributor sales patterns.
An emergency call that alerts the crew that someone aboard has gone overboard and must be rescued.
An ocean carrier company operating vessels not on regular runs or schedules. They call at any port where cargo may be available.

The classification of an organisation’s spend in a hierarchical order that usually ranges from 3 to 5 levels depending on the complexity of their spend. They are usually classified as: Level 1 (Group), Level 2 (Family), Level 3 (Category), Level 4 (Commodity); where Level 1 is the highest level which is broken down in Families and Families in turn are further divided into various Categories, and Categories are divided into Commodities. The last level (Commodities) encompasses the unique set of suppliers with similar core competencies.
A bottleneck, obstacle, or planned control that limits throughput or the utilisation of capacity.
The amount of items to be produced by a machine or process that supposedly minimises the costs associated with production and inventory holding.
The penalty a seller must pay if the construction project does not meet contractual standards or deadlines.
Abbreviation for: Station Identifier and Standard Instrument Departure.
Rail or rubber-tired gantry crane. Large yard (ship or rail) container crane. Lifts from a stack of containers 5, 6, 7 wide, and deposits onto truck chassis or rail flatcar.

An accounting period (general ledger, AP, AR, etc.) for which a manual or system-generated close has been performed. Once closed, final reports are generated and any new transactions for the module must be done in the next open period.

A wide range of advanced technologies and ideas, which, in combination, can improve mobility and transportation productivity, enhance safety, maximize the use of existing transportation facilities, conserve energy resources, and reduce adverse environmental effects.
The products which are currently being moved from one location to another.
International Standards for Phytosanitary Measures (EU).

A multiple-level bill of material listing the end item at the far left side (often noted as level 0), with the immediate lower level (1) components indented one place to the right. Items used in the level one components (level 2) are listed under each level one item and are indented an additional place to the right. Subsequent levels are presented in the same way.
Any finished goods, end time, or part that is mixed, fabricated, assembled, stirred, or blended from one or more other components.
FAA Headquarters
To state all 32 points of the compass, starting at north, proceeding clockwise. Sometimes applied to a wind that is constantly shifting
Barcode symbol identifying the transportation unit (for example, the container). The SSCC is the code used to track the merchandise.
A situation where two related processes are started and run concurrently without waiting for the other to complete.

RTLS describes any wireless technology that can be used to continuously determine and track the real-time location of assets and personnel, inside and outside a facility. In a typical solution, assets are tagged with an RFID tag that periodically communicates with locating system readers, which confirm and estimate the tag locations.
Abbreviation for: Congestion Mitigation Air Quality Act.
Abbreviation for Return on Invested Capital.
Abbreviation for: Airports Council International.
Abbreviation for: Enterprise Development Unit.
Abbreviation for: Multilateral Trade Negotiations.
Abbreviation for: Real-time Weather Processor
The difference between the predicted and observed values of a model due to random error including missing and incomplete data.
Abbreviation for: Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Swaziland (members of SACU).
A reporting system that accumulates multiple daily records into a larger, user-specified time frame (weeks, quarters, years,etc.).Enables easier analysis when daily detail is not required.
Abbreviation for: Schedule Variance.
Practice that occurs when vendors ship goods directly to the retail store instead of to the retailer’s distribution centre (DC). Syn.: direct to store.
To capsize a boat stern over bow, rather than by rolling over.
A warehouse order picking scheme that uses LED readouts for each inventory location that display the locations and quantities to be picked based on data from the warehouse management or ERP system.
Abbreviation for: Horizontal Situation Indicators.
See: Agreement
What the customer is willing to pay for the product.
The total number of miles travelled by vehicle using a highway system.
Companies that do business with each other via EDI (e.g., send and receive business documents, such as purchase orders).
A warehouse that is available to all companies and persons who wish to use the services offered.
National African Federated Chamber of Commerce.
Group of men who handle ground tackle when the ship is anchoring or getting under way

The height of a ship’s hull (excluding superstructure) above the waterline. The vertical distance from the current waterline to the lowest point on the highest continuous watertight deck. This usually varies from one part to another.
A set of tactical and execution-level business activities that includes master scheduling, material requirements planning, and some form of production activity control and vendor order management.
Act of throwing cargo or equipment (jetsam) overboard when a ship is in danger.
An actuator is a device that acts on the basis of information it receives from a sensor.
It describes the transfer of goods from the buyer when the material is on high sea.
Abbreviation for: Chief Information Officer.
Points in time within a project plan; together with activities, they form network planning diagrams.

A diagram of a system, in which the principal parts or functions are represented by blocks connected by lines that show the relationships of the blocks. The block diagram is typically used for a higher level, less detailed description aimed more at understanding the overall concepts, and less at understanding the details of implementation
Abbreviation for: Aeronautical Quality Assurance Field Office.

Racking system that uses bolts or other mechanical fasteners (as opposed to Boltless Pallet rack). Structural Pallet Rack is sometimes used to support the roof of the structure (Rack-supported buildings), eliminating the need for posts.
The assignment of dollars or currency to units, as in multiplying on-hand inventory quantities by the standard cost, or open customer order units by list price.
A major trading partner can connect to its supply chain to access data in real time.
A document issued by the supplier confirming agreement to the buyer’s purchase order.
A wire or rope contrivance placed around cargo and used to load or discharge it to/from a vessel.
Abbreviation for: Preferential Procurement Policy Framework Act, Act No. 5 of 2000.
Abbreviation for: Eurasian Economic Community.
Lifted by a buoy, often referring to cables lifted to prevent trailing on the bottom.
A report, normally handwritten, which is created by the procurement and production areas, to advise management regarding orders which are not expected to be complete.
Airway Facilities.
The variety that occurs when a process is not designed to prevent it.
Abbreviation for: Radar Tracking and Beacon Tracking Level.
Abbreviation for: Local Access and Transport Area.
Abbreviation for: Build To Order.
Abbreviation for: Technology Working Group.

A concept permitted by some jurisdictions whereby a claimant may arrest both the vessel that is subject to the claimant’s maritime lien and any “associated” vessel, which is any vessel owned or controlled by the same owner.

Product ordered, but out of stock, and promised to ship when the product becomes available.  1.The act of retaining a quantity to ship against an order when other order lines have already been shipped. Back orders are usually caused by stock shortages. 2.The quantity remaining to be shipped if an initial shipment(s) has been processed. Note: In some cases back orders are not allowed, this results in a lost sale when sufficient quantities are not available to completely ship and order or order line
Abbreviation for: MegHERTZ.
Abbreviation for: In-Flight Emergency Assistance.
Glide Slope Indicator.
Abbreviation for: Delivery In Full on Time. A measure of performance for transport/logistics providers.

1. In the 18th and 19th centuries, a small sailing warship carrying 18 or fewer guns with a single continuous gundeck. 2. In the 18th and 19th centuries, any sailing warship bearing fewer than 20 guns. 3. In the 19th-century United States Navy, the term used for the type of sailing warship known in other navies as a corvette. 4. In the early and mid-20th century, a small ocean-going warship not intended for fleet deployments, used instead for convoy escort, gunboat duties, etc.
A productivity score that measures output levels relative to more than one input.
Parts which have been replaced by an alternative but which may still be used until stock is exhausted.
Abbreviation for: Minimum IFR Altitudes.

term: CSCMP’s Definition of Supply Chain Management
definition: Supply chain management encompasses the planning and management of all activities involved in sourcing and procurement, conversion, and all logistics management activities. Importantly, it also includes coordination and collaboration with channel partners, which can be suppliers, intermediaries, third party service providers, and customers. In essence, supply chain management integrates supply and demand management within and across companies
Abbreviation for: Calculated Landing Time.

A general rule in marketing is that you do not base your selling price on the cost price of the product, but rather on what the market can bear. In this reasoning, the price that the buyer is willing to pay is related primarily to the value it attaches to the product. This pricing method is often used for consumer products (well-known branded articles).
Abbreviation for: Provincial Investment Promotion Agency.
A sailing rig consisting mainly of sails that are set along the line of the keel rather than perpendicular to it. Such sails are referred to as “fore-and-aft rigged.”
Sum of money from public funds set aside for a specific purpose.

A common carrier is liable for all shipment loss, damage, and delay with the exception of that caused by act of God, act of a public enemy, act of a public authority, act of the shipper, or the goods’ inherent nature.

Capacity planning systems that stay within defined capacity limits when loading proposed production schedules against resources. Finite systems rearrange the initial dates for planned and open production orders by moving them forward or backward in time, as far as needed, in order not to exceed the available capacity. Infinite capacity planning systems leave orders on the existing dates and merely show whether the load on a resource is over or under its defined capacity, without recommending changes.
An unproven process or technology so far ahead of its time that it may create a competitive disadvantage
The fraction of sales that contributes to the offset of fixed costs. Alternatively, unit contribution margin is the amount each unit sale adds to profit: it is the slope of the profit line.

Covers activities aimed at determining the purchasing specifications based upon ‘fitness for use,’ selecting the best possible supplier and developing procedures and routines to be able to do so, preparing and conducting negotiations with the supplier in order to establish an agreement and to write up the legal contract, placing the order with the selected supplier or to develop efficient purchase order and handling routines, monitoring and control of the order in order to secure supply (expediting), follow-up and evaluation (settling claims, keeping product and supplier files up-to-date, supplier rating and supplier ranking).
A production system organised and sequenced according to the steps involved in the manufacturing process where the product moves seamlessly and continuously through the entire manufacturing process.
Abbreviation for: Green Supply Chain Management.
Terminal-to-terminal freight movements in transportation.
Goods and/or services are exchanged against other goods and/or services of equivalent value. No money changes hands between the buyer and seller.

1. A sailor. Also jack tar or just tar. 2. A flag. Typically the flag was talked about as if it were a member of the crew. Strictly speaking, a flag is only a “jack” if it is worn at the jackstaff at the bow of a ship.
Crew’s slang for the captain (master or commanding officer) of a vessel.
Abbreviation for: Contract Line Item.

Specific to legal matters; a written question or questions submitted to the other party involved in litigation usually under oath. Interrogatories are usually performed by attorneys representing the parties (Garner, 2004).
Abbreviation for: American Customer Satisfaction Index.
The direct interchange of data between computers, without re-keying

The capability of a manufacturer to compete with any other manufacturing organisation in a chosen market, with the aspiration of achieving world class excellence in all organisational aspects. It encompasses the practices of total quality management, continuous improvement, international benchmarking, and flexible work schedules.

An analytical way to uncover all the lifetime costs that follow from deciding to own and owning an asset, be it tangible or intangible. It is a financial estimate aimed at assisting procurers to quantifiably determine the following: • Direct costs associated with a product. • Indirect cost associated with a product. • Opportunity cost associated with a product, and, • Socio-economic implications associated with a product.
NADIN Switches.
Abbreviation for: Fixed Base Operator.
A draft that matures at a fixed or determinable time after presentation or acceptance.
Expenses reasonably incurred in the inspection, receipt, transportation, and care of goods rightfully rejected by a purchaser.
In six sigma and other quality improvement programs, the identification and prioritisation of true customer needs and requirements through the use of focus groups, interviews, and other methods.
A sequence number associated with a specific batch or production run of products and used for tracking purposes. Syn.: Lot number.

Your company sells and ships to the distributor. The distributor sells and ships to the end user. This may occur in multiple stages. Ultimately, your products may pass through the Indirect/Distributor Channel and arrive at a retail outlet.
In shipbuilding, a diagram showing an elevation of the ships sheer viewed from the broadside.
A blend of gases tailored to replace the normal atmosphere within a container.
Abbreviation for: High Level Language.
A symbolic image at the head of a traditional sailing ship or early steamer.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Advisor.
See: Barquentine.
AFS Field Office.

The graphical representation of the level of equality between two sets of data (as in cumulative percentage of population and cumulative percentage of net income). Perfect equality is represented as a 45 degree angle.

Recently formed or incorporated Entity that has been in operation for less than one 1 year. A start-up enterprise does not include any newly constituted entity which merely a continuation of a pre-existing entity.
Abbreviation for: Coega Development Corporation.

Canadian The identification of an individual contractor in the contracting organisation’s hierarchy as the prime contractor, subcontractor or other. The individual contractor’s designation in the hierarchy determines the legal responsibility of that contractor and reporting structure relative to the customer (Owner).
Abbreviation for: Air Route Surveillance Radar.
Average time between the commencement and completion of a manufacturing process, as it applies to make-to-stock products. Calculation: [Average # of units in WIP] / [Average daily output in units].
Abbreviation for: NWS Weather Excluding NXRD.
Products that are designed and produced from the start to meet unusual customer needs or requirements. They represent the highest level of customisation.
Abbreviation for: Distributed System Object Model.

A type of corridor study that identifies facility-specific transportation issues and opportunities within the corridor for enhancing the movement of people and goods, improvements in emergency management and response, enhancing homeland security, and ensuring opportunities for economic development. It also discusses potential options for implementation. The study is one of many that contribute to the concept and evaluation stages of the Corridor Planning and Screening Process.
Abbreviation for: South African Vanguard of Technology.
A shipment that moves between cities and over distances more than 100 to 150 miles in length.
Average Days To Sell Inventory = (Average Inventory/Cost of Goods Sold) x 365.
Abbreviation for: Total Quality Management.
A term used in acceptance sampling to indicate the probability of accepting a lot with quality worse than the LTPD level.
Company that transports freight under contract with one, or a limited number of shippers.
A stocking location used in the receiving process, which may include the receiving dock, inspection, hold, or material review, final primary or random location and others.
Abbreviation for: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. U.S. federal codification passed in 1936 which standardises carrier’s liability under carrier’s bill of lading. U.S. enactment of The Hague Rules.
To bring the vessel so close to wind that the sails shake.
A ship’s destination, typically an area to be patrolled or guarded.
The ability to work from home using telecommunications and/or computer technology.
Abbreviation for Risk Management Committee.
A performance dimension that differentiates a company’s products and services from its competitors. Firms win a customer’s business by providing superior levels of performance on order winners.
Abbreviation for: Man Machine Interface.
Refers to: Training.
A general term for a high level of competitive performance as defined by benchmarking and use of best practices.
National Qualification Framework.
Abbreviation for: Total Productive Maintenance.

An inventory control system where all the variables and parameters used are known, or can be calculated with certainty. The rate of demand for items, and the associated inventory costs, are assumed to be known with assurance and the replenishment lead time is assumed to be constant and independent of demand.
A number assigned to a shipment by the carrier for tracking purposes.
The process of removal of inventory items from an organisation’s premises.

Abbreviation for: Immediate Transport. The document (prepared by the carrier) allows shipment to proceed from the port of entry in the U.S. to customs clearing at the destination. The shipment clears customs at its final destination. Also called an “In-Transit” entry.
The distance that a system that transmits signals, such as a network or RFID device, can reliably complete transmission.

A collective term for all merchant ships registered in a given country and the civilians (especially those of that nationality) who man them; the ships and personnel in combination are said to constitute that country’s merchant marine. Called the merchant navy in the United Kingdom and some other countries.
A measure of density that compares a given item or substance to the density of water.
See: Anchor sentinel.
Abbreviation for: Request Full Route Clearance.

1. A mitred backing timber which extends the after line of the rabbet in the stem to give extra support to the ends of the planks and the bowsprit. 2. A bollard or bitt. 3. Either of two timbers rising from the keel of a sailing ship and supporting the inner end of the bowsprit.
Abbreviation for: Productive Asset Allowance.
See: Boatswain’s Call.
Abbreviation for: Sustainable Asset Management.
An order that must be fulfilled in less than the normal lead time.
See: National Development Plan
1. The volume of output generated by a resource in a specific period of time. 2. In the theory of constraints, the rate at which a system generates money.
To stimulate larger quantity orders, many suppliers use quantity discounts in which the advantage for the buyer is that he can realise a lower price per unit.
Charge associated with a load that has more than one drop off point. Typically, the first stop of a multistop load is free, and then charge are applied to the subsequent stops.
A plan that identifies interregional transportation needs involving Strategic Intermodal System (SIS), Emerging SIS, regionally significant and local facilities in a corridor.
The measure of machine hours recorded against production vs. the hours available or scheduled for a given period.

Abbreviation for: Please Authorise Delivery Against Guarantee. A request from the consignee to the shipper to allow the carrier or agent to release cargo against a guarantee, either bank or personal. Made when the consignee is unable to produce original bills of lading.
Abbreviation for: Telecommunications Request.
Turbulence behind a vessel. Not to be confused with wash.
Having too great a sail area up to safely maneuver in current wind conditions.
A device to record temperature in a container while cargo is en route.
A statement of an organization’s assets, liabilities, and shareholder equities.
Generic Term Related to Risk Management System (ISO).
Abbreviation for Remote Maintenance Monitoring System.
Shell or body of a ship.
Firms that securely pack export products into a container or crate to protect the cargo from damage during an ocean voyage.
To bring the foreyards flat aback to stop the ship.
Syn.: Labour cost.
An EOQ that is not on the valid total cost curve when costs are discounted.
Trading firms that trough physical stores or webstores deliver their products and services directly to consumers.
Abbreviation for: Canadian International Development Agency.
Properly set up or provisioned.
Any device, or collection of devices, that collects, manipulates, stores or distributes information, nearly always used to mean computer-based devices.
Housing, serving, and maintaining files for a customer’s web site. Connection to the Internet via T-1 or T-3 lines.
A lot size technique that orders to cover requirements for a variable number of periods based on order and holding costs, as opposed to a fixed period quantity that uses a standard number of periods.
A for-hire air carrier operating within Alaska.
Cargo more than eight feet high that cannot fit into a standard container.
Abbreviation for: Global Navigation Satellite System.

The meaning as defined in the Labour Relation Act 66 of 1995 as amended. For the avoidance of doubt, a member of the broad who is not employed in the day to day management of a entity is not an employee of that entity notwithstanding the fact he/she may be remunerated or the performance of that function.

A physical or logical production area used as a unit for scheduling and routing operations. It is usually defined as being either labour or machine constrained, and while it may contain multiple machines or personnel they are considered identical in terms of the capability to process products assigned to that centre. A work centre may perform multiple operations, but capacity requirements are usually tracked only at the total work centre level. Work centre definitions can be flexible based on the process and reporting capabilities and requirements of the organisation.
A person or firm, licensed by the treasury department of their country when required, engaged in entering and clearing goods through Customs for a client (importer).
The use of software programs to control production and support equipment such as CNC machines or robots.

This clause, also known as “hold harmless,” “defend,” or “indemnify,” is used to protect a purchaser or supplier from loss or damage. The words “hold harmless” and “indemnify” refer to getting reimbursed for penalties or liabilities incurred by one party because of another’s action and pertain to monetary or financial loss. The word “defend” imposes an obligation on one contracting party to defend the other in a legal action and to incur the cost of such action. These clauses are used in purchase orders.
A Norwegian classification society which certifies seagoing vessels for compliance to standardised rules regarding construction and maintenance.
Place in the ship’s hold for pumps.
A mainsail that is not connected to a boom along its foot.

A strategic organisation-wide initiative for the firm to consider the impact of its actions on society, the environment and the world at large and to identify actions to minimise or eliminate detrimental impacts.
The lower part of a sterndrive.
Abbreviation for: Information Resources Management Plan.
The rope or iron used to keep the centre of a yard to the mast.

A two- or three-masted lugger used for fishing on the coasts of Spain and Portugal and more widely in the Mediterranean Sea in the late 17th and 18th centuries. The British Royal Navy also used them for shore raids and as dispatch boats in the Mediterranean.

Also known as “in extremis.” The point under International Rules of the Road (Navigation Rules) at which the privileged (or stand-on) vessel on collision course with a burdened (or give-way) vessel determines it must manoeuvre to avoid a collision. Prior to extremis, the privileged vessel must maintain course and speed and the burdened vessel must manoeuvre to avoid collision.

term: CONTRACT, FIXED PRICE WITH ECONOMIC PRICE ADJUSTMENT (FPEPA)
definition: A type of contract providing for upward or downward revision of the stated contract price upon the occurrence of a specified contingency. Adjustments may reflect increases/decreases in actual costs of labor or material, or in specific indices of labor or material costs.
A transportation solution that seeks to exploit the strengths of multiple transportation modes through physical, information, and monetary flows that are as seamless as possible.
The design angle between the keel and horizontal.
Abbreviation for: Leased Interfacility NAS Communications System.
The charts used within statistical process control to record process performance.
In dinghy sailing especially (but can include other boats), a boat is said to be turtling or to turn turtle when the boat is fully inverted with the mast pointing down to the lake bottom or seabed.
An air- or foam-filled bumper used in boating to keep boats from banging into docks or each other.
Abbreviation for: Co-operative Incentive Scheme.
An insurance policy in which the sum to be paid in case of loss is fixed by the terms of the policy; especially relating to fire insurance.
Material flow activity, whereby materials are shipped to customers from a secondary shipping point rather than from a preferred shipping point.
Wind resistance of the boat.
A graphical representation of the relationship between two variables.
An air carrier classification for carriers that operate between major population centres. These carriers are now classified as major carriers.
1. A tapered wooden tool used for separating the strands of rope for splicing. 2. A bar used to fix an upper mast in place.

Specification that a project task, shipment, or delivery may not occur after a given date, due to its effect on a later task or the inability to use a late shipment in production or for a specific sales promotion.
These materials are not absorbed physically in the end product, instead they are used or consumed during the production process.
A line used parallel to that of the length of a craft, to prevent fore-aft motion of a boat, when moored or docked.
Abbreviation for: Optimised Production Technology.
A quality and maintenance measure of the average time between failures for a resource or product that causes them to be unusable.
See: Supplier Selection Relationship Development and Management.
Method of transport used for the carriage of goods and/or persons. E.g.: by air or by road.
Abbreviation for: Heads Up Display.

The lead agency environmental management and stewardship, protecting Florida’s air, water and land. DEP is divided into three primary areas: Regulatory Programs, Land and Recreation, and Water Policy and Ecosystem Restoration.
A collection of components which have been put together into a unit, or the activity involved with putting components together to form a unit.
Description of standardised, acceptable methods, controls, and production facilities used in pharmaceutical, medical device, and food manufacturing industries.
A label required on shipments of flammable articles.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Remittance Advice.

Supplier performance management involves activities that focus on improving the performance and capability of suppliers. The primary logic of managing supplier performances is that both parties will share in the benefits of better performance, better quality, shorter cycle times and/or lower costs.

The height from the lowest part of the hull inside the ship, at its midpoint, to the ceiling that is made up of the uppermost full length deck. For old warships it is to the ceiling that is made up of the lowermost full length deck.
A term used to describe products which are not functional when delivered. Syn.: defective.
Automated Execution.
Abbreviation for: Container Yard. The designation for full container receipt/delivery.

Abbreviation for: Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays Excepted. Refers to loading and discharging of cargo as agreed to in the charter party. This indicates when time does not count in the calculation of demurrage and despatch.

The delivery slip is a legal document used to summarise the delivery of an order. Its structure is similar to that of the order and it informs the customer of quantities delivered and not delivered for each line of the original order. In certain cases, the delivery slip can reflect several orders, but in this case, it would be organised accordingly with several subheads. The delivery slip is addressed to the buyer or the customer delivered to. The latter can thus verify the delivery of the order and authorise or refuse its payment.
A productivity score that measures output levels relative to single input.

Number of times inventory is consumed or sold during a one year period. Generally calculated by dividing the average inventory level (or current inventory level) into the annual inventory usage (annual Cost of Goods Sold).
Abbreviation for: Effective Management Systems, Enhanced Messaging Service, Emergency Management System, and Electronic Manufacturing Services.
A signal on the bosun’s pipe to signal the end of the day, requiring lights (and smoking pipes) to be extinguished and silence from the crew.
Abbreviation for: Export Trading Company and Employee Transportation Coordinator. A person who helps employees at a particular work site use carpooling, vanpooling, and other ridesharing programs.
A warehouse operated by the owner of the stored goods.
The number of available options a customer can choose from within a product category.
1. A vessel traveling upstream. 2. Westward-traveling vessels in the Great Lakes region (terminology as used by the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation).
The paperwork that accompanies a shipment, pallet, or smaller unit and describes its contents and quantities, and normally references the order number or numbers involved.
Team of two drivers who alternate driving and resting.

The process of identifying, aggregating, and prioritising, all sources of demand for the integrated supply chain of a product or service at the appropriate level, horizon and interval. The sales forecast is comprised of the following concepts: 1. The sales forecasting level is the focal point in the corporate hierarchy where the forecast is needed at the most generic level, i.e. Corporate forecast, Divisional forecast, Product Line forecast, SKU, SKU by Location. 2. The sales forecasting time horizon generally coincides with the time frame of the plan for which it was developed, i.e. Annual, 1-5 years, 1-6 months, Daily, Weekly, Monthly. 3. The sales forecasting time interval generally coincides with how often the plan is updated, i.e. Daily, Weekly, Monthly, and Quarterly.

British term for a room located in the interior of a ship containing computers and other specialised equipment needed to calculate the range and bearing of a target from information gathered by the ship’s spotters and range finders. These were designated “plotting rooms” by the United States Navy.
The number of persons in a ship’s crew, including officers.

1.A spar, similar to a bowsprit, but which projects from the stern. May be used to attach the backstay or mizzen  sheets.  2.An iron bar (projecting out-board from a ship’s side) to which the lower and topsail brace blocks are sometimes hooked
Financing for the full life of a piece of equipment.
Abbreviation for: Airport Surveillance Radar.

term: Maritime Security and Safety Information System (MSSIS)
definition: It shares and displays vessel Automated Identification System (AIS) data real–time with multiple international users through a web–based, password–protected system.
The extent to which a process, products, or service has systems or components that are used only when other systems or components fail.
Abbreviation for: Command Communications Outlet.
Business-unit managers are responsible for their own purchasing activities and financial results.
The system of masts and lines on ships and other sailing vessels.
Abbreviation for: Localiser Directional Aid and Landing Directional Aid.
A user-defined grouping of trailers based on common characteristics such as dimensions, weight, or door type.
Abbreviation for: Distribution Resource Planning.
Characteristics of a process that allow it to continue operation or produce acceptable output when faced with a condition outside its normal design parameters.
Recognizing revenues and expenditures as they occur, rather than when actual payment is received or made (as in the cash accounting method).
Abbreviation for: Full Services Access Network.
Contractual description of service delivery performance specifying terms and conditions that may involve posting a bond.

An organisation established by the members of an ocean conference, which acts as a self–policing force with broad authority to investigate tariff violations, including authority to scrutinise all documents kept by the carriers and their personnel. Violations are reported to the membership and significant penalties are assessed.

1. A type of small boat, often carried or towed as a ship’s boat by a larger vessel. 2. Also a small racing yacht or recreational open sailing boat, often used for beginner training rather than sailing full-sized yachts. 3. Utility dinghies are usually rowboats or have an outboard motor, but some are rigged for sailing.
Freight transported by air.

Measure time on-board ship. One bell sounds for each half hour. One bell means 12:30, two bells mean 1:00, three bells mean 1:30, and so on until 4:00 (eight bells). At 4:30 the cycle begins again with one bell.
The period of time after processing is complete that a given item is not available for usage due to curing, drying, or other requirement that does not involve active use of resources.
Abbreviation for: Local Content Policies (LCPs).
Abbreviation for: Terminal VHF Omnidirectional Range.

A set of characters that uniquely identifies a single unit and can be used for traceability and warranty purposes. It does not normally refer to the use of a single identifier for a batch or lot composed of multiple units.
A special version of the adaptive feedback loop to monitor a single control variable and provide the ability for corrective action.

A sail control that lets one apply downward tension on a boom, countering the upward tension provided by the sail. The boom vang adds an element of control to sail shape when the sheet is let out enough that it no longer pulls the boom down. Boom vang tension helps control leech twist, a primary component of sail power

1. A strong rope supporting a mast, and leading from the head of one mast down to some other mast or other part of the vessel; rigging running fore (forestay) and aft (backstay) from a mast to the hull. The stays support a mast’s weight forward and aft, while the shrouds support its weight from side to side. 2. To incline forward, aft, or to one side by means of stays, e.g., to stay a mast. 3. To tack; put on the other tack, e.g., to stay ship. 4. To change; tack; go about; be in stays, as a ship. 5. A station or fixed anchorage for vessels. 6. In stays or hove in stays: in the act of going about while tacking. 7. Miss stays an unsuccessful attempt to tack.

Discounts offered to a buyer from a supplier based on the quantity purchased, the size of the order, or total annual volume. It is based on the economic theory of economies of scale – the larger the quantity purchased, the lower the unit price. Also see Economies of Scale, Quantity Discount and Volume Leveraging.
Abbreviation for: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Headquartered in Paris with membership consisting of the world’s developed nations.
Abbreviation for: Self-Monitoring Analysis and Reporting Technology.
Abbreviation for: Volpe National Transportation System Centre.
Economically Active population as determined and published by stats SA.
Contracts are closed based upon recognizing interests of key supply chain partners.
A formal statement of a need and the expected manner in which it is to be met (the customer’s view of the work product).
Abbreviation for: Compressed Integrated Product Engineering.
The amount that a ship is blown leeward by the wind. Also see: Weatherly.
Abbreviation for: Height Above Landing.
The rungs fastened between the shrouds permanently rigged from bulwarks and tops to the mast to form ladders enabling access to the topmasts and yards. Also known as: Rattlins or Ratlins.

The contracting authority can negotiate face-to-face with market parties about the contents, execution, and costs related to the contract. The negotiation procedure can be used with or without (pre)announcement.
Abbreviation for: Advanced Shipping Notice.

Refers to the extent of category spend with suppliers that do not feature on the pre-approved suppliers list. It is usually denoted as a percentage of the total spend and predominantly experienced in ‘indirect categories’ where stakeholders opt to offer business to alternate sources.
A cry for attention. Used to hail a boat or a ship.
Syn.: manufacturing instructions.
Mobile truck equipment with the capacity for lifting a container within its own framework.
Trips of 100 miles or more.

Association of Southeast Asian Nation is an organisation formed in 1967 to promote economic growth, social progress, cultural development, and peace in Southeast Asia. Member countries include Brunei, Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.
The part of a service operation that is completed without direct customer contact.

A tool to aid decision-making with respect to an identified transportation need; evaluates cost and effectiveness of alternatives; required by ISTEA when a need for a major metropolitan transportation investment (MMTI) is identified and federal funds are potentially involved.

Includes measurements for how well the company has adhered to the procurement schedule, the distribution schedule, the warehousing schedule, the transportation schedule, and the manufacturing schedule.
Abbreviation for: Land and Hold Short Operation.
The design contest is a procedure used to obtain a plan or a design based on competition among expert parties. The design is judged by a professional jury.

term: Average Annual Production Materials/Related A/P (Accounts payable)
definition: The value of direct materials acquired in that year for which payment has not yet been made. Production-related materials are those items classified as material purchases and included in the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) as raw material purchases. Calculate: Use the 5-point Annual Average.

A system or process that initiates action by end users or locations, rather than by a consolidated central organisation that pushes data, goods, or services to those points based on its own parameters.
A fixed price contract with a provision for rewarding the vendor for faster delivery or superior performance.

1. The practice of relating resources, activities, and cost objects using the drivers underlying their cost-causal relationships. The purpose of tracing is to observe and understand how costs are arising in the normal course of business operations. Syn.: Assignment. 2. Determining a shipment’s location during the course of a move.
Financial instruments that are intended to provide security against expenses and losses that result from a failure by a supplier to perform its obligations.
Loaded vessels lashed tightly, one on each side of another vessel, and then emptied to provide additional buoyancy that reduces the draught of the ship in the middle.
Computer model used to determine motor vehicle emissions (in lbs.) based on emission factors for a given assumed fleet mix of older and newer motor vehicles.
1.Port charge relating to a vessel moored at approved anchorage site in a harbour. 2.A suitable place for a ship to anchor. Area of a port or harbour.
A data distribution that is not symmetric, or that shows distortion in a positive or negative direction.

Contracts where the buyer is in no position to bargain effectively with the seller. In this context, the seller presents a “take it or leave it” contract for the purchase of goods with the intent to take advantage of the buyer’s lack of knowledge and sophistication.
Any learning programme set out in the learning programme matrix.
Abbreviation for: Airport Noise and Capacity Act.

One of a family of traditional paddled long boats of various designs and sizes found throughout Asia, Africa, and the Pacific Islands. For competitive events, they are generally rigged with decorative Chinese dragon heads and tails. Dragon boat races are traditionally held during the annual summer solstice festival.
Abbreviation for: Delivered Duty Paid (Incoterms) and Distributed Data Processing.
Measured in two ways: 1. By the number of damage occurrences per 1000 shipments, or 2. Claims dollars paid as a percentage of Cost of Goods.

“Paying” the devil is sealing the devil seam. It is a difficult and unpleasant job (with no resources) because of the shape of the seam (up against the stanchions) or if the devil refers to the garboard seam, it must be done with the ship slipped or careened.
Abbreviation for: Profitable to Promise.
An Incoterm of sale meaning the seller delivers to the buyer at seller’s named premises.
Those items of cost related to the activities associated with the movement and storage of finished products. This can include inventory costs, transportation costs, and order processing costs.
A sourcing strategy in which the buying firm shares its business across multiple suppliers.
Planning that covers a shorter period, usually 12 to 24 months out, although the planning horizon may be longer in industries with very long lead (e.g., engineer-to-order firms).
Abbreviation for: Technology Implementation Group.

Abbreviation for: Commercial Vehicle Information Systems and Networks (CVISN). A national program administered by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration designed to improve motor carrier safety and to enhance the efficiency of administrative processes for industry and government.
An open case. The term is often used interchangeably with “repack” or “less- than-full-case” to name the area in which materials are picked in that form.

The large-scale introduction of manufacturing, advanced technical enterprises, and other value-adding productive economic activities into an area, society, or country. The purpose of industrialisation is largely value addition to local resources before local or international consumption.
A lightly armoured steam-powered river gunboat used by the United States Navy during the American Civil War (1861–1865).
The use of credit cards to help manage and control small expenditures with many suppliers..
Value is the exchange for which a customer pays. A product or service’s capability provided to a customer at the right time, at an appropriate price, as defined in each case by the customer.
“Warehouse in a box” concept where specialised equipment can go to almost any location to process outbound shipments.
Two containers, one on top of the other, loaded on a railroad flatcar; an intermodal service.
Abbreviation for: Distributed Execution System and Delivered ex. Ship (Incoterms).
Abbreviation for: Incubator Support Programme.

A method of fixing together two pieces of wood, usually overlapping planks, by driving a nail through both planks as well as a washer-like rove. The nail is then burred or riveted over to complete the fastening.
An entity, such as personnel or equipment, that performs activities or services and normally has a cost associated with that performance.
Abbreviation for: Partner Integration Process.
A systematic investigation of the extent to which (technical) processes are capable of meeting established standards in a predictable way.
A firm engaged in providing commercial motor freight or long distance trucking.

The authorisation for use (‘‘protocol”) of RFID transmission frequencies is governed by local law. A tag ideally should be readable worldwide, but local laws mandate regional variations in reader configurations
A rate made up of two or more factors, separately published.
Abbreviation for: Evaluation and Appraisal Report. A periodic review and evaluation of a local government’s comprehensive plan; generally due every five years.
National Communications System.
Abbreviation for: Operational Acceptable Level of Traffic.
Abbreviation for: Vendor Owned Inventory.
The element of the triple bottom line that assesses an organisation’s performance in terms of how it affects the natural environment.
Abbreviation for: Planning and Service Area, Public Service Announcement, Public Service Act, and Public Service Association.
A document used to detail proposed goods or services requirements and invites responses and bids from prospective suppliers.
Order to restrict the hauling of freight. A government’s total ban on trade with a specific country.
Best possible outcome from a negotiation
The part of the hold of a ship within the angle of the bow.
The process of putting small box shipments into a larger carton, also called over packing or strapping cases together.
Refers to the placing of purchase orders at a supplier against previously arranged conditions or when orders are placed directly at the supplier, without questioning the supplier’s conditions.
A legal entity denoting the legal relationship that exists between two parties, in which one is authorised to perform or transact specified business activities for the other.
Abbreviation for: Notices To Airmen Publication.

The use of software and computer hardware in developing engineering drawings and designs and accessing stored product and engineering data and history. CAD systems allow for multiple iterations, views and comparisons of proposed designs.
Abbreviation for: Estimate of National Expenditure.
Abbreviation for: Property, Plant & Equipment.
If the material or product fails to meet the quality or other specification warranted by the supplier breach of warranty is said to have occurred
Measurement information. Control charts based on variable data include average (X-bar) chart, range (R) chart, and sample standard deviation(s) chart.
Software that integrates all the common activities in project management.
Rules administered by the U.S. Department of Transportation that limit the maximum time a driver may drive in interstate commerce; both daily and weekly maximums are prescribed.
Cabinet level department in the United States Government, charged with developing energy and safety policies and guidelines regarding the handling of nuclear material within the United States.

In monetary theory, the use of someone else’s assets in exchange for a promise to pay (usually with interest) at a later date. The major examples are shortterm loans from a bank, credit extended by a supplier, and commercial paper. In balance of payment accounting, an item such as exports that earns a country foreign currency.

Those activities and/or processes that must be completed and/or controlled to enable a company to reach its goals. Necessary conditions for success that can be measured quantitatively for effectiveness, economy, and efficiency; those few areas where satisfactory performance is essential in order for a business to succeed; characteristics, conditions, or variables that have a direct influence on a customer’s satisfaction with a specific business process; the set of things that must be done right if a vision is to be achieved
Synonym: Lot size.
The shaft or hole in the side of a vessel’s bow through which the anchor chain passes.
A government document which permits the “Licensee” to engage in the export of designated goods to certain destinations.
The command given to come about (tack through the wind) on a sailing boat.
Products designed, produced, and controlled by a store, carrying the store’s name or a brand owned by the store. Also known as a store brand or dealer brand.

A discount or reduction from a list price based on the position of the purchaser in the distribution channel, for example as a distributor, retailer, or original equipment manufacturer. Trade-In Value: The value obtained when trading one piece of equipment for another.
Abbreviation for: Crypto Ancillary Unit.
The transaction or interchange that occurs at the time a container is received by a rail terminal or water port from another carrier.

In computer science, a group of logical operations that must all succeed or fail as a group. Systems dedicated to supporting such operations are known a transaction processing systems. Examples would include bill payment, credit card processing.
Products that are produced by an operation to support its services.
Losses of inventory resulting from scrap, deterioration, pilferage, etc.
By means into the wind, while large means with the wind. “By and large” is used to indicate all possible situations. I.e. “the ship handles well both by and large.”
Abbreviation for: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

A production step or activity with a defined start and stop time that may be composed of individual tasks, but is not broken down into smaller increments in rate and capacity calculations. Unlike designating material used on a bill of material, a product routing has flexibility in grouping or splitting individual operations based on the commonality of the resources and rates involved.

A quality philosophy based on the idea that a level of perfect quality, as in zero defects, is achievable and should be a company-wide goal. It emphasises the examination of all factors that lead to quality problems versus a system that builds in an average or acceptable quality level.

A combination of hardware and software that allows a person to ask questions and provide answers by pressing keys on their touch-tone phone. IVR systems are used to automate data entry, eliminating the need for 24-hour staffing of very routine jobs.
The transfer of cargo from one conveyance to another.

Order shipping documentation that includes returns information and a ship label with authorization for return. Used in instances when a product can be returned without contacting a customer for authorization.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Computer Complex.
A specialised form of an optimisation model that attempts to assign limited capacity to various demand points in a way that minimises costs.

1. A small stowage locker at the aft end of a boat. 2. A ship or building used for quarantine of sick patients. 3. An area on some merchant ships where provisions are stored. 4. In modern shipbuilding and on powerboats of all sizes, the location of the steering gear equipment for the vessel.
Special pennant flown to indicate the absence of a commanding officer, admiral, chief of staff, or officer whose flag is flying (division, squadron, or flotilla commander).
A small boat, traditionally a coastal or river craft, for leisure or fishing, with a single person or small crew. Sailing skiffs have developed into high performance competitive classes.
Abbreviation for: Ocean Shipping Advice.
Total weight of a loaded combination vehicle, such as a tractor-semi trailer or truck and full trailer(s).
Using programs, including price, new product launch, trade and sales incentives, promotions, and marketing programs, to increase what customers want to buy.
Abbreviation for Activity-on-Node Network.
Abbreviation for: Manufacturing Automation and Design Exploration.
To transfer goods from one transportation line to another or from one ship to another.
A term used to describe those items where you don’t have much influence in the market and that are not business critical
Software programs that provide self-paced student instruction, tests, and learning feedback with no, or only periodic, involvement by an instructor.
Abbreviation for: Group Technology.

The stock resulting from the assessment of an all-time requirement and delivery of an all-time order. If necessary, controls can be set for such stock to avoid consumption of items for reasons over and above those for which usage was predicted.
Abbreviation for Regulation Identification Number. Identification number given to each federal action listed in the Unified Agenda of Federal Regulations.
Sophisticated, computer-controlled systems that manage the mixtures of gases within a container throughout an intermodal journey reducing decay.
Pertaining to work performed when demand is present.

A deep data-gathering approach to examine the individual attribute or features of a product (or service) and to identify measures that allow direct comparison of attributes and entire products (or services) on to another. The purpose of attribute analyses is to identify opportunities for improvement by direct comparison.

Data describing the characteristics of inbound, outbound, or internal orders (outbound is most common). Examples of characteristics incorporated into an order profile could include: line items per order, pieces per order, weight per order, cube per order, time of day, destination, shipment method, order type, etc. Characteristics are often broken into logical groups such as breaking line items per order into groups of items.
Abbreviation for: Human Resources.
See: Boatswain’s Call.
To heave up (an anchor) preparatory to sailing.
The extent to which a supplying resource satisfies customer requirements, often expressed in terms of error rate, resource availability, or accuracy in meeting requested dates.
Abbreviation for: Lead-in Lights.
A chiefly British term for a narrow clinker-built skiff having outriggers, for one oarsman.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain and Logistics Association of Canada.

A method by which two or more EDI trading partners periodically report conformity to agreed upon standards of control, and audit. Management produces statements of compliance, which briefly note any exceptions, as well as corrective action planned or taken, in accordance with operating rules. Auditors produce an independent and objective statement of opinion on management statements.
A law limiting the time in which claims or suits may be instituted.
A leg has an origin, destination, and carrier and is composed of all consecutive segments of a route booked through the same carrier. Also called “Bookable Leg.”
Abbreviation for: Drop and Insert Point.
Total assets less total liabilities.
Abbreviation for: Baltic and International Maritime Council, the world’s largest private shipping organization.
Abbreviation for: Systems Development Life Cycle.

Learning approach originally consisting of observing and analyzing the management of certain processes in a company, operating in a different business, but with comparable challenges. By extension, benchmarking now designates the approach of comparing a company’s performance for a given process (the logistics process, for example) to that of the leader in their sector.
National Research Council (Canada) and Non-recurring Charge.
A count performed when shipments are received in order to track and record their condition.

A thinking process tool, used in the theory of constraints to focus attention on the management and improvement of a system and its constraint. The steps include: 1. Identify the constraint. 2. Exploit the constraint. 3. Subordinate other activities to the constraint. 4. Elevate the performance of the constraint. 5. Prevent inertia from setting in.
The person/entity to whom an offer is made usually in response to a Request for Proposal (RFP).
A reason or defense for proceeding with a purchase in a non-competitive environment, such as a sole source.
Finished Goods.

Overhead costs that change as a result of changes in production volume, but cannot be directly traced to a given product or line. For example, utility costs that increase for a given facility in proportion to increased overall levels of production.
A design process that creates products and processes with automatic or integrated test and measurement systems.
A retail location that ultimately sells your product to consumers, but who purchases your products from an intermediary, like a distributor or wholesaler.

A body of theory based on applied statistics which suggests that productivity levels can improve rate as people and even systems “learn” to do tasks more efficiently. In formal terms, learning curve theory states that for every doubling of cumulative output, there is a set percentage reduction in the amount of inputs required.
Abbreviation for: Trade Unit Number. A barcode that describes multiple units of APNs in packs or shippers.
The overall long-term approach to ensuring that an organisation’s human resources provide a strategic advantage.

A 5-year plan, updated annually, developed by each state agency to achieve state goals, agency program objectives and the service outcomes from those programs. It provides the framework for developing agency budget requests and related performance measures.
A flat deck used for the launch and recovery of aircraft.

A corporate strategy that has identified a focus on time as providing a competitive edge due to its value by the customer. It may assume no advantage in product or quality characteristics while focusing on the reduction of variability and total design, production, and delivery lead time.
Types of spend by commodity, department, or supply base.
A container fitted with a rear door and a minimum of one side door.
A name usually given to a state body having control or regulation of public utilities.
A railroad charge for a shipper’s exclusive use of special equipment.
Abbreviation for: Consortium for Advanced Manufacturing –International.
Stipulations typically located at the end of the contract document, specifying how the parties to the contract should govern their relationship and administer the contract.

Any ship which is used primarily in commerce: 1. For transporting persons or goods to or from any harbour(s) or port(s) or between places within a harbour area; 2. In connection with the construction, change in construction, servicing, maintenance, repair, loading, unloading, movement, piloting, or salvaging of any other ship or vessel.
The Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, an international organisation of 11 oil-exporting nations, which coordinates and unifies the petroleum policies of its member countries.
Abbreviation for: Administrative Data Transmission Network
Abbreviation for: Uniform Freight Classification.
Abbreviation for: Digital Still Camera.
Abbreviation for: Enhanced Vortex Advisory System.
A multi-hour period in which travel is greatest.

A long range (20-year) strategy and capital improvement program developed to guide the effective investment of public funds in transportation facilities. The plan is updated every three years and may be amended as a result of changes in projected federal, state and local funding, major improvement studies, congestion management system plans, interstate interchange justification studies and environmental impact studies.
Abbreviation for: Baltic Panamax Index.
National Association of Purchasing Managers (USA).
The need to align network-design decisions to the company’s overall strategy.
An observed value so far removed from the normal distribution that it may be considered an abnormality or one-time event.
The functions, processes, and department that source materials and services, negotiate terms, respond to material requests, and manage order status.
Duplicating information from a PC to a diskette, ensuring information is available in case of loss or damage.
Abbreviation for: Mass Customisation.
The carrier charges and fees applied when rail freight cars, ship, and carriers are retained beyond a specified loading or unloading time.
The time taken to manufacture or produce an item after an external order has been received until the item is available for packing.
A study of the vulnerability of supply chains to disruption.

A contract which provides for contractor payment based on a direct labor, hourly rate that includes benefits, payroll taxes, overhead and contractor profit and for the cost of materials and equipment used in performance of the contract.
Relates to a situation when the organisation wants to purchase a new product from a known supplier, or an existing product from a new supplier.

An order issued by a seller against a purchaser; directs payment, usually through an intermediary bank. Typical bank drafts are negotiable instruments and are similar in many ways to checks on checking accounts in a bank.
A hand-held movable device passed over an item to read its barcode.
A charge made against a carrier for loss, damage, delay, or overcharge.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Secondary Radar Service.
Pulling a function back in-house as an outsourcing contract expires.
A technical rail ramp, used for equalisation of points not actually served.

Abbreviation for: Roadway Congestion Index. A tool used to identify congestion on freeways and principal arterials; compares daily vehicle miles of travel per lane-mile to calculated daily vehicle miles of travel per lane-mile for identified congested conditions; an index value of 1.0 or greater indicates undesirable congestion.
A term used in work study to indicate the extra time allowed for rest, relaxation, and personal needs.
Abbreviation for Raster Navigational Chart.
A label, generally both human- and machine-readable by an automatic scanning device. Often used in shipping.
A document or entry program used to record actual labour time against an order or project that may also specify the operation, location, and category or type of task being performed.
The ability to provide a new product with minimal delay.
A European agreement on the international carriage of dangerous goods by road.
A detailed map that identifies the specific activities forming the informational, physical, and/or monetary flow of a process.

The principle of assuming that the contents of a shipment are the same as those presented on a shipping or delivery note. Shipping and receiving personnel do not check the delivery quantity. This practice is used in conjunction with barcodes and an EDI-delivered ASN to eliminate invoices and facilitate rapid receiving.
Abbreviation for: Maintenance Control Centre.
Abbreviation for: Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon.
A characteristic of an outcome or item that is accounted for by its presence or absence, such as “defective” versus “good” or “late” versus “on-time."
Country in which the goods have been produced or manufactured.
Abbreviation for: Decision Support System.

An industrial vehicle used to tow carts through a warehouse or production facility. Tuggers are typically used when materials need to be moved over long distances, and will typically tow multiple carts at a time. Tuggers may also be called “Tow Vehicles” or “Tow Tractors.”
Computer software for analysing the capacity of signalised and non-signalised intersections and their level of service.
The area alongside a quay or the state of being moored at a quay.
Four major principles underlie each of the procurement directives: non-discrimination, equality, transparency, and proportionality.
Refers to: Tower (non-controlled).
Expenditure on goods and services acquired to be part of the good or service being created for sale.
The management of inventories, addressing primarily the questions such as how much quantity to hold, when to order and how much to order for an item.

Inventory management approach based on collaboration between manufacturers and distributors developed as part of ECR. Based on a defined continuous restocking plan, the two partners use EDI to exchange information concerning orders and stock movements so that the supplier can replenish distributor warehouses. In the same model, inventory management can be assigned to a third party, that is, a Logistics Service Provider.
Contractual relationship where parties pursue different objectives.

A method to determine the most efficient program, when competing programs exist, that are designed to meet the same objective. This analysis is conducted by using the measures of cost and anticipated benefits of the competing programs to determine which program produces the greatest net benefits. Then funds (budget) may be allocated appropriately to that most beneficial program.
A policy aimed at stimulating long term inclusive socio-economic development to help reduce poverty, increase local value add, industrialisation and local job creation.
A slang term for oilskins, the foul-weather clothing worn by sailors. Also see: oilskins.

Organisations, groups or individuals who, under contract or agreement, provide products or services to the organisation which it defines as vital to success. Significant time and attention should be spent with these suppliers to develop joint values, shared understanding of strategic direction, and joint problem solving methods.
Abbreviation for: Environmentally Sustainable Electronics.
The idea that the mix and volume of activity should even out over time so as to make output routine and regular, sometimes known by the Japanese term ‘heijunka.’
The quantity of an item shown in the inventory records as being physically in stock.
Abbreviation for: Facility Master File.
See: Ships.
Raster Chart Display Systems.
A protruding bulb at a ship’s bow below the waterline, modifying water flow around the hull to reduce drag, increase speed, fuel efficiency, and stability.
Issued in connection with documents such as letters of credit, tariffs, etc. to advise that stated provisions will expire at a certain time.
Abbreviation for: Technology for Women in Business.
Data that relate to people’s size, shape, and other physical abilities, which is used in the design of jobs and physical facilities.
A prioritized report of released production orders for a manufacturing facility or specific department.
Abbreviation for: Very High Frequency.

The interrelationship among system variables indicates that a change in one variable has cost impact upon other variables. A cost reduction in one variable may be at the expense of increased cost for other variables, and vice versa.
Abbreviation for: Association of Manufacturing Excellence.
A direct line between two points (which might cross land) which is the way crows travel rather than ships which must go around land.
A version of exponential smoothing where the smoothing (alpha) factor is automatically adjusted, or adapted, based on interpretations of observed forecast error.

Some U.S., state, city and parish government jobs are protected under civil service systems which are designed to provide a degree of security to employees and to deter nepotism, political patronage, and arbitrary treatment of workers.
Abbreviation for: On Line Analytical Processing.
The stock level at which it is time to place another order for materials (generally the lead time demand plus safety stock minus any stock on order).
Abbreviation for: World Wide Web Consortium.

The purpose of open innovation is to create close collaboration on research and development, new product design and development and market introduction with parties that would share the company’s business interests in such collaboration.
Storage racking equipment that has side rails to enable warehouse operators to stack product high in deep rows. It provides access only from aisles.
Integrated Disbursement and Information System.
Contractor designs and provides in accordance with the client’s requirements, plant and/or other works.

A concept which describes the psychology, attitudes, experiences, beliefs and values (personal and cultural values) of an organisation. The values and customs shared by people and groups in an organisation which govern how they interact with each other, and with outside organisations.
the meaning defined in the Code of good practice on key Aspects of Disability in the workplace issued under section 54of the employment Equity Act.
Abbreviation for: Instrument Approach Procedures Automation.
Keeping the warehouse presentable, organised, and safe for all parties.

A contract scorecard is one of the approaches that can be used to measure the performance of a contract. It provides both the parties an understanding of progress and performance. The scorecard aligns the parties on the measurement parameters and process of measurement. Frequently used measures include financial performance, KPIs and overall outcomes.

Independent computer systems, owned by independent organisations or entities, linked in a manner
to allow one system to retrieve information from another. For example, a customer’s computer system is able to retrieve an order status from a supplier’s computer.
1. A rope (line) leading from gaff to either side of the deck, used to prevent the gaff from sagging. 2. See: Boom vang on page 73
A certified document showing the origin of goods; used in international commerce.
Used for securing goods onto a pallet. Can be metal or plastic.
Abbreviation for: Input/Output.
A quality perspective that holds that quality must be judged, in part, by how well the characteristic of a particular product or service align with the needs of a specific user.

Typically, the length of time from the purchase of raw materials to the collection of payment from customers. In retail settings it may refer to the length of time from sales to payment receipt. Also see: Cash-to-Cash Cycle Time.
A key measure that represents the central tendency of a group of samples used in conjunction with range (R).

A type of order point replenishment system where the “min” (minimum) is the order point, and the “max” (maximum) is the “order up to” inventory level. The order quantity is variable and is the result of the max minus the available and on-order inventory. An order is recommended when the sum of the available and on-order inventory is at or below the min.

Three Japanese terms often used together in the Toyota Production System (and called the Three Ms) that collectively describe wasteful practices to be eliminated. Muda: Any activity that consumes resources without creating value for the customer. Mura: Unevenness in an operation; for example, an uneven work pace in an operation causing operators to hurry and then wait. Muri: Overburdening equipment or operators.
Objective method(s) employed to determine, in a quantified form, the actual status of a process variable or product attribute.
The ability of a system to handle increased volume or complexity.
Contractor delivers project or work turnkey.
Freight payable to the carrier at the port of discharge, or ultimate destination. The consignee does not pay the freight charge if the cargo does not arrive at the destination.
A project task with no predecessor or successor.

A suggested production, purchase, or replenishment order generated by an MRP, or other planning system, to meet a projected shortage against desired safety stock levels. The shortage date becomes the due date, the release date is backward scheduled based on lead time, and the quantity is based on the specified lot size. Planned orders for upper-level items create requirements for lower-level components, and MRP generations delete existing planned orders and regenerate new ones based on changes in requirements. Planned orders must be firmed or accepted before releasing to production or to a vendor.
Cargo-securing devices mounted in a container floor for lashing and securing cargo.

Threshold values represent the purchasing volumes beyond which public institutions are obliged to follow European legislation when making purchasing decisions. Different threshold values exist for work, suppliers, and services.

1. Differentiated from goods through four basic characteristics, i.e. intangibility, perishability, heterogeneity, and simultaneity. Basically, four types of services can be identified: (1) component services, that are passed on unaltered to the final customers of the buying organisation (e.g. luggage handling at the airport for an airline company), (2) semi-manufactured services, that are being integrated into the buying organisation’s value proposition to its customers (e.g. in-flight catering services contracted for by an airline), (3) instrumental services, that are used by the buying organisation to change their primary processes (i.e. management consultancy to professionalise the airline’s operational processes) and (4) consumption services, that are used in different support processes within the buying organisation (e.g. cleaning services for offices of the same airline company). 2. Relate to a series of more or less tangible activities, which normally take place in the interaction between customer and supplier employees and/or physical resources and systems, which are offered as an integrated solution to customer problems.
The width of a ship.
A device that transmits a radio signal to power passive RFID tags and receives information back from passive and active tags. It converts radio waves into data that can be used by a computer system.
Abbreviation for: Good Manufacturing Practices.
Abbreviation for: Corporate Average Fuel Economy. Federal fuel efficiency standards for automobiles.
Abbreviation for: Materials Review Board.
Abbreviation for: Fast Moving Consumer Goods.
A specified limit for the total dollar sum of open orders for a given customer or vendor that is checked by the system at entry time, and may prevent acceptance of the order.
Abbreviation for: Distributed Transaction Processing.
The strake closest to the keel (from Dutch gaarboard).
A device to correct the ship’s compass, for example, counteracting errors due to the magnetic effects of a steel hull.
Method of chartering a ship leaving the charterer with almost all the responsibilities of the owner.

Monetary value of qualifying contributions made by the measure Entity to a beneficiary in the form of grants, donations, discounts that are similar quantifiable benefits which are not recoverable by the measured Entity.
Activities used to detect and remove special causes of variation to maintain or restore statistical control, leading to quality control.
Change is a condition that disrupts the current state.
An arrangement for giving every package of material moved an identifying tag, usually a barcode or magnetic strip.
A formula for calculating the optimum order quantity.
Abbreviation for: NWS Regional Headquarters.

The set of processes used in the theory of constraints to manage the buffers used to ensure continued operation of the constraint. Activities and materials processing operations are prioritised on the basis of their criticality to maintaining or rebuilding buffer stock
A short-range communications network enabled by Bluetooth technology. A PAN typically covers only a few feet and allows a wireless scanning device to communicate with a mobile computer or printer.
A program that triggers the manufacturing and movement of product through the supply chain when the identical product is purchased by an end user.
See: Indicator
A matrix indicating four quadrants, representing four basic supply strategies. Based upon financial impact and supply risk represented by a specific product category.
Abbreviation for: Life Cycle Assessment.
The space taken up on a truck by one Chep pallet, nominally 1.2m x 1.0m x 1.385m high.

1.
