A basis point is a unit that is equal to 1/100th of 1%, and is often used instead of percentages when discussing interest rates, rates of return, and other percentage-based performance metrics that can occur as fractions of a percent. 1% change = 100 basis points, and 0.01% = 1 basis point. 2. One one-hundredth of one percent. Used primarily to describe changes in yield or price on debt instruments, including mortgages and mortgage-backed securities.
The number of pallets, rolls, and skids that can be safely stacked on top of each other; the client supplies this information.
A container designed with openings in the side and/or end walls to permit the ingress of outside air when the doors are closed.
Comprises the money that measured Entity spends on skills development. It excludes the skills development levy payable by the measured Entity under the Skills Development Levies Act of South Africa.
Conveyer that moves product using wheels.

Specification that a project task, shipment, or delivery may not occur before a given date. Early product shipments are normally considered as a negative in evaluating delivery performance due to customer storage space or payment considerations.

This procedure acknowledges two distinct stages: the stage of selecting suppliers that are interested, and the stage in which the preselected suppliers are invited for tender. It is also referred to as the procedure with pre-selection
Collection of computer programs in symbolic representation.
An iterative four-step problem-solving process typically used in business process improvement. It is also known as the Shewhart cycle, Deming Wheel, or Plan-Do-Study-Act.
A shore downwind of a ship. A ship which cannot sail well to windward risks being blown onto a lee shore and grounded.
See: Green Supply Chain Management.
An intermediate level assembly used in the production of an upper level.

A tiered structure within a building used to provide worker access to various levels. Mezzanines can be free-standing structures supported by posts and trusses, or can be a series of walkways supported by storage equipment (rack-supported mezzanine).
The incorporation of the operation’s impact on its stakeholders into operations management decisions.

The responsibility of an organisation for managing the funds and resources entrusted to it by its member states and other donors in an ethical and transparent manner, and for the welfare and in the interest of the designated beneficiaries of the funds and resources entrusted.
Regional Economic Community.
Preparing to deal with calamities (e.g. floods) and non-calamitous situations (e.g. strikes) before they occur.
Shallow draught, making the vessel capable of sailing in unusually shallow water.
Abbreviation for: Television Microwave Link.

A (supplier) partner is defined as a firm with whom your company has an ongoing buyer-seller relationship, involving a commitment over an extended period, a mutual sharing of information and a sharing of risks and rewards resulting from the relationship.
Abbreviation for: Production/Operations Management.
To re-book cargo to a later vessel.
Goods of which any one unit is similar to other units or where the qualities marketed by various producers are treated as equivalent or nearly similar, e.g. grains.
Abbreviation for: Quick Response Program.

Each or eaches refers to the units you are using (either in physical processes or in your inventory system). In most cases eaches implies you are using the smallest possible unit of measure (the individual pieces).

A measure, usually expressed as a percentage, of the costs incurred to hold inventory as a result of the cost of the item itself, insurance, obsolescence, theft, damage, use of storage facilities, and other causes.
Abbreviation for: Code of Federal Regulations. Compilation of the rules of the executive department and agencies of the federal government.
Removing cargo from a container (devanning).
Measures of quality that can take one of two states, for example, right or wrong, works or does not work, etc.

A carrier giving a customer illegal preference to attract cargo. This can take the form of a money refund (rebate); using lower figures than actual for the assessment of freight charges (under-cubing); misdeclaration of the commodity shipped to allow the assessment of a lower tariff rate; waiving published tariff charges for demurrage, CFS handling or equalisation; providing specialised equipment to a shipper to the detriment of other shippers, etc.
A partial refund of an import fee. Refund usually results because goods are re-exported from the country that collected the fee.
Raw material, ingredient, part, or subassembly that goes into a higher level assembly, compound, or other part.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Funds Transfer. Where payment is made electronically directly into a bank account.
An organisation that organises other 3rd party logistics partners for outsourcing of logistics functions.
The process of pulling a set of component items from stock to group them for production or for movement to another area. Kitting is usually done for a specific production or sales order.
Abbreviation for: Supplementary Aviation Weather Reporting System.
Abbreviation for: Free on Rail.
A situation where a buyer asks for bids from different suppliers, creating a level playing field (identical to tender).
Federal Communications Commission and Finance Control Committee.
A South African Government initiative aimed at stimulating growth for people carrier vehicles in the country.
The visible hull section of a vessel above the waterline. Also known as topsides.
Abbreviation for: Differential Global Positioning System.
A boat on sentry duty, or one placed on a line forward of a position to warn against an enemy advance.

Term used to describe the running of the programs that convert demand into planned orders. Depending on the operation, MRP Generation may be run daily, weekly, or even monthly. Since this processing requires a lot of system resources it is generally confined to off hours or weekend processing.
Polyethylene or similar substance heat– treated and shrunk into an envelope around several units, thereby securing them as a single pack for presentation or to secure units on a pallet.
See: Self-sustaining
See: Zone Picking
Abbreviation for: Independent Public Trade Exchange.
A work study technique that attempts to assess a worker’s rate of working relative to the observer’s concept of standard performance– controversial and now accepted as being an ambiguous process.
Manufacturers’ scheduling approach which assumes there is a finite production capacity.
The British system of authorising naval construction by an annual bill in Parliament.
A product delivered or used in production with a low frequency or in relatively low numbers per period.
Part of the principles of just-in-time which relates to the elimination of waste by having only required materials when needed.
A pre-determined stock level such that, if the net stock falls to or below it, action is taken to replenish stock.
1. Treating old sails with oil or wax to renew them. 2. A verbal reprimand.

A scheduling technique that uses the goal of making every product every day and only when required by demand, as opposed to large runs of individual items that will stay in stock for a period of time. It normally requires operating flexibility, short lead times, and small lot sizes.
A variable that can be measured along a continuous scale, such as weight, length, height, and temperature.
Seller is responsible for the cost of placing the goods at a named point of exportation. Some European buyers use this form when they actually mean FOB vessel.
An enabling wind shift that allows a close hauled sailboat to point up from its current course to a more favourable one. This is the opposite of a header.
National Institute of Standards and Technology.
An understanding between buyer and seller as to the meaning of certain words, phrases and characteristics of a given item or service that are established by agreement or general usage.
See: Boatswain’s Chair.
When used in medium-term capacity management, it indicates the temporary use of other operations to perform some tasks, or even produce whole products or services, during times of high demand.
The construction system employed in container vessels; permits ship containers to be stowed in a vertical line with each container supporting the one above it.

Generally describes an item made of metal or plastic that is produced by forcing the raw material through a die (extruding). The result being a long item with a uniform shape throughout the length. Extrusions will often (though not always) require cutting and other machining processes to turn them into a finished item.
Abbreviation for: Air Route Traffic Control Centre.
Abbreviation for: International Air Traffic Authority and International Air Transport Association.

1.Forecasting of future demand for a family of products, or for a single product, across multiple dimensions of source – including planned production and customer orders.  2.An estimate of sales, often time phased, for a grouping of products or product families produced by a manufacturing facility or firm. Stated in terms of units or dollars, or both, the aggregate forecast is used for sales and aggregate planning purposes.
Locations in the supply chain for performing logistic activities, often including stocks and warehousing.

term: CHARTERED INSTITUTE OF PURCHASING AND SUPPLY (CIPS)
definition: The world’s largest procurement and supply professional organisation, A global not-for-profit organisation, with regional offices around the world in the UK, Africa, Australia, MENA and soon in China, supporting corporates, public sector and SMEs in all sectors
Abbreviation for: 1.Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals. 2.Certified Supply Chain Management Professional (OI PMAC –Canada).
Stop, cease, or desist from whatever is being done. From Dutch hou’ vast (“hold on”).
Assets required for the process to complete the activities necessary to produce a specified output (work product); that which the process transforms into an output.
Abbreviation for: Governments Incorporating Procurement Policies to Eliminate Refuse.
A branch of work study that is concerned with measuring the time that should be taken for performing jobs.
Delay in start-up. An insurance policy to protect the seller of a construction project from penalties if the project is not completed on time.
Synonymous with workflow.

A computer term for the following: 1. Highest subdivision of the Internet, for the most part by country (except in the U.S., where it is by type of organisation, such as educational, commercial, and government). Usually the last part of a host name; for example, the domain part of ibm.com is .com, which represents the domain of commercial sites in the U.S. 2. In corporate data networks, a group of client computers controlled by a server system.
Abbreviation for: Enterprise Development.
Abbreviation for: American Trucking Association and Air Transport Association of America.
Refers to: En Route Equipment Systems.
A formal, long-term relationship between organisations, which involves a mutual sharing of information, risks, and rewards.

Rail cars grouped in a train by destination so that segments (blocks) can be uncoupled and routed to different destinations as the train moves through various junctions. Eliminates the need to break up a train and sort individual rail cars at each junction.
Abbreviation for: Trade Related Investment Measures.
A manufacturing operation done instead of the standard or normal operation. Typically used due to short-term material or capacity shortages.
Vehicles used for industrial purposes. Generally used to transport materials and personnel within industrial facilities. Lift trucks (forklifts) are the most well-known type of industrial truck.

Forms of production waste identified by Taiichi Ohno, specified as: overproduction vs. demand, idle time, unnecessary transport, inventory, excess processing, excess operator motion, and production of defective parts. The categorisation of the seven major wastes typically found in mass production: 1. Overproduction: Producing ahead of what’s actually needed by the next process or customer. The worst form of waste because it contributes to the other six. 2. Waiting: Operators standing idle as machines cycle, equipment fails, needed parts fail to arrive, etc. 3. Conveyance: Moving parts and products unnecessarily, such as from a processing step to a warehouse to a subsequent processing step when the second step instead could be located immediately adjacent to the first step. 4. Processing: Performing unnecessary or incorrect processing, typically from poor tool or product design. 5. Inventory: Having more than the minimum stocks necessary for a precisely controlled pull system. 6. Motion: Operators making movements that are straining or unnecessary, such as looking for parts, tools, documents, etc. 7. Correction: Inspection, rework and scrap.
The process of housing or storing materials and packages in larger quantities, generally using the original packaging or shipping containers or boxes.
Services provided to the customer after products have been delivered. This can include repairs, maintenance, and/or telephone support. Syn.: field service.
Abbreviation for: Maximum Authorised Altitude.
A load that is picked up at the warehouse by the customer (usually within the same day that the order is placed).
The set of expected benefits to the customer encapsulated in a product or service design.
A report of on-hand inventory that may also include days of supply, allocation, and availability information.
Maritime punishment: to punish by dragging under the keel of a ship.
A method of surveying the underwater parts of a ship while it is still afloat instead of having to drydock it for examination of these areas as was conventionally done.
Area in the warehouse that is used to accommodate the loading and unloading of trailers.
The amount of debt a lender deems manageable before granting a loan.
Tacking away from the wind in a square-rigged vessel. Also see: Gybe.

A linked set of manufacturing equipment or workstations that sequentially process a standard group of products or product families; most often used in a high-volume, repetitive manufacturing environment.
A private carrier hauling the goods of a subsidiary and charging the subsidiary a fee: this is legal if the subsidiary is wholly owned (100%) or if the private carrier has common carrier authority.
A highest level, end-item assembly that fills customer order or inter plant demand and is not used as a sub assembly for other items.

term: Customer Receipt of Order to Installation Complete
definition: Average lead-time from receipt of goods at the customer to the time when installation (if applicable) is complete, including the following sub-elements: time to get product up and running, and product acceptance by customer (An element of Order Fulfilment Lead Time).
Abbreviation for: Contracts for the International Sale of Goods.
Automobile, Bicycle, Bus, and Pedestrian.
When a vessel is moving under its own power.

Software used on desktop and portable computers that allows the computer to act like a terminal connected to a mainframe system. If you have a networked desktop PC and are accessing mainframe programs (a.k.a. green screen programs) you are using terminal emulation. Terminal emulation is also a common method used to connect portable computers (as in warehouse bar code data collection systems) to mainframe software. Also see: Screen Mapping
Abbreviation for: Defence Information Technology Contracting Office Agency.

term: Taking the Wind Out of His Sails
definition: To sail in a way that steals the wind from another ship. cf. overbear.
The number of times a year all inventory is sold.
Closed innovation implies that companies try to develop new products and processes based on the idea that the company itself has the best possible knowledge and resources for innovation.
This market structure is similar to many actual markets and is characterised by a high degree of product differentiation.
The evaluation of alternative designs with the purpose of reducing the number of design options being considered.
Method of valuing stock issues by calculating the average unit value of stock on-hand as the total value of the stock divided by the quantity stocked.
Abbreviation for: South African Chamber of Business.
Inherent uniformity of outcomes that can be produced by resource consuming process components performing specific work activities.
Container conforming to standards laid down for air transportation.
A steamship engaged in the tramp trade.
Abbreviation for: Framework Based Environment.
Abbreviation for: Automated Data Interchange System Service B

Bank that opens a straight or negotiable letter of credit, and assumes the obligation to pay the bank or beneficiary if the documents presented are in accordance with the terms of the letter of credit.
Abbreviation for: Value-Based Management.
Conflict Resolution Advisory.
Slanted rack that allows for easier picking. Items are put into the high end of the rack and then picked from the low end. Desirable for FIFO picking procedures.

Describes fully-automated facilities. The idea being that if the facility requires no human operators, you can run it with no lights. Use of AS/RS units, AGVs, automated conveyors, robots, etc. makes this possible. Also referred to as: Lights-out facility.
A capacity strategy in which capacity is added only after demand has materialised.
Part of the cost of any activity associated with an output that could be saved by not performing that activity.
Abbreviation for: Offshore Flight Data Processing System.
Abbreviation for: Department of Trade and Industry.
The area surrounding a city or town to which rates quoted for the city or town also apply; the area is defined by the ICC.
1. In the rigging of a sailing ship. 2. Above the ship’s uppermost solid structure. 3. Overhead or high above.
This discount is applied to improve manufacturing capacity utilization in periods when sales are low. Buyers ordering out of season, get a lower price.
A chart presenting actual data from quality tests that shows the range, upper and lower limits, and deviation characteristics of a set of observations.
A ship designed for the carriage of liquid cargoes in bulk with cargo space consisting of tanks. Tankers carry a variety of products including crude oil, refined products, and liquid chemicals.
Average time from when a unit is declared shippable by manufacturing until the unit actually ships to a customer.
Refers to the lowest level of division for a process, product structure, network, etc.
Abbreviation for: Total Profit Improvement and Tonnes Per Inch Immersion.

Relates to all those individuals and groups who participate in the purchasing decision-making process, who share some common goals and the risks arising from the decisions (identical to decision-making unit).
Abbreviation for: Mean Time To Restore.
Any activity that consumes resources but creates no value for the customer.
The projection of a value based on the position of two known values.
A sea where waves are directly opposing the motion of the ship.

Four dimensions are suggested on which measurement and evaluation of purchasing activities can be based: (1) a price/cost dimension, (2) a product/quality dimension, (3) a logistics dimension and (4) an organisational dimension
A ship’s steering mechanism; see tiller and ship’s wheel. The wheel and/or wheelhouse area. Also see: Wheelhouse.

The main focus of this strategy is to continually work at reducing the cost price of the end product. If a company succeeds in marketing products at a lower cost price than its competitors, it will achieve a satisfactory return.
1. To steer (a vessel) closer to the direction of the wind. 2. To shift forward, i.e., more toward the bow of the vessel.
Abbreviation for Remote Monitor Control Facility.
An attendant on passengers and crew. Often a young man.
Abbreviation for: House of Quality.
Abbreviation for: Marine Accident Investigators’ International Forum.
Abbreviation for: Retail Service Centre.
Abbreviation for: Automatic Direction Finding.

Any place to which ships may resort for shelter, or to load or unload passengers or goods, or to obtain fuel, water, or supplies. This term applies to such places whether proclaimed public or not and whether natural or artificial.
The planning (at the lower planning levels) by which it is decided in detail where and when each activity can and/or must be carried out.
A person who designs, builds, and repairs ships, especially wooden ones.

Addresses interaction between the web servers and corporate data and enables information to flow between the browser, web server, and corporate data store. For example, the API allows authorised users to use a browser to view financial reports generated directly from the back-office accounting system database.
See: Fill Rate
An electronic forum that hosts posted messages and articles related to a common subject.
A supplier with a proven performance track record, given preference during supplier selection.

Percentage compliance of the associated entity for all the indicators of the associated entity ownership scorecard. The calculation of indicators percentage follows the rules in statement 100 using the actual percentage compliance for each indicator and not the resulting scores.

A flag flown to distinguish ships of one seagoing service of a given country from ships of the country‘s other seagoing service(s) when ships of more than one of the country‘s seagoing services fly the same ensign.
Abbreviation for: Hypertext Mark-up Language.
Shows how closely two variables are related.
Abbreviation for: Released Value Not Exceeding. Used to limit the value of goods transported, referring to carrier liability when paying claims for lost or damaged goods.
An external supplier of goods or services.
Stockless (virtual) warehouse, where suppliers deliver aggregate orders in bulk, and goods are picked by line into store lanes.
A formula of the specific factors or elements that control the making of a rate. A rate can be based on any number of factors (i.e., weight, measure, equipment type, package, box, etc.).
Abbreviation for: Make To Stock.
When a company postpones final manufacturing, assembly, packaging, labeling, or other value-added activities until a final customer order is received.
Abbreviation for: Economic Research and Policy Co-ordination.
That element of an order that has been added to the basic order quantity to meet a constraint imposed by the manufacturer or to optimise overall supply chain costs
A rate that applies to any size shipment tendered to a carrier; usually means that no discount rate is available for large shipments

1. Commercial trawler, a fishing boat that uses a trawl net or dragnet to catch fish. 2. A fisherman who uses a trawl net. Naval trawler, a converted trawler, or boat built in that style, used for naval purposes. 4. Recreational trawler, a pleasure boat built in the style of a trawler.

The Consolidated Rail Corporation established by the Regional Reorganisation Act of 1973 to operate the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad and other bankrupt railroads in the Northeast; funding was provided by the 4-R Act of 1976.
A version of vendor-managed inventory (VMI) where the supplier physically restocks required parts at the production point.
Abbreviation for Activity-on-Arrow Network and Air Operations Area.
Abbreviation for: Central Flow Control Service.

A government or international organisation program that specifies duties, tariffs, documentation, and other conditions for countries doing business within the program. Trade programs are often designed to spur business for companies and countries inside the program, at the exclusion or penalty to outside companies. Consideration of established and proposed trade programs are critical in evaluating sourcing, facility locations, and other factors.
Air Force Reserve Station.

Only systems elements or subassemblies are in stock at the manufacturing centre and final assembly takes place based on a specific customer order. In other words, manufacture of components takes place based on forecast and final assembly takes place based on customer orders.

The under-side of the deck above. The inside of the boat is normally panelled over to hide the structure, pipes, and electrical wires. It can be in thin wood planks, often covered with a vinyl lining, or in thin PVC, or now even in fiberglass planks.

A stock-less (or virtual) distribution centre where goods are generally not placed into storage for subsequent picking, but arrive and depart relatively quickly – by passing “across the dock.” This is achieved by suppliers delivering individual store orders. Also Consolidated Distribution Centre and Combined Distribution Centre

Two lights associated to form a range (a line formed by the extension of a line connecting two charted points) which often, but not necessarily, indicates the channel centreline. The front range light is the lower of the two, and nearer to the mariner using the range. The rear light is higher and further from the mariner.
Purchasing of all materials and products that are used for manufacturing companies' end products.
Satellite-based location system, used in vehicle positioning.
In forecasting models, the process of removing an underlying upward or downward trend to present a normalised baseline view of the demand.
Short semi-trailer, usually between 26 and 32 feet long, with a single axle.
Abbreviation for: Logistical Information System.
Abbreviation for: Research and Technical Development.
A quality award organised by the European Foundation for Quality Management (EFQM), it is based on the EFQM excellence model.
Bringing together requirements for similar goods, works, or services so that they can be addressed in one procurement exercise.

The defense, law and treaty enforcement, and counter-terrorism activities that fall within the port and maritime domain. It includes the protection of the seaports themselves, the protection and inspection of the cargo moving through the ports, and maritime security.
Contractor gets paid for all costs plus profit, plus premium depending upon actual performance.
This refers to the general economic and business environment. It focuses on factors that can influence the future balance between supply and demand.

A framework agreement is an agreement between one or more contracting entities and one or more suppliers, the purpose of which is to establish the terms governing contracts to be awarded during a given period, in particular with regard to price and, where appropriate, the quantities envisaged.
Abbreviation for: Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.
Maximizing the efficiency and productivity of a process while also ensuring effectiveness.
Item Fill Rate = Received Quantity / Ordered Quantity
Anything that has gone overboard
A sub process within procurement that focuses on maximising the total acquisition benefits and implications associated with a need vis-a vis organisation, industry and society.
Abbreviation for: Said to Weigh and Speed through (the) water. STW refers to the speed of the vessel relative to the surrounding water (and as shown by a Log). Used in navigation.
Buyers of by-promaterial as inputs into production processes.

Changing the flag and pennant display when a moored vessel becomes underweight, and vice versa. A highly coordinated display that ships take pride in; the desired effect is that of one set of flags vanishing while another set flashes out at precisely the same time. Also, slang for changing out of one’s Navy uniform into civilian clothes to go ashore. The U.S. Navy’s newsletter for retired personnel is nicknamed Shift Colours from this reason.
The carrier whose name is printed on the bill of lading and with whom the contract of carriage exists.
An opening in the bulwark of the ship to allow passengers to board or leave the ship.

A formal recognition issued by a full- time AIB International (AIBI) inspector, stating that a facility has successfully passed an inspection of good manufacturing practices prerequisites and food safety standards. Once issued, recognition documents do not expire, however most companies request to have an inspection conducted at least once a year. There are three levels of recognition that companies can receive: Recognition of High Achievement, Recognition of Achievement, and Recognition of Participation.
1. A United States Navy destroyer of the World War I-era Caldwell, Wickes, or Clemson class, produced in very large numbers. 2. Any ship with a flush deck.
Approaches to inventory control that place orders of variable size at fixed intervals of time.
A manufacturing or production order.

A Japanese word meaning ‘horizontal deployment’ and refers to the practice of copying good results of kaizen in one area to other areas. Yokoten can also apply to copying product design ideas, business processes or better machine setting, materials, or methods in general. Yokoten requires a culture of ‘go see’ information sharing between departments, both for successes and failures. Within the 8-step practical problem-solving process known as TBP (Toyota Business Practice), the yokoten activity happens in step 8. 1. Clarify the problem 2. Break down the problem 3. Set a target 4. Analyse the root cause 5. Develop countermeasures 6. See countermeasures through 7. Evaluate both results and process 8. Standardise successes, learn from failures (Pinnacle Partners TN)

A short nine-tailed whip kept by the bosun’s mate to flog sailors (and soldiers in the Army). When not in use, the cat was kept in a baize bag, this is a possible origin for the term “cat out of the bag,” though livestock trade was more likely where this phrase came from. “Not enough room to swing a cat” also derives from this.
These items represent a relatively limited value in terms of money but they are vulnerable with regard to their supply. They can only be obtained from one supplier.
Abbreviation for: Procurement Technical Assistance Centre.
Warehouse operated by a 3PL Company that houses the products of their clients.
Trucking company which consolidates less-than-truckload cargo for multiple destinations on one vehicle.
Abbreviation for: Minimum En Route Altitude.

A fishing boat that takes recreational fishermen out for a fee paid individually by each person (i.e., per head). A head boat differs from a charter boat, which is a fishing boat that a party of fishermen hires for an agreed-upon period.
In a short-sale transaction, the portion of interest or dividends earned by the owner (lender) of shares that are paid to the short seller (borrower) of the shares.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Radar Approach Control Facility.
Abbreviation for: Alternate Network Connectivity.

A specification for Electronic Data Interchange between businesses, which uses the Internet’s webpage protocol: Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).The specification is an extension of the earlier version, Applicability Statement 1 (AS1). Both specifications were created by EDI over the Internet (EDIINT), a working group of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) that develops secure and reliable business communications standards

Vertical frame components fitted at the corners of a container, integral to the corner fittings and connecting the roof and floor structures. Containers are lifted and secured in a stack using the castings at the ends.
A substance such as oil that reduces friction when applied as a surface coating to moving parts.
Any vehicle carrying two or more passengers. The term usually refers to private vehicles.
Suppliers are invited to submit general information that may help them to qualify for a potential tender.

The adaptability of a process to handle future changes, customer expectations, and today's individual special customer requirements. It is managing the process to meet today’s special needs and future requirements.

Abbreviation for: Destination Delivery Charge. A charge based on container size, which is applied in many tariffs to cargo. This charge is considered accessorial and is added to the base ocean freight. This charge covers crane lifts off the vessel, dray age of the container within the terminal, and gate fees at the terminal operation.
Costs incurred in preventing defects and to “do the job right the first time.” Costs associated with actions to minimize the cost of non-conformance.

A characteristic of modern information systems, gauged by the ease with which data can be substantiated by tracing it to source documents, and the extent to which auditors can rely on pre-verified and monitored control processes.
Abbreviation for: Continuous Replenishment Program and Capacity Requirements Planning. Abbreviation for: Cost Recovery Rate.
A state in which all the members of a group support an action or decision, even if some of them don’t fully agree with it.

These are locations in a warehouse used specifically for order picking. When you use forward pick locations it is assumed that you also have reserve storage locations. Also see Reserve Storage Locations.
A contract where an ocean carrier provides cargo space at a specific time and price for an exporter or importer.
The element within supply chain management focused on sourcing and purchasing goods and services.
A Latin term meaning “For the sake of form.”
A board or plate lowered through the hull of a dinghy on the centreline to resist leeway.
Abbreviation for: Defective Goods Inventory.

A BEE certificate issued by a verification Agency in compliance with the Amended Codes. These include both public Broad-Based Verification and Narrow-Based Verification Certificate as may be appropriate.

A document certifying that merchandise (such as perishable goods) was in good condition immediately prior to its shipment. The document issued by the U.S. Coast Guard certifying an American Flag vessel’s compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
A tender evaluated on the basis of Quality, value for money and impact on organisation and society
The operation’s ability to introduce new or modified products and services.
The numerical designation in a routing that indicates the order in which operations are performed.
Abbreviation for: Modular Terminal Communications System.
Individuals in large firms who take responsibility for the development of innovations within the organisation (Business, 2002).

A defined operational plan which is designed to be implemented in the event of disruption of normal operations. Disruptions may be the result of natural disasters, civil or labour unrest, etc. CSCMP provides suggestions for helping companies do continuity planning in securing the Supply Chain Research. A copy of the research is available on the CSCMP website.
Abbreviation for: Pacific Islands Forum.
The United States Oil Pollution Act of 1990.
The ability to provide interactive health care utilising modern telecommunications technology.
Abbreviation for: Sector Maintenance Processor Subsystem.
Abbreviation for: FAA Telecommunications Satellite.
A raised crossmember that supports a boom when the sail is lowered (obviates the need for a topping lift).
The agreement of each party to all the terms and conditions in the same context and with the same meaning.
Includes quantity on open purchase orders or manufacturing orders. May or may not include quantities on transfer orders from other branches
The average normal use stock, combined with both the average lead stock, and safety stock.
The review of project task and resource status immediately prior to cut over that assesses risks and the probability of success.

A contract clause which may be contained within boilerplate language that allows for contract to be ended at the discretion of the governmental entity. Action by which the purchasing entity, in accordance with contract provisions, unilaterally cancels all or part of the contract work for the best interest of the jurisdiction, and with no reflection on the contractor’s performance.

term: DOS - AVERAGE INVENTORY / MONTHLY DEMAND X 30
definition: For example, if a component is consumed in manufacturing at the rate of 5 per day, and there are 50 units available on-hand, this represents 10 days’ supply.
Forward stock cover based on predicted sales taking into account marketing events planned for the period.
The costs associated with the design and manufacture of a product such as direct material, direct labor, and allocated overhead. They do not include selling and general administrative costs.
Abbreviation for: Safety Management Certificate.
Abbreviation for: National Empowerment Fund.
Abbreviation for: Knowledge-Based Engineering.
Contingency planning specifically related to recovering hardware and software (e.g. data centres, application software, operations, personnel, telecommunications) in information system outages.

1. A bill of materials, giving an ordered list of all the materials needed to make a product, and also the order in which the materials are used. 2. A listing of all components used in the production of a parent item that does not reflect its structure or intermediate levels, and is not useful in time-phasing requirements based on lead time offsets.
Abbreviation for: Flight Service Station Automated Service.
A Six Sigma process that outlines the steps that should be followed to improve an existing business processes.

This document is used for the carriage of goods by road. Like the airway bill it is evidence of the contract of carriage, acts as a receipt for the goods, and sets out the relevant rules and regulations for road transport.
Abbreviation for: Canadian European Comprehensive Economics and Trade Agreement.
Pinwheeling is a process of arranging pallets on a truck or product on a pallet to make the best use of space when dealing with items of different sizes.

The set of activities that specifies acceptable material and process parameters and measures actual performance in meeting defined quality standards. When used in reference to a department—quality assurance (QA) or quality control (QC)—it often indicates that responsibility for meeting quality standards has been delegated to that department, and is not an assumed function of other company operations
Abbreviation for: Dynamic Special Use Airspace.
Set of charges related to the product Carrying Costs, Storage Costs, and Product Movement Costs.
1. To remove from a vessel. 2. To remove an oar or mast from its normal position.
Abbreviation for: Power Amplifier.
The logical linkage between higher- and lower-level items in the BOM.
National Communications Switching Centre.
Material held in a facility which is intended to be consumed in manufacturing/assembly or sold in a specified period.
A sailing vessel with three or more masts, all of them square-rigged. A full-rigged ship is said to have a “ship rig.”
The incorporation of the operation’s impact on its stakeholders into operations management decisions.
The direction of the geographical North Pole.

A legal expression which means "Let the buyer beware". For a contract for the sale of goods it implies that the buyer must satisfy himself about all aspects of them before he buys the goods, there being no provision under common law for implied warranty as to the suitability of the goods for any specific purpose.
Abbreviation for: Computer Aided Design.
Using two or more data collection technologies together to perform tasks. For example, using a voice-directed order picking system combined with a bar code scanner.

A wooden block with holes (but no pulleys) which is spliced to a shroud. It is used to adjust the tension in the standing rigging of large sailing vessels, by lacing through the holes with a lanyard to the deck. Performs the same job as a turnbuckle.

A signal from a consumer, customer, or using operation that triggers the issue of product or raw material. The demand signal is most efficiently an electronic data transmission, but could be a physical document, kanban or telephone call.

Also known as supply-chain visibility and event management, these applications monitor the supply chain for events that are important to the end users. Logistics visibility and control solutions combine alerts with escalation rules to report those events to decision makers who can act on them before they mushroom into problems.
Abbreviation for: Freight All Kinds. Usually refers to full container loads of mixed shipments.
Fall Back Switch.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Facility.
A fin mounted on the side of a boat (usually in pairs) that can be lowered on the lee side of the ship to reduce leeway (similarly to a centreboard).
Abbreviation for: Interim Standard Microwave Landing System.
Abbreviation for: Collect (cash) on Delivery, or Carried on Docket (pricing).

A specific determination of the cost, timing, description, and terms associated with a projected good or service to be provided by a supplier to a customer. A quote is normally valid for a certain time frame, or up to a specified quantity limit, and modified based on changes in the item or service configuration
A process capability index measuring the ratio between actual spread (upper control limit minus lower control limit) divided by allowable or expected spread as measured by standard deviation.
A ship with a crane specialized in lifting heavy loads.
A cost for an item that is not considered direct construction cost. Soft costs include architectural, engineering, financing, and legal fees, and other pre- and post construction expenses.
Pricing a service or item based on its consumption or usage, rather than a flat rate for a given service or period of time.

A change implemented to address a weakness identified in a management system, usually brought to the company’s attention by a customer complaint, nonconformities identified during an internal audit, or adverse/unstable trends in product and process monitoring identified by the statistical process control (SPC).
Abbreviation for: United States Coast Guard.
The process of systematically evaluating the company’s operating network, suppliers, customers, and product offerings to find and eliminate inefficiencies and redundancies.
The process of determining the organisational costs and benefits of a proposed alternative.

A written communication used to inform the buyer that the supplier has accepted the purchase order placed on them. An acknowledgment creates a bilateral contract, as long as the terms of the acknowledgment are not significantly different from those of the purchase order.
(1) Abbreviation for: Regional Planning Council. (2) Abbreviation for: Restoration Priority Code.
Abbreviation for: Warehouse Management System. Computer programme that manages warehouse operations.
A formal documentation of a proposed system’s capabilities, processing methods, and points of integration that serves as the basis for approval and work initiation.
A specific run, batch, lot, or other discrete group of production with an identifiable beginning and end, and to which material usage and labour charges can be meaningfully assigned.

A type of sailing ship with a single mast and square-rigged single sail first developed in the 10th century and widely used, particularly in the Baltic Sea region, in seagoing trade from the 12th through the 14th century.
Abbreviation for: Enhanced Target Generator.
National Motor Freight Classification.
See: Shrinkage.
See: DMZ Separation.
Abbreviation for: Support Programme for Industrial Innovation.

Stacking lift truck fitted with fork arms (which can be replaced by another device) on which the load, either palletized or not, is put in a cantilever position in relation to the front wheels and balanced by the mass of the truck.
A method for combining variation at each process step to predict total process variation.

An identification applied to a product container or label which provides the specific date of production of the contents. Sometimes it is an actual date, but frequently it is coded for internal purposes. Date codes are often used during product recalls.

A final item description tool used in assemble-to-order (ATO) environments that defines the available product options and accessories, and builds product cost and sales price information from the options chosen. Rules may be defined to require options to be chosen from certain categories, to allow more than one choice from a given category, to not allow certain combinations of options, and other considerations that ensure product performance and safety. The configured product is identified by a base product number, and an additional code, that describes the option chosen for a given order.
Abbreviation for: Area Control Facility.

A type of large capital ship of the first half of the 20th century, similar in size, appearance, and cost to a battleship and typically armed with the same kind of heavy guns, but much more lightly armoured (on the scale of a cruiser).It is therefore faster than a battleship, but more vulnerable to damage
According to PDMA, the overall process of strategy, organization, concept generation, product and marketing plan creation and evaluation, and commercialization of a new product.
Abbreviation for: Office of Management and Budget.

A measure of the measured Entity’s ability to successfully secure formal permanent or long-term contract employment for the learner or assist the learner’s proceed with further education and training.
A long, curving wave breaking on the shore.
The ability of a process to handle large variations in volume without significant changes in time or facility requirements.

A downward or sternward projection from the keel in front of the rudder. Protects the rudder from damage, and in bilge keelers may provide one “leg” of a tripod on which the boat stands when the tide is out.
Abbreviation for: DoD Automatic Voice Network.
Lift truck attachment that operates like a paper roll clamp except the clamping surface is flat rather than circular.

1. A commissioned officer senior enough to be entitled to fly a flag to mark the ship or installation from which he or she exercises command, in English-speaking countries usually referring to the senior officers of a navy, specifically those who hold any of the admiral ranks, and in some cases to those holding the rank of commodore. In modern American usage, additionally applied to U.S. Coast Guard and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Corps officers and general officers in the U.S. Army, U.S. Air Force, and U.S. Marine Corps entitled to fly their own flags. 2. A formal rank in the mid-19th- century United States Navy, conveyed temporarily upon senior captains in command of squadrons of ships, soon rendered obsolete by the creation of the ranks of commodore and rear admiral.
The procurement procedure where tendering is open to all local or international legal entities interested to submit a tender.

TEI helps us to combine the gross margin and turnover. A logic behind TEI is to keep high ITR for SKUs or brands generating low margins and to satisfy with medium- or low-level ITR for SKUs or brands generating high margins. TEI(ITR) x (Gross Profit %) x 100.
A professional association of transportation and traffic practitioners.
A branch of applied statistics dealing with planning, conducting, analysing, and interpreting controlled tests to evaluate the factors that control the value of a parameter or group of parameters.
A railroad yard with many tracks used for assembling freight trains.
A pole with a hook on the end, used to reach into the water to catch buoys or other floating objects.
The lower part of the stem of a ship.
Techniques to control quality through sampling and statistical process control.

An environment that uses a combination of discrete, repetitive, or process manufacturing instead of only one type. A company may produce major lower level sub-assemblies in high volumes using repetitive, schedule-based techniques while using a discrete production order-based method to conduct final assembly operations for specific customer orders.
A domestic water carrier industry association representing barge operators on the inland waterways.

A state or local governmental authority for a special district for operating ports and transportation infrastructure. Port authorities are usually governed by boards or commissions and can include wharfs, docks, and terminals.
The components of a parent item that have been pulled from stock.

Standardised label formats used by trading partners. Compliance labels are used as shipping labels, container/pallet labels, carton labels, or piece labels, and usually contain barcodes. Many barcode labelling software products now have the more common compliance label standards set up as templates.

1. The maximum throughput of a process in a given time. 2. For auto mode: The maximum number of vehicles that reasonably can be expected to traverse a point or a uniform section of roadway during a given period under prevailing conditions.

A technique for comparing the attractiveness of alternative locations that allocates a score to the factors that are significant in the decision and weights each score by the significance of the factor.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Control Area.
Abbreviation for: Airline Office.
Front of a container or trailer–opposite the tail.
Government standards defined in 1967 that describe the management and reimbursement criteria for projects performed by private contractors.

1. To haul down or lower (a flag, mast, etc.). 2. To surrender the vessel to the enemy, from strike the colours. To remove a naval vessel’s name from a country’s naval register (after which the vessel is considered stricken).

Railroad terminal where containers are received or delivered and trains loaded or discharged. Originally, trailers were moved onto the rearmost flatcar via a ramp and then driven into position in a technique known as “circus loading.” Most modern rail facilities use lifting equipment to position containers onto the flatcars.
Hull shape, when viewed in a transverse section, where the widest part of the hull is some way below deck level.
Abbreviation for: Integrated Computer-Aided Definition Language. A process modelling technique comprising graphic and narrative symbols and rules.
Abbreviation for: Inspector General.
Abbreviation for: South African Revenue Services.
Scanners that can read barcoded documents at up to 600 documents per minute.

A measure of a company’s earning power from ongoing operations, equal to earnings (revenues minus cost of sales, operating expenses, and taxes) before deduction of interest payments and income taxes. Also called operating profit.

Consists of a number for each specific forecast period that describes the relationship of each period’s demand to the average demand (level) over the complete seasonal cycle. A seasonality index is used to adjust the forecast to account for these cyclical changes in demand. The average demand is represented by the number 1. If seasonality for a period results in demand greater than the average demand, it will be represented by a number greater than 1. For example, if December’s sales were, on average, 30% greater than the average monthly sales for the year, you would have a seasonality index of 1.3 (1 plus .30) for December. If January’s sales were, on average, 20% less than the average monthly sales for the year, you would have a seasonality index of 0.8 (1 minus .20).
Abbreviation for: Woefully Inept Manufacturing Process.
Abbreviation for: International Federation of Ship Masters’ Associations.
The date and time a package or shipment is expected to be delivered to a given destination.
Established the standard basis for adjusting general average and stated the rules for adjusting claims.
The force that restores a ship to equilibrium when a heel alters the relationship between its center of buoyancy and center of gravity.
Negotiations to establish a price for each order for a particular customer, as opposed to setting a uniform price for all customers.

A feature of MRP type systems which allows for defining the point in time from the current date where all forecasted orders should be discarded in favour of actual customer orders. There may be a blend of actual and forecast orders beyond the time fence.
Expenses directly tied to the level of business activity.
See: Logistics Service Provider.
Arranging transforming resources in a sequence defined by the processing needs of a product or service.
A request for materials, which is created in advance of formal need due to long lead times for components, etc.
1. Living in the open ocean rather than coastal or inland waters, (e.g., “a pelagic shark”). 2. Taking place in the open ocean (e.g., “pelagic fishing,” “pelagic sealing”).
Abbreviation for: Average Vehicle Ridership. The number of employees scheduled to start work during specified hours, divided by the number of vehicles arriving at the site during those same hours
An arrow diagram used in planning and managing processes and projects
A ship that has run upon her own anchor, so the anchor cable runs under the hull.
A signal flag on a vessel.
Abbreviation for: Job Order Contracting.
A small flag, typically triangular, flown from the masthead of a yacht to indicate yacht-club membership.
A tariff term referring to ocean rate, less accessorial charges, or simply the base tariff rate.
See: Gybe.
Replenishment policy with variable date and set quantity, based on defining the stock level (Order Point) that triggers the order signal.
Placing a port on a vessel’s itinerary because the volume of cargo offered at that port justifies the cost of routing the vessel.

For the purpose of the Strategic Intermodal System designation process, military bases refer to U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force or Marine Corps installations to which active duty soldiers, sailors or aviators are assigned.

The methods and systems used to prioritise, track, and report against production orders and schedules. They include the procedures used to evaluate current resource status, and the update of labour, machine hour, and other associated information, as required, to support the overall planning, scheduling, and costing systems.
Abbreviation for: Consortia Trade Exchanges.
The 1200–1600 (noon to 4 p.m.) watch.
Internal organisational functions such as production operations or cycle counting that normally do not interact with outside entities.
Connections between a semi-trailer and the powered tractor for purposes of controlling the air brake system.
The relative slackness of an anchor chain where the anchor chain is slack and hangs vertically down from the hawsepipe.

1. Having freedom of motion interfered with by collision or entanglement; entangled; the opposite of clear. For instance, a rope is foul when it does not run straight or smoothly, and an anchor is foul when it is caught on an obstruction. 2. A breach of racing rules. 3. An area of water treacherous to navigation due to many shallow obstructions such as reefs, sandbars, or many rocks, etc. 4. Foul the range: To block another vessel from firing her guns at a target.
To perform customs and immigration legalities prior to leaving port.
An industry association representing subsidised U.S. Flag steamship firms.
The helmsman or crew member in command of a boat.
The description of the materials, processes, and resources used in the production of an item, as contained in the bill of material, routing, and work center records.
Abbreviation for: Free and Secure Trade.
A contract that provides for a fixed price not subject to any adjustment on account of cost increases that a supplier may experience in the course of execution of the contract.
The price of the product is determined on the market and is generated exclusively by market circumstances such as demand, supply, stock, positions, the economic situation, and political factors.
The order quantity used as the minimum for a planned order, even if the lot size rule calculated a smaller amount.
Abbreviation for: Tactical Aircraft Control and Navigation.
To stop a sailing vessel, especially by turning into the wind.
Abbreviation for: Industrial Development Division.
A piece of equipment which is typically sold as an optional separate unit, and may be combined with the main product at the factory or in the field.
Refers to: En Route Broadband Radar.

1. A structured, conceptual framework that defines the management of software development and maintenance processes. 2. A management tool for software and IT organisations to systematically improve their development and maintenance processes.
Abbreviation for: Export Market and Investment Assistance.
A term used in job design to indicate increasing the authority given to people to make decisions within the job or changes to the job itself.
Includes suppliers that meet the buyer’s prequalification criteria and will be requested to submit a fast proposal.
A non-commissioned officer responsible for discipline on a naval ship. Standing between the officers and the crew, commonly known in the Royal Navy as ‘the Buffer.’

An arrangement whereby a steamship company, under rules and regulations established in the freight tariff of a given trade, accepts small packages at rates below the minimum bill of lading, and issues a parcel receipt instead of a bill of lading.
An agreement that is oral and not in writing. Usually enforceable in the court of law.
The license plate number on a trailer.

Mobile procurement refers to any business software that allows users to control their procurement processes from any mobile device. With mobile procurement solutions, users can create purchase orders, receive notifications, engage in real-time analysis of their procurement activities and control the entire S2P operation.
A process that addresses the main value-added activities of an organization.
Charges added to a bill, particularly a freight bill, to cover additional costs that were not originally included.

The idea that the improvement in one aspect of operations performance comes at the expense of deterioration in another aspect of performance, now substantially modified to include the possibility that in the long term different aspects of operations performance can be improved simultaneously.
Refrigeration equipment attachable to an insulated container that does not have its own refrigeration unit.
Referring to the four main points of the compass: north, south, east, and west. Also see: bearing on page 62
A sound signal which uses electricity or compressed air to actuate either a disc or a cup shaped rotor.
An inventory system that is used to manage independent demand inventory. The inventory level for an item is checked at regular intervals and restocked to some predetermined level.
A variation of a fixed price type of contract which provides for the upward or downward changes in prices of specified materials and/or of labour costs.
Persons and property carried by transport lines.
The measurement point above the centreline in a process control chart or report that indicates an out-of-bounds condition or a warning signal.

The strategy aims to serve a specific, clearly-defined group of customers in an optimal way. A focus strategy means that the company studies the activities of the customer group, becomes familiar with their operational requirements and provides specific solutions.
Abbreviation for: Continuous Flow Manufacturing.

A set of calling conventions that define how a series is invoked through software. API allows programs written by users or third parties to communicate with certain vendor- supplied programs, which in tum allows users and third parties to add functions to vendor-supplied software
A manufacturing process of gas, liquid, or other form that is not broken into individual batches or lots as it moves from one status or stocking point to another.
The time for those work elements that adds value to the product or service from the customer’s point of view.
National Ambient Air Quality Standards.

Direct shipping and drop shipping are two terms generally used interchangeably. They describe a process whereby three parties interact with the sales transaction (the buyer, the seller, and the supplier). The buyer initiates a purchase from the seller, who then arranges with the supplier to ship the product directly to the buyer. The seller does not carry inventory of the product and the supplier does not have any direct communication with the buyer. The buyer pays the seller and the seller pays the supplier. In the case of a “Blind” direct shipment, the supplier information is intentionally hidden from the buyer.
A container insulated on the walls, roof, floor, and doors to reduce the effect of external temperatures on the cargo.
Changing the consignee or destination on a bill of lading while shipment is still in transit. Diversion has substantially the same meaning.
A contracting method that enables just in time deliveries of products and services this avoiding amongst others inventory and personal carrying costs.
Symbols used to classify different types of activities, often derived from scientific management or information-system flow-charting.

An item, automatically generated by the production process of another item that has value and is inventoried. The by-product is not scheduled but can be planned as an expected receipt as a result of scheduling the generating item, and its cost may be netted against the original item.
A term for lower shipping rates for cargo moving through West Coast ports to inland destinations.
Abbreviation for: High Frequency.

The philosophy and methodologies that seek to reduce product and process variation, quality problems and cost by identifying and eliminating non-value added tasks, and standardising component and resource usage.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Commerce Resource Centre.

A hedge lead time added to the actual or calculated lead time that initiates earlier order release. Items planned on a to-order instead of a to-stock basis may use safety lead time instead of safety stock to handle critical requirements when carrying additional inventory is not desirable.
Expenditure on goods and services being acquired to support a business.
Short term or current period data used to project results for a hypothetical full year that filters out seasonality and abnormalities.
A B/L wherein the paying customer has contracted with the carrier that shipper or consignee information is not given.
Abbreviation for: Cost of Goods Sold.
Abbreviation for: Weather Message Switching Centre.
Abbreviation for: Virtual Product Model.
Shipment using more than one transportation mode (rail, truck, air, etc.) where the original shipment is containerised or otherwise kept together in its original condition.
Abbreviation for Return on Inventory Investment and Return on Initial Investment.
Abbreviation for: High Altitude EFAS.
General Aviation Reliever Airport.
Abbreviation for: Industrial Policy Action Plan.
Abbreviation for: Navigational Electronic Chart System Association.
A ship or craft designed to function as a floating barracks for housing military personnel.
Sea conditions with a tidal current and a wind in opposite directions, leading to short, heavy seas.
A modified ABC analysis in which a subjective value of criticality is assigned to each item in the inventory.
Abbreviation for: Joint Service Agreement.
Specification of desired outcomes of contractor work.
Abbreviation for: Flight Level.
A way to identify goods stored without using the full description or item name, utilized in warehouse management systems.
Port where a ship discharges or receives traffic.
Abbreviation for: British Offshore Support Vessel Owners Association.
The middle section of a vessel relative to the athwartships plane, as distinguished from port or starboard.
Deliveries of shipments from a single shipper to multiple consignees along the route leading to an ultimate destination.
Abbreviation for: Group Decision Support System.
Abbreviation for: Quick Response.
Abbreviation for: Shared Economic Infrastructure Facility.
National Service Assurance Plan.
Generic Quality Management System Standard (ISO).
The individual or firm that issues a draft, and thus, stands to receive payment.

A high-level capacity planning system, often developed at the family level, that provides an overall check of critical resources and verifies the feasibility of the master production schedule and sales and operations plan. It uses a bill of resource for items or families that specifies the requirements for key resources only, as opposed to all operations, as done on the routing. Resource requirements from the S&OP and suggested MPS are compared to availability, on an overall weekly or monthly basis, and indicate projected over and under capacity situations that could impact the successful completion of the plan
These encompass all products which are purchased to be sold, after negligible added value, either together with other finished products or manufactured products (identical to trade items).
A sailing vessel of three or more masts, with all masts but the sternmost square-rigged, the sternmost being fore-and-aft-rigged.

The comparison of plans, programs, and schedules of one agency with related plans, programs, and schedules of other agencies or entities with legal standing, and adjustment of plans, programs, and schedules to achieve general consistency.
This directs the yard jockey to move a trailer from a door to a location in the yard.
Abbreviation for: Value Stream Mapping.
Abbreviation for: Transition Tree.

A combination of cooperation and competition that offers the counter-intuitive possibility for rivals to benefit from each other’s seemingly competitive activities. In short, there are circumstances where having more players to cut the pie means bigger pieces of pie for everyone. An example would be found in the group buying setting where its use refers to the activity of multiple, normally competitive buying group members, leveraging each other’s buying power to gain reduced pricing.
A slang term (in the US, mostly) for a raised portion of a ship’s deck. A doghouse is usually added to improve headroom below or to shelter a hatch.

A joint Bureau of the Census’ International Trade Administration form used for compiling U.S. exports. It is completed by a shipper and shows the value, weight, destination, etc., of export shipments as well as Schedule B commodity code.
A traditional, flat-bottomed Venetian rowing boat.
A three-level, multiple-variable experiment design method that assumes values at the centre point and eliminates extreme values

the qualifying contribution that are unique to the industry in which entities operate. For the purpose of the Amended codes an industry may be grouped in major divisions in accordance with the standard industrial classification coding system used by statistic South Africa.
A tractor, usually unlicensed, for moving containers within a yard. An employee who drives a tractor for the purpose of moving cargo within a container yard.
Person who inspects a ship hull or its cargo for damage or quality.
A tariff published by an agent on behalf of several carriers
Abbreviation for: Component Based Solution Assembly and Canadian Border Services Agency.
Syn.: Production order.
Near a ship.
A change in the wind direction which forces the helmsman of a close hauled sailboat to steer away from its current course to a less favourable one. This is the opposite of a lift.

1. IMO performance standard for ECDIS. 
2. Abbreviation for: Engineered Performance Standards.
A product design methodology that provides a quantitative evaluation of product designs.
Abbreviation for: Telecommunications Management System.
A lighted board used in production areas to provide a visual signal that indicates an actual or potential problem at a specific workstation
Abbreviation for: Central Computer Complex Host.
Abbreviation for: Management By Objectives.
The number used in exponential smoothing models to give the most recent period a different weight than the previous periods. Syn.: alpha smoothing factor.
Pallet intended to be discarded after a single cycle of use.

Supplier evaluation includes every activity performed to assess a potential supplier. The parameters for evaluation depend on the nature of acquisition and usually revolve around the quality of service, the supplier’s capacity, technical capability and financial health.
To haul and tie up by means of a rope.
The truck unit into which freight is loaded as in tractor trailer combination.
Area Flight Plan.
The staff of the organisation who have particular responsibility for managing some or all of the resources which compose the operation’s function.

A propeller drive system similar to the lower part of an outboard motor extending below the hull of a larger power boat or yacht, but driven by an engine mounted within the hull. Unlike a fixed propeller (but like an outboard), the boat may be steered by twisting the drive. Also see inboard motor and outboard motor.
Abbreviation for: Upper Control Limit (Statistical Process Control).
The difference between the value of a country’s exports and imports.
An agreement to hold a carrier harmless with regard to a liability.
A party responsible for the payment as evidenced by the given instrument. Under letters of credit, the payer is the party on whom the draft is drawn, usually the drawee bank.
To let a vessel’s head fall off from the wind (to leeward).
On-hand stock which has been segregate and is not available to meet customer requirements
A revision to a drawing or design released by engineering to modify or correct a part.
Abbreviation for: Rough Cut Capacity Planning.

Continuous Process Improvement is a strategic approach for developing a culture of continuous improvement in the areas of reliability, process cycle times, costs in terms of less total resource consumption, quality, and productivity.
Abbreviation for: Automated X-ray Inspection.
Goods that have completed the manufacturing or assembly process and are ready for sale to external customers.

A current asset; the expected value to be received from customers for items shipped and services performed, but not yet paid for. Also refers to the department that applies cash received from customers against open invoices, and manages invoice adjustments and credit memos.
A certificate issued by a port indicating that the ship carries no infectious diseases. Also called a pratique.
A part on a ship that has no use.
The activity of measuring and assessing the various aspects of a process or whole operation’s performance.
Abbreviation for: Point of Purchase and Point of Presence.
Abbreviation for: Air Transport Association of Canada.
An event that causes a temporary, significant disruption in transportation services.
Abbreviation for: Committee on Trade and the Environment.
A long, thin triangular flag flown from the masthead of a military ship (as opposed to a burgee, the flags thus flown on yachts).

A key element of successful contract administration. It provides specific information on how the Contract Administration Team will observe and evaluate performance according to the standard required in the contract. PAP includes information on how the “evaluators” will observe, survey, sample, test, evaluate and document supplier performance.
Abbreviation for: American Apparel and Footwear Association
Abbreviation for: Engineering Change Management.
Abbreviation for: Time-Phased Order Point.
Abbreviation for: Middle Compass Locator.
Performing one full-time job by two part-time employees. (Ferrell, 2002)
A form of punishment for young sailors known as "Kissing the gunner’s daughter."
Tollgates are process checkpoints where deliverables are reviewed and measured and readiness to move forward is addressed.
Relationship between operations in a supply network that rely on formal and/or legal contracts that specify obligations and roles.
A large area of elevated sea floor.

Minor errors made in the form of bidding; for example, failure to insert a decimal point. Clerical mistakes, apparent on the face of the bid, may be corrected. Once a mistake is suspected, the purchasing official is required to request verification of the bid.
Relates to a situation when the organisation wants to purchase a new product from a known supplier or an existing product from a new supplier.
An arrangement for the supply of goods or services established for a fixed period of time.
Abbreviation for: Switched Data Service.
NADIN Concentrator.
Abbreviation for: National Industry Participation Programme.

An overall quality related term common in purchase agreements that encompasses the physical attributes of something (form), its desired outputs or performance (function) and fitness (appropriate for the application).
U.S. Commerce Department document, “Shipper’s Export Declaration.”

Supplier's expenses in development of a design or a prototype to help the buyer decide whether the product conforming to this would meet his intended use. As part of a two-stage tendering procedure these costs will not be reimbursed by the buyer.
Required for advertising claims.
Mode Select Beacon System.
Abbreviation for: Carriage and Insurance Paid (Incoterms) and The Critical Infrastructure Programme.
A measure of the rate at which shipped items are returned.
A warehouse order picking scheme utilising zones in which pickers select materials within their own area only and the total material required for the order is later grouped together.
Goods in active pick locations and ready for order filling.
The process definition that includes the customer-supplier communication protocol and the procedural flow; the communications and activities that make up the customer-supplier dialogue.

A small anchor. A fouled killick is the substantive badge of non-commissioned officers in the RN. Seamen promoted to the first step in the promotion ladder are called ‘Killick.’ The badge signifies that here is an Able Seaman skilled to cope with the awkward job of dealing with a fouled anchor.

The location designated by carriers for receipt of cargo to be packed into containers/equipment by the carrier. At destination, CFS is the location designated by the carrier for unpacking of cargo from equipment/containers.
Abbreviation for: Tokyo International Conference on African Development.

A method by which a larger quantity is ordered on a purchase order to secure a lower price, but delivery is divided into smaller quantities and spread out over several dates to control inventory investment, save storage space, etc.

A process to develop tactical plans by integrating marketing plans for new and existing products with the management of the supply chain. The process brings together all the plans for the business into one integrated set of plans. Also called aggregate planning.

term: WORLD TRADE ORGANISATION-AGREEMENT ON GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT (WTO-AGP)
definition: Replaced the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on January 1, 1996. It is a multilateral agreement to reduce trade barriers between the United States and Canada, the European Union, Japan, Korea, Israel, Norway and Switzerland.

A measure used in warehouse slotting to determine the appropriate size of a location. Cubic velocity generally measures the volume (cubic feet/cubic inches) that moves out of a location during a predefined period of times (days, weeks, etc.). This is primarily used with picking locations, so you would multiply the average units sold during a period by the cube of each unit to determine the cubic velocity.
The combination of shipments from multiple points at an intermediate facility, reducing the number of individual shipments to end locations.

A product for which independent demand can exist for which there is also demand as part of another higher-level product e.g. a single can and a multi-can pack or a sub-assembly spare and the major assembly of which it forms part.
A separately identifiable collection of one or more goods items (available to be) transported together.
Cluster picking is a methodology of picking into multiple order containers at one time. The containers could be totes containing order batches, discrete order shippers, or discrete order totes.

The requirements for an item based on its gross requirements (from forecasts, customer orders, or upper level demand), minus stock already on-hand and scheduled receipts. If the total is below the specified safety stock, a planned order is generated based on the lot size. The generation of a new planned order for a given net requirement is normally done only after calculating the effect of rescheduling all incoming receipts to the dates required.
Abbreviation for: Body of Knowledge.
An official request to suppliers to offer a bid, quotation or proposal.
Abbreviation for: Western Truck Lines.
Seller is responsible for goods and preparation of export documentation until actually placed aboard the vessel.
The length of time between two consecutive replenishment shipments.

Usually used with automated systems such as automated conveyor systems, a Jackpot Line refers to an area where exceptions are routed. Exceptions may include orders that could not be completed (shortages or WMS error), orders requiring special processing, or weight or size exceptions. The terms Jackpot Lane, or Jackpot Area are also used to describe similar exception areas.
An 18th- and 19th-century term originally used to refer to a naval vessel out of service for repair or maintenance, later coming to mean naval ships in reserve with no more than a caretaker crew.
Abbreviation for: Key Action Plan.
Computer application and component of SCE packages, with the goal of optimising the organisation and cost of transport runs.
The use of techniques to uncover the root cause of failure; techniques may include accident investigation, complaint analysis, etc.
Pre-contractual, negotiations and closure and post-contractual.
Abbreviation for: Trade and Development Cooperation Agreement.
A barcoded transaction card with an attached barcode label. The card and label barcodes match. Label is removed from card and placed on merchandise.
Under U.S. tax law, a corporation created to obtain tax exemption on part of the earnings of U.S. products in foreign markets. Must be set–up as a foreign corporation with an office outside the USA.

A South African Government initiative aimed at growing and developing the automotive sector through investment in new and replacement models and components that will increase and sustain plant production volumes.
Abbreviation for: Complete and On Time Delivery.

Air consignment note. A document made out by, or on behalf of, the carrier(s), confirming receipt of the goods by the carrier and evidencing the contract between the shipper and the carrier(s) for the carriage of goods by aircraft as described therein
A rope loop, usually at the corners of a sail, for fixing the sail to a spar. They are often reinforced with a metal eye.
The combination of multiple orders for picking and loading, based on destination, size, priority, and other parameters.

A manufacturing approach in which equipment and workstations are arranged to facilitate small-lot, continuous-flow production.
