In a manufacturing “cell,” all operations necessary to produce a component or sub-assembly are performed in close proximity, thus allowing for quick feedback between operators when quality problems and other issues arise. Workers in a manufacturing cell are typically cross-trained and, therefore, are able to perform multiple tasks as needed.
A specialised tractor used only to move trailers around the warehouse facility and place them at doors where they can be loaded or unloaded.
A list of bidders and prices in a sealed bid procurement.
Finely divided water swept from crest of waves by strong winds.
Abbreviation for: Department of Commerce and Document of Compliance (as per ISM Code).

A process employed in the shipment of citrus fruits and other perishable commodities. The fruit is packed and placed in a cold room from which the heat is gradually extracted. The boxes of fruit are packed in containers that have been thoroughly cooled and transported through to their destination without opening the doors.
Abbreviation for: Flight Service Station.
Abbreviation for: Local Exchange Carrier.
Regulations governing the military and naval forces of UK and USA; read to every ship’s company on commissioning and at specified intervals during the commission.

Short Sea Shipping means the movement of cargo by sea between ports situated in geographical Europe, or between those ports situated in non-European countries having a coastline on the enclosed seas bordering Europe (Baltic, Mediterranean, and Black). It is a successful mode of transport in Europe.
Members of a supply chain (i.e. suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, retailers, etc.) who work in conjunction with one another to manufacture, distribute, and sell a specific product.
Contracts are closed based upon client’s key interests and requirements.
A type of boat traditionally used for carrying cargo or passengers on rivers and canals in England, particularly on the River Thames and the Norfolk and Suffolk Broads.
A draft payable upon presentation to the drawee.
The planks immediately either side of the keel.
A communication indicating that something has been received or understood. It usually refers to a form that is received by a supplier that accepts, or sometimes modifies, the purchase order.

Term used to describe the ratio of the Gross Margin Dollars of an item divided by the Cost of the item. Many people use the terms Margin & Markup as though they mean the same thing but they are very different. One of the main differences: Mark-up %, being based on cost, is seldom realized due to shrinkage, while Margin %, being based on actual sales, represents what has actually been achieved. In some instances it is beneficial to know how to convert markup to margin, and vice versa.

Actual sales shipment data that records product, quantity, customer, and other pertinent information and can be used in future demand calculations. It usually nets gross (outgoing) sales against customer returns.
Abbreviation for: Telephone Company.
Abbreviation for: Bright Radar Indicator Terminal Equipment.
Returned product can be handled in various ways, such as restocking, returning to vendor, auction, liquidation, destruction, or eco-friendly disposal.
The use of computer systems to program, setup, control, monitor, and generate reports for manufacturing equipment and processes.
A quantitative forecasting model that uses a time series to develop forecasts. With a time series model, the chronology of the observations and their values are important in developing forecasts.
A cause and effect diagram used in the theory of constraints to identify and construct the logic and sequence of actions required to reach intermediate and ultimate objectives.
Rear of a container or trailer – opposite the front or nose.

In supply chain terms when a customer order cannot be immediately fulfilled from stock, the customer requirement may be placed on ‘back order’. This implies that a replenishment order will be raised on the next tier of the supply chain and, when sufficient materials are available, the outstanding ordered amount will be forwarded to the original customer.
A group of vessel operators joined together for the purpose of establishing freight rates.

An error condition resulting from a transaction that drives the perpetual inventory below zero. Systems that allow negative inventory usually provide exception reports for cycle counting and analysis, and specify how the negative is handled in modules such as MPS and MRP.
The open procedure implies that every market part within the EU should be able to subscribe to a governmental tender.

A planning tool to diagram a sequence of events, or activities (nodes), and the interconnectivity of such nodes. It is used for scheduling and especially for determining the critical path through nodes
A merchant ship configured primarily for the transportation of cargo, but also for the transportation of at least some passengers.

A plan developed to ensure the application of measures on board the ship and designed to protect persons on board, cargo, cargo transport units, ship’s stores, or the ship from the risks of a security incident.
Abbreviation for: Rapid Response Manufacturing.
Intercompany, computer-to-computer transmission of business information in a standard format.
All the goods and materials that are stored by an organisation until they are needed.
Determination of the dutiable value of imported merchandise by a customs official who follows procedures outlined in their country’s tariff, such as the U.S. Tariff Act of 1930.
Abbreviation for: World Meteorological Organisation.
Abbreviation for: Supplier Selection Relationship Development and Management.

A light piece of string, yarn, rope, or plastic (often magnetic audio tape) attached to a stay or a shroud to indicate the local wind direction. They may also be attached to the surface and/or the leech of a sail to indicate the state of the air flow over the surface of the sail.They are referenced when optimising the trim of the sails to achieve the best boatspeed in the prevailing wind conditions

A document, issued by a bank per instructions by a buyer of goods, authorising the seller to draw a specified sum of money under specified terms, usually the receipt by the bank of certain documents within a given time.

A manufacturing order that reserves capacity and allocates material but, unlike a work order, has not been authorised for release to the production floor. MRP planned orders are automatically changed by the system at each regeneration; FPOs are manually controlled by the planner and are normally either turned into actual work orders, or cancelled. A tool for what-if capacity analysis, and also sometimes used to allocate known components on a bill of material that is not complete and requires finalisation before releasing to production orders for the floor.
A quality conformance test that does not eliminate the future usage of the product or service being tested.
The lowest deck of a ship of the line. The deck covering in the hold.
Use of a bay for storage.
Abbreviation for: Excess and Obsolete.

Is a type of auction in which the roles of buyer and seller are reversed. In an ordinary auction (also known as a forward auction), buyers compete to obtain a good or service by offering increasingly higher prices. In a reverse auction, the sellers compete to obtain business from the buyer and prices will typically decrease as the sellers undercut each other.
When a buyer takes over a seller’s mortgage upon purchasing a home.
Refuse container or dustbin.

The quantity of a planned or actual order for purchased or production items, calculated as a result of lot size rules that consider the reason for the order (to order or to stock), and the costs created by the trade off in creating and setting up orders vs. carrying inventory for a period of time.
Abbreviation for: Marine Environment Protection Committee.
Abbreviation for: Global Air Cargo Advisory Group.

1. Prior to about 1900, the term for a variety of explosive devices designed for use in water, including mines, spar torpedoes, and after the mid-19th century, “automotive,” “automobile,” “locomotive,” or “fish” torpedoes (self-propelled weapons which fit the modern definition of “torpedo”). 2. Since about 1900, a term used exclusively for a self-propelled weapon with an explosive warhead, launched above or below the water surface, propelled underwater towards a target, and designed to detonate either on contact with its target or in proximity to it.
A term used to describe the monetary requirements (CAPitalEXpenditure) of an initial investment in new machines or equipment.
To deliberately flood compartments on the opposite side from already flooded ones. Usually done to reduce a list.
The uppermost continuous deck extending from bow to stern.
Abbreviation for: Projected Available Balance.
A person who steers a ship.
Hinged cowling around a fixed propeller, allowing the drive to be directed to the side or forwards to manoeuvre the vessel.
Vehicles that a carrier assigns to a specific shipper for its sole use.
The charges related to the movement of products within the logistics chain, including inbound transport, internal transport, and handling.

EAN is a barcoding standard which is a superset of the original 12-digit Universal Product Code (UPC) system developed in North America. The EAN-13 barcode is defined by the standards organisation GS1. It is also called a Japanese Article Number (JAN) in Japan. UPC, EAN, and JAN numbers are collectively called Global Trade Item Numbers (GTIN), though they can be expressed in different kinds of bar codes. The EAN-13 bar codes are used worldwide for marking retail goods.
Abbreviation for: Passenger Boarding Bridge.

An integrated set of system functions designed to manage the locating, put-away, movement, picking, and cycle count/inventory verification activities of a warehouse or distribution centre. It normally receives purchase, sales, and inter-plant order data from a base ERP system that serve as the authorisation to initiate activities. Warehouse locations are described in terms of their weight and volume capacities to enable proper direction when moving or stocking material. Inventory and order status data, collected in real time often through the use of data collection devices, is normally uploaded to the base ERP system on a batch basis.
A logically linked sequence of activities in a network diagram.
The major shipping point in a local area; carriers consider all points in the local area to be the rate basis point.
Abbreviation for: International Field Office.
A boat that has been hauled and is now sitting on dry land.
The aftermost deck of a warship. In the age of sail, the quarterdeck was the preserve of the ship’s officers
Abbreviation for: Consumer Goods.
Abbreviation for Statistical Office of the European Communities.
Abbreviation for: General Aviation.
An approach to making the current and planned state of an operation or process transparent to everyone.
Specific combination of products and services provided in a “packaged” form to satisfy certain specialised needs. (The products in this context are sometimes also known as deliverables.)

A type of battleship designed with an “all-big-gun” armament layout in which the ship’s primary gun power resided in a primary battery of its largest guns intended for use at long range, with other gun armament limited to small weapons intended for close-range defense against torpedo boats and other small warships. Most, but not all, dreadnoughts also had steam turbine propulsion. Predominant from 1906, dreadnoughts differed from earlier steam battleships, retroactively dubbed “predreadnoughts,” which had only a few large guns, relied on an intermediate secondary battery used at shorter ranges for most of their offensive power, and had triple-expansion steam engines.
Literally, having cargo loaded as high as the ship’s rail; also means extremely drunk.
Location on a ship where the wheel is located; also called pilothouse or bridge.
A method by which cargo is loaded onto and unloaded from an ocean vessel, which in this case is with a crane.
Abbreviation for: Automated Meteorological Observation Station.
Bringing a person or thing up short, that is an unforeseen and sudden stop.
A system or report that provides the transactions and background data that created a current status.

The length of time into the future planning systems generate requirements and messages. The horizon should be at least as far out as the single longest cumulative lead time for any item in the system.

Describes the various designs of lift-truck attachment used to handle 55 gallon drums. Some are smaller versions of a paper roll clamp while others may engage the upper rim of the drum, or the lower rings. Some drum attachments are capable of picking up multiple drums at the same time.
Abbreviation for: Available Seat Mile.
Abbreviation for: Accelerate-Stop Distance Available.
An enterprise that offers services via ocean (water) transport.
Provides an image of the degree to which a company succeeds in making everything run perfectly, according to its own standards and requirements.
The ability of a company to operate in three major world markets – United States, the European Union, and Asia.
Abbreviation for: Completely Knocked Down. Parts and sub-assemblies being transported to an assembly plant.
A net advantage gained by a common location with other companies
The centralized update of distributed devices and systems with separate databases to bring them up to the same status.
A structure attached to land where vessels are moored.

A branch of job design that is primarily concerned with the physiological aspects of job design, with how the human body fits with process facilities and the environment; can also be referred to as human factors, or human factors engineering.
The fixed quantity which should be ordered each time the available stock (on hand plus on order) falls below the re-order level.

Series of interdependent companies (considered as links of the chain) collaborating to carry out activities (procurement, production, and distribution) for the movement of products or services from product development to end of life (after-sales service and withdrawal logistics).
Abbreviation for: Runway Safety Action Team.
A sea where waves are moving perpendicular to the direction a ship is moving.
The categorisation of a system that has high functionality, reliability, and consistency when operating in a normal capacity and can endure periodic stress conditions.
Warehouse approved by the Treasury Department and under bond/ guarantee for observance of revenue laws. Used for storing goods until duty is paid or goods are released in some other proper manner.
Abbreviation for: National Facsimile Service.

Turnkey outsourcing applies when the responsibility for the execution of the entire outsourced function (or set of outsourced activities) lies with the external provider. This includes not only the execution of the activities, but also the co-ordination of these activities.

Program providing Canadian Border Services Agency officers with electronic pre-arrival cargo information so that they are equipped with the right information, at the right time, to identify health, safety, and security threats related to commercial goods before the goods arrive in Canada.
A discounted cash flow method used to specify the return rate for an investment, in which the present value of cash inflows is balanced against the present value of outflows.
A list of all products routed through a given work centre. Useful in evaluating the impact of rate, cost, or process changes.
Maritime Satellite System.

A specific date used as a boundary for policy changes in planning or other systems. A policy that seeks to stabilise the master production schedule may prohibit changes to the existing schedule inside the time fence (which is based on lead time) and allow changes under certain circumstances after that date. Another example is the reaction to demand based on customer orders only inside the lead time fence, and based on forecast thereafter.
A person unfamiliar with being on the sea.
Abbreviation for: BEE Verification Agency.

A physically or logically segregated area within a warehouse defined by the type of material it contains (bulk or rack storage, hazardous material, etc.) or the division of equipment and personnel used to put away, move, and pick.
The constant price of a product at all geographic locations within a zone.

Two or more motor carriers working together to haul the shipment to a destination. Carrier equipment may be interchanged from one carrier to the next, but usually the shipment is re-handled without the equipment.

The company-wide demand and supply plan that provides the next level of detail in fulfilling business plan objectives by describing family-level sales, production, and inventory targets and incorporates the planned effects of new product or promotion introductions. It usually undergoes a monthly joint review by all departments that analyses current status against the previous plan to provide corrective action. The proposed S&OP is used by rough cut capacity planning (RCCP) to provide the initial view of aggregate capacity requirements and sets target production and inventory levels for the master production schedule.

Forms of transportation service that are more flexible and personalised than conventional fixed routes, fixed schedule service; often utilised to accommodate the elderly and disabled passengers unable to use the fixed route service.
In lean manufacturing, a work cell or line in which single parts are automatically offloaded that allows operators to directly move the part between successive machines without wait time.

Guidance system used with very-narrow-aisle vehicles such as order selectors and turret trucks. A steel rail is mounted on each side of the aisle, and rollers are mounted on the lift truck to guide it between the rails.
A government official residing in a foreign country, charged with representing the interests of his or her country and its nationals.
Anchor pin at the centre of a semi trailers’ upper coupler which is captured by the locking jaws of a tractor’s fifth wheel to attach the tractor to the semi-trailer.
an agreement between an apprentice and an employer for a set period of time during which the apprentice works and receives training in the workplace.
Abbreviation for: Public Data Network.
Changing from one tack to another by going through the wind. Also see: gybe.
First-in, last-out system of inventory.
Contract is based upon a fixed price (per period) for executing the project or a certain activity.
Abbreviation for: Cost, Insurance, Freight, and Exchange.

A pre-approved list of commodities/ products, usually grouped by manufacturer, which have proven to be in conformance with developed specifications and standards. The list may result from performance testing of the product, or as a result of field testing or laboratory analysis

A product or service that has a lesser or reduced impact on human health and the environment when compared with competing products or services that serve the same purpose. Such products or services may include, but are not limited to those which contain recycled content, minimize waste, conserve energy or water, and reduce the amount of toxics either disposed of or consumed.
A physical customs warehouse (i.e., where goods are not subject to excise duty) in which the warehouse keeper takes full responsibility for the goods stored or owns them.
Abbreviation for: Inter-governmental Organisation.

A future estimated inventory balance calculated by taking the current on-hand inventory, adding scheduled receipts, and subtracting requirements or allocations. Used in planning systems to determine reorder needs.

The set of supply chain activities that focus on evaluating demand for material and capacity, and formulate plans and schedules based on meeting that demand and company goals. System functions often involved in the planning cycle include MPS, MRP, Rough Cut Capacity, CRP, DRP, and Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS).

Accounting method of valuing stock issues that does not consider the real value of the purchases but rather the value of the next purchase. In an inflationary period, this method results in lower reported values and therefore faster alerts.
The order shipment date requested by a customer, or the initial target date evaluated by a vendor when determining their actual promise date.
The ratio of the effective green time (g) to the traffic signal’s cycle length (C).
A fast, door-to-door service for high-valued goods and documents; firms usually limit service to shipments weighing fifty pounds or less.
Abbreviation for: Manufacturing Control System.

A tag consisting of a microchip (which holds information) and an antenna (which sends and receives radio signals). Many companies use "smart labels" that combine an RFID tag with a barcode. Active tags have a battery and transmit signals independently, while passive tags are activated by a reader's signal. Active tags have a read range of up to 100 feet, while passive tags are limited to less than 10 feet.
A carrier which has a direct physical connection with, or forms a link between two or more carriers.

A percentage or fixed-dollar amount that allocates department or product overhead expenses to production on a labour hour, machine hour, labour dollar, material dollar, or unit basis. Syn.: Overhead rate.
Abbreviation for: Artificial Intelligence.
A screening technique sometimes used to examine the effects of several variables in one experiment and to avoid multiple runs of the same basic test.

The graphical representation of the current status of a system or process that defines its inputs, data flow, and outputs and provides the starting point for identifying changes required to reach a desired future state.

A computer term which refers to the processing of computer information after it has been accumulated in one group, or batch. This is the opposite of “real-time” processing where transactions are processed in their entirety as they occur
Extra stocks of inventory which are being held above known requirement in order to accommodate trends or promotions. May also be used to hedge against risk of supply problems
Abbreviation for: Sustainable Production Policy.
The cost variance created by using more or less actual labour hours than the standard labour hours for a given amount of production, while assuming the actual pay rate equalled the standard pay rate.

A traditional fishing boat used off the coast of England and the Atlantic coast of America for most of the 19th century and in small numbers up to the mid-20th century. Originally a cutter-rigged sailing boat, after about 1865 lengthened and given a ketch rig. Some had a topsail on the mizzen mast, others a bowsprit carrying a jib.
Under letters of credit, one or more shipments are allowed by the phrase “partial shipments permitted.”
The strategy of planning capacity levels such that they are always less than or equal to forecast demand.
Abbreviation for: Financial Reporting Standards Council.
The act of introducing new ideas to products, services, or processes.
Abbreviation for: Continental United States.
Abbreviation for: Canadian Aviation Regulations Advisory Council.
A rope used to control the setting of a sail in relation to the direction of the wind.
1. A vessel’s lateral motion from side to side. 2. To hoist: “Sway up my dunnage.”

Movement of cargo by water from one country through the port of another country, hence, using rail or truck, to an inland point in that country or to a third country. As example, a through movement of Asian cargo to Europe across North America.
Abbreviation for: East African Community.

Specifies how, when, and where to transport goods. Transportation planning and scheduling applications may provide weight/size restrictions, merge-in-transit, continuous move, mode or carrier selection, and less-than-truckload/full truckload planning functionality
Suppliers who supply first-tier suppliers with whom organizations have no direct contractual relationship.
A form of warehousing that attempts to position seasonal goods close to the marketplace.
Cost associated with each order for materials placed with suppliers.
A design decision that represents the company’s ability to profitably capture future market share.

The process of identifying and measuring the gaps and imbalances between demand and resources in order to determine how to best resolve the variances through marketing, pricing, packaging, warehousing, outsource plans, or some other action that will optimise service, flexibility, costs, assets (or other supply chain inconsistencies) in an iterative and collaborative environment.

term: BLACK PROFESSIONAL SERVICE PROVIDERS SOUTH AFRICA
definition: Black individuals who provide service of professional nature.
Abbreviation for: Eastern Central Motor Carriers Association.
A particular type of tensioning lever, usually for running backstays. Their use allows the leeward backstay to be completely slackened so that the boom can be let fully out.
Models that allow decision makers to evaluate various alternatives across multiple decision criteria.
Abbreviation for Aggregate Production Plan and Approach.
That period between rising tide and falling tide, or that period between falling tide and rising tide when there is no tidal induced current.
1. To repair a mast or spar with a fillet of wood. 2. To secure an anchor on the side of the ship for sea (otherwise known as “catting”). 3. A slang term for a self-propelled torpedo.
A wedge shaped piece of timber used to secure barrels against movement
Shipping corridors marked by buoys which separate incoming from outgoing vessels. Improperly called Sea Lanes.
Abbreviation for: Freeze Speed Parameter.
A part of an organisation which is managed like a separate business with its own profit and loss financial reporting. For example, in the General Motors group Chevrolet is a business unit.

An international goods classification system for describing cargo in international trade under a single commodity-coding scheme. Developed under the auspices of the Customs Co-operations Council (CCC), an international customs organisation in Brussels, this code is a hierarchically structured product nomenclature containing approximately 5,000 headings and subheadings. It is organised into 99 chapters arranged in 22 sections. Sections encompass an industry (e.g., Section XI, Textiles and Textile Articles); chapters encompass the various materials and products of the industry (e.g. Chapter 50, Silk; Chapter 55, Man-made Staple Fibres; Chapter 57, Carpets). The basic code contains four-digit headings and six-digit subheadings. Many countries add digits for customs tariff and statistical purposes. In the United States, duty rates will be the eight-digit level; statistical suffixes will be at the ten-digit level. The Harmonised System (HS) is the current U.S. tariff schedule (TSUSA) for imports and is the basis for the ten-digit Schedule B export code.
Abbreviation for: Medium and Heavy Commercial Vehicles Automotive Investment Scheme.
A clockwork device used aboard a warship to continuously calculate the range to an enemy ship.
An attachment to a forklift that allows it to encircle and grasp a product.
Abbreviation for: Telecommunications Information Management System.
Abbreviation for: High Capacity Carriers.
Organisations that bridge strategic distances between a company and its supply chain partners.

The top of the boat; the surface is removed to accommodate the seating area. The structures forming the approximately horizontal surfaces in the ship’s general structure. Unlike flats, they are a structural part of the ship.
The work centre that performs the initial operation or process in a routing.

A method of supply used to satisfy the requirements of departments and agencies by arranging with suppliers to submit a standing offer to provide goods, services or both during a specified period. An RFSO is an invitation to suppliers to provide with a standing offer. The quantity of goods, level of services and estimated expenditure specified in the RFSO are only an approximation of requirements given in good faith. Standing offers are not contracts. If and when the government issues a call-up against a standing offer, a contract is created.

Abbreviation for: Enterprise Resource Planning. Refers to a system that integrates various functions within an organisation. It may be used for forecasting, materials management, etc. It is generally a computerised system.
A hull construction design in which a vessel has only one hull.
Regardless of the length of stay, a vessel is charged a one-time fee for use of shed space and/or marginal (waterside) rail track space. The charge is based on the length of a vessel.
Holding safety stock in a single location instead of multiple locations. Several locations then share safety stock inventories to lower overall holding costs by reducing overall safety stock levels.

A means to monitor the status and accuracy of orders that are being shipped to your customers. This visualisation displays a number of key metrics on a regional map like order accuracy, shipment department and arrival times, and the number of units shipped to each region. Tracking metrics should be tracked in real-time to allow your team to respond to developing situations and notify customers of any issues before they notify you of issues.

A ratio of stock to e.g. sales, set as standard and expressed as percentage, or as a factor number’ of days, weeks or months. The stock norm is determined by taking into account the: Safety stock, Production batch stock or shipment batch stock, Normal seasonal stock, Normative pipeline stock.
A vessel of 70,000 to 119,000 DWT capacity. The largest tanker size in the AFRA (average freight rate assessment) tanker rate system
Abbreviation for: Load-Bearing Area.
A long-term (20-50 years) general end that is achievable and marks progress toward a goal.
Free time given to officers and crew of a naval vessel when they are off duty and allowed to disembark and spend time on land. Also see: Liberty on page 312.

1. An object designed to prevent or slow the drift of a ship, attached to the ship by a line or chain; typically a metal, hook-like or plough- like object designed to grip the bottom under the body of water. 2.To deploy an anchor (“She anchored offshore.”)
In this situation, the price is based on the amount of profit that should be realized. Based on the fixed and variable costs and the expected selling price, the required sales volume is calculated.
Abbreviation for: Leased A B Service.
The classification of items based on similar production processes and resources required. Used in facility design evaluation and in some scheduling systems.

A supplier evaluation based on quality, delivery performance, price, involvement in process improvement programs, and other parameters that often results in vendor classifications such as preferred, approved (qualified), or unsatisfactory.
Finite Elements Method.
Accuracy of inventory records, calculated in number of units out of 100 that fall within accepted tolerances during a stock count.
Abbreviation for: Merchant Ship Search and Rescue Manual.
The process of raising the mast.

Differentiated from goods through four basic characteristics, i.e. intangibility, perishability, heterogeneity, and simultaneity. Basically, four types of services can be identified: (1) component services, that are passed on unaltered to the final customers of the buying organisation (e.g. luggage handling at the airport for an airline company), (2) semi-manufactured services, that are being integrated into the buying organisation’s value proposition to its customers (e.g. in-flight catering services contracted for by an airline), (3) instrumental services, that are used by the buying organisation to change their primary processes (i.e. management consultancy to professionalise the airline's operational processes) and (4) consumption services, that are used in different support processes within the buying organisation (e.g. cleaning services for offices of the same airline company). (5). Relate to a series of more or less tangible activities, which normally take place in the interaction between customer and supplier employees and/ or physical resources and systems, which are offered as an integrated solution to customer problems.
Abbreviation for: Empowerment and Enterprise Development Division.
A length of wire or rope secured at one end to a mast or spar and having a block or other fitting at the lower end. Often used incorrectly when referring to a Pennant (flag).
Abbreviation for: State Block Grant Program.

A batch-sizing technique in MRP or inventory management that will always cause planned or actual orders to be generated for a predetermined fixed quantity in MRP, or multiples thereof if net requirements for the period exceed the fixed order quantity.
The latest an activity can be started and still finish the project on time, calculated by subtracting the activity’s duration from its latest finish time.

The functions and department that process incoming material against purchase orders, inter-plant orders and customer returns, verify proper item, quantity and physical condition, move to stocking locations, and perform receipt update and documentation duties
Abbreviation for: Sector Suite.

All countries require that the importer make a declaration on incoming foreign goods. The importer then normally pays a duty on the imported merchandise. The importer’s statement is compared against the carrier’s vessel manifest to ensure that all foreign goods are properly declared.
Period consisting of the typical life phases (such as product launch, market penetration, market saturation) of a product.
Abbreviation for: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
A schematic representation of the elements in a defined system that defines their interrelationships and the rules for their interaction. Often used in electronic design and/or test systems.
Also known as an expedited order, this order is placed and processed to be picked and shipped in an expedited manner.

A demand for a mobility improvement that has been identified on the basis of accepted and adopted standards and other assumptions (e.g., land use) and documented in a formal long range or master plan.

Voice-recognition technology converts human speech into electrical signals. Operators wear a microphone/speaker headset connected to a mobile computer that communicates with a host computer system. Voice technology allows operators to execute instructions and to collect and communicate data in a hands-free environment.

All areas and things of, on, under, relating to, adjacent to, or bordering on a sea, ocean, or other navigable waterway, including all maritime related activities, infrastructure, people, cargo, and vessels and other conveyances.
Abbreviation for: Consolidated Uniform Payroll System.
The Security and Accountability For Every Port Act of 2006 which is an Act of Congress in the United States that covers port security.
A challenge to the award or proposed award of a contract for procurement of goods and services or a challenge to the terms of a solicitation for such a contract.
A process designed to have many sequential stages, each performing a relatively small part of the total task; the opposite of short fat process.
The skills and knowledge that operations staff need to meet customer expectations.

Like a hotel at sea, a ship needs many supplies to operate and serve its crew—groceries; paper products; engine parts; electronics; hardware; etc. A chandler sells these supplies to the ship’s agent. Originally, chandlers (candle makers) provided illumination to ships. Over time they expanded the variety of products they could provide to ships.

Relates to the management (planning, execution and control), and the realisation of housing and accommodation, the services related to these, and other means in order to enable the organisation to realise its mission.
Abbreviation for: Special Compensation P&I Clause.
Abbreviation for: Private Corporation other than ARINC or MITRE.
A record agreement that a proposed project meets all applicable requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), as issued by the designated lead agency.
Quality control concept based on inspection and test to detect and remove defects prior to releasing the product or service to the customer(s).
Abbreviation for: Less Than Truckload.
Abbreviation for: Non-governmental Organisation.
Not Otherwise Indexed.
An occasion determined by a specific day and time on which the bids received from vendors are opened, often in the presence of bidders, purchase executives, and related personnel.
The use of resources within the firm to provide products or services.

New technologies to enable real-time communications continue to emerge. Mesh networking is a new development to improve the performance of wireless LANs. In a typical RF application, each device on the network talks to a radio at an access point, which in turn, communicates to a base station and the Ethernet. A mesh network, on the other hand, is a loose grid that can relay data from one radio to the next. The radios locate each other and determine the best way to route a packet of data back to the Ethernet. A mesh network, in theory, would allow a user to extend the LAN network into areas like a yard.
1. A barrel with a hole in used to hold water that sailors would drink from. By extension (in modern naval usage), a shipboard drinking fountain or water cooler. 2. Slang for gossip.
Software that has the source code freely available for modification. In most cases, open source software is also “Free software” in that it requires no licensing fees.
Abbreviation for: Bureau for Economic Research.
A supply chain vendor or customer that does business with a given organisation and normally has linked communications.
Abbreviation for: Process Flow Scheduling.
A large bracket attached firmly to the deck, to which the foot of the mast is fixed. It has two sides or cheeks and a bolt forming the pivot around which the mast is raised and lowered.
The value of the imported goods on which duties will be assessed.

An inventory system in which a replenishment order is issued each time a withdrawal is made, and the order quantity is equal to the amount of the withdrawal. This type of system is also referred to as a par-stock system (bringing stock back to par level).
All deaths in which a motor vehicle was the cause of the fatality. This includes pedestrians and bicyclists killed by motor vehicles as well as vehicle occupants.
An item number identifier that uses a small portion of the number, normally the first few characters, to categorise it as part of a group and random characters for the rest.
The process of identifying, conducting negotiations with, and forming supply agreements with vendors of goods and services.
The percentage of orders that are error-free. total orders – error orders) / total orders) * 100
The ability of a carrier to provide service between an origin and a destination
A U.S. airline industry association.
The probability of meeting all demand in a stock cycle.
Abbreviation for: Baltic Freight Index.

A sailing boat with two masts with a standard rig consisting of a main dipping lugsail and a mizzen standing lug sail developed in Scotland; used for commercial fishing from the 1850s until the 20th century.
Comparing an organization’s processes with those of non-competitors that have been identified as superior.
Abbreviation for: Message Switching Network.
A shared administrative agency created to perform the purchasing function for two or more governmental units in a joint administrative purchasing arrangement.
An analytical tool used in public planning; a ratio of total measurable benefits divided by the initial capital cost.
A shipment passing between one port and another, or between a port and a final destination.
Abbreviation for: Business Activity Monitoring.
A vessel with two hulls.
Contractor delivers project or work turnkey.

A system which is designed to facilitate and organise the coming, going, and staging of trucks and trucks with trailers in the parking ‘‘yard,” that serves a warehouse, distribution or manufacturing facility.
Exposed varnished wood or polished metal on a boat
A complete listing of all cargo entering the country of discharge. Required at all world ports and is the primary source of cargo control, against which duty is assessed by the receiving country.
Quoted price for the product or service per unit delivered.
A bank that acts as an agent to the seller’s bank (the presenting bank). The collecting bank assumes no responsibility for either the documents or the merchandise.

term: Cycle Time to Process Excess Product Returns for Resale
definition: The total time to process goods returned as Excess by customer or distribution centres, in preparation for resale. This cycle time includes the time a Return Product Authorisation (RPA) is created to the time the RPA is approved, from Product Available for Pick-up to Product Received and from Product Receipt to Product Available for Use.
A check done by the VAN/third party network or the translation software to ensure the data being exchanged is in the correct format for the standard being used.

Item that is often used by a number of users and fulfils certain standards set up. The term is generally used in the context of government procurement of such items as stationery, vehicles, typewriters, and other office equipment, machines or accessories.
A device (chip) used for identification, which automatically transmits certain coded data when actuated by a special signal from an interrogator.
The process of creating individual orders or time-based schedules that serve as production or purchase authorisations.
Great Lakes slang term for a vessel with a conveyor or some other method of unloading the cargo without shore side equipment.
A restricted area at a seaport for the handling of duty-exempted import goods. Also called a Foreign Trade Zone.

Changes to a contract may require additional work and expense on the contractor. Change work, either directed by formal contract modification or through constructive change, entitles the contractor to seek an equitable adjustment. The contractor must prove that they are entitled to an equitable adjustment. The contract must contain language specifying the conditions under which an REA will be considered.
Abbreviation for: Employee Value Proposition and Executive Vice President.
See: Anticipation Stock.
A piece of wood or other material placed at the side of cargo to prevent rolling or moving sideways.

Systems and software that enable group participation in a problem or process. Collaboration systems supply methods for group definition, common technology, interaction and follow up, and present a common situation view to all participants, while enabling faster problem resolution.
A cargo ship that has fittings to carry standard shipping containers and retractable tweendecks that can be moved out of the way so that the ship can carry bulk cargo.
An arrangement of typing and function keys laid out in a specified manner used for entering data.
Abbreviation for: Ontario Institute Purchasing Management Association of Canada.
See: Million Gross Ton-Miles/Mile.
An equity equivalent contribution made by a multinational under an Equity and Equity Equivalent programme.
Abbreviation for: Traffic Management Coordinator.
See: Activity Based Costing
Abbreviation for: Marine Diesel Oil.
Contract is based upon a fixed price (per period) for executing the project or a certain activity.
Abbreviation for: Sales and Operations Planning.
Data Entry and Display System.
An approach to cost management that focuses on the relationships between activities, cost drivers, and resources to identify and separate value-added and non-value-added systems and functions.
A professional development organisation providing certification, networking, and advanced professional development opportunities for the supply chain sector.
Abbreviation for: Standard for the Exchange of Product model data.
Inventories, generally of finished products, that are in the possession of customers, dealers, agents, etc., but remain the property of the manufacturer by agreement with those in possession.

In cost management, a representation of resource costs during a time period, that are consumed through activities, and traced to products, services, and customers, or to any other object that creates a demand for the activity to be performed.
Masts or yards lying on board in reserve.

A marine insurance term which refers to partial loss on an individual shipment from one of the perils insured against, regardless of the balance of the cargo. Particular-average insurance can usually be obtained, but the loss must be in excess of a certain percentage of the insured value of the shipment, usually three to five percent, before a claim will be allowed by the company.

Warehouse design that uses structural pallet racks to support the roof of a building, eliminating the need for posts. Rack-supported buildings are usually designed for AS/RS systems or turret truck systems where racking is 40 to 100 ft. in height.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis and Retrieval.
Abbreviation for: Single Side Band.
Plugging is a method of switching direction, stopping, or slowing down without using a brake on electric industrial vehicles.
To steer (a vessel) away from the wind.

Suspension which supports the load on air-filled rubber bags rather than steel springs. Compressed air is supplied by the same engine-driven air compressor and reservoir tanks which provide air to the air brake system.
Abbreviation for: Central Business District. The area of a community with the most intense commercial and business development.
Instructions and methods used for a specific process or situation. They document the normal or accepted methodology and help form the basis for conformance evaluation.
Abbreviation for: Advanced Automation Program.
The amount of cargo a ship carries or is able to carry.

Term used by fire codes to describe the space to either side of pallets in racked storage. Flue spaces allow the water from an overhead sprinkler system to reach lower levels of the rack. Normally a transverse flue space of at least 3 inches is required (6 inches may be required under some circumstances). Also see: Longitudinal Flue Space.
The number of days in the logistic process that inventory sits idle compared to the number of days the inventory is moving.
Abbreviation for: South African Police Service.
Groups of people who meet to discuss ways of improving product quality
The process of integrating data residing in different sources, and creating a unified view of the data for users.
A structured measurement driven process that continually reviews and improves performance.
A pointed metal spike, used to separate strands of rope in splicing.

Computer application integrating all information flows to do with operational management of activities making up the Logistics Chain. SCE packages are generally made up of three main interfaced information management applications: TMS (Transportation Management Systems), WMS (Warehousing Management Systems) and AOM (Advanced Order Management).
See: Planning bill of material.
A system of catering in which a standard ration is issued to a mess supplemented by a money allowance which may be used by the mess to buy additional victuals from the pusser’s stores or elsewhere.
An approach to medium-term capacity management that attempts to adjust output and/or capacity to reflect fluctuations in demand.
A Latin term meaning “In proportion.”

1. Galley, the kitchen of a ship. 2. Galley, a type of ship propelled by oars used especially in the Mediterranean for warfare, piracy, and trade from the 700s BC to the 1500s AD, with some in use until the early 1800s. 3. A type of oared gunboat built by the United States in the late 18th century, akin to a brigantine but termed “galley” for administrative and funding purposes.
See: Third mate.
Passenger boarding at airports.

The company tries to win customers by charging them fairly low prices for high-quality offerings. Value pricing is not just setting lower prices but re-engineering operations to be a low-cost producer without sacrificing quality, attracting value-conscious customers.

A tier 1 supplier is the immediate or primary set of vendors directly used by a company, and tier 2 is a vendor to tier 1. In some industries the final customers or dominant chain partners are consolidating (reducing) their number of tier 1 suppliers, and requiring proof of the communications and fulfilment capabilities between tier 1 and tier 2.
The cycle of steps designated as define, measure, analyse, improve, and control, that are used to examine a process or product in the six sigma quality improvement methodology.

An inventory system where counts are performed continuously, often eliminating the need for an annual overall inventory. It is usually set up so that A items are counted regularly (i.e. every month), B items are counted semi-regularly (i.e. every quarter or six months), and C items are counted perhaps only once a year.
Abbreviation for: Airfield Delay Simulation Model.

Shipping trade on the spot market in which the vessels involved do not have a fixed schedule or itinerary or published ports of call. This contrasts with freight liner service, in which vessels make regular, scheduled runs between published ports.
A predefined labour group that works as a whole at a given operation or on a specific job. Used instead of reporting the individual personnel who did the work
An order picking method where each individual order is picked, line by line, prior to beginning the picking of another order.
A warehouse order picking scheme that selects the item locations with the smallest quantities first.
Removal of a shipment from a vessel.
Cost associated with having inventory on hand. It is primarily made up of the costs associated with inventory investment and storage; also called holding cost.

A condition in which traffic demand is sufficient to cause the LOS to be or at or below LOS standard (note: congestion is not necessarily, related to speed or delay). Adjectives describing the severity of congestion are: 1. Mild 2. Heavy 3. Severe. Adjectives describing the types of congestion are: 1. Non-recurring 2. Recurring
Similar to pick-to-light, using lights to guide where picked items should be placed.
The erosion a nation’s local industrial activity through the uncontrollable importation of the country’s needs be it industrial or consumer.
A product or service that is provided for the benefit of many normally at a cost recovery price and not necessarily for profit.
After receipt of unsaleable product at returns processing centre, product owner may choose to sell or dispose of product for nominal pricing.
Federal Express (Courier).
Abbreviation for: Approach Lighting System.

Supply-chain action initiated by the customer. In a pull environment, a customer’s purchase sends replenishment information back through the supply chain from retailer to distributor to manufacturer, so goods are “pulled” through the supply chain.
Abbreviation for: International Communications Switching Systems.
Abbreviation for: LABS Remote Equipment.

A process, usually statutory, whereby a government purchasing office may procure items without formal bidding procedures because of unique circumstances related to that particular action. For example, bids are waived for emergency purchases that are needed, due to a threat to the public safety.
A transportation line that hauls export or import traffic between ports and inland points. An enterprise that offers overland service to or from a point of export.
A symbolic (mathematical, textual, or graphic) representation of a process in its current ("as is") or intended ("should be") state.
The planned elimination of superficial, accidental, and deliberate differences between similar parts, in the interest of reducing part and supplier proliferation.
Debris ejected from a ship that sinks or washes ashore. Also see: Flotsam.
A lift truck fitted with lifting attachments operating to one side for handling containers.
Automated Export System (USA).

The period in which a vessel is unable to perform the services for which it is immediately required under a time charter. Off-hire periods can include days spent on repairs, dry docking, and surveys, whether scheduled or not.
Abbreviation for: Weighted Mean Absolute Percent Error (Statistics).
To change from one tack to the other away from the wind, with the stern of the vessel turning through the wind. Also see: going about and wearing ship.
Abbreviation for: Automatic Identification and Data Capture.
Ultra Large Crude Carrier. A tanker in excess of 320,000dwt.
One or more companies or individuals who participate in the flow of goods and services from the manufacturer to the final user or consumer.

A planned purchase, production, or inter-plant replenishment order generated by MRP or other planning system in response to a projected shortage against the specified safety stock level or order point. A suggested order generates capacity and lower level component requirements, but is not released and treated as an incoming receipt until reviewed and accepted.
Structural members on the longitudinal sides of the base of a container.
Abbreviation for: Airports Geographic Information System.

A value, usually expressed as a percentage, which expresses the level of precision incurred during transactions. An example is comparing actual inventory levels to those expected from bookkeeping records.
A future projected receipt based on the generation of a planned order that has not yet been firmed into a scheduled receipt.
The fixed dollar amount or percentage rate used to allocate overhead costs to a specific product.
A reference number on an engineering drawing that corresponds to a part number, usually listed in a table. Syn.: Bubble number.
A response to a bid or offer that does not conform to the mandatory or essential requirements contained in the Invitation for Bids (IFB).
Something of value given or done as recompense that is exchanged by two parties; that which binds a contract.
A term used in planning and control to indicate that a workstation requests work from the previous station only when required, one of the fundamental principles of just-in-time planning and control.
Abbreviation for: International Trade Centre.
Cost associated with each shortage (which may be dependent or independent of the amount of shortage or its duration).

1. A piece of fabric attached to a vessel and arranged such that it causes the wind to drive the vessel along. It may be attached to the vessel via a combination of mast, spars, and ropes. 2. The power harnessed by a sail or sails to propel a vessel. 3. To use sail power to propel a vessel. 4. A trip in a boat or ship, especially a sailboat or sailing ship. 5. In American usage, a sail is a tower-like structure on the dorsal (topside) surface of submarines constructed since the mid-20th century which houses periscopes, access trunks for the bridge, etc.; called a fin in European and British Commonwealth countries. It differs from the conning tower of earlier submarines, which was similar in appearance to a sail or fin but housed instruments and controls from which the periscopes were used to direct the submarine and launch torpedo attacks, functions not performed in a modern sail (or fin).
The range of different products and services produced by a process, a key characteristic that determines process behaviour.
Orders printed in Distribution Centres by 5pm local time for shipping the next day.
Abbreviation for: Uniform Accounting System.
A bill of lading issued by a consolidator as a receipt for merchandise that will be grouped with cargo obtained from other shippers.
A component, raw material, or other item used in the production of the next-level assembly (parent) item.
Expenses associated with storing inventory, such as leasing, climate control, and administrative costs.
A purchase or production order that occurs at a regular time interval and covers the variable demand during that period.
Refers to: VOR collocated with TACAN.
Purchasing of all materials and products that are used for manufacturing companies end products.
Abbreviation for: Centimetre.
Used for sending messages to outside companies. Messages are transmitted via Western Union, ITT, and RCA. Being replaced by fax and internet.
1. On the lee side of a ship. 2. To leeward.

Any investment made by or through any third party regulated by legislation on behalf of the actual owner of the funds, pursuant to a mandate given by the owner of the funds, pursuant to a mandate given by the owner to a third party, which mandate is governed by that legislation.
A light used to illuminate the inside of a trailer in order to aid in the loading and unloading processes.

A type of large, heavily armoured warship of the second half of the 19th century and first half of the 20th century armed with heavy-calibre guns, designed to fight other battleships in a line of battle. It was the successor to the ship-of-the-line of the Age of Sail.
Abbreviation for: Exclusive Economic Zone.
Inventory items whose demand levels are tied directly to a company’s planned production of another item.
Code also known as Traded Unit Code. A unique barcode that identifies the SKU and quantity contained within the outer case.
Freight railroads which are not Class I or Regional Railroads, which operate less than 350 miles of track and earn less than $40 million.
The methods used to respond to outside product demand that include producing to stock or to order, fill rate % and other targets.
Organisational entity in charge of all, or part of, the planning and/or implementation of logistics-related activities.

Inventory held in order to be able to: Satisfy a demand with seasonal fluctuations with a production level that does not fluctuate at all or that varies to a lesser extent than the demand. It enables organisations to cope with erratic production or deficiencies in production capacity
An expanded version of the exponential smoothing model that includes a trend adjustment factor.
Abbreviation for: Central Flow Weather Unit.
A class of mathematical models used when the user seeks to optimise some objective functions, subject to some constraints.
Abbreviation for: Visual Display Unit.

The idea that many different ways of processing products and services at many different locations or points in time combine to result in an exceptionally large number of feasible options; the term is often used in facilities layout and scheduling to justify non-optimal solutions (because there are too many options to explore).
A system of programs designed to assist in specific applications
Abbreviation for: Facility.
Abbreviation for: Terminal Navigational Aids.
The Auto Regressive Integrated Moving Average forecast technique based on time series analysis and regression modeling, useful for short-term forecasts.
An organisational structure that groups together either its resources needed to produce a product or service group, or those needed to serve a particular geographical area in separate divisions.

The date required to firm, or release, a planned order based on the specified lead time until the planned receipt date. Many systems allow the selection and review of planned orders based on specifying a release date time frame.
Generic Environmental Management System Standard (ISO).
Coefficient representing a series of reference data used in the context of forecasting seasonal demand.
Abbreviation for: Approach Lighting System Improvement Plan.

The total amount of time between the recognition of a required task, operation, or process, and its completion. Elements of lead time can include order entry, material accumulation, machine setup, queue, processing, move, and other activities which can be classified by systems that seek to eliminate waste as valued-added (processing that actively adds value as perceived by the customer) and non-value-added.

1. The management of inter-connected value adding activities and channel relationships for long term value chain benefit (Boateng, 2013). By its nature, it collaboratively helps to breakdown silos and self-centred thinking within a value chain, thus ensuring the creation of a shared vision for sustainable long term, ‘win-win’ partnerships. 2. A set of business processes that seamlessly work together to ensure that requirements of the end user are at all times satisfied within reasonable time and cost limits (Boateng, 1998).
Purchase Order Management. To allow receiving of contract warehouse inventory, purchase orders (at $0) are sent by inventory owner and mirrored in systems.
Very Large Crude Carrier. A tanker of 200,000 to 319,000dwt. It can carry about 2 million barrels of crude oil.

Property required by a lender and offered by a borrower as a guarantee of payment on a loan. Also, a borrower's savings, investments or the value of the asset purchased that can be seized if the borrower fails to repay a debt.
The Internet service that transfers files from one computer to another, over standard phone lines.

Here, the contracting authority can negotiate face-to-face with market parties about the contents, execution, and costs related to the contract. The negotiation procedure can be used with or without (pre)-announcement.

Term used to describe an approach to complying with customer requirements for physical identification of shipped goods. Most recently, slap-an-ship has been used to describe complying with RFID requirements (such as those from Wal-Mart), however, it is also applicable to any compliance labelling requirement (such as compliance bar code labels). Slap-and-ship implies you are meeting the customer’s requirement by applying the bar code labels or RFID tags, but are not utilising the technology internally.
Abbreviation for: Cost-of-Sales.
To combine two or more shipments going in the same direction or to the same destination on a single trailer.

A ship of the same class as, and therefore virtually identical in design and appearance to, another ship. Sister ships share an identical or nearly identical hull and superstructure layout, similar displacement, and roughly comparable features and equipment. Often, sister ships become more differentiated during their service lives as their equipment (and, in the case of military ships, their armament) are separately altered.
A privately owned ship authorized by a national power (via a Letter of Marque) to conduct hostilities against an enemy. Also called a private man-of-war.
A vessel directed to keep her course and speed where two vessels are approaching one another so as to involve a risk of collision.
The capacity used in evaluating requirements for a given material planning period, which may differ from demonstrated capacity due to temporary additions or downtime for scheduled maintenance, etc.
The assignment of a specific number for a top-level manufacturing order that is carried through all succeeding levels and orders, and pegs costs and material to a single project.
U.S. Customs’ master computer system, “Automated Commercial Systems.” Now being replaced by the Automated Commercial Environment system.
Abbreviation for: Consolidated NOTAM System Processor.

term: Toe the Line or Toe the Mark
definition: At parade, sailors and soldiers were required to stand in line, their toes in line with a seam of the deck.
A technique used in the design of cell layouts to find out which process groups fit together naturally.
Abbreviation for: Monthly Recurring Charge.
The activity of monitoring and improving levels of quality of the products and services delivered by suppliers; also used to assess supply capacity when choosing between alternative suppliers.
Abbreviation for: Saturday and Holidays Excluded.

A system or service that combines data or items with similar characteristics (geographic area, target market,
size, etc.) into larger entities. Value is derived from cost savings, or the ability to reach a larger market and charge higher prices from bundling multiple goods or services
Abbreviation for: Design for Assembly.
The disassembly and analysis of a competing product to evaluate its comparative strengths and weaknesses in preparation for the possible manufacture of a similar item

A database file, often created manually as needed, that contains static records used to identify items, customers, vendors, bills of material, work centres, etc. as opposed to files used to track the dynamic status of orders and inventory balances.
Abbreviation for: Actual Landing Time Calculated.
Overhead costs incurred in support of the manufacturing process that can not be directly allocated to specific items, and do not vary with production changes as do direct material and labour costs.
The attractiveness to the operation of a process, product, or service.

Used primarily in the food industry for products such as seafood, meats, and cheeses; catch weights refer to the actual weight of variable-weight items that use weight as the sales unit of measure. Catch weights are generally recorded during the order picking or shipping process. Systems using catch weights must be able to correctly process sales order line items based on the catch weights being within specific tolerances of the “order quantity.”
One of two major decision categories addressed by a strategy. Includes tangible resources, such as buildings, equipment, and computer systems.
On a three-masted ship, having the sheets of the three lower courses loose will result in the ship meandering aimlessly downwind. Also, a sailor who has drunk strong spirits beyond his capacity.
Abbreviation for: Automatic Dependent Surveillance.
Bending over the barrel of a gun for punitive beating with a cane or cat.
Abbreviation for: Micro-electromechanical Systems.

A document which is issued by a procurement entity to obtain statements of the qualifications of potential development teams or individuals (i.e. consultants) to gauge potential competition in the marketplace, prior to issuing the solicitation.
Certified Quality Auditor.
Grouping like parts or materials under one buyer’s control for the procurement of all requirements in support of a need.
See: Genoa.

A written notification from the public entity to the successful bidder, or offeror stating that there is an award of a contract in accordance with a bid or proposal previously submitted, and that effective with receipt the vendor or contractor shall proceed with performance; allows work to start while contract is printed and readied for distribution.
The amount of money an ocean carrier pays to the railroad for overland carriage.
Abbreviation for: Quality Assurance and Quality Agreement.
The practice of obtaining the same type of product, component, or service from more than one supplier in order to maintain market bargaining power or continuity supply.
Abbreviation for: Department of Defence (USA) Directive.

The time between the receipt of the customer order and the delivery
of the product to the customer.

Abbreviation for: Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. USA law which restructured transportation planning and funding by requiring consideration of multimodal solutions, emphasis on the movement of people and goods as opposed to traditional highway investments, flexibility in the use of transportation funds, a greater role of MPOs, and a greater emphasis on public participation.
In the British Royal Navy, a fourth rate was, during the first half of the 18th century, a ship of the line mounting from 46 up to 60 guns.
Abbreviation for: Liquefied Petroleum Gas.
A time series forecasting model that derives a forecast by taking an average of recent demand values.

A travel time reliability performance measure defined by a designated travel time (typically based on a 45 mph speed or 1.33 travel time index); conceptually represents a trip that arrives or does not arrive within a defined travel time.
The return of goods previously moved or shipped to a stock location without modification or usage.
Air Force Base.
The measure of a process, such as units, hours, weight, etc.

Inventory physically at a customer site that remains the financial possession of the vendor. The inventory is considered transferred when agreements specify it is physically recounted by the vendor, when it is used in production by the customer, by a customer self-billing process, or other method.
A firm that breaks down wastes in essential elements.
Process of shipping direct from a manufacturer’s plant or distribution centre to the customer’s retail store, thus, bypassing the customer’s distribution centre. Also called Direct-to-Store Delivery.
Abbreviation for: Distance Early Warning Identification Zone.
Abbreviation for: Broad Based Black Economic Empowerment.
Refers to: Surface Picture.
Abbreviation for: Bill of Materials.
Pricing based on competitive tendering among preselected suppliers, often using e-auctions or formal tendering processes.
An agreed-upon set of terms and conditions subject to which the customer will accept the process output. The basis for the supplier’s commitment.
A knot tied in the end of a rope, usually to stop it passing through a hole; most commonly a figure-eight knot.
A marine barometer. Older barometers used mercury-filled glass tubes to measure and indicate barometric pressure.
Description of internal customer requirements for goods and/or services needed from suppliers, serving as the basis for the purchase order.
Assessing the internal quality and control system of an organisation using a systems approach.
Abbreviation for: Design for Automated Assembly.
A type of plastic or metal strapping that helps support a load and hold it together. It can be used to strap and secure product on a pallet or skid
National Credit Regulator.

The portion of demand for a given item not created by the requirement for any other item. Whether for an end item or a component, independent demand is created by a sales or internal distribution order for that item, and not because it is used in an upper-level assembly.
A production schedule that exceeds actual production capabilities.
The study of the behavioural of supply chains, especially the level of activity and inventory levels at different points in the chain; its best known finding is the bullwhip effect.

An accounts receivable function that uses an escalating series of notices and defined verbiage to document the contacts and attempts made in collecting payment from a customer. Evidence of the attempts are a legal requirement in certain countries if claims are made for unpaid bills.
A for-hire air carrier that is subject to economic regulation and requires an operating certification to provide service.

An aspect of a company’s social responsibility program related to the use of all people in the workplace, regardless of ethnicity, gender, age, religion, disability, national origin and sexual orientation.
Data label adhered to a product for the purpose of asset tracking at the end customer location.
Purchasing cost reductions are sustainable in character. These may be the result from a change of the specification, a change of supplier, or omitting an unnecessary product quality requirement.

Totality of communications and procedural activities required to produce a committed outcome (execute a single business cycle or transaction) over time. The customer-supplier dialogue comprises four phases: definition, negotiation, performance, and assessment.
Agreement among competing vendors to sell at the same price.
A document similar to, or the same as a purchase order, which is provided to a supplier as confirmation of a previous verbal purchase request.
This discount is applied to improve manufacturing capacity utilisation in periods when sales are low. Buyers ordering out of season get a lower price.
Abbreviation for: Civil Aviation Security Office.
Having direct access to the computer. Changes, additions, and deletions are immediately updated.

The date required to initiate an operation or process in order to achieve on-time completion by the due or finish date. The start date is often determined by establishing a required due date and backing into the start date based on the standard lead time for a given quantity.
The opening in the side of the ship or in a turret through which the gun fires or protrudes.
State-of-industry performance or application. Standard published operating methods found to produce the best performance and results in a given industry or organization.
The ability to fulfil customer demand by accurately forecasting the inventory and distribution of products required.
The output resulting from a process, such as the quantity of finished products from manufacturing.
The countries of the world that have advanced economies and high human development indices, typically democratic and capitalistic.

Provides for a price that is not subject to any adjustment on the basis of the contractor’s cost experience in performing the contract. This type of contract places upon the contractor maximum risk and full responsibility for all costs and resulting profit or loss. Provides maximum incentive for the contractor to control costs and imposes a minimum administrative burden on the government.
Abbreviation for Accounting Officer / Accounting Authority.

1. A period, traditionally on Wednesday afternoons, when a tailor boarded a sailing warship while the vessel was in port; the crew was excused from most duties and had light duty mending uniforms and hammocks and darning socks.When the ship was at sea, the crew similarly was excused from most duties on Wednesday afternoons to engage in mending chores.  2.After uniforms began to require less care, and through the mid-20th century, a period on Wednesday afternoon when naval crew members were excused from their regular duties to run personal errands.  3.Since the mid-20th century, any period of free time when a naval crew is given early liberty or otherwise excused from its normally scheduled duties
Abbreviation for: Automatic Data Processing.
Abbreviation for: Economic Order Quantity.

A field or code that classifies an item, vendor, customer or other entity as part of a group that has common characteristics. Many reports, files, and processing functions provide for the use of group codes instead of requiring individual entries.
Abbreviation for: Delivered at Place (Incoterms).

A computer term. A piece of information from your computer that references what the user has clicked on, or references information that is stored in a text file on the user’s hard drive (such as a username). Another way to describe cookies is to say they are tiny files containing information about individual computers that can be used by advertisers to track online interests and tastes. Cookies are also used in the process of purchasing items on the Web. It is because of the cookie that the “shopping cart” technology works. By saving in a text file, the name, and other important information about an item a user “clicks” on, as they move through a shopping Website, a user can later go to an order form, and see all the items they selected, ready for quick and easy processing.
Allows a text message to be defined and printed on every packing slip.
Person who operates a yard tractor.
A meeting arranged by a procurement office to help potential bidders understand the requirements of an RFB or an RFP.
A group of products shipped together as an unassembled unit.
Abbreviation for: Ground Proximity Warning System.
A series of activities, which combined, define a business process; the series of activities from manufacturers to the retail stores that define the industry supply chain.
The display of only one level on a bill of material or where-used report, as in the set of immediate components for a parent or the next higher level of parent when tracing a component.
A rack system that pushes stored products up an inclined ramp for deep pallet storage.

1.A strategic performance management tool used for measuring whether the smaller-scale operational activities of a company are aligned with its larger-scale objectives in terms of vision and strategy. By focusing not only on financial outcomes, but also on the operational, marketing, and developmental inputs to these, the Balanced Scorecard helps provide a more comprehensive view of a business, which in turn helps organisations act in their best long- term interests. See also: Scorecard 2.A structured measurement system based on a mix of financial and non-financial measures of business performance.

An existing or planned transportation facility providing an interface between more than one mode of transportation [at least one of which must provide interstate or interregional service to be designated as Strategic Intermodal System (SIS) or Emerging SIS].
The assembly of received product onto pallets to facilitate optimum storage efficiency or to replace non-compatible pallets.
Abbreviation for: Initial Public Offering.
To comply with the U.S. regulations, exporters are required to provide special notices to inland and ocean transport companies when goods are hazardous.
This is transportation shorthand for intermodal exchange. In an IMX yard, containers can be lifted from truck chassis to rail intermodal cars or vice versa.
A similar term to a cell layout but sometimes used to indicate a larger clustering of resourcing. Also see: ‘Shop-within-a-shop’.
Remote Control Interface Unit.
Risk that both contractual parties will primarily pursue their own interest.
Abbreviation for: Canadian Association for Production and Inventory Control (obsolete—now APICS).
Abbreviation for: OLE for Process Control.
A long ton of cargo that can be stowed in less than 40 cubic feet.
Products According to Paul Harmon, these include “software tools that allow analysts to model processes and . . . then automate the execution of the process at run time.”
Used synonymously with a bill of materials in process industries.

An organisation made up of local elected and appointed officials responsible for development, in cooperation with the state, transportation plans and programs in metropolitan areas containing 50,000 or more residents. MPOs are responsible for the development of transportation facilities that will function as an intermodal transportation system and the coordination of transportation planning and funding decisions.

A high-speed, high-capacity transmission channel. Broadband channels are carried on radio wave, coaxial, or fibre optic cables that have a wider bandwidth than conventional telephone lines, giving them the ability to carry video, voice, and data simultaneously
Traditional Royal Navy term for a day (or shorter period) of rest and relaxation.
Abbreviation for: Off-airway Weather Station.
Abbreviation for: Client Side Browser Based
The act of taking an activity traditionally performed by a designed agent and outsourcing it to a large group of people in the form of an open call.
