1. The upper aftermost corner of a fore-and-aft sail; used in many combinations, such as peak-halyards, peak-brails, etc. 2. The narrow part of a vessel’s bow, or the hold within it. 3. The extremity of an anchor fluke; the bill.
2,204.6 pounds or 1,000 kilograms.
The practice of providing a carrier with detailed information and negotiated pricing prior to scheduling pickup. This practice can help assure contract compliance and facilitate automated payments.
A special form of bar chart that shows frequency counts from highest to lowest.

Systems where decision-making, flow of data or goods and services, or the beginning of activities are initiated at the same central point and disseminated to remote points in the chain or organisation.
A collection of methods that can be used to ensure that an operation (usually with a fixed capacity) maximises its potential to generate profit.
Federal.

The sharing of internal schedules, often as generated by MRP, for specified items with a vendor, instead of placing individual purchase orders as required. A vendor schedule is often divided into zones, such as a firm commitment zone in which the customer will pay for any vendor production against that schedule, an information zone, which projects requirements that authorise the vendor to purchase raw material but not add labour, and an information zone that gives foretasted long-term requirements but does not make a commitment.
The number of concurrent or maximum users, or sometimes devices, allowed under software license agreements.

Evaluating and testing returned goods with certified technicians to restore to working order and sell as refurbished. Product can be made available for sale through standard channels or auction sites, and is then warehoused.
Abbreviation for: Declaration of Dangerous Goods (Hazardous materials as defined in regulations declaration document) and Deputy Director General.
A business that owns ships that operate in international trade.
Abbreviation for: Revenue Acquisition Process.
Any Time Day or Night Sundays & Holidays Included. A chartering term referring to when a vessel will work.

Unpowered Great Lakes vessels, usually a fully loaded schooner, barge, or steamer barge, towed by a larger steamer that would often tow more than one barge. The consort system was used in the Great Lakes from the 1860s to around 1920.
Abbreviation for: Cost Plus Award Fee.
A bill of lading term to provide surrender of the original bill of lading before freight is released; usually associated with a shipment covered under a letter of credit.
Refers to carriage of goods by lighter and the charge assessed there from.
Using cost management techniques to reduce the organisation’s costs and improve profit while supporting its value proposition.
The same as FOB named inland carrier, except the seller pays the freight charges of the inland carrier.

Reply to an order or command to indicate that it, firstly, is heard; and, secondly, is understood and will be carried out. (“Aye, aye, sir” to officers). Also the proper reply from a hailed boat, to indicate that an officer is on board.

A statistical method used for a single dependent variable that performs comparisons and tracks the effects of a number of discrete factors (independent variables), each of which may have a number of levels, and may interact to affect the dependent variable
Abbreviation for Return on Marketing Investment.

The real cost associated with purchasing materials and services, and paying internal personnel. A standard cost system tracks actual usage, as defined by hours or units consumed, based on a standard value, to calculate and track variances versus the standard hours or units; an actual cost system—often used in to-order environments—attempts to assign the true cost of every purchase, material issue, and labour activity to jobs and products.

An order picking efficiency technique that combines multiple orders for a date or customer range and summarises the total requirements for items on all orders. It allows going to an inventory location once to pick for several orders instead of returning to the same location multiple times.
From Facility.
An official request from an internal user/customer for the fulfilment or procurement of goods, services or works.
Abbreviation for: Self-Managed Work Teams.
Black people who also satisfy all of the criteria in the definition of “persons with disabilities” in terms of section 54(1)(a)of the Employment Equity Act of South Africa.
A bill of lading issued by a forwarder to a shipper as a receipt for goods that the forwarder will consolidate with cargo from other shippers for transport.
A valve, which can be opened from the inside of the ship, that connects the sea to internal fuel, water, or ballast tanks (see also seacock).

Manufacturing Resource Planning. Direct outgrowth and extension of closed-loop MRP. Was developed as a method to calculate the utilization of resources (machines, material, and people) in a manufacturing company. The concept covers the step-by-step planning starting at the highest level in the planning hierarchy. Most ERP Systems are based on this principle.
Abbreviation for: Employment Creation Fund.

A technique for strategically positioning inventory to meet customer service levels while minimising inventory and storage levels. Excess inventory is replaced with information derived through monitoring supply, demand, and inventory at rest as well as in motion.
An operation that performs few, if any, value-adding activities itself, rather it organises a network of supplier operations, seen as the ultimate in outsourcing.
Financial Intelligence Centre Act.
Abbreviation for: Transportation Control Measures.
A classification of regulated carriers based upon annual operating revenues: Motor carriers of property - $5 million; Railroads - $50 million; Motor carriers of passengers - $3 million.
1. A fore-and-aft structural member of the hull fitted over the keel to provide a fixing for the garboard planks. 2. A rough flat scrubbing brush for cleaning a ship’s bottom under water.
A type of bird that has little fear and therefore is particularly easy to catch.
The act in which the inventory level is being adjusted for a specific item.
Key subcontractor contracts reflect all conditions of the main contract.
Profit from the sales of goods and services, before interest expenses, investment results, and taxes.

A term used in work measurement to indicate the process of timing (usually with a stopwatch) and rating jobs; it involves observing times, adjusting or normalising each observed time (rating) and averaging the adjusted times.
Abbreviation for: Signal Integrity Verification.

Overall term for the use of network-based techniques for the analysis and management of projects; for example, included critical path method (CPM) and programme evaluation and review technique (PERT).
Abbreviation for: Short Takeoff and Landing.
Requires funds to be used only for needs or services in the year of the appropriations obligation period.
A technique to improve management focus and overall productivity by creating autonomous business units within a larger physical plant.
Abbreviation for: Throughput Value Added.

Light cord attached to a mooring line at two points a few inches apart with a slack section in between (resembling an inch-worm) to indicate when the line is stretching from the ship’s rising with the tide. Obviously only used when moored to a fixed dock or pier and only on watches with a flood tide.
Abbreviation for: Tower Communications System.
Abbreviation for: Export Credit Insurance Corporation.
A possible source of supply for military logistics.
Refers to: Special Visual Flight Rules.
Required by some countries for protection against the dumping of certain types of merchandise or products.
Abbreviation for: Canadian Minimum Navigation Performance Specification Airspace.
The level of rate of output from a process, a key characteristic that determines process behaviour.
A very fast sailing ship of the 19th century that had three or more masts, a square rig, a long, low hull, and a sharply raked stem.

Sailing into the wind (by), but not as close-hauled as might be possible, so as to make sure the sails are kept full. This provides a margin for error to avoid being taken aback (a serious risk for square-rigged vessels) in a tricky sea. Figuratively it implies getting on with the job but in a steady, relaxed way, without undue urgency or strain.
Shared boundary between two or more processes across which objects (material) and information (communications, data) are passed.
Standing rigging running from a mast to the sides of a ships to support the mast sideways. The shrouds work with the stays, which run forward and aft, to support the mast’s weight.
A safe harbour, including natural harbours, which provide safety from bad weather or attack.
See: Corps of Engineers
Abbreviation for: Oil Pollution Preparedness and Response.

Uses an incentive whereby the contractor’s profit is increased or decreased by a predetermined share of an overrun or underrun. A firm target is established from which to later compute the overrun or underrun. A ceiling price is set as the maximum amount the government will pay. Necessary elements for this type of contract are: target cost—best estimate of expected cost; target profit—fair profit at target cost; share ratio(s)—to adjust profit after actual costs are documented; and ceiling price—limit the government will pay.
Abbreviation for: Telecommunications Ordering and Pricing System (GSA software tool).
Abbreviation for: Applicability Statement 2.

A method of inventory control which divides items into categories based on value of usage, something like a Pare to division, where the items which constitute the highest dollar value are tracked more closely than those with lower value movement. In this method an item with high volumes of movement, but low cost, such as a small cheap fastener, would more than likely be counted less frequently than a slower mover which has a very high cost. Items are typically divided by a company’s defined set of values into an “A”, “B” and “C” group, and sometimes even a “D” group. Count frequencies are then applied to each of the groups.
For example, “A” class items may be counted weekly, “B” class items monthly, and “C” class items quarterly, as a part of a cycle counting program
Abbreviation for: Dual Call, Automatic Answer Device.
Or e-procurement – systems for electronic purchasing of materials, often using the Web.
Abbreviation for: Dynamic Data Exchange.
Abbreviation for Air National Guard.
Any change made to the terms of a credit. The applicant initiates the amendment which then follows the same process as a letter of credit.
The method of estimating relationships between dependent variables and one or more independent variables that measures how the distribution of a variable changes as input conditions change.
The National Consumer Commission.
Increasing the possibility of individuals varying the time during which they work.
The common basic features of all social, organic, and mechanical systems.
A structured list of all the materials or parts and quantities needed to produce a particular finished product, assembly, sub-assembly, or manufactured part, whether purchased or not.
Process used for environmental review of qualifying non-federal major transportation projects, as defined by DOT Project Development and Environmental manual.

To include or contain: As applied to a naval task force, the listing of all assigned units for a single transient purpose (mission). “The Task Force comprises Ship A, Ship B, and Ship C.” ‘Comprise’ means exhaustive inclusion—there aren’t any other parts to the task force, and each ship has a permanent squadron existence, independent of the task force.
A method of allocating indirect/ overhead costs to inventory items and costs of sales. See also: Absorption Costing
Abbreviation for: International Ship Managers’ Association.
A freestanding pinrail surrounding the base of a mast and used for securing that mast’s sails’ halyards with a series of belaying pins.

A description of types of activities dependent on the functional area. Product-related activity levels may include unit, batch, and product levels. Customer-related activity levels may include customer, market, channel, and project levels.
Compensation for loss or injury suffered by one party to a contract as a result of the other party’s breach.
An identified potential consumer of a company’s goods or services, often tracked in CRM, SFA, or contact management systems.
A two-masted fore-and-aft rigged sailboat with the aft mast (the mizzen) mounted (stepped) afore (in front of) the rudder.

The process of connecting a moving rail car with a motionless rail car within a rail classification yard in order to make up a train. The cars move by gravity from an incline or “hump” onto the appropriate track.

A traditional wooden sailing boat with a rig consisting of one or two lateen sails, used in protected waters of the Red Sea and eastern Mediterranean and particularly along the Nile in Egypt and Sudan, and also in Iraq.

A universal connector that replaces serial and parallel connections for PC peripherals, with a standard plug and cable carrying both data and power. The USB significantly increases the number of peripherals that can be attached.
Conformity of a list of specified items to administrative specifications, with all quantities correct.
Abbreviation for: Commerce Service Provider and Customised Sector Programme.
Rail cars that permit top loading and bottom unloading of bulk commodities; some hopper cars have permanent tops with hatches to provide protection against the elements.
According to the PDMA, “the design of products to be less sensitive to variations, including manufacturing variation and misuse, increasing the probability that they will perform as intended.”
A combination of a prime mover and two independent trailers (one ‘lead’ trailer and one ‘tag’ trailer). Commonly sized to carry 32 or 34 pallets. Allowed to travel only on B-double approved routes.
A groove cut in wood to form part of a joint.
Instrument used to take bearings of celestial objects.
Abbreviation for: Gross National Product.
A small shipment that does not qualify for full truckload (FTL) rates based on weight or volume, and normally has a longer delivery time due to consolidation with other LTL shipments.
Abbreviation for: Distribution on Demand and Direct Outward Dial.
Forecasting techniques based on intuition or informed opinion. These techniques are used when data are scarce, not available, or irrelevant.

Financial diagnostic tool to calculate the company’s return on investment based upon sales margin and capital turnover ratio. Used to assess the effect of a 2% purchasing saving on the company’s return on investment (ROI).

In the context of new product development, the second phase of a product development effort. Here, the company begins to address the feasibility of a product or service. In the context of project management, the third of five phases of a project. Here, project planners prepare detailed plans that identify activities, time and budget targets, and the resources needed to complete each task.
A hull designed to travel through the water, rather than planning over it.
The members of a system.
Free Discharge.
The upper limit, expressed in quantitative, financial or time-based terms, to which the stock of an item should normally be allowed to rise.

A massive structure, usually of stone or concrete, used as a pier, a breakwater, or a causeway between places separated by water. May have a wooden structure built upon it and resemble a wooden pier or wharf, but a mole differs from a pier, quay, or wharf in that water cannot flow freely underneath it.

The act of making a group or individual responsible for certain activities or outcomes. For example, managers and executives are accountable for business performance even though they may not actually perform the work.
Abbreviation for: Aeronautical Radio, Inc.
Abbreviation for: Labour Management System.
Refers to: Airport and Airspace Simulation Model.
Any body of rate tariffs that are not part of an agreement or conference system.
A sailor who ‘knows the ropes’ is familiar with the miles of cordage and ropes involved in running a ship.
Collecting items from a storage location to satisfy a shop or customer order.
Count-per-unit chart.
The costs associated with errors and failures that are dealt with inside an operation but which cause disruption; an element within quality-related costs.
Abbreviation for: Joint Venture and Journal Voucher.
A fee charged for cargo passing through a pier or dock. Also known as a Warf Age Fee.

The division of a single original manufacturing lot or batch into two or more lots due to processing or lead time reduction considerations, or the requirement to modify part of the original batch into another form.
Abbreviation for: Programme of Action.
An extra or additional charge.
A sub-dimension of quality that addresses whether a product was made, or a service performed, to specifications.
A business that does not manufacture its own products, but purchases and resells products. Such a business usually maintains a finished goods inventory. Syn.: wholesaler.

A professional organisation with more than 100,000 members which advances learning, quality improvement, and knowledge exchange to improve business results, and to create better workplaces and communities worldwide
A device on a chassis or rail car to hold and secure a container.
The process of avoiding failure in a system or network by providing additional capacity or building in replacement material or facilities.
A government office where duties are paid, import documents filed, etc., on foreign shipments.
A fore-and-aft structural member of the hull sloping up and backwards from the keel to support the counter.
Resources or material that have not been used for a specific period of time and may have become obsolete, or are purposely being held in anticipation of possible future requirements.
A cause-and-effect diagram developed by Kaoru Ishikawa. Syn.: fishbone diagram.
Products that are ready to ship.
See: Unit Cost.
A term used in European and British Commonwealth countries for a tower-like structure on the dorsal (topside) surface of a submarine; called a sail in the United States.
Abbreviation for: Team Data Manager.
Refers to: 2,240 pounds.
Temporary “parking lots” for containers or cargo, located off the wharves and sometimes next to rail yards or import warehouses.

1.Historically a vessel with two square-rigged masts. 2.An interior area of the ship used to detain prisoners (possibly prisoners-of-war, in war-time) and stowaways, and to punish delinquent crew members. Usually resembles a prison-cell with bars and a locked, hinged door

Software planning functions that automatically move existing purchase or production orders to new dates based on calculated requirements, without manual intervention. Many systems use time fences to limit the use of auto- rescheduling beyond a defined date in the future to avoid disruption of short- term schedules and commitments

1. The standard size or quantity of a stock item. 2. An object for which a measurement or observation can be made; commonly used in the sense of a ‘unit of product,’ the entity of product inspected to determine whether it is defective or non-defective.

Broadly, insurance covering loss or damage of goods at sea. Marine insurance typically compensates the owner of merchandise for losses sustained from fire, shipwreck, etc., but excludes losses that can be recovered from the carrier.
Abbreviation for: Customer Operations Performance Centre.
Product classification based upon product or supply market characteristics. Bases for category-sourcing strategies.
The initial design of a product or service outlining its main components and functions without many specific details.
Inventory on hand that will satisfy future demand for products that are no longer in production at your factory.
Abbreviation for: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
A set of quality tests measuring trend, lack of variation, and observation of consecutive results of the same values.

Method of preparing orders combining operations of stock picking and packing. This method becomes very effective if it is performed on the basis of pre-packing, where the parcels for each order are predetermined, and printed transport labels are prepared in advance.
The functions that manage the three core processes of any business: marketing, product/service development, and operations.
A tanker with capacity ranging from 27,000 to 37,999 dwt.
The act of determining whether products and services conform to specific requirements.

The electronic transmission of funds from one party, usually the Purchaser to the other party, usually the Supplier. The transfer is often done through the internet using credit card electronic point of sales (EPOS). A system that records transactions at a cash register and transfers the information to stock control and other functions.
Gross sales less allowances for returns and discounts.
See: Decoupling Stock

A framework agreement is an agreement between one or more contracting entities and one or more suppliers, the purpose of which is to establish the terms governing contracts to be awarded during a given period, in particular with regard to price and, where appropriate, the quantities envisaged.
To steer a sailing vessel more towards the direction of the wind until the pressure is eased on the sheet.
Abbreviation for: Institute for Interconnecting and Packaging Electronic Circuits.
A market condition in which supply exceeds demand and the economic forces of business cause prices to be close to the purchase’s estimated cost.
A short string of characters used to authenticate transactions between trading partners.

A term most commonly utilised in relation with FedEx. A tracking number can be the waybill number, air bill number, bill of lading number, or other unique reference number for identifying a particular shipment. In motor carriage it would be referred to as a “Pro Number.”

applies to any BEE owned or controlled company in the ownership of the entity in calculating exercisable voting rights and economic interest. Where in the chain of ownership, black people have a flowthrough level of participant in excess of 50%, then only once in that chain may such black participation be treated as if it were 100% black. The modified flow-through principle may only be applied in the calculation of vpting rights and economic interest in the hands of black people. In all other instance, the flow-through principle applies.

Lift trucks designed to work in hazardous environments where highly combustible materials are present. Vehicles are designed to avoid sparks and components reaching combustible temperatures. Special electrical systems and materials are used to achieve this.
Abbreviation for: Field Replaceable Units.
Abbreviation for: Life Cycle Product Cost.
The Japanese term for waste.
A lever used for steering, attached to the top of the rudder post. Used mainly on smaller vessels, such as dinghies and rowing boats.
Abbreviation for: Expanded Charted Visual Flight Procedures.
Abbreviation for: General Ledger.
Abbreviation for Remote Maintenance Monitoring.
A propeller mounted on a rigid shaft protruding from the hull of a vessel, usually driven by an inboard motor; steering must be done using a rudder. Also see: outboard motor and sterndrive.
Abbreviation for: Obstacle Free Zone.
Abbreviation for: Harmonised Sales Tax (Canada).
Strategies that determine the frequency and timing of purchases. These strategies are influenced mainly by market forces.
A person or organisation who performs work and is paid on an hourly or volume basis, but is not considered on the payroll and does not receive company benefits.
A term describing the process whereby machines are remotely monitored for status and problems reported and resolved automatically or maintenance scheduled by the monitoring systems.

An initiative that enables companies along a supply chain to work together, communicating via the Internet, to develop a single, more accurate demand forecast, and to create a plan for delivering product to meet that demand.
The second sail (counting from the bottom) up a mast. These may be either square sails or fore-and-aft ones, in which case they often “fill in” between the mast and the gaff of the sail below.
Abbreviation for: Part Period Balancing.
A product that is made with 100 percent new raw materials and contains no recycled materials.

A systematic process that has the goal of reducing the number and severity of traffic crashes by ensuring that all opportunities to improve highway safety are identified, considered, implemented as appropriate, and evaluated in all phases of highway planning, design, construction, maintenance and operation; and by providing information for selecting and implementing effective highway safety strategies and projects.
Abbreviation for: Global Positioning System.
Abbreviation for: Digital Signal Processor.
Abbreviation for: Eco-Management and Audit Scheme and Engineered Materials Arresting System.
Abbreviation for: Decibels A-weighted.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain Management Professional (PMAC Canada).

1. The armoured control tower of an iron or steel warship built between the mid-19th and mid-20th centuries from which the ship was navigated in battle. 2. A tower-like structure on the dorsal (topside) surface of a submarine, serving in submarines built before the mid-20th century as a connecting structure between the bridge and pressure hull and housing instruments and controls from which the periscopes were used to direct the submarine and launch torpedo attacks. Since the mid-20th century, it has been replaced by the sail (United States usage) or fin (European and British Commonwealth usage), a structure similar in appearance which no longer plays a function in directing the submarine.
A range control chart.
Disqualification of a person/ organisation to receive invitations for bids or requests for proposals.
A specialized form of cross-docking where shipments come from a single source or manufacturer.
Any of a number of methods (such as mediation, arbitration, mock trials, etc.) used to resolve disputes outside of litigation.

A large collection of activities performed to transform inputs into outputs; a process that is part of, but subordinate to, a larger process; a single execution of all activities required to produce one process output; a single transaction or business cycle. Also see: Activity and process.
1. A loop in rope or line – a hitch or knot tied on the bight is one tied in the middle of a rope, without access to the ends.2. An indentation in a coastline.
Abbreviation for: Automated Weather Observation System.
Describes the technical properties and characteristics of the product as well as the activities to be performed by the supplier.
Delivery Order: a release document used to claim goods from clearance for delivery to an identified consignee and destination.

The generic name of a number of traditional sailing vessels with one or more masts with lateen sails used in the Red Sea and Indian Ocean region, typically weighing 300 to 500 tons, with a long, thin hull. They are trading vessels primarily used to carry heavy items, like fruit, fresh water or merchandise. Crews vary from about thirty to around twelve, depending on the size of the vessel.

The analysis of data that exhibits an ongoing upward or downward pattern that is not due to seasonality or random noise. Analysing trends is useful in detecting patterns that could lead to future quality problems, and in forecasting future demand periods.
Initial allocation of inventory to an order which will commit the inventory to the order but not specifically pull it from a certain lot.

Computer systems that schedule, track, and monitor maintenance activities and provide cost, component item, tooling, personnel, and other reporting data and history. CMMS systems can often be interfaced with production scheduling and cost systems, and may be used to follow preventive maintenance policies.

The linked set of resources and processes that begins with the sourcing of raw material and extends through the delivery of end items to the final customer. It includes vendors, manufacturing facilities, logistics providers, internal distribution centres, distributors, wholesalers, and all other entities that lead up to final customer acceptance. The extended supply chain for a given company may also include secondary vendors to their immediate vendors, and the customers of their immediate customers.
The desire to share and the ability to trust in an information sharing situation.
Abbreviation for: Maritime Security Act and Minimum Safe Altitude.

Personal adherence to a strict moral or ethical code of conduct. The National Institute of Governmental Purchasing has published an ethical code of conduct for its membership and a guide to those in the public purchasing profession.
Statement of the overall purpose and aims of an organisation.
Refers to the charge assessed against the vessel for berthing at the facility or for mooring to a vessel so berthed.
Refers to the calculations used to determine inventory cost. Also see: Average Cost, Current Cost, Standard Cost, Actual Cost, Landed Cost, First-in-first-out, Last-in-last-out.
Syn.: Phantom.
Abbreviation for: Central American Free Trade Agreement.
The activity (usually a predetermined process) of minimising the effects of an operation’s failure.
The last part or loose end of a rope or cable. The anchor cable is tied to the bitts; when the cable is fully paid out, the bitter end has been reached.
1. Propeller. 2. Propeller-driven (e.g., screw frigate, screw sloop).
Abbreviation for: Product Information Management.

Demand in the form of booked customer orders and inter-plant orders (not actual sales). Actual demand is netted against forecasted demand for a given time period to generate requirements for material planning systems.

The term stacking is used in the context of warehousing for the piling up of pallets. A product is “stackable” if its physical characteristics make it possible to stack its pallets. Certain warehouse management systems can limit stacking by product and/ or by store, and use this concept to manage the storage capacity of locations automatically and by context
The first phase of a product development effort. Here a company identifies ideas for new or revised products and services.

The A3 method is a means of describing a business process in a compact form. It was originally created by the Toyota Motor Corporation, and was named after the size of the paper on which it was printed: A3 (11” x 17”). Toyota used the A3 methodology to develop its famed Toyota Production System (TPS).
Abbreviation for: Aviation Weather Products Generator.
Highest average level water reaches on an incoming tide.

The purpose of open innovation is to create close collaboration on research and development, new product design, and development, and market introduction with parties that would share the company’s business interests in such collaboration.

Abbreviation for: Intelligent Vehicle/ Highway Systems. Technologies that focus on monitoring, guiding, or operating motorised vehicles, or providing information to travellers about road and traffic conditions; examples include computerised navigational systems in cars, collision warning systems and freeway ramp metering.
Abbreviation for: Integrated Bridge Control System.
1. The place to which a shipment is consigned. 2. The place where a carrier actually turns over cargo to consignee or his agent.
Traveling crane used for the movement and positioning of containers in a container field. RTG’s may also be used for loading and unloading containers from rail cars.
The determination of the latest finish and start times for each project activity.
Approach used to determine the best placement and locations for products in the warehouse depending on its dimensions and how often the item is picked.
Filling a seam (with caulking or pitch), lubricating the running rigging; paying with slush, protecting from the weather by covering with slush. Also see: the devil to pay. French from paix, pitch.
1. A leg of the route of a sailing vessel, particularly in relation to tacking and to starboard tack and port tack. 2. Hard tack. 3. The front bottom corner of a sail.
Abbreviation for: Chief Supply Chain Management Officer.
National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System.

A contractual agreement in which an acquirier contracts with a vendor to provide the acquirer’ requirements at a predetermined price. Usually involves a minimum number of units, orders placed directly with the vendor by the purchase, and limited duration of the contract.
Abbreviation for: Air Traffic Control Command Centre.
Contracts are closed based upon interests of buyer and seller only.
Elements in measurement and decision support systems that identify recurring relationships and distributions of data in a given set.
The loss generated by comparing an actual quantity to the expected or book amount; commonly refers to a physical count that reduces the perpetual inventory.
Abbreviation for: Direct to Store Delivery.
An asphalt mixture designed to resist the rutting and fatigue cracking caused by heavy loads and extreme temperatures, as experienced with the previous standard (known as the Marshall mix).
Abbreviation for: Urban Airshed Model. Regional air quality model which allows overall concentrations for an entire region to be predicted.
Segregating materials into cartages that will be processed, sold, or disposed of separately.
An organisation or individual that carries out work for a contractor as part of a larger project.
A soft covering for cables (or any other obstructions) that prevents sail chafing.

The overall set of factors that influence planning, scheduling, and strategic production decisions which include type and timing of demand, product and process complexity, physical product form, logistics and vendor capabilities, and internal functional capabilities. Describing the overall environment often includes the response to demand (to stock or to order), physical facility layout (job shop, production line, cell, batch processing or other) and methods and requirements used in planning and scheduling (discrete, repetitive, or process). Many companies have characteristics of more than one environment.
(1) A mast above the topgallant mast on large sailing ships. (2) The sail of such a mast.
Labour costs directly attributed to the production of specific units that includes wages and associated fringe benefits.
Allows a manager to legally bind their company to an external partner.
Specialists from user departments and buyers are put together in teams to develop specific sourcing and commodity strategies and plans
A wrongful act, other than a breach of contract, such that the law permits compensation of damages.
The classification for the largest sailing warships of the 17th through 19th centuries. They had 3 masts, 850+ crew and 100+ guns.
The ability to rapidly and cost-effectively adapt to market changes with no significant negative impact on quality or dependability.
Synonym for Bill of Material.
A mechanized device for transporting two standard pallets simultaneously.
Abbreviation for: Compressed Video Transmission Service.

A sourcing strategy in which a company uses a single supplier for one particular part or service and another supplier with the same capabilities for a different part or service, with the understanding that each supplier can act as a backup for the other supplier
Access to operations support, such as customer service call centres, available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

term: Warehouse Withdrawal for Transportation Immediate Exportation (WDEX)
definition: Allows merchandise that has been withdrawn from a bonded warehouse at one U.S. port to be exported from the same port without paying duty.

The length of time needed to identify and qualify prospects, define the goods or services, and accept and acknowledge the order. The length of the sales cycle often depends on product complexity and degree of custom engineering, and may include the use of firm planned orders based on partially-completed bills of material to order long lead time items.
Occurs when a value is not known exactly, but follows a known probability distribution.
The use of mathematical models to find optimal stock levels and ordering policies.
A labor-reporting system that compares individuals’ work achievement to standards or averages.
An oligopoly is a market type characterised by a limited number of suppliers and a limited product differentiation.
Submitted by the contractor for review as to its Value Engineering (VE) applicability. If accepted by the government, normally the contractor is compensated for saving the government money.
Abbreviation for: National Human Resource Development Strategy.
The simulation of the outcome of various scenarios and alternatives when changes to the inputs and parameters is done.
Abbreviation for: Airport Traffic Control Tower.
Conflict of interest between buyer and seller due to conflicting goals and information asymmetry
A combination of less than truckload (LTL) freight built to form a full or almost full truckload. By “sharing” space in a vehicle, the client and Nexus can minimize cost.
A classification of regulated carriers based upon annual operating revenues: Motor carriers of property - $1 million; Railroads - $10 million.
1. A vessel of considerable size for deep-water navigation. 2. A sailing vessel having three or more square-rigged masts.
The downstream supply chain in situations where multiple echelons exist such as, manufacturer to distributor to retailer to end user.

A software contract that specifies acceptable usage and normally includes clauses regarding the right to copy, distribute, and modify; the number of overall or concurrent users able to use the system; restrictions to specific sites or hardware; whether the software is owned by the buyer or granted access through the payment of annual maintenance fees, and other terms.

The process of authorizing the pick of material for a given order, generating the paperwork, and releasing it to the picking department. Many variations exist in which the pick slip may be manually selected for a given order, is automatically generated a set number of days before the requirement, or is held until the calculated available inventory equals the requirement. Order processing systems often have controls that flag or stop changes to orders when the pick slip has already been released.
An area designated by the government of a country for free trade; a port, city, or region designated for free trade.
A performance dimension that refers to how quickly the operations or supply chain function can fulfil a need after it has been identified.

A tenderer who may have been disqualified to tender/offer for any one of such reasons as unsatisfactory past performance, attempts at influencing awards, or inability to meet the prequalification standards for inclusion in the list of approved tenders (holding the requested business license, nationality,...), or for any valid reason.
Abbreviation for: Long Range Navigation.
Abbreviation for: International Business Machines.
The bearing of an object in relation to north. Either true bearing, using the geographical or true north, or magnetic bearing, using magnetic north. See also bearing and relative bearing.
The Employment Equity Act 55 of 1998, as amended.
Harbour with piers or docks. Left side of a ship when facing forward. Opening in a ship’s side for handling freight.

A warehouse operation managed by a third-party logistics (3PL) provider for a specified period of time. The 3PL manages a client’s inventory and order fulfillment processes. Pricing scenarios may vary, and storage, labor, and equipment resources are typically dedicated to the client for the duration of the contract. The client may or may not share in the building and equipment expense.
Abbreviation for: Business Process Outsourcing.
An early stage business which is similar to a start-up. However, an early stage business is typically 3 years old or less.
The person/entity who submits a proposal in response to a Request for Proposals (RFP). One who makes an offer in response to a solicitation.
1. A navigable body of water. 2. A strake of timber laid against the frames or bulwark stanchions at the margin of a laid wooden deck, usually about twice the thickness of the deck planking.

An approach to product and process design which seeks to ensure that the organisation is capable of providing products or services that meet Six Sigma quality levels-in general, no more than 3.4 defects per million opportunities.
Material and components stored on the production floor used as needed for multiple production orders, and not pegged or issued to individual orders. Normally lower-dollar value, back flushed items.
Abbreviation for: DoD Automatic Digital Network.
Abbreviation for: Hazardous In-Flight Weather Advisory.
Products and systems from multiple vendors that can be used together without modification or development of custom interfaces and tools.
FSS Radio Voice Communications.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Product Code.
Abbreviation for: Free In and Out.
Certified for, and capable of, safely sailing at sea.

term: UNITED NATIONS STANDARD PRODUCTS AND SERVICES CODE
definition: The United Nations Standard Products and Services Code is a hierarchical convention that is used to classify all products and services. It was developed jointly between the UN and Dun & Bradstreet (D&B). Has a five level coding structure (segment, family, class, commodity, business function) for nearly 9,000 products.
A type of bulk cargo that consists of liquid items, such as petroleum, water, or liquid natural gas.
Toyota system which allows workers to “stop the line” when they discover production problems. The Japanese symbol for jidoka literally translates into “man and machine system.”

Originally developed and published in Dr. Eliyahu Goldratt’s book The Goal, this theory argues that a system has a single goal, and that systems are composed of multiple linked activities, one of which acts as a constraint on the whole system. It places emphasis on methods to achieve the primary business goal of making money through increasing throughput and reducing inventory and operating expenses, ways to synchronise the production pace of linked activities and ensure continued operation of the system constraint, and the use of thinking processes to identify problems and propose alternatives.
The price of the product is determined on the market, and is generated exclusively by market circumstances such as demand, supply, stock, positions, the economic situation and political factors
Abbreviation for: Selling, General and Administrative expenses.

when measuring the rights of ownership of any category of black people in a measured entity only right held by natural persons are relevant. It the rights of ownership of black people pass through a juristic person are measurable. This principle applies across every tier of ownership in a multi-tiered chain of ownership until that chain ends with a black person holding rights of ownership.
Customer designated as party paying for services.
Activities needed to develop the technical specification of the work.
These measures include: Short ton (American) 2000 lbs. Long ton (English) 2240 lbs. Metric ton (1000 kg.) 2204.6 lbs.
An articulated five platform rail car that allows containers to be double stacked. A typical stack car holds ten 40-foot equivalent units (FEU’s).
Purchase requisitions /Indents generated and transmitted by computer, replacing paper forms.
Abbreviation for: Medium-Term Expenditure Framework.
Department responsible for scheduling the movement of merchandise loaded on trailers going to the stores.
Generally refers to freight handled.
Abbreviation for: Early Manufacturing Involvement.
Abbreviation for: Oceanic Navigational Error Report.

A large winch with a vertical axis. A full-sized human-powered capstan is a waist-high cylindrical machine, operated by a number of hands who each insert a horizontal capstan bar in holes in the capstan and walk in a circle. Used to wind in anchors or other heavy objects; and sometimes to administer flogging over.

One or more statements of the specific, measurable, intermediate end that is achievable and marks progress toward a goal and long range objective. Specific objectives may be associated with more than one goal or long range objectives.
The cost added to an existing product or project status by processing the next operation or performing an additional activity.
Abbreviation for: Long Range Radar.
A list of Contractors or Suppliers selected from an Approved List or from responses to a Contract Notice and invited to submit their tender for a specific contract.
Abbreviation for: Trade, Investment, Development and Co-operation Agreement.

term: American Society for Training and Development (ASTD)
definition: A membership organization providing materials, education, and support related to workplace learning and performance.
A published rate that is never assessed because no freight moves under it.
Abbreviation for: BRITE Alphanumeric System.
Abbreviation for: Dispute Settlement Body.
Abbreviation for: Private Branch Exchange.
Expediting or accomplishing an operation or project task in less than its originally-planned duration.
Abbreviation for: Billing Analysis Reporting Tool (GSA software tool).
A means of settling disputes between parties in which an outsider acts as an arbitrator - who acts as a fact finder and decision-maker. The parties agree to abide by the decision of the arbitrator.

The intentional or voluntary relinquishment of a known right, or conduct that warrants an inference that the right has been relinquished. Examples of waivers in supply management may include a waiver of certain contract requirements such as delivery dates, testing requirements, and performance standards.
Last-In-First-Out convention for valuing stock.
Abbreviation for: Computer-Aided System Engineering or Computer Assisted Software Engineering, and Community Agency for Social Enquiries.
Abbreviation for: Centre Radar Approach Control, Central Radar Approach, and Combined Centre/Radar Approach Control.
Abbreviation for: Safety Factor.
A code describing a commodity, or a group of commodities, pertaining to goods classification. This code can be carrier tariff or regulating in nature.
The latest an activity can be finished and still finish the project on time, as determined by the latest start time for all immediate successors.
Segments of a value stream with boundaries broken into loops to divide future state implementation into manageable pieces.
A bond covering a group of persons, articles, or properties.
The portion of total lead time an item is being moved from one department or operation to another.
Cargo which has been booked, but does not arrive in time to be loaded before the vessel sails.
The monthly rate of negative cash flow; when measured against current positions it indicates the date an organisation will run out of cash unless a new, or one-time source, is found.
Abbreviation for: Global Tracking Item Number. It is a product or APN number.
Abbreviation for: Design For Environment.
Person who operates a yard tractor.

Customs duty charged in terms of percentage on the value of goods that are dutiable, irrespective of quality, weight, or any other considerations. The ad valorem rates of duty are ascertained from the invoice.
Abbreviation for: Visual Navigational Aids.
Abbreviation for: Timber Load Line.
The amount of money that is invested in all levels of stock at any given point in time.
The ongoing use of an external third party instead of an internal resource to perform various functions.
Abbreviation for: Data Acquisition.
Abbreviation for: Air Traffic Control.
Refers to either the cargo carried or the charges assessed for carriage of the cargo.

The path and systems used in the linked flow of activities with a specific start and finish that describe a process. The flow defines where inputs are initiated, the location of decision points, and the alternatives in output paths, and is used in systems that perform automatic routing.
The connection of two variables or project tasks based on a direct cause or dependency, rather than coincidence.
Abbreviation for: Administrative Data.
Said when an anchor is just clear of the bottom.
Abbreviation for: Expanded Inward Access Features.
Abbreviation for: Council for Trade in Goods.

An imperative to leave the vessel immediately, usually in the face of some imminent overwhelming danger. It is an order issued by the Master or a delegated person in command. It is usually the last resort after all other mitigating actions have failed or become impossible, and destruction or loss of the ship is imminent. It is customarily followed by a command to “man the lifeboats” or life rafts.
Abbreviation for: Precision Distance Measuring Equipment.
Total quantity of goods committed to the pipeline for a ship to, or selling location. This includes the current inventory at a location and any open purchase orders

The analysis of cost issues over the entire life cycle of a given product, rather than a specific fiscal period. It includes factors based on product life cycle stage (introduction, growth, maturity, and decline) and all research and development, design, marketing, production, and logistics costs. A cross-functional approach used in investment and facility decisions.

A method used to categorise inventory into groups based upon certain activity characteristics. Examples of ABC stratifications would include ABC by velocity (times sold), ABC by sales dollars, ABC by quantity sold / consumed, ABC by average inventory investment, ABC by margin. ABC stratifications are used to develop inventory planning policies, set count frequencies for cycle counting, slot inventory for optimised order picking, and other inventory management activities.
A standard that imposes no inherent obligation regarding its use.
Use of Internet technologies to manage purchasing and procurement.

1. During the Age of Sail and immediately afterwards, a captured ship used to stow supplies and other goods for naval purposes. 2. Since the mid-20th century, a type of naval ship which provides supplies such as frozen, chilled, and dry provisions and propulsion and aviation fuel to warships which are at sea for an extended period of time. In some navies, synonymous with replenishment oiler, fleet replenisher, or fleet tanker.

1. A waterborne machine that removes unwanted silt accumulations from the bottom of a waterway. 2. The process of removing sediment from harbor or river bottoms for safety purposes and to allow for deeper vessels.
The acquisition and use of information about events, trends, and relationships in an organisation’s internal and external environments.
1. A spar or derrick with a block at one end, used for stowing cargo. 2. To incline upwards at an angle (esp. of a bowsprit) rather than lie horizontally; to set at a particular upwards incline.

A phrase incorporated by tenderer in his quotation indicative of no commitment to accept a contract at the price quoted; a safeguard against prices rising between the time of giving the tender/ offer and the contract being placed.
A project task or operation date determined by an external constraint that a given resource cannot change.
1. A specialised vessel designed for catching or processing whales. 2. A person engaged in the catching or processing of whales.
National Machining and Tooling Association.

Represents a contract provision that permits the adjustment of contract prices by an amount or percent but only if certain specified contingencies occur, such as changes in the vendor's raw material or labour costs.
A suite of protocols that defines the Internet and allows communication between different types of computers and networks connected to the Internet.

term: Logistics Structure, Making and Sending to Stock (MSS)
definition: Products are manufactured and distributed to various distribution points which are dispersed and located close to the customer.Manufacturing is based upon forecasts and on the expected stock turnover at the points of distribution

Used to describe equipment or technologies that do not follow an open standard design that would allow them to easily integrate with other equipment or technologies. Proprietary equipment and technologies are usually patented or otherwise protected, making it difficult or impossible for other companies to offer similar or complementary products.
The delivery of goods by a supplier to a customer in a particular time period and expressed in quantitative or financial terms.

1. Refers to marine matters such as an Admiralty Court. 2. A high naval authority in charge of a state’s Navy or a major territorial component. In the Royal Navy (UK), the Board of Admiralty, executing the office of the Lord High Admiral, promulgates Naval law in the form of Queen’s (or King’s) Regulations and Admiralty Instructions.
The use of an outside organisation to perform non-core activities (which are outsourced).
Abbreviation for: Airport Cooperative Research Program.

This is a document tendered by the carrier making a delivery of a shipment, handed over at the time of delivery to the consignee that identifies the shipment, quantities of cartons, etc., for the receiver to confirm and if any variances exist at that time they are to be noted on the document and acknowledged by signature of both parties (driver & receiver).

A department responsible for providing a safe transportation system that ensures the mobility of people and goods, enhances economic prosperity, and preserves the quality of the environment and communities.
Abbreviation for: Business Process Outsourcing and Offshoring.

Short rope used to bind a cable to the “messenger” (a moving line propelled by the capstan) so that the cable is dragged along too (used where the cable is too large to be wrapped round the capstan itself). During the raising of an anchor the nippers were attached and detached from the (endless) messenger by the ship’s boys. Hence the term for small boys: “nippers.”

Fee-based service of receiving, managing, and storing of client-owned inventory so that it is available to the rapid pick, pack, and ship distribution engine. Product is stored accurately and efficiently in multiple forms and selling units.
Situation when an organisation decides to buy a completely new product, supplied by an unknown supplier.
Abbreviation for: Wireless Mark-up Language.
The act of disregarding minor informalities, errors, or technical nonconformance in the bid which will not adversely affect the competition or prejudice one bidder in favor of another.
A capacity strategy in which capacity is added in anticipation of demand.
The on-hand balance minus allocations, reservations, backorders, and (usually) quantities held for quality problems. Often called “beginning available balance.”

term: Free on Board (FOB – U.S. Domestic Use)
definition: Shipped under a rate that includes costs of delivery to and the loading onto a carrier at a specified point.
A valuation method based on the current market price to replace an item, rather than its initial or previous cost.
An accounting period not yet closed as a result of the month-end process that is still available for transactions and adjustments.
A graph that uses vertical bars of varying heights to represent the proportion or relative frequency of a given class of data within a population.
To smash inward, to force a hole or break in, as in a cask, door or other (wooden) barrier.

Set of activities with the goal of making available the desired items and quantities of raw materials, semi-finished products, equipment, etc. at the time desired by the company (information contained in the Material Requirements Plan) at the best pricing terms. This process involves the definition of a supply policy (supply management method, delivery cycle time, management of inbound transportation, establishment of a supplier network, information system to be developed, etc.).
A situation in which traffic demand is sufficient to cause the level of service to be below DOT LOS standard.
A manifest that lists all cargo carried on a specific vessel voyage.
Syn.: Milestone.

The management of product categories as strategic business units. The practice empowers a category manager with full responsibility for the assortment decisions, inventory levels, shelf-space allocation, promotions, and buying. With this authority and responsibility, the category manager is able to judge more accurately the consumer buying patterns, product sales, and market trends of that category.
Abbreviation for: Gross Margin.
A comparison of the strengths and weaknesses of the various offers received in a competitive bidding process.
Goods and materials purchased from certified suppliers that skip incoming inspection and go directly into inventory upon delivery.
A loan that allows a home buyer to take over a seller’s mortgage when purchasing a home.

A national or provincial department as defined in the South African public finance management Act no 1 of 1999. A municipality as contemplated in the constitution; Parliament; A provincial legislation, and Any other institution or category of institution included in the defined or “organ of state” in section 239 of the constitution and recognised by the minister by notice in the Government Gazette as an institution or category of institution to which this Act applies.
A planning approach in which an organisation updates its sales and operations plan regularly, such as on a monthly or quarterly basis.
Merchandise that is requested by a customer but is temporarily unavailable. Also referred to Out of Stocks (OOS).
The prediction, projection, or estimation of expected sales over a specified time period.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Discharge Machine and Electronic Data Management.
Bids submitted by two or more bidders that have identical pricing. May signal collusion.

A storage system that assigns a permanent inventory location for a given item, usually based on its physical size and usage volume. Seasonal stock level variations may mean the dedicated location sometimes takes up more space than needed, or that temporary random locations will also be required.
Abbreviation for: International Transport Forum.

A smooth, seamless, plastic or fiberglass container with a lid for transporting small items (e.g., candy, general merchandise) from the distribution center to the retail store. It is a lightweight container used to separate and protect high-value items.
A small test run of a system or production process to verify its acceptance and capabilities before going full-scale.
A French classification society which certifies seagoing vessels for compliance to standardised rules regarding construction and maintenance.
A form of the moving average model that allows the actual weights applied to past observations to differ.

The most capacity that can be obtained from a given resource, as opposed to its planned or demonstrated capacity (as in a machine normally operated 10 hours a day with a maximum capacity of 24 hours/day). Sometimes used in what-if planning for stress or volume testing.
A type of contract stating the work in terms of an amount of effort (usually labor-hours or labor-years) to be performed by specified classes of employees over a given period of time.
A private network of computers within a company or organisation, that serves shared applications intended for internal use (Jansen, 2002).
Determines the order size for a periodic review method (with order size equal to target stock level minus current stock minus amount already on order).
Abbreviation for: Outer Fix Time.
Abbreviation for: Master Container Freight Station.

The labour involved in moving product received from the trailer into the warehouse dock and then into the storage location on the “IN” and moving the product out of the storage location and into a staging location to then be loaded onto a trailer on the “OUT.” The warehouse forklift / clamp operator moves product IN and OUT. If additional handling is involved such as opening on days off, pick packing etc., that are not the normal handling as defined in the warehouse contract, these would be defined as additional accessorial charges for handling.
More than one travel mode potentially including the four highway modes (auto, bicycle, bus, pedestrian), aviation, rail, seaport, and transit.

A process using demand from open production orders and MRP planned orders, work centre/production line rates, and capacity data to determine over or under capacity conditions. A short-term, detailed view of capacity that verifies the feasibility of firming up planned orders, and releasing them to the floor. CRP systems normally function as a capacity status report, without generating exception messages that recommend order reschedules, or moving production to alternate work centres or lines.
Demand for an item before netting against on-hand inventory and scheduled receipts.
Abbreviation for: Instrument Approach Procedures.

A legal document executed by the original parties to a contract and a successor to whom interest in the contract has been transferred by one of the parties, which transfers all obligations and rights under the contract to the successor.
Includes the four phases of procurement and associated costs of owning assets, namely the acquisition planning phase, the procurement phase, the in-life-use phase and the disposal phase of the asset.
Abbreviation for: Commercial Vehicle Operations.
Operations that buy resources and produce only when demanded by specific customers.
A blessing wishing the recipient a safe journey and good fortune.
Company which leases vehicles.
A technique used for time series forecasting that begins with an exponentially-smoothed current forecast and adjusts for trend by using a second smoothed estimate.
Abbreviation for: Electronic Freight Invoice.

A movable loop or collar, used to fasten a yard or gaff to its respective mast. Parrel still allows the spar to be raised or lowered and swivel around the mast. Can be made of wire or rope and fitted with beads to reduce friction.
A floating object of defined shape and color, anchored in position to aid navigation.
A rule that suggests that 80 percent of an outcome is generated by 20 percent of an activity. For example, 80 percent of a company’s sales are often generated by 20 percent of its customers.
A model that identifies the categories of activity that supposedly ensure high levels of quality; now used by many companies to examine their own quality-related procedures.
A widely used measure of inventory performance expressed as the ratio of the cost of units sold to the average value of stock.
Taking something small and exploding it. Can be financial or technological.

A subset of customer relationship management (CRM) functions that focuses on the definition, scheduling, and tracking of marketing campaigns. It includes the identification of target markets, advertising delivery, budget definition, results analysis, and other related activities.
Abbreviation for: Coast Guard Air Station.
Remote Communications Outlet.
Place where cargo leaves the care and custody of the carrier.

An operations layout that groups facilities that have a common purpose together; the term was originally used in retail operations but is now sometimes used in other industries, very similar to the idea of a cell layout.
A bidder whose bid does not vary from the specifications and terms set out in the invitation for bids.
Abbreviation for: Weather Service Office.
RCL Terminal.

Here, the company tries to win customers by charging them fairly low prices for quality offerings. Value pricing is not a matter of simply setting lower prices. It is a matter of reengineering the company’s operations to become a low-cost producer without sacrificing quality and lowering prices significantly to attract a large number of value conscious customers.

A series of 14 points by W. Edwards Deming that propose improving quality by emphasising management commitment, employee training, eliminating slogans and posters that solely emphasise productivity, inter-departmental cooperation, and other related factors.
Abbreviation for: Air Traffic Control Beacon Indicator.

A document used at the outset of a team-based project as a basis to define and agree key aspects of the project including scope, targets, membership, roles, responsibilities, and timings. May also be called a Project Charter.
Used to indicate that an item may be substituted for a required item if it is equal in quality, performance and other characteristics.
Issues to production orders not originally specified on the pick slip that indicate usage variances, bill of material errors or process changes.
An average of quantities that have been adjusted by the addition of a statistical value to allow for their relative importance in a data set.
Abbreviation for: Labour Relations Act.

Nationwide Personal Transportation Study. A transportation study, periodically undertaken by the Bureau of Census, which looks at travel patterns and frequency, transit use, and other travel characteristics at a national level.
Contractor completes and operates work at own risk and gets paid based upon actual performance.
A code assigned to a product to identify it in an article coding system. Glossary | United Nations Standard Products And Services Code
Abbreviation for: Currency Adjustment Factor. A charge, expressed as a percentage of a base rate that is applied to compensate ocean carriers of currency fluctuations.

A simple diagram of every step involved in the material and information flows needed to bring a product from order to delivery. The first step is to draw a visual representation of every step in a process, including key data, such as the customer demand rate, quality, and machine reliability. Next, draw an improved future-state map showing how the product or service could flow if the steps that add no value were eliminated. Finally, create and implement a plan for achieving the future state.
The finite rate at which materials are added to stock.

A group of people, typically including a procurement official, project manager, technical staff, financial analyst, and legal expert who have the essential skills or knowledge necessary to reach a sound agreement. This team can determine: the most appropriate type of contract; terms of the contract; special warranty or delivery provisions; technical and engineering specifications; subcontractors needed, as well as other negotiable goals. The complexity of the negotiation will determine the size of the team. A negotiation team is usually selected for a major acquisition and may include some or all members of the Evaluation Committee.
Abbreviation for: Justification and Approval to Limit Competition (USA).
Also known as “dunnage,” includes materials such as foam, paper, or wood used to minimize movement within the container.
Abbreviation for: Technical Advisory Committee.
Refers to: Service O.

Term used in work measurement to indicate the rate of output that qualified workers will achieve without over-exertion as an average over the working day provided they are motivated to supply themselves, now generally accepted as a very vague concept.

Verb used in reference to a rudder, as in “the rudder begins to bite.” When a vessel has steerageway the rudder will act to steer the vessel, i.e. it has enough water flowing past it to steer with. Physically this is noticeable with tiller or unassisted wheel steering by the rudder, which exhibits resistance to being turned from the straight ahead – this resistance is the rudder “biting” and is how a helmsman first senses that the vessel has acquired steerageway
A training or measurement tool that provides a graphic display of data or concepts to increase understanding.
Research which focuses on specific sectors of industry.
39.37 inches (approximately).

Abbreviation for: Lighter Aboard Ship. These 900-foot-long ships carry small barges inside the vessel. Just as cargo is transported by barge from the shallower parts of the Mississippi River to the Port of New Orleans for export aboard ocean-going ships, LASH barges are lifted into these unusual ships. Overseas, the ship can discharge clusters of barges in the open waters. Then several towboats will assemble the barges into tows bound for various ports and inland waterways, without the ship having to spend time traveling to each port.

A general rule in marketing is that you do not base your selling price on the cost price of the product but rather on what the market can bear. In this reasoning, the price that the buyer is willing to pay is related primarily to the value they attach to the product.

term: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)
definition: International trade agreement specifying conditions, duties and acceptable commerce practices.
A market structure where neither suppliers nor buyers can influence product pricing.
A statement that explains why an organisation exists. It describes what is important to the organisation, called its core values, and identifies the organisation’s domain.

The systems that help in strategically balancing the inventory policy and customer service levels throughout the supply chain. These systems calculate time-phased order quantities and safety stock, using selected inventory strategies. Some inventory planning systems conduct what-if analyses that compare the current inventory policy with simulated inventory scenarios and improve the inventory ROI.
Abbreviation for: Fund for Research into Industrial Growth and Equity.
Abbreviation for: Customs Border Protection.
A kind of metallic shafting (a rod of metal) to hold the propeller and connected to the power engine. When the tailshaft is moved, the propeller may also be moved for propulsion.
Software used in the context of an EAI for transferring data between two computer applications not initially able to communicate with each other.
The quantity of goods that may be imported without restriction during a set period of time.
The farthest point above the mouth of a river that can be navigated by ships.
American National Standards Institute Accredited Standards Committee X12.
A special form of the Kanban system that uses one card to control production and another card to control movement of materials.
Abbreviation for: Human Resource Management.
Human inspection of items or processes for colour, scratches, or other parameters that does not involve the use of equipment.

An accuracy measure that combines average forecast error with bias, as defined as the ration of the exponentially smoothed error and the exponentially smoothed mean absolute deviation. When the tracking signal exceeds a certain value, the forecast error may be considered to be non-random and the forecast no longer usable.
Abbreviation for: Early Finish Date (Project Management).
A PC-based control is a computer programmed to control automated materials-handling and control systems.

Contract in which the buyer agrees to pay the supplier all materials costs and employee hours against predetermined hourly rates and margins for services rendered (identical to time and materials contract).

A computer system capable of assembling, storing, manipulating, and displaying geographically referenced information, i.e., data identified according to their locations. Practitioners also regard the GIS as including operating personnel and the data that go into the system.
A diagram of the fluctuations in the level of economic activity in a country over time.
Abbreviation for: Federal Transit Authority and Free Trade Agreement.
Allowing employees to have experience in multiple tasks, job functions, or across multiple accounts in order to increase productivity and provide backup.

1.One side of a vessel above the waterline. 2.All the guns on one side of a warship or mounted (in rotating turrets or barbettes) so as to be able fire on the same side of a warship. 3.The simultaneous firing of all the guns on one side of warship or able to fire on the same side of a warship. 4.Weight of broadside, the combined weight of all projectiles a ship can fire in a broadside, or the combined weight of all the shells a group of ships that have formed a line of battle collectively can fire on the same side.
Abbreviation for: Design to Order.
The process of determining timely and economic delivery methods, arranging internal or external transportation, and tracking shipment status and logistics network issues.
A written agreement signed by the parties to the agreement that they understand the agreement in its entirety and nothing shall be deemed to constitute a waiver of the agreement.

An evaluation technique used to score proposals. This approach requires the Evaluation Team to evaluate the technical differences between proposals in order to determine if these differences justify paying the cost or price differential.
Customer Relationship Management / Central Receiving and Marking.

1. Stock Valuation: The method of valuing stocks that assumes that the oldest stock is consumed first and thus issues are valued at the oldest price. 2. Stock Rotation: The method whereby the goods that have been longest in stock are delivered (sold) and/or consumed first.

The economic consequences of an internal or external stock out, such as missed sales, delayed deliveries, anticipated lower sales in the future because of loss of goodwill, costs resulting from production stoppages, and all kinds of associated costs.
Dimensions of ships structural members, e.g., frame, beam, girder, etc.
The formal process of working with selected suppliers to evaluate and improve supplier quality.
Inventory items whose demand levels are beyond a company’s complete control.
The water area of the open coast seaward of the ordinary low-water mark, or seaward of inland waters.
A strategy for reducing and smoothing out workforce requirements that involves having customers perform part of the work themselves.
Light, bulky articles.
A trailer towed by a rigid truck that has one axle at the front and rear of the trailer.
In re-manufacturing, the balance of the customer credit assigned to returned, salvageable units or assemblies, which is netted against the costs of future activities and shipments for that customer.

Is the result of a calculation that takes quantity on hand and reduces it by allocations (for sales orders, manufacturing orders, etc.). Quantity available may or may not be date specific and therefore take into account future receipts. Quantity available calculations are sometimes very complicated and vary from one software product to another.
A large rope.
Abbreviation for: Precision Runway Monitor.
A note for one month’s wages issued to sailors on their signing a ship’s articles.
The difference between the actual stock held and calculated stock or registered stock.
Unable to move due to lack of wind; said of a sailing vessel.
The height pallets can be stacked while leaving clearance for product movement or for lights, sprinklers, etc., hanging from a ceiling.
A person authorized to transact business on behalf of another. Agents include brokers, commission merchants, resident buyers, sales agents, and manufacturer’s representatives.
An ordered item that requires custom engineering, components, or processing and is not considered a standard offering.

Abbreviation for: Community Transportation Coordinators. People contracted by the Transportation Disadvantaged Commission to provide complete, cost-effective, and efficient transportation services to transportation disadvantaged (TD) persons.

The manual or system-generated process of calculating product cost based on the individual components and cost types (material, labor, overhead) included. Usually done for a complete assembly, but may also be done for a single level, or the material or routing (production) portion only.
Traditional lower-deck slang for the Royal Navy.
Graphic means for depicting the flow of work steps, tasks, or activities, and related descriptive information in a process.
Abbreviation for: Commercial Driver’s License.
The extent to which an activity does not vary.
A list of all products processed through a given operation. Useful in tracing impacts when the operation rate or process changes.

Systems that track interaction between a sales force and customers or prospects, supply chain partners, or other relationships. Functions usually include call date tracking, notes files, follow up reminders, birthday or anniversary date reminders, and other methods to provide systematic ways to initiate and track interaction over time.
Time and date for payment of a draft.
To cut off the wind from a sailing vessel, either by the proximity of land or by another vessel.
Abbreviation for: State Implementation Plan and Strategic Industrial Projects.

A method typically used between retailers and distributors or manufacturers that uses point-of-sale inventory and sales data to trigger automatic replenishments, with the vendor assuming responsibility for initiation and fulfilment.
The charge for moving a container through a container yard off or onto a ship.
A unit of length equal to 6 feet (1.8 m), roughly measured as the distance between a man’s outstretched hands. Particularly used to measure depth.

This is a container parking lot, or any open area where containers are stored in a precise order according to the ship loading plan. Containers terminals may use a grounded or wheeled layout. If the cargo box is placed directly on the ground, it is called a grounded operation. If the box is on a chassis/ trailer, it is a wheeled operation.

Standard Carrier Abbreviation Code identifying an individual common carrier. A three-letter carrier code followed by a suffix identifies the carrier’s equipment. A suffix of “U” is a container and “C” is a chassis.
Abbreviation for: Anti-submarine warfare.
Abbreviation for: Supply Chain Council and System Command Centre.
Pre-scheduled activities to maintain production resource availability and process specifications or based on monitoring system alerts.
Abbreviation for: Enterprise Transportation Management.
Abbreviation for: Personal Property Information Management System.
Abbreviation for: Available to Promise and Advanced Technology Program.

Denotes a detailed and documented analysis of the cost drivers associated with planned sourced item. The cost drivers include all material costs, labour costs, overhead costs, and profit margins that would apply to the item.
A system of determining demands for inventory at distribution centres, and consolidating demand information in reverse as it is put into the production and materials system.
Abbreviation for: Time Division Data Multiplexer.

A fore-and-aft or gaff-rigged sail on the aft-most mast of a square-rigged vessel and the main fore-and-aft sail (spanker sail) on the aft-most mast of a (partially) fore-and-aft rigged vessel such as a schooner, a barquentine, and a barque.
